I have played this game for 1,000 hours on Xbox and 200 on PC. This game can be fun and it has its moments. However, this game after 7 years is still extremely clunky and buggy. Most of my time was spent on Official PvP servers. You have to treat this game as a hardcore survival game because you will never survival unless you've been playing for years and are in an alpha tribe. The latest dlc genesis part 2 makes the game mind numbingly easy. It makes it easier for you to start. but it also makes it infinitely easier for bigger tribes to farm a ludicrous amount of top tier weapons to wipe you. The only, and I mean only, way to survive even just a little bit is to hide. 

The game balance was and still is stupidly broken. You have to buy the dlc to be on somewhat of a level playing field. If not you will be locked out of powerful dinos and resources. These developers literally sold a dlc with one of the most powerful dinos locked away WHILE STILL IN EARLY ACCESS. I will give some credit as they do bring it free maps implemented from mods, but there is always a paid map with newer better things so they free players are always behind.

Any turrets you make are useless so don't waste your time. These tribes have existed so long that they have bred dinos with 200k health and farmed 120 armor saddles. They have vaults worth of tames to soak your base. You can make explosives so easy its not even funny. Anyone that knows what they are doing can have c4 in under 2 hours with enough to foundation wipe a base. You can never go toe to toe you must fight like a guerilla. Hidden with a small enough base to stay off the radar. This also becomes a problem as you need space to breed and place indy forges, indy cookers, and tek replicators. You hit a ceiling and if you build up any more you are on limited minutes. It is just a matter of time before someone comes to destroy. It's no joke its so easy to raid that people will scour the map looking for something to raid as they've already raided everything else. Ark allows transfer of servers so there will always be people visiting looking to raid. 

The PvP is awkward and clunky. It is nice to see the different builds people make. You can go all in on melee and one hit people with clubs. Most people focus movement speed so it just a bunch of midgets running around trying to bola one another. Bow and arrows have some of the worst hit registration I've seen in a game to date. You watch the arrows stack up in the body but zero actual hits and damage. A lot of times you end up fighting someone with God tier armor and your primitive weapons will do practically nothing. Most of the dino PvP is flyers which is mostly who can pick each other off the tame first. Unless you are fighting a managarmr which completely breaks PvP shooting a freeze breath instantly killing any other tame. Land dino PvP is rare and usually its only late game dinos unless you are messing around with noobs. Ocean PvP is almost non-existant except for boat PvP which is so glitchy you can just drive into any enemy boat jump and phase through the walls and kill the driver. This only happens on Ragnarok because someone at Wildcard had the bright idea to add a giant whale, aggressive only to rafts. 2 hits it, adds it to every map except Ragnarok, and there is nothing you can do about it. 

The aforementioned paragraphs pertain to regular players being able to screw you, but that doesn't scratch the surface. The game is full of cheaters. If you think you can hide, think again people have an esp that tells them exactly what things are where so just pray you are out of range of those cheater. Aimbot is super common, the tek railgun can shoot through literally anything so cheaters can box themselves in a metal paracer and shoot into someone base without any fear. People will mesh outside the map and build and there is nothing you can do to raid them. I've submitted reports on player meshing with video proof and coordinates, everything so they are dead to rights only to get a response days later saying they'll look into it and nothing happened to them. I think there are supposed to be game admins but as far as I'm concerned they don't exist. It is even worse because they game never wipes and so everything these people accumulate they keep. Ark allows you to transfer servers so they can take their stuff to other servers and trade with anyone. Can you guess what happens? The cheaters and I suppose alpha tribes. but they may as well be synonymous with cheaters, have so much they can sell their goods for real money. There are Facebook groups and Discord servers of these tribes selling tames, structures, ammo, you name it. It incentivises cheaters to protect their position to keep selling.  This game is practically a job to get anywhere, but some people make this their job. Ark has been out for years and they are releasing a new game and still don't have control of Ark.

The only thing I can recommend is the single player. Which unfortunately has a tether between anyone who joins you, Unless you get another pc to host the server. The unofficial servers are usually have boosted rates and have active admins. However, some of the admins are biased and some servers sell you things making them pay to win anyway. PvE may be fun I've never tried it, some people may build where you want and may block off resources. Less stressful than PvP and you also will need to get on regularly to prevent decay. 

Ark is fun building big bases and progressing. Albeit at a very slow rate. All of the hundreds of dinos are interesting and have their own quirks. It is unlike any other game. It is also unlike any other game with its atrocious game design/balance, lack of support, ridiculous grind, and greed.
It's a great game to play when you hate your life :)

ARK is truly a game of its generation, but sadly it has suffered badly from exploiting and cheating.

If you want to play PVE and have a fun experience taming and playing with all of the creatures that Ark has to offer, then this is a fantastic game.

Sadly the PVP mechanics create a massive inventive for Real Money Trades, which has created a huge black market which incentivises cheating, exploits and all-manner of hacks. Sadly, the policing strategy from the in-game GMs is very lacking.

Last month, we lost a 2-year-old base to infinite railgun hackers that could float inside of the mesh. The architecture of the character and transfer system means there is no paper-tail for the cheaters.

I truly doubt there will be another game that matches Ark's PVP in terms of its creativity, flexibility, but it is savagely undermined by the RMT market and lack of policing.

Create your flawlessly imperfect beach bob, short stubby legs, arms longer than the rest of your body, and a big bobble head. Spawn into one of many huge maps, start on the beach or spawning area of your choice, and get eaten by a pack of raptors. Re-spawn in a different area, start building your base by punching some trees, picking up rocks and destroying the local environment. Build a thatch shack and get killed in bed whilst you're offline by a T-Rex. After a few dozen hours, you're getting the hang of this, you've got some Dino's, and then lose everything to a Giga finding you. Make some friends with others online, tame said Giga, build a  huge fortress with your tribe with enough room for your army. It's time to take on the boss, aaaand everything's dead.... Ark isn't a game you can relax playing, it can be punishing early on, much like many games in the survival genre. At a low level the game really is more about surviving. As you progress though your experience, you'll become more obsessed with better stats in your creatures,taming newer, stronger dinos, breeding new and stronger versions with the perfect genetic line, and building that mega base that causes the server to lag. Every. Single. Minute. Worth it. The anger from getting a tame killed, being ambushed by Giant Scorpions, or mistakenly hitting [E] key and dismounting off your Pteranadon and falling to your death. You'll re-spawn and keep wanting to get further, the challenge and dopamine reward for getting past that point is what you'll strive for. Take on Land, Air, and Sea, conquer all that ark has to offer and ascend... and that's just PvE. There's still a whole server full of new problems in PvP.

I like this game, it is fun and has some cool ideas and mechanics. The singleplayer is fun but with friends is better. PvE is nice but in big servers all the land gets taken up in the nice spots, not a huge complaint! I was really excited to play the PvP but was actually really disappointed with that aspect, only part I didn't like. I put several hours each into about 5-6 different PvP servers and generally you just run around punch people alone with ur fists/club/axe. It defeats the whole purpose of the game which is to develop these new materials and dinos, I wish there was a middle ground where people fought but actually built a tribe up somewhat. There is only tribes with no fighting (PvE), or solo running around punching people while children wail over the mic (PvP). There doesn't seem to be anything in between where tribes will form and actually go to war, the closest I have seen to that is one tribe asked another to tear down someones base when the people there went offline so they could build there instead. If you are looking for a tribal or even group PvP this is not the game for you, if you are looking for a unique survival game and have some friends also interested then this is totally for you.

Also if anybody knows servers that ARE like this please let me know, and yes I have tried normal, small tribes, conquest, etc. I am also not shitting PvP it is fun at times to punch everyone and I get people will like it, but this is my opinion on my review.

Its an amazing survival crafting game with unforgiving and brutal gameplay.  Its main feature of dinosaurs could leave you either happy or down right angry. There are how ever bugs that have been in the game and broken game mechanics since launch that haven't changed.

Pros:
beautiful graphics
nice progressions system
nice amount of things to craft
nice variations of materials to collect and use to craft with
different worlds to transport or teleport to

Cons:
random spawns are not new player friendly. IF you die be for making a base with a bed or bedroll, you could find some where else on the map after dying. Some people like this, I particularly do not.

With procedural or randomly generated dino spawns you could find your self on a spawn or that of your base being near a spawn and not know it. Now imagine if said spawn was 100 levels higher than you. This is not fun then.


OVERALL:
8/10 at its base price of 19.99 its worth the money playing with friends.

I would recommend ARK only in 1 specific case – you have a group of friends and will play on a private/local server. You get to enjoy the game at your own pace, with modified server multipliers, without the worry of PvP and server-dominating tribes. Graphics are great, the world is beautiful, lots of cool dinos to tame. There’s a lot to do, to build, to explore, to figure out.

But playing on a large PvP server is horrible experience. You are at a mercy of alpha tribes that have everything and can do anything. Slow progression, server wipes, laggy combat, so much grinding to catch up just to have your base destroyed while offline. Maybe you could find some servers where all this is more balanced but even then, it just becomes a game of who can grind more. It’s just not something I would ever recommend.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I would play this game more if it didn't play like garbage with an almost 400 gb download. It's fun at times and annoying most others. Great concept, and the meme of waiting for ark 2 has been made a reality. I love this timeline.

I'm nowhere near finishing any map on this game, however I can safely say that it's a lot of fun, if you have 2tb worth of disk space. The designs, despite mostly being great, lack accuracy in some places, but the game isn't trying to be accurate so doesn't matter, the lore of the game is interesting, even if I don't know all of it, the game will get a bit grindy in the late game though.

[h1](Dino's)[/h1] 4/5
Ark is a game that has become a little bloated over time. The number of dinosaurs has grown over the years to the point that I'm not sure it's possible to own a breeding pair of every single one anymore. At least if they aren't cryopod'd.(Ark's version of a Pokeball.)While most dinosaurs have a use of some kind, even if it's.. questionable, a lot of them feel like they are just there to be there. 
[hr][/hr]
[h1](Environment) [/h1]2/5
The environment on Ark offers zero challenge outside of stuff like temperature. If you wear the right clothes or ride, you'll be fine more or less. Instead Ark hinges on making wild dinosaurs and other players the true danger, which again if you wear the right gear, are basically not a threat.
[hr][/hr]
[h1](Building and Crafting) [/h1] 3/5
Building is time consuming but also one of Ark's best features - if you can piece it together correctly. You really just need to experience it for yourself. Crafting on the other hand is resource intensify and will likely have you farming for materials for hours just to finish a single project in the late game. It's a chore.
[hr][/hr]
[h1](Online)[/h1] 2/5
As far as the online play goes, The community is as toxic as you'd expect and bigger tribes will routinely wipe new groups just to keep their status more often than not. PVE servers don't fare much better, with most of the official servers being pillar locked. Private servers and single player/tethered co-op are your only options. 
[hr][/hr]
[h1]Overall[/h1] - 6/10 - The bottom line? [b]Get it while it's on sale if you want it.[/b]

[b] Game is Meh when you play alone [/b]
[b] But Night Sky Jelly is Great when you make alone [/b]

[Night Sky Jelly]
Lemongrass butterfly pea tea bag...2 bags 
Water...300ml
Sugar...30g 
Bamboo charcoal powder...1 tsp 
Sheet gelatin 6g

[Night Sky Jelly liquid 2]
Water...300ml 
Sugar...30g 
Sheet gelatin 6g
Blue curacao syrup…a little

[Lemon sauce]
Lemon juice... 1 tablespoon 
Honey... 3 tablespoons

*Lemon sauce is optional. Please enjoy your meal.

Advance preparation
Dissolve bamboo charcoal powder in a small amount of water.

1. Make Night Sky Jelly liquid. Soak the gelatin in cold water for about 1 minute.
2. Put 300ml of water in a small pot and when it boils, turn off the heat and add a lemongrass butterfly pea tea bag to extract the tea leaves. Wait a few minutes for the color to appear.
3. Scoop the tea leaves, put a small amount of bamboo charcoal powder dissolved in sugar and water over the heat, dissolve and mix.
4. Add the softened sheet gelatin and mix until it dissolves, then cool with ice water.
5. Put half the amount of jelly liquid in a container and leave it at room temperature, pour the other half into the mold and cool it in the refrigerator until it hardens.
6. Make Night Sky Jelly liquid 2. Put water and sugar in a small pan and heat to dissolve. Add the softened gelatin sheets and mix until dissolved, then cool with ice water.
7. Pour the blue curacao syrup into the container from Step 5, add 100ml of Night Sky Jelly Liquid 2, pour into the mold, and chill in the refrigerator until it hardens.
8. Pour the remaining Night Sky Jelly into the mold and chill in the refrigerator for at least 3 hours until it hardens.
9. Remove from the mold and apply edible silver foil. Serve with lemon sauce if desired.

It is recommended to add black pigment such as bamboo charcoal powder to add depth to the color.
If the jelly in the first and second layers hardens too much, it will split.

I got this game for free and I still want my money back.

ARK is a broken, repetitive, horribly unoptimized mess of a game that somehow looks even worse than it plays. The graphics are an absolute eyesore, the UI and controls are embarrassingly bad, the progression is yawn-inducting, and you can forget about any kind of explanation, guidance or even just a general attempt to explain what's going on or how to play. This is, of course, without even mentioning the astonishingly awful technical state the game is in, with so many bugs, glitches and crashes that it often becomes unbearable.

Even if you *do* somehow manage to see beyond all this crap, you'll quickly discover that when it comes to actual gameplay... ARK has practically nothing to offer. The first few hours (and I mean in the single digit) may hold some value as you explore and (very clunkily) engage with the basic game loop (find creature, knockout creature, kill or tame, repeat), but even this wears off very quickly as you discover that there's actually very little to do after that. Within mere hours you'll be at the point where your gear beats any creature, your base is unbreakable, and any resemblance of a challenge is officially gone. Now what? Nothing. That's ARK for you, pretty much. Sorry, were you expecting more? We don't do this here - it requires effort. Meh.

What about PvP, you ask? Goodness gracious. I won't get too far into the details as there are other reviews explaining it better than I ever could, but to summarize: if capitalism came in the form of a really, really bad video game, it would be ARK PvP. Unless you're slaving yourself as part of a big alpha tribe, or give up everything else in your life to grind this trash without stopping, you will not get anywhere. You'll be stomped on, destroyed, and probably even peed on. Unless you're really into being humiliated constantly (a kink is a kink I guess?), I cannot possibly see how any of the people who designed this experience thought it will be enjoyable. You know, the thing that a game is suppose to be: fun. Not a painful chore with zero reward other than more chores and possibly a headache. It's just not fair, was never designed to be fair, and the developers couldn't care less that it's not fair.

There are far, far better survival games out there than this sad excuse of a game, which nullifies any remaining reason to justify buying this crap. Games that put at least some sort of effort into improvement and a better player experience. Games that look better, play better, or offer a better experience in general. Games where the graphics don't make you want to poke your eyes out, or where the gameplay cannot be summed up as "the shittiest pokemon clone you've ever paid too much for". Games where there's a proper onboarding experience, with actual thought and consideration put into the UI and the controls, with a better planned end game, and with a tech stack that is more than a bunch of memory leaks taped together. Games that make the player feel respected, not an afterthought to the bottom line.

But not wildcard, no. For a game with over half a decade on the modern gaming market, you'd think that for how commercially successful this game is, they would at least *try* to make a better impression, let alone fix their shit or balance it out. Funny, but no. There is none of that, yet players keep handing over their money regardless of how much they're spat on. Sadly, we are well beyond the days in which consumers would rile up and protest such blatant garbage daring to give itself a price tag. The people buy, and the developers are laughing in our face all the way to the bank. Voting with your wallet is not a thing anymore.

ARK is not just a bad game; it's yet another example for everything that is wrong in today's gaming industry: underwhelming, overpriced, and soulless - all without a single drop of shame, nor, sadly, consequences. A hastily cobbled-together idea, marketed as something it's not, then kept as a bare-minimum disappointing experience with the one purpose of being milked dry to the last drop. There are very few games out there that make one feel like their very intelligence is insulted by playing them, but hey, this nightmare needs to have *something* going on for it, right?

Don't bother. You're better off getting an actual day job. At least there they pay *you* to disappoint you constantly and require your attention for the vast majority of the day, not the other way around.

Pretty map, awful gameplay loop. My first 5 minutes were pretty intresting, crafting tools and clothes to help survive the night and gather more resources, pants, gloves, shirts, spears, axes, picks etc, and the following 2 hours were the most mindnumblingly boring sh*t experience I have ever had in any game ever that prompted me to uninstall the game and write this review.

If you venture outside the starting beach area, you get destroyed by high level monsters. To fight high level monsters, you need better gear, you unlock better gear using blueprints that you get from leveling up. How do you level up? Bash rocks against one another for 2 hours straight.

So I started bashing and bashing and bashing, hoping to finally level up enough to unlock blueprints for leather armour or iron weapons or something so I could explore, a hope that never came because the first several dozen levels of unlocks are exclusively fucking furniture which I couldn't give less of a fuck about because all I wanted to do was PROGRESS.

All I wanted to do was explore the island, If wanted to play minecraft, I'd boot up minecraft, who's idea was it to put DECORATIONS as early and mid level rewards with ACTUAL progression being after you've already inveted 10 hours into a save file?

Sure, I may still be fighting t-rexes using a stone spear, but at least now I got a... *checks notes* stone fence support?

Yeah that's gonna help me survive when I've barely started and can't even set foot outside due to being oneshot by all the high level dinos that I do no damage to.

What pushed me over the edge was when I thought this would be more fun with a friend (Which isn't much of a ringing endorsement, being boiled alive is more fun with friends) who owned the game off steam, but after fiddling with servers for 20 minutes we couldn't figure out how to play toogether and just gave up.

Avoid this game like the f*cking plague, go play Vrising instead.

Strangely unintuitive game and not sure if there were glitches or what. Had to google every step on the way. In the beginning I could choose and craft items, but not anymore after I crafted a campfire. I had loads of engram points, I was on level 11 and had the resources but couldn't make any clothes and therefore had to sit by campfire through the night. Also the character can only make little jumps, meaning much of the terrain is not walkable. Glad I got this game for free on sale.

If you do play - find a nice unofficial server server to play on. Otherwise you get these max lvl players hunting you down and harassing you everytime you log in or they come once a week and clean your bases out with 400+ lvl tames.  Cheating is rampant in this game with aimbots, esp and other things like Duplication.

I got this game for free during a promotion a few months ago and I have real mixed feelings about it. The game is excellent to play with friends and taming dinos and building your base is the highlight obviously. The maps are massive and nearly impossible to fully explore without sinking inordinate amounts of time. It's like exploring actual wilderness.  I wish there was a way to skip night time in private server the way valheim does it, if everyone gets into beds, because the night can be truly terrifying even with some levelled dinos. For example, lost a level 210 carnotaurus because I was lost and couldn't see further than torchlight and I was repeatedly ambushed by much lower level raptors. Yes, I also had a couple smaller escorts as well. So it ends up being that you just... wait... all night at the base if you don't have any home improvement projects to work on because leaving the base at night might cost you literally hours of dino taming no matter how well you prepare.

One thing that is absolutely inexcusable is the grossly misrepresented storage needed. They advertise it as a 60 gb game and the file on my computer is WELL OVER 300GB. I have it on two different computers so ARK is consuming nearly 700gb of storage in my life. Even before the DLC, it was around 180 which is egregious but at least there are other games in that ballpark. I have friends with 480/512gb drives that are wholly dedicated to windows and ARK and have barely enough space leftover to not slow down the SSD. If you have a 250, you can forget any DLC right now. I personally used an old hard drive and just tolerate the load times to not eat up the majority of my ssd.

Wow, if you want to play a game that abuses you ARK is it. I don't think I have done corpse runs like this since EQ1 days and I thought Valheim corpse runs were terrible.  I am pretty sure this game purposefully spawns in more hostile dinosaurs around your corpse as soon as you die. I can literally run around and explore and run into zero hostile dinos and then as soon as I die suddenly I have to fight through a swarm of 20 hostiles to get back to my original corpse. It reminds me of Dying Light in that the game seems to be designed to pile on you and punish you right when you are most vulnerable.

It is graphically a very pretty game but you can tell the base building mechanics are old and janky AF. No grids and poor snap points and very little information in game on what any of the close to 1000 craftables are for. You end up building some REALLY ugly bases in stark contrast with the beautiful environment.

There are several dangerous tiny dinosaurs you will often run into during the early game. One is called a Troodon and this little PoS will literally troll you like a real-life troll on a PvP server. These things are small and fast and do very little damage but they will POISON you, poison in ARK does NOT kill you. It knocks you out and you fall on the ground helpless. Then these Troodons often won't kill you!?!! They will just run around you and every minute or so hit you once to reapply the poison and keep you unconscious for another minute. They will keep doing this OVER and OVER and just keep you helpless forever until a bigger dinosaur comes by and finally puts you out of your misery. There have been several times now where I got knocked out by this and I just sit there helpless for over 10 minutes praying that something else comes by and quickly kills me so I can respawn, meanwhile your corpse decay timer with all your good gear is ticking down. I have literally Alt-Tabbed out of the game watching videos and reading up while waiting to finally be allowed to die. At least the Titanoboas have the consideration to finish you off quickly after their poison knocks you out after 1 or 2 bites.

I initially thought that a 3 hour corpse decay timer was generous. Every time I finally get back to my corpse that decay timer is down to the last 10 to 20 minutes. Every corpse run has taken me almost 3 hours to get back to my body with all the extra dying and fighting against the seemingly random dino spawns that just happen to appear when you die.

Avoid this game unless you like games that punish your face or set the game settings down to easy mode.

I've given this game three separate "goes". The gameplay loop is decently fun and addictive. It's plagued with a lot of really obvious oversights, bugs, and UI issues that sap a lot of fun out of the base game. You can likely mod it into working as intended, but it's unconscionable to have this many issues 5 years after release and after releasing however-many DLC's.

I remember my first day spawning on the beach like it was yesterday when in reality it's almost been 5 years. My friend and I decided to check out "cool dinosaur game" only to be met with exactly that. We spawned on different sides of the island on accident and had to run a quarter way around the map to meet up. Along the way we were massacred by Raptors, T-Rexs, Gigas, and many of the other giant scaly reptiles that inhabit the world of ark. PVE is amazingly polished and is fun for hours on end. This is an extremely enjoyable game and I highly recommend giving it a try.

Ark is an absolutely amazing game. I've played it on and off since October 2017 and I have never found a game that could hold a torch to either the base game or its modding community. The Devs are amazing and incredibly open with the ARK players and over the years have turned community made maps into fully implemented free DLC maps which I quite love. Most of my hours were played a few years ago during the modding community's prime with mods like Primal Fear being used on just about every unofficial server. A good chunk of the old mods are a little buggy now because the creators have moved on to new projects or focused on other areas of their lives, (which is completely fine, I don't blame them) but their mods still work for some incredible game play. I watched this game grow from the initial addition of the Ragnarok map to the final chapter of the story and I cannot be happier with how well this glorious game ended up. I am so excited to see how ARK 2 turns out, so much so that I wishlisted it the moment I saw the announcement.
Dinosaurs r cool. Extinction is my favorite dlc

Look, for those of there out there who are bothered by the clunky controls, the sometimes clunky graphics, the..unrefined user experience...stick it out.  Ark is a game where achievement drives all. The incredible difficulty and punishing losses all serve to contrast the incredible highs of taming that one rare dino. Or killing that boss finally. As someone who churned after a 10 hour first run, i've come back for 275 and loved every one of them. Excited for #2

Ark: Survival Developed

Ark is one of those games that came out in early access when it was still a "new thing"  and kind of set the standard for what ongoing development games could be...if not headed by AAA studio idiots.  The team at Wildcard has consistently delivered content updates and maps new things to build and items to craft...Its what studios should do when they value the customer.  

This is one of the more immersive games I've ever played and I can't recommend it highly enough...If you haven't played ark...Get to it.

Game has very little in game help on what to do, and how to do anything in game. No direction on how to tame, level up, build or survive. Players have to search up out of game on how to do most things, and this takes away from the experience. Servers are laggy and slow at times, if not down. The game is beautiful and there are cool things you can do once you learn the game, getting to that point takes time.
Its a fun and challenging game

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

If you love it when everything you own gets destroyed by a random wild dinosaur, this is the game for you.

Not only that but the work I DID do was lost when i logged on last time. i tried to play againand loadmy character and it loaded without any clothes or weapons i made. You can loose your single player world it never saves quite right.  It will just up and vanish one day.  Recommend playing pve multiplayer official or unofficial.  Use Battlemetrics site to see if servers are populated and don't join servers with a bad health rating.  

Pay attention to ping you want the lowest ping possible for you.  Most servers are in germany but still watch your ping.  Lot people quit this game say lag sucks broke but they didn't bother joining servers with lowest ping for them.

People and the devs will hurt your feelings.  Keep a thick hide.  It's not as bad as Rust but it will burn you at times.  Be ready for it.

With the sequel coming soon, only buy this game if it's steeply discounted. my friends and I got it during a free promotion. Also it still feels very 'beta survival game' in that it can be quite janky at times. My review would probably change for the positive if we were able to survive to actually tame dinos etc. but this has the curse like many other long-open-developed games of difficulty creep, so if you jump in late into the cycle without a clue of what to do, it's completely impenetrable and impossible to make any progress without half your playtime being spent on google.

The game is great, its fun, I genuinely like to play the game. One issue, if you're a linux player, its a bit buggy but it still works. The forums said to opt into the nativelinux beta but it isn't as simple as that. Opt into linuxnative beta, go to compatibility and use proton 5.13-6 , if it asks to install battle eye, just click cancel. this so far get the game to be playable. Its a bit laggy but that may be my computer. hope this update helps others. Previously I said that it wouldn't work on linux at all, but after over 5 hours I managed to get it to work. 6/10

You get the point. This is going to be you experience for the beginning of the game. You'll die of starvation or dehydration if you manage not to make it on the dino's dinner plate, but once you start getting your footing on the game you will get used to it.  The amount of patience you are going to need for the amount of sh!t that is going to happen in this game has to be godly. I suggest playing on NON dedicated servers if you don't have the time (real life time... yeah you're gonna need that on dedicated) to play this game.  I always enjoy it with my sister, whenever we hop into it. I do recommend it, it's not for everyone, but if you love dinos this will be an experience.

I'm a 41 year old Dad that plays this game with my two sons.  Official settings are not a good fit for us.  Fortunately, WC lets me run my own dedicated server with settings that make it more "fun" for us.  The fact that this game has dedicated servers makes it great in my book.  I miss the days of running my own MW or BF2 server.  Hopefully they keep this feature for ARK 2.

The game has its share of bugs.  I fell through the map and lost all my gear the other day.  It didnt feel great, but I was able to recover with a few admin commands.  Building can be janky at times, but once you learn how to make things snap the way you want, its not so bad.  The dinos are great, the survival aspects are alright, and combat is fun enough.  This game scratches a lot of different itches.  Mod support is icing on the cake.  

Overall, great game.

Like many survival and crafting games, ARK gives you a challenging progression of both tech and taming. There's always plenty to see, do and conquer. Dangers include the elements, dinosaurs and other players. Highlights include loads of dinosaurs and areas to explore. 

Best moments: finding and taming elusive dinosaurs with teammates (personal favorite would be the Quetz) 
Worst moments: loading into a very established server and being unable to get started due to persistent stompage 

Highly recommend: Boot up your own server and set your own challenges. The game has plenty to explore.

ARK Survival Evolved is a game that re-imagines the survival scene. Taking a prehistoric approach, the game offers a new experience for players as they step into the world of dinosaurs as a lowly human being. 

there are many positive notes about this game which I've listed below:

- Visually, the game is beautiful. the free DLC's each offer unique and vast lands to travel, as do the paid ones. sites high up on mountain ranges and deep into valleys create picturesque views to stop and look at during travels. 
- the graphics are strong. The dinosaurs, plants, rocks and characters are generously detailed to help immerse the player into the new world.

- audio-wise, the game captures the sounds of dinosaurs as we would have expected them to sound when they roamed the earth. Wandering around at night and hearing a piercing screech from an Argentavis can send a shiver down your spine as you sprint for cover. 

- There are challenges you'd expect to find in a real survival situation. Searching for food and water and building a shelter before nightfall are the first few tasks for a new player. doing this while trying to stay alive presents a realistic scenario for the type of setting--video game wise, that is. 

- There's a vast range of options for a player as they step into the ARK. playing single player and attempting to go lone wolf or playing on a server with many others. Creating tribes and making friends.
- For each map you play on, you are able to customize the rules and settings of the game. Taming speed too slow? Slide the bar or enter any number in the box next to the bar labeled "Taming Speed" to adjust the companion gaining process. Change how long night or day lasts or create new challenges for yourself as you please. 
- Single players also have a Champaign route they may choose to take. when starting, you'll find there are these giant statues of metal. A green one, a Red and a Blue. These are the obelisks. Taking artifacts to them helps you to create portals to bosses to fight with your army of dino's by your side. There's an easy one, a medium one and a hard one. You can upload your character to the obelisks and once you conquer one map, you can move on with your character from the map you completed to conquer the next one. 

Though the game has many ups, there are a few downs--especially for new players--to overcome. 

- the game doesn't have a tutorial. When you first spawn in, you must learn how to survive on your own or with help from an experienced player. 
- the first few nights and days will be brutal. Since the game doesn't have a system that adjusts the difficulty as you play, you may find yourself dying often early on. Don't get frustrated and quit. This wont last long. As you start to get more materials and weaponry, the game gets easier. Taming Dino's is the best and fastest way to thriving.

- because the game is large ans has a lot of specs it carries, sometimes there will be lag spikes or moments when you freeze. it doesn't happen a lot, but it may. Don't panic, let the game resolve the issue itself. It typically doesn't take long.

I do recommend the game for those who love a good challenge. it's completely open world and creativity is limited only to where you will go. Finding dino's and making them your own, finding ways to overcome difficulty and learning to thrive all comes in this game.

185 GB download, I can handle that I guess. I don't need the D:Cs though, so having to download them at the same time as the base game is just lazy/coercive game development. Every year I lose another 10-20GB of storage waiting for this game to work the way I want. Just let me be a happy caveman, not getting mobbed by 10 dinos spawning at once in my back yard all night long. I don't need all the green and red shafts of light, monolith towers and mini guns. That garbage just upsets the vibe.

Thankfully there are mods that bring the game to a less arcade-like feel. I like to use Remove obelisk, Palisade walls, No loot crates, and anything that removes modern and sci-fi paraphernalia and spaces out creature spawns, so its not a crowded neon petting zoo atmosphere.

Buggy as heck, but a great game. I played it on my xbox a lot before, but i wanted to play online with my friends, and they had the PC version, So i got the PC version. because, even though there's like no difference from the two versions, it's not cross play, idk why. i didn't think i would be able to do this because Ark is such a massive game and i have a MacBook Pro, which aren't known for their gaming capabilities. but when i saw it was MacOS supported, i was very very surprised, and happy. so, when it went on sale, i bought it. then i waited an entire day for it to download. and when it was done, i clicked play and started loading it. it took a while to load but when it finished and showed me the title screen, and immediately crashed. i tried to load it again, but all i saw was a split second of the title screen before it crashed again. now, this happened every time i tried to load the game, you could imagine my frustration. i checked everything about my computer and found that i'm doing absolutely nothing wrong. i have enough storage, i have the system requirements, i have everything it needs. but no, it wouldn't let me play it. turns out that Ark isn't compatible with the latest MacBook system update. you'd think that Wildcard would rush to fix this big of a problem, but they're too busy adding more bugs than content to the game. i'm sure there are others out there with the same problem i have. all this to say, IF WILDCARD SEES THIS REVEW, PLEASE MAKE THE DANG GAME PLAYABLE FOR MACBOOKS!!!

A honest review.
"ARK: Survival Evolved" is not too bad, yet I cant recommend it.

The Graphics are, mediocre (2014 "Planetside 2" Graphics) for the Gear which it needs, to run it.
The music and sounds are ok, nothing special, nothing striking nice made with it, yet The Game works and I have not noticed heavy glitches.
The Gameplay feels fine, as long as a Heavy PC can run it smoothly.

The Problem I have, with It:
1. It needs 200 to 300 Gbs of Drive Space. (there are ingame things that are there but don't make the game better.)

2. starting the Game, is not starting the game. The Menu looks like a "hobby player made" server, a good showcase could be seeing, what the player will see ingame (a Trailer), and easy navigation.

4. The Hardware requirements are too high to run smooth.

5. The Models scale doesn't feel right.

6. there is no "Introduction" to the game, and how it all works.
A good Introduction to the game would be one, where the players play through it, to learn the basics, when launching the game the first time (skippable and relauncheble).
Not by learning by looking at the keybind Settings menu.
A Bad Intro would be: A tutorial which is just a long Text.

My suggestions: randomly generated map, low system requirements less to download, max ~20GBs, good menu, intro, gameplay, better looking gam, nice music and sound integration.

Thank you for reading.

I really wanted to like this game.

Don't be fooled by the trailers or preview images, the games is such low quality and fairly buggy. 

- It has the worst HUD of any game I've seen out of early access
- There is basically no tutorial, and almost nothing is explained
- Early game you are constantly bombarded by levelling up, with objectively terrible graphics projected annoyingly on the screen and no actual explanation of the levelling or stat system at all
- I don't believe there's any way to check what status effects are applied, except images in the corner of the HUD, these are not explained and provide no tooltip with more info
- Every time you die and respawn, you get the same starting equipment which adds up annoyingly in your inventory if you bother to loot your corpse
- The layout is and unrefined

I could add a whole other review about the character creation; what the fuck? If I had to pick the worst thing about it, I'd wanna know why the put the hair colour selection on a single slider scale. Just...why?

There are obviously good things about it.
- I like the dinosaurs
- The ability to sort your inventory and crafting items into custom folders is fun and helpful

But overall I found the UI just jarringly bad and the whole game felt like it should still be a few years from full release. Astonishing that it's such a popular game given all these problems. Kudos to people who are play despite that, but I doubt I'll be able to overlook the glaringly low-quality visual elements.

The best thing about this game will be the absurd amount of space I'll free up by uninstalling.

The game is good in concept, but has some of the most tedious, frustrating and buggy issues infesting every single facet of the game. Maybe as a single player experience it could be worth it, but in multiplayer (which is clearly the more popular way to play) unless you have the time to absolutely no life the game, then you get left completely in the dust and the tedium starts to affect you 3x more than those around you. 

Ultimately the game is worth playing for the right person, and no one can argue that taming dinosaurs and cool beasts isn't amazing. The issue comes in for anyone without a decent computer, time to throw at hours and hours of unrewarding/easily lost progress, or those who want a more robust PvE experience.

Don't let my review stop you from trying it out, but pick it up on one of it's very common sales or maybe wait for the 2nd game to come around in the near future.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is

What is an addiction?
Recognizing an addiction problem in someone you know can be harder than it seems. The American Society of Addiction Medicine (ASAM) defines addiction as a chronic disease that affects the brain’s reward, motivation, and memory functions. Someone with an addiction will crave a substance or other behavioral habits. They’ll often ignore other areas of life to fulfill or support their desires.

   I've sunk numerous hours into this game over the years and have had a good time. That being said, I would never play on public servers, nor would I play alone. Pvp is unplayable, and offline raiding is as toxic as any game with offline raiding and then some.    I wish that they took a little more care of this game instead of letting greed get into their way.

Is this game large? Yes
Is this game janky? Yes
Is this game as flawed as a Bethesda game at launch? Yes
But there is no other game that lets you tame and ride dinos while shooting rocket launchers leading a horde of C4 dodos and a flock of murder owls. Get your friends, make a tribe, and go and live the dreams you had as kids.

You can see that I have almost 800 hours in this game. I have tried to play it time and time again. I just finished a determined effort to get the game to work and enjoy it. It didn't happen. It plays well until it doesn't. Which is entirely too often.

I'm writing this review after my 10th attempt in a week to get a game to complete without bugs cropping up that ruin the experience. Particularly annoying is the "deleted resource nodes" bug/feature/"as designed", who knows? That used to only show up in single player and hosted sessions. Now, it's showing up in the dedicated server.

Several of the bugs that were there on day one keep recurring. They'll fix one. Then break it again in a future update.
 
There are several things that aren't game breaking but are annoying:
- typing into an edit box and pressing enter does not submit by default ... you have to click the accept button
- there's an option to save a character preset. It gets deleted when you delete the settings which you have to do to change your map
- if you don't squint one eye and hold your tongue between your teeth while you delete settings, the settings may or may not get deleted. You just never know until you start up a new game whether you are starting on a new map or starting on the previous one that you just deleted.
- A safe zone should be safe. I don't how many times I've gotten a death message while still on the character creation screen because my character spawned right on top of a one-hit wonder dino.

It's a great game idea. Poor implementation.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Okay. Pretty great. I like the alternate time period trope here. The best part is you can mod it, unlike the console versions. What I don't like about it is the fact vsync is not enabled automatically by default when playing the game. In fact, THERE IS NO V-SYNC OPTION AT ALL. In order to enable it, you have to do so via console command by typing this in the console: r.vsync 1. Shoutout to steam user axenation who posted this solution via reply to OP in an old thread. Please devs put an option for enabling vsync into the game. Very important that it not be left out. Also, a much easier way from another user (DemitriX) is to do this:

Goto
Steam\steamapps\common\ARK\ShooterGame\Saved\Config\WindowsNoEditor
Open up Gameusersettings with notepad
ctrl + F and search "bUseVSync="

change
bUseVSync=False
to
bUseVSync=True


If you use console command above, you will most likely have to retype it every time you launch the game, this way you run it always with vsync when starting.

So make sure to read this review over and even past it in google docs or as a text file on your PC so you can easily look back to it when you forget how to enable it via command or within the files. 

Anyway, highly recommend this game to anyone who loves dinosaurs, first person shooters, survival games, and games that take place in an alternate time period!

I have a love/hate relationship with Ark. I've spent years of my life with this game, dating all the way back to the early days of early access.
The game is still buggy, laggy, unstable and totally unrealistic, but that is the charm...
I really mean it, you can expect to always have a laugh, surprise or heck even a set of jump scares here and there just because of the "bugs" in this game.
Imagine yourself waking up on a beach, not knowing where the f*** you are or why you're there, all you know is that that implant in your arm is itchy as hell, that turtle is definitely floating ABOVE the sea UPSIDE DOWN, aaaaaand that's an Alpha Raptor coming to kill you...

(In all seriousness, I love this game)
I would not pay for this...

I would avoid this mess of a game. It is not optimized in any way. The graphics are meh at best. There is a lot of stuff to see but getting around and actually exploring is a terrible experience. This game is just a mess and is not looking like its getting any better.  Also buyer beware this game takes hundreds of gigs of hard drive space to install. Yes if you don't install all the dlc maps the game install file is smaller but right now with all dlc maps installed I am at almost 360 gigs of hard drive space being used for this one game, and it doesn't even run well. As contrast conan exiles takes 120 gigs of hard drive space and seven days to die only takes 37 gigs of hard drive space. So just be forwarned.

wow,  I just realised I've player over 2K hours on this game. Enough, I'd imagine to have a reasonable opinion of the game.
I've played on The Island, Ragnarock, The Centre, Valguero, Crystal Isles and currently on Fjordir. Crystal Isles has been my favourite so far just due to variety of biomes and dinos.
I mostly love the building aspect of the game (although not adverse to a bit of breeding and caving :P). There's such a wide range of mods providing an ample selection of building types that can often be mixed together for incredible results. You can also play without any mods which obviously limits what type of buildings you have.
There are some lovely maps out there with breathtaking landscapes encouraging the avid builder to want to place down foundations and build a base. I'm personally a huge fan of building over/near waterfalls and always want to see a floating Ark through my kitchen window.
Its a brutal game when you're starting out, especially alone.. much better with friends. Everything is against you - so whilst you stand there trying to figure out what to do - you're getting hungry/cold and those flesh eating dinos are wandering one step closer to you. The cries and chaos of nearby veg eaters can often be the best sign that danger is close. So pay attention to everything if you wanna survive longer.
The biggest advice I can give is - do not give up! keep punching those trees and making tools/clothes/huts.. which will eventually turn into castles with dinos you can ride and fine equipment. 
This game really requires you put the time in to reap rewards and game satisfaction. If you're not a grinder, likely this game aint for you, but hugely satisfying if you have the time and patience.
The cons - mainly the game optimisation. It's really tough on your machine. Mine is built for gaming (graphics/memory) but I know people who struggle to run this, often with disconnects. I can't really be specific about this 'cause i'm not really into specs, I just have witnessed it being an issue when I had a lesser machine or for other people I play with.
Looking forward to seeing Ark2!

My only complaint is the south zones seem more like a between easy and medium than just easy. Rexes wander around there as do carnos, a crap ton of raptors, theris, etc. You die quite a few times before really getting a decent base set up, and even once you do, if you havent GRINDED like crazy for metal to make spike walls or a strong house, big predators like carnos will knock it down somewhat easy depending on their level. Not to mention the alpha carno that decided it was a good idea to come along and most of my tames were killed and it took down multiple spike walls in a few hits. Moral of the story is, just make sure you grind and level up fast so you can get decent defenses, and im not against the idea of using console commands to spawn in a good tame to cover your arse until you have good defenses, whether the tame helps you grind or protects your base. Other than the complaints about the aggressive predators spawning a bit too much on the island for it to be easy, this game is quite addicting and i do recommend it, just expect a challenge and to have your favorite tames killed.

This game is fun dont get me wrong, the survival aspect of the game is actually pretty decent. There's a few things in my mind that makes me frustrated and outright bored, (REMEMBER THIS IS ENTIRELY MY OPINION AND DOESN'T APPLY FOR EVERYONE):

Let's start off with one of the obvious flaws that I find annoying is the enemies themselves that cancels your plans ALOT. Wanna go mining up on the mountains? "Oh hell nah" send those FAT raptors towards you running faster than Usain Bolt himself, and good luck retrieving your items after because they will be guarding it(I know it's not intentional game design).

Second of all is the CLUTTER of USELESS & UGLY skins that each take up 1 INVENTORY SLOT!!! Like what???? Why should skins take up inventory slots? It just makes inventory management super cluttery, makes no sense.

The building aspect of the game is EXTREMELY poor, the amount of what I would call "barrier jumping" tricks you have to do in order to even make something look decent JUST because the ground is just a little bit uneven just makes my creative mind cry. Why cant we place foundations on top of each other? Why can't we make the foundations float? Why can't we clip foundation inside the ground? I know that this game wanna bring some realism to it but come on, it's not a sandbox game without floating/clipping building mechanics.

I already play Ark on the PS4, and playing it on PC only makes it even better!  I love spending my gameplay building bases with complex/intricate design, as well as exploring through the world (to find more spots for additional bases).  I have also always had a passion for dinosaurs since really young, watching Jurassic Park on repeat, so the fact that you can tame and have dinosaurs assist you in adventuring/building/farming, etc. is amazing!  If you have a powerful enough computer, with the graphics all maxed out on EPIC it's pretty satisfying.  This go around, we're also jumping into additional DLC content, including Genesis 2 which has a jetpack (awesome!!!) with all the engrams from previous maps included.  I don't really mess with PvP so I can't speak towards that too much, but playing on a private server with a group of friends is definitely worthwhile.

AMAZING graphics, animals, details. The maps and terrain is insane and amazing! Lots of different places, coves, forests, jungles, swamps and you name it! So So SO much fun! It's totally worth the money. You can play on a server, single player, or play with friends. And one of the best things, you get to tame DINOS!

This game has some nice depth and potential, however this is heavily marred by very bad controller support and very bad menu and interface design. Navigating and working in and around menus and cross-hair options is awkward and clunky at best, especially when you're trying to build and place non-snap-able objects with clear sight-lines and precision or try to master the general workflow of motions. In fact, No Man's Sky does this best with their 'maneuverable camera orbit' option for object-placements and the Ark devs should pay very close attention to that if they're going to be staying in the 'dev open-world survival' game at all so that they can learn from it.

Even the creative mode and console commands system is extremely awkward and poorly implemented. This must seriously be one of the worst and most awkwardly designed games (that also has such depth and potential to be great, I mean) that I've ever seen. Because there's just no good sense of work-flow to be found when trying to develop a groove with the game's mechanics. I spent so much time recently trying to "correct" the game when it bugged out on me or simply refuted my intentions that I can't even enjoy what I've managed to build out of it anymore.

And forget about doing anything on the fly with tamed dinos in any surprise enemy AI (solo) situations with any skill and grace. The erratically spazzy cross-hair highlight system is more than likely to trip you up and cost you a tamed dino or your own character's life in such situations. Meanwhile, enemy melee AI has perfect aim and never misses. Oh, were you trying to ride your suddenly spazzed flying mount to get away from an enemy ambush of all perfect attacks? Well, because of the erratically appearing and disappearing cross-hair options you have to perfectly spam the ride button -- just don't overspam since that will just dismount you again right into the loving arms (or more appropriately the toothy maws) of your enemies!

...Of course this game requires a high learning curve to master, is ultimately designed for PVPing mega-tribes, and has much tweaking options for private settings -- I am well aware of and fully accept all of that. What I cannot accept is all the inherently bad interface designs that go along with it. When, patiently try as you might, session after session, the 'work' aspect STILL exceeds the 'fun', then you know you've got a horribly interfaced game. (Maybe M+KB is better but I refuse to play exclusively that way and already have to combine in some KBM anyway in order to try and find the best rhythm of play for me.)

P.S. I have many more hours offline and other campaigns both online and offline in this on another account, and have read some of the wiki, so I know how to play this game fairly well already.

P.S.S. Devs need to pay close attention to two very important and much better designed (imo) games and those are 'No Man's Sky' and '7 Days to Die'. They are of course not perfect in every sense, but they do all my complaints here far better justice. And any minor grievances can easily be worked around in order to achieve what the goal of the game should always be once the learning curve has been satisfied for the most part: and that is to have fun.

Ignoring the issues this game has, it is really good. Open world with dinosaurs, no monetization or very little, steam workshop, good selection of maps to start out with, guns feel nice albeit a low amount of them, and plenty of creatures. Oh yeah, this game looks like Crysis 1...kind'a. 

However, this game has a mess of problems that can't be ignored. Let's start small, shall we? The building is a bit jank, sometimes things will just spaz out when trying to be placed making it feel inconsistent, sometimes why something can't be placed makes no sense, then there is other times where it can be placed and it just falls apart. 

Next issue! This game on occasion will give blueprints that you can't literally use or make because of how many slots of 1 item it might need due to quantity. Just today had an occasion like that with an assault rifle needing so much metal and resources it wouldn't fit into the fabricator...Or other occasions where trying to find the right resource is not existant or remotely possible.

Next on the list is, stuttering. This game stutters, almost all of the frickin time. Whenever loading into a new zone from texture pop in (which is so bad turning around deloads textures then takes a solid 20 seconds to reload them in). Sometimes stuttering would be so bad you'd have to wait a minute before you can play again then it'll kick right back up. 

Up next is optimization...Oh boy where do I begin...This game at menu, the frickin menu, was runnin at 30fps. While in game with occasional dips below 10fps at around a steady 60 - 80 fps (which doesn't last long at all, maybe for a solid 5 minutes at most depending where you are) with consistent 40 - 55 fps or lower. That's damn near unplayable and doesn't not feel fun to play or deal with, especially during boss fights or high intensity encounters with say a giga or a high lvled rex, when you just get froze screened and wind up dying. 

Yet another issue is a map issue/map in general, The Center. Buggy as all can be, did co op on it and water makes your buddy teleport to the host unless host is in water too or better yet moving to a different zone in same water column makes your buddy teleport to you. Tethering on The Center was so bad at times my co op buddy could only move 10ft away from my relative position before simply just being teleported back to me, like he's a dog on a leash. Other times even mid-air he would get teleported below me and usually over water.  Going into caves was chore especially, because I would crash then have to get server up again and then try to survive whatever onslaught of creatures nibbling at my shins or yet there would be so many spawned in at once, it was impossible to move because of loading everything in. Had one occasion where it was literal hundreds of piranhas mixed with other hostile creatures that came after me in the water. 

Even more issues concerning, caving. Can't do it. Would crash for me when loading into zone or one occasion today, so bad  that I could not reload up the server, tried everything I could. That is when I said "I'm done with this game."

My GPU is my only bottleneck as I have a 1060 TI with 6 gb of data/ram. The minimum requirements is a 680 with 2 gb...If your game can not at 60 fps or higher with recommended specs or tuned properly minimum specs, then it is not optimized well enough. Before you say my computer is not strong enough, my PC can run Crysis 3 on damn near max settings and not have any stuttering, crashing or freezing issues in all parts of the game. A Crysis game running better (granted it is more linear nor is is open world, but semi-open world in most cases in later half of it), than a Unreal Engine 4 game...Riddle me that. 

So in conclusion, I do not recommend this game. Far too many issues to be even considered polished, too many issues to be considered fun, too many issues with optmization which made it hard to enjoy this game.

Game overall review
- Good, it's a lot of fun but people just don't give it a chance cause of how time consuming it is.

Community
- Most of it's toxic, but there are some really nice communities if you look hard enough. Please don't trust random people you find on Ark, they will likely be chill for the first few days but then they will steal all your stuff and leave the tribe with no trace, this is known to the community as insiding. I recommend inviting existing friends to avoid being insided.

Modding
- Lots of awesome mods, anywhere from playing straight up tower defense to minigames like capture the artifact.

How time consuming is this?
- If you are playing PVP, it's very time consuming if you want to survive, otherwise it's just however long you play. But in general, this game is very time consuming.

How demanding is this game?
VERY. I have an RTX 3070, R5 3600, 16GB of 3200MHz DDR4 yet it's still a laggy mess on some maps using low settings. (Fjordur mainly) However, if you have a bad PC, you can still play this game with the use of apps like GeForce Now.

When should I buy this game?
- Buy it when it's on sale and you have watched many videos of this game to know what you are jumping into because you are absolutely not refunding it because of how time consuming it is.

Learning curve?
- The learning curve is not too big for the basics of the game but even as somebody with over a thousand hours I still learn new stuff about the game everyday.

How much is there to do?
- Too much to comprehend.

How buggy is this game?
- You'll run into many bugs in your playthrough because Wild Card would rather work on a second game than fix their existing game.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

That being said, without mods, this game is pretty bad. If you buy it, I highly advise you to at least search up and download some of the essential mods like S+. While this game isn't horrible without mods and is still pretty fun, it can get annoying and hard to play. With mods, this game is one of my favorites of all time.

This game can be very unforgiving at times and very nice to you at others. If you get this game, you might absolutely love this game, like me, or have a horrible time. It's up to you if you want to get this game but personally with my experience I would recommend it.

Been playing this game for years on console and moving to PC has been an absolute blast. Although it can get rough at times, the feeling of accomplishment and progressing when really doing anything in this game feels really good. Playing with even a small group of friends really make this game so much more fun than the core gameplay loop, with all the screwing around and growing as a tribe. Although something that has always been an issue in my opinion is the late game. There really isn't much end game content, and the content that does exist is just so boring and monotonous. Basically breed for days on end until you can defeat the bosses, which the reward is there, but the journey is not worth it. When the end game loop is not fun, it's hard to keep a full set of friends online playing at the same time due to how boring it gets at times. Mods can somewhat fix this issue of lack of end game content, but that's not the vanilla experience of the game that some people like and isn't even made by the developers. Although, for all the garbage this game throws at you whenever it feels like it due to years of unfixed issues and lazy development, this game has a certain charm to it that probably won't be replicated by another game for a while.

It's difficult for me to recommend this game. Having about 1,500 hours, I have enjoyed this game as far as it will take me. I like every aspect of it, except the boss battles. Boss fights just aren't my thing.
First I will go into the cons.
Every map seems to follow a very particular... Meta, if you can call it that with a couple exceptions.
1. Typically you want to tame:
anky for metal
doed for stone
therizino for wood
pteranodon for travel.
Almost every game I started REQUIRED these actions. Otherwise I was going to be grinding endlessly for a stupidly low amount of resources for high resource crafts. It's just not efficient, and after repeating this dozens of times, it gets very tiring.
2. Building is an issue. Not one bit of it is enjoyable. Getting the resources, finding a perfect base spot, and building are all frustrating due to the many scuffed bugs that happen during building in particular. Most of the time I dread this, in fact.
3. The absolute necessity that is meta. If you wish to do well, in single player or pvp, you must do specific things. Tame specific dinos, build in inaccessible areas, and breed for hundreds of hours. The game feels very stale, especially for those who are not masochists like those who unironically play on official servers.
4. Most buggy and glitchy game I've ever played. I can't even get into words how frustrating it is losing your character and/or your dinos to a mesh glitch.

Pros:
1. Once you've worked yourself up from a measly little grub on the beach, boy do you feel powerful. The game feels extremely rewarding for pushing past your frustrations and annoyances. Nothing can stand in your way, though when building up, it is very much possible to lose every little thing you worked for. Creates a sense of danger every moment you play the game, which is nice for those seeking a thrill.
2. Highly customizable settings are this game's best attribute. It's truly amazing how you can either play a relaxing save or constantly dangerous and thrilling gameplay. It's all up to you.

Not much else I can say besides, play the game if you're a masochist :)

Where to begin...

ARK Survival Evolved is unlike anything you have or will have ever played. A sandbox survival experience in every sense.

From it's initial reach of simply surviving an island overrun with dinosaurs looking to eat you at every turn, to taming them and building your army, as you rise through the ranks of overcoming your survival limitations, in both character progression, and knowledge, to engage with an overarching story that take you from a primitive level of thatch hut living to commanding the skies in tek tier, being able to build as far as your imagination takes you, and using just that to create your own stories, across a range of play modes suited to your play style, in a competitive MMO where the race to be ahead of the competition, and fearing throughout will always be at the forefront, learning new ways to play the game, whether it be just simple in-game mechanics, or full blown game changing mods... and after 7 years running, can still feel as fresh as when you first played it, creates an offering you will never experience elsewhere.

ARK is love. ARK is life.
