I love this game, but only in singleplayer or cooperative servers. PVP servers take all of the fun out of it for me. Overall an excellent game, very difficult at first. You will die a lot. It has a story but the game isnt focused around it very much.

Yes, but only if you have tweaked the world rules. The concept is solid, the core gameplay is fun, if somewhat staightforward, and while I have my own personal gripes with how the creatures scale to each other and the player, (like seriously, how does a 10 tonne triceratops lose to a 2 tonne carnotaurus, why does a 7 tonne parasaurolophus have no defences, why is the giga so enormous) the only real issue with the game is the grind. Resources are heavy, you can only carry so many, and you need loads of them for anything. Taming and breeding creatures can be agonisingly slow, and working at night is suicidal due to minimal visibility. If you are interested in the game, I can only reccomend making night time as short as possible, making taming and breeding speed as fast as possible, and making weight increase a bit faster.

Oh and good god, the graphics settings are broken. Gloves don't render in when you spawn, so you have to unequip and re-equip them, I have yet to find graphics settings that don't leave everything looking kind of pixellated, and the only way I've found to stop the game being stretched and distorted in fullscreen is to go into windowed mode, then back into fullscreen. It doesn't save either, you have to do it again whenever you log in.

Other than that, pretty damn good.
The only positive I have to say about this game is that no matter what PC you have, it will run like hot garbage.

Do you enjoy dying for stupid reasons?  How about potentially game breaking bugs?  Or waiting hours on end for a virtual animal to wake up so you can ride it.  Well if you answered yes to any of these questions then I believe ARK is for you!

The playerbase is toxic and will destroy all your hard work in a matter of a few hours!  But there are good sides to the game too right?  Yeah, I just cant think of any while writing this review.  And that is why, I am going to give this game a 9/10.  I cant put it down.  Even when I think I am done, I always come back to it.  It's fun with friends I guess.  Idk.  I can feel myself slowly slipping into madness. Been up for 32 hours.  Sleep deprivation is fun right?

I have over 500 hours in this game on PS4, compared to a lot of ARK players I'm still a noob, so if you aren't ready to turn this into a full time job, don't even bother thinking about getting this game. I'll explain why this game is a full time job later on, but basically it punishes any player that can't or won't play it 24/7.

First I'll talk about the PvE. I started playing PvE on a private server with friends and had tons of fun discovering everything there is to enjoy. We started on The Center, the biggest and in my opinion the coolest of the three maps. The beginning is the hardest part for new players. Every dino you meet can easily kill a noob, even the spitter dinos. It can be annoying running around naked and getting killed by raptors, but stick with it and find your friends and build a safe place. Once you get the base built, the game gets so much more fun. Every new dino you find is cool, and it so fun the first time you get all your friends together and explore a cave. The most dangerous foes we encountered in PvE were the alpha predators. Our base got destroyed multiple times by alpha raptors, but it was fun because it showed us that even though we had a big base with spike walls and guard towers, there was still a threat out there that had to be beaten. Of course once you build a metal base nothing can break it anymore, and once you tame flying mounts you don't have to worry about dangerous expeditions so late game it got boring. We basically got to the point that nothing PvE had to throw at us outside of boss battles was a challenge, and even fighting bosses had no point because what would we use the tek gear to kill? Harder versions of that boss? That's why we decided to turn to PvP to see if that was better late game.

Pro tip, don't PvP. This game is designed in such a way that the big tribes that are on top stay on top. New tribes and new players just get pooped on in every single way unless they join an alpha and become a resource harvesting slave. Let's walk through all the reason PvP is horrible.

1.) Alpha tribes. They wipe the server once or twice a week and completely blow up any new players base and kill their dinos. They own the server, they won't let anyone else even enjoy the game.

2.) Unless you're alpha, you don't get a base, they might let you live in a thatch hut. Refer to reason 1.)

3.) Unless you're alpha, you don't get to tame dinos, they might let you tame dodos. Refer to reason 1.)

4.) Unless you're alpha, you don't get to upgrade any of your gear. Alphas block all loot drops (the good ones anyway) and fill all the caves with auto-turrets to gun down anyone that tries to explore them.

5.) Alpha tribes are literally impossible for smaller tribes to fight. They have huge metal bases with hundreds and hundreds of turrets and plants that will mow you down if you so much as look at it wrong. Rockets get shot down in mid air by these turrets, and you won't get close enough to plant c4. You won't be able to bring dinos to tank the turrets either, refer to 1.)

6.) Offline-raiding. Just imagine working for 2-3 weeks building a pretty cool base completely surrounded by plant-x and taming about 20 dinos then logging on to see a smoking crater where your base was. You don't get to save any of your gear, you don't get to save any of your dinos, you don't even get to fight back, it's all just gone. This happens all the time, and honestly offline-raid protection should be baseline on all servers.

7.) Battlemetrics. Alpha tribes and griefers use this website to figure out if you are online or not. If you log off for some reason, sleep or work or whatever, then they will know and they will raid you. They can even get text alerts that tell them the second you have logged off or on, or if anything else unusual is going on on "their" server. Basically, this site and sites like it are cancer. Also, it doesn't tell them your in game name, but your steam name, that means even if you make another character they will know it's you. Also, if you piss them off and try to go to another server, they can just look up where you went using Battlemetrics and come find you. There is no hiding and no escape, so you have to be nice and can't even PvP or else some loser with no life is going to come and find you on every single server you go to. If you run into anyone named "123" and a private profile, BEWARE!

8.) Breeding. Just another way to keep big tribes on top. They have huge metal air-conditioned rooms where they hatch 20 eggs at once, each hatched dino is gonna be 2x the level of anything a noob will have.

9.) Tek gear. If the fact that they have 2-3x better gear by monopolizing all loot crates wasn't a big enough edge, if the fact that they have 2-3x better dinos by building huge breeding rooms wasn't a big enough edge, now they get tek gear too. If they come at you with anything tek and you have baseline gear and baseline dinos, you are DEAD!

10.) Ark is a full-time job. You must log on every day to feed dinos or they will die. Breeding and imprinting are horrible and time consuming processes that I won't even touch. You must log on every day to make sure you haven't been raided, and you must grind harder than everyone else to make sure you have the defenses and dinos to stop raiders. Don't bother, you won't.

Look, I'm tired of typing this review, just know that if you enjoy PvP because you enjoy winning through skill, then don't PvP. No PvP skill is required at this point, their gear will have much higher armor and damage, their dinos will have much higher hp and damage, just accept your death and wipe multiple times because you will lose everything and you won't even be online to defend it, not like you'd have a chance even if you were.

EDIT:
I never expected my review to actually be popular, but now that it is I feel like I should address all the kids telling me I suck and that I'm still a noob who doesn't know what he's talking about.

Firstly, this is NOT a skill based game. This is a grind based, offline raid based, exploit based game. You can't come here and say I'm a noob, especially when I've played the game solo and as a small tribe for over 300 hours, and I joined an alpha tribe for a week or two so I know how it goes on a larger scale. My opinion actually got even worse after joining the alpha tribe because I realized just how bad the game panders to them. Here are some more reasons why I will never recommend this game to anyone that I found from my time with the alphas.

1.) Alpha tribes can grind resources WAY easier than a new player. Now, you would probably expect this. After all, they have more players so it is only natural that they could send 5 out to grind while your tribe could only spare 1. No, numbers isn't even what I'm talking about here, I'm talking about EXPLOITS with a farming dino and a Quetzal. A noob with a hatchet can get 50-60 wood from a single tree. An alpha tribe can get 1500 wood from a single tree. A noob with a pickaxe can get 50-60 metal from a vein, an alpha tribe can get 300 metal from a vein. A noob would take hours to farm 1-2k metal, an alpha tribe can farm 20-30k metal in an hour. The list goes on and every single resource you can think of they can get insane amounts much faster and easier. Now, noobs wont know how to do this, and wouldn't be able to because Quetzals are hard to tame, and hard to hide from alpha tribes. If they saw you flying around harvesting, they would bring a Wyvern after you and start looking for your base.

2.) Large scale PvP is extremely laggy. The servers are supposed to support up to 100 players, but if you get more than 20 players in a server, the lag becomes unbearable. Once again, alpha tribes exploit this by logging as many people as they can onto a server (kind of like DDOS) to block out defenders from connecting, or to force the server to get so laggy that you can basically avoid taking damage from things.
Don't touch Official Servers or PVE Servers and the game is fairly good.
Even when i didnt play the game alot and have almost no hours. Its a fun game to play with friends!

A terribly designed, unfun game meant for 10-year-olds. I have no idea how this... awful game is popular. Because it's the only one with dinosaurs I guess? The UI is abysmal, the gameplay loop is dull and punishing for no reward, and everything is hostile. It's basically an extremely polished example of what I'd expect to see if 10-year-olds were AAA game developers. As if to underscore the point, the game makes a HUGE point of having everything poop--constantly--and with great audible fan-fare. Ark might only surpass Subnautica in its level of utter lack of explanation. No tutorial, no guide, no anything. Button mappings don't even follow customary genre guidelines, as if to just make it even more needlessly annoying. This "game" is a horrible mess from top to bottom, and I'm not even complaining about the performance (which is... fine... I guess). It's not fun, not interesting, grindy as hell, and needlessly punishing. Just to do what... ride a dinosaur? Whoopdee-do. Oh, and how do 10-year-olds make friends with dinos? By literally beating them unconscious and sharing lunch with them. Yup. Makes sense. Avoid this game, unless you're 10 and grinding for 60+ hours being killed by unseen things constantly makes you excited. Or you just want to literally beat dinosaurs unconscious with a club over and over again. I got this game for free and it still isn't worth it.

Worst gaming experience i've had ever, bad performance, horrible UI, lack of game design, boring gameplay, and so on. Most positive reviews of the game are memes or plain jokes. 

Even if you got this game for free, you were scammed.

Truly horrible server issues, such as completely losing your character out of the blue, and having to create a new one, which means you lose all your stuff and your tamed dinosaurs. Even in dedicated servers. 

Honestly fed up with all the troubleshooting, forum browser etc to try and fix issue after issue. Today we spent about 4 hours total setting up to play. To once we were done, my character being gone. We didn't get to play or do anything with this free time, it's not the first time, certainly it won't be the last and support is useless. If I could I would get a refund at this point and scrub ark from memory.

Was starting to lose hope in video games with the abundance of microtransactions and repetitive mechanics amongst other games. This game has blows me out of the water so far and I'm still in the early portions of the game 62 hours in. There's a plethora of mechanics that synergize  with one another incredibly well. There's no pay for any in game advantage, and, I haven't even experienced the pvp component of the game as well. 10/10 would recommend.

Before i played ARK: Survival Evolved, i had a small wee-wee, no friends, no girlfriend, depression,and absolutely no life. These things haven't changed, but the game is pretty good.

I recommend this game especially if you got it for free like me. It's far from a perfect game but it does a lot of things right. However there's so many things that bother me in this game.
Don't get this game if you plan on playing on your own. Playing with a friend or make a new friend is a much better experience!!!!!

+ So many hours worth of content
- A large portion of it is just doing chores like feeding your dinosaurs or grinding materials.
+ This game has great progression, not overwhelming whatsoever
- This game is painfully difficult to start on depending where you spawn. You can't really fight back against anything significant and any dino can ruin you.
+ The dinosaurs are cool and often have a lot of useful abilities.
- The AI of the dinosaurs is pretty awful
+ You can make bases the way you want
- There's pillars everywhere claiming territory where you want to build, this is very annoying.
+ PVE community is a good community.
- I keep glitching through the floor when I log out and get drowned by someone so they can steal my stuff.
- This game demands you to get on a very frequent basis, otherwise you'll be punished heavily
- THE SERVERS ARE SO BAD
- Raising some dinosaurs is so tedious, it's not fun and takes up so much time.
- In PVE people can troll you and go offline and there's nothing you can do against it.

ARK is a busted, ugly, broken ass game, but there's a reason people enjoy it so much, the developers have clearly cashed in on a niche that hasn't been explored in this way before and there's a lot to enjoy, I just wish that one day they could optimize their damn file-sizes. Also research into the behaviors of these animals could do the game some good, rather than just random spawns of animals and basic "see food enemy, eat" AI, with as long as this game has been out, there are a lot of aspects that could have been given love and attention. Regardless, this is a decent little dino survival game, it just needs more attention in places that matter, it's fun and all to have all these giant maps with cool dinosaurs, but it's for naught if the rest of the game isn't polished and fleshed out.

The premise of this game is something I've wanted in a video game since I was child. However, there are a number of really obvious base level issues with this game that the devs never bothered to fix which severely hold it back. So much wasted potential with this game. I got the base game when it went free and bought the DLC pass for $20USD and definitely regret my purchase. 

The first issue is obvious when you try to download the game. I bought the DLC pass and went to download all the game + the DLC listed on the store page. The files are apparently not compressed. The game takes 432.6GB on my harddrive without any additional mods being added. You should also expect frequent downloads to the game ranging from less than a GB to 10s of GB. 

Second, the animal animations are hardly existent. My first encounters with animals showed me that them attacking basically consist of them running into you and a hitbox on the front of their head doing tick damage every few tenths of a second rather than them actually animating attacks. The walking animation are obviously clumsy and look like something from an alpha build of a game with animals getting stuck on terrain features, walking up impossible cliffsides, and sometimes randomly flying into the air. Also, beware of flying Kaprosuchus, my first game I was "ambushed" by it and it literally jumped 50+m into the air with my in its mouth. 

The game is filled with bugs past just the animals. In multiplayer servers, you will frequently encounter players that are under the map. Even in single-player, these bugs can be frustrating. Multiples times I've just been walking along and die randomly to weird collision meshes on the maps.

Animal AI is also a joke. Animals will pick fights seemingly without any regard to the winability of the battle (you routinely see small animals pick fights with apex predators and get predictably destroyed.) You'll also see things like herbivores you get a bit too close to chasing you relentlessly across the map. Once combat starts, the animals essentially just sprint at you doing tick damage for you hitting their hit boxes and don't stop. Most animals are reduced to killing machines that fight anything within their detection range. 

After you get a grasp on that, you'll see that the leveling system is a lot of grinding. ARK becomes a chore simulator as you work to feed yourself, your dinosaurs, and level up. The system they have in place isn't fun nor rewarding. After playing, my friends and I largely felt like it was a waste of time. 

Next comes issues with crafting, one of the core features of this game. The crafting menus are terribly designed, with obvious category issues like "wooden stairs" not being listed under "wooden structures."  The UI is very clunky, after you finally level up and unlock many of the craftable things, you pretty much have to use a search function and remember the name (if you don't, it could take up to multiple minutes to find a specific item.) Building also has a bunch of weird quirks that at times made me laugh at the absurdity of it. The distinction between what is craftable by your person, and what you need some sort of crafting station for seem completely arbitrary. The placement of structures onto the ground is not great and often leads to buildings look pretty bad without putting a lot of effort into it. The most I laughed while playing this game came when I was trying to build a bridge. I knocked out support pillars and one of the 2 sides connecting it to land and nothing happened, but after rebuilding them, demolishing a single floating pillar left alongside the bridge made the entire thing collapse. 

I'll also mention that one of the things listed as DLC (Primitive+) is completely broken and unusable. I have attempted to play this, but it pushes load times way up to 20+ minutes. Chances are it will crash quickly if it does manage to load. When I looked on the forums, the community acted like people asking about this were idiots for expecting something listed on the official Steam page to work. It's not supported at all by the devs.

Lastly, the community is extremely toxic. This is easily one of the most toxic player communities I've encountered. The way servers are set up seem to promote griefing so that it forces out randoms and their slot of the sever can be taken by friends of the griefers. I would recommend avoided any public server, unless getting repeatedly killed when you start by players with high level gear over and over and over is your idea of a fun time. Anytime you mention problems on forums, fanboys basically act like your an idiot for expecting basic issues to be fixed by the dev. Practically any forum thread I've seen with some criticism or legitimate concerns about the game has them getting insulted for posting.

From playing the game, it's obvious the devs released this into early access and just keep piling new things on the game to encourage people to buy new DLC rather address the core issues with the game, and it's really disappointing.
allways been a fan give it a try
great game 4 survival game nerds ( totally not me) or dinosaur  chads.

Ark definitely has some flaws, but it's a great game nonetheless. I picked it up a couple months ago (at review time) when it was free, but it's definitely worth $30. There are also plenty of free DLC maps to download and play (they take up a lot of space because of their size though, so be ready for that).  I would recommend turning down the difficulty settings, especially for a first run, because this game is hard on its defaults. To summarize it, it's good fun in singleplayer, and great fun in multiplayer.

I want to start this off by saying that I am on the fence about recommending this game. The game is pretty, fun, entertaining, great for people who like dinosaurs/fantasy creatures, and those who like modding games. However, the game is very badly optimized (as I am sure many have said before me). This can cause the game to run badly on lower end pcs. For example, my old desktop pc that I purchased in 2015 struggled to run this game from 2016 to 2019 (I upgraded to a new pc in 2019 but we will get to that later). Single player was okay to run, however, I wanted to play with friends on a server. It could take me 30 minutes to 4 hours to get into the server. I could also crash at any moment in the game, anywhere. Yet, I still played the game all the time because I loved it. That's part of the reason I'm so torn about this review. I love the game when it can be played how it is meant to be played, but the optimization, occasional game breaking bugs, and huge download stray me away from a positive review. Currently on my new pc, I have no troubles running the game. I still love the game, even if I haven't played it in a while. 

TLDR: The game is hard to run on low-end pcs but for those who have higher-end pcs, it's a fun game with plenty to do. I mean, look at my hours.

In the year 1993, Hollywood saw something unlike anything else, the film Jurassic Park. Never before 1993 had dinosaurs been so breathtaking and realistic on the silver screen.

The plot is very original. A group of scientists cloned dinosaurs, and are about to open an amusement park where people can see the dinosaurs. The creator John Hammond(Richard Attenborough) invites a group of people, along with his grandchildren, to see the dinos and enjoy a relaxing time at the park. Could anything go wrong, at the time it doesn't seem like it, but something else is going on. Employee Dennis Nedry is planning to steal dinosaur embryos. In order to do this, he causes a security breakdown so he can get the embryos and escape. He isn't the only one that can escape, as hungry dinos also escape. After this, everyone on the island is in danger, and loose dinosaurs are everywhere. That is where the fun in Jurassic Park comes in.

This is an underrated movie according to the IMDb ratings. It isn't even in the top 250. Today, people don't appreciate it as much, mainly due to the fact that other movies like it have been made. Growing up in the 90's, this was one of my favorite movies. As a kid, I only watched it to see the dinosaurs, as I didn't understand a whole lot of it. Today, I realize how great the plotting and suspense are.

This spawned two sequels. The second one wasn't bad, but the third wasn't very good. I would recommend seeing the second after this, but the third is passable.

The story is great, how at first we see how the magic was created, and then later we see the magic turn into a disaster, in which everyone's life is at stake.

The special effects are still good today, but they were revolutionary for back in 1993. The acting is good, and the ensemble cast is great. All of the action sequences are perfectly executed, creating plenty of suspense and tension.

Younger kids may get scared by this, as I remember a lot of young kids being scared by it in 1993. If kids aren't scared by dinosaurs, they will probably enjoy the movie.

I highly recommend Jurassic Park. It is quite underrated in my opinion, it deserves more credit than it gets.

Watch this at all costs if you have somehow missed it and see what everyone was amazed about back in 1993.

Lots of google searching required. Very weak guidance on subtle gameplay mechanics. You will die and lose progress for dumb reasons constantly. Menus are a compromise between controller and keyboard; best of neither world, average of both. Once you get past these things and grasp all the ins and outs, the game can occasionally shine.

Beautiful worlds, although the coloration of the creatures is downright absurd sometimes.
Fairly good setting for graphics, brightness control is via command line. Not the most fun but what's a survival game without survival challenges, right?

Movement is poor. Physically, you are more like a ball than a biped. You will ramp off cliffs for no reason and die from fall damage instead of sliding down. Go s-l-o-w-l-y. Recommend attempting parkor constantly because it WILL be a survival skill. I've been chomped plenty after failing to escape by tying to jump over/past obstacles that are knee high.

Okay that's all. Go have fun. Best with a friend.

I love this game.  There is so much to do. You can play PvE for casual mode where you can build up epic and unique bases and decorate it. There are plenty of dinosaurs and pets to tame.  Many dinosaurs have some sort of purpose to help you advance in the game like helping you obtain materials faster.  In PVE mode you can play at your own pace with out worrying about your base being destroyed. If PvP is your thing, they got that to. In fact, the biggest Ark community are pvpers. In PvP mode you build bases to defend and you raid others.  Dinos also help you with these things too.  Its extremely immersive. The maps are beautiful with many different terrains and ecosystems. There is literally something for everyone in this game.  I'd recommend this game to everyone.

I got this game when it was free, I knew I couldn't play it because my ROG pc died a few weeks ago. So I rented at GeForce Now (Cloud gaming. If your pc sucks like mine, give it a try, but Nvidia is not the only one, make sure you check out their compatible games) and discovered one amazing game.

Not always easy to figure out if you are like me and do not look at tutorials or walktroughs but when you discover something new you're super glad about it.

You're going to die a lot at first (Probably), but the amazing graphics and polyvalent gameplay are gonna make you continue. HUGE inventory (So far I added and added and never went out of space), lots of nice little crafts and interactions with the dinosaures. The only thing I would say is bad is the way you tame them. Not scary but can be nerve tensing at some moments. It's a survival so yeah, you're going to have crafting, fishing, hunting and building. This game is horrible in the worst way possible. It lures you into a good game that requires a lot of time and once you put in that time and effort, the game break in one of A MILLION different ways. 

Hours of work will disappear because the game decides not to save when you upload things to a new server or an invisible rex in the middle of the ocean killing all your dinos while you just sit there wondering why you ever decided to give this POS another try.

Concept is great, and when it works its a very empty open-world game with not much to do but exist and survive, but i like that. The problem is IT NEVER WORKS. The moment you think "That freak glitch could never happen again", some ENTIRELY different freak glitch manages to destroy hours of work.

It feels like a gut punch. And that horrible feeling of being robbed IS ABSOLUTELY NOT made up for by the game play. The gameplay is LITERALLY just making stuff and having stuff and trying keep that stuff by playing well. When that is taken from you through no fault of your own the ENTIRE EXPERIENCE is completely gone.

TL;DR The game is broken and it will make you very angry and sad more often than happy or entertained. DO NOT BUY.

Game Pros
• Open World
• Weapons ranging from spears, to rocket launchers, and turrets
• Weather System
• Multiplayer
• Crafting system
• Consistent updates
• Day/Night Cycle
• Ton of skills to master
• Base building
• Grouping/Spawning System
• PvP/PvE
• You can tame/ride dinosaurs
• Steam workshop
• Selfie/Orbit Cam so you can look at yourself
• You can host Servers and have access to console commads
• 3rd person (Can be accessed on servers that have it enabled)

Game Cons
• Requires a very decent PC to achieve stable FPS
• Dinosaurs hover on certain terrain (Very minor)
• Dinosaurs need pathfinding work
• Chance of spawning on a hostile dinosaur, killing you upon spawn
• WARNING: Hackers
• Developers released DLC before the game was anywhere closed to finished
• Terrible optomization for full priced game. Especially if you buy it knowing you have an outdated graphics card.
• Developers provide little or no customer support

Relateable Games
• Rust
• The Forest

Conclusion
ARK is an amazing game, But rememeber that the game is still in ALPHA STAGES. It still has a ways to go before it finished, but it is headed in the right direction. It gets your heart pumping when you have a lot to lose, and you got a giant dinosaur chasing you down through a forest.

Score
65/100

This game is great, you will get lost in the beautiful map designs and the evident hard work these devs into this game. Modding is easy as almost all are available through the workshop. Almost if not all of the game settings can be adjusted before playing.

However... a warning must be noted. This game is just as brutal as it is fun. When playing this game you must be prepared and welcome death as it can and will come to you quickly and often. It doesn't matter if just spawned on the "easy" spawns or have progressed to mid/late game on a map. One false move, misstep and you die. This game can be fun and you will lose yourself and sense of time in it. But this game can also be brutal and does not care for your feelings and will drop you into the game as immersive as possible, lost and confused.

Oh, I also recommend playing either with friends or by yourself. Just stay away from the official servers. Everyone on the is already well established and sweaty and will not hesitate to kill you on site.

The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a quick building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy.

Strategy
When he is jumping over the river, he cannot be targeted by any ground attacking units. The Log and Earthquake will fail to damage a Hog Rider while he is jumping. Air troops can still attack him though, and the Inferno Tower and Inferno Dragon will continue to ramp up their damage.
When countering Hog Riders, obviously use buildings. But be wary as it the offender would usually play around it with cards such as Earthquake. Air swarms such as Minion Horde can help due to the Hog's usual support tools not countering them.
On the offender's side, a powerful move is to accompany him with an Earthquake, obilerating almost every building, and also grounded swarms. To a lesser extent, Lightning could also be used, retaining the same point of almost destroying every building while also crippling troops such as the Wizard or the Hunter.
The Log could also be an effective first play as a cycle, but it only kills swarms and sometimes a non-center-placed Tombstone.
The Hog Rider can be paired with the Lumberjack as both a swarm bait and damage combo. It is a very fast combo with an extremely high damage output potential, so the defender will likely try to counter it with a swarm. If this happens, the offender should use a spell like Arrows to render the defender poetically defenseless. If they manage to defeat the Lumberjack, the dropped Rage will make the Hog Rider even more dangerous than it normally is.
A fast and deadly combination is the Hog Rider and Mini P.E.K.K.A. combo. Both units are fast but the Mini P.E.K.K.A. does much more damage and does not attack only buildings so the Mini P.E.K.K.A. can deal with troops like the Executioner and Musketeer. However, this combo can be defeated with swarms like Skeleton Army, which will defeat both of them since neither of them can deal area damage. They are also unable to target air troops, so the Minion Horde can stop this easily.
A Hog Rider combined with a Goblin Barrel can be awkward for the opponent to defend against. Timing it so that the Hog Rider is tanking the tower shots for the Goblins is the most effective way to deal damage.
A Barbarian Barrel can shut this down with minimal Tower damage for a positive Elixir trade, as long as the Goblin Barrel was placed directly on the Tower. Use another card to counter the Hog Rider if it is necessary.
His fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. However, the Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though they are vulnerable to spells. Swarm cards like Skeleton Army, Goblin Gang, and Minion Horde can also very easily counter him.
Use this to your advantage by placing a bulky swarm dealer in front of the Hog Rider (eg. Ice Golem, Valkyrie) so that the Hog Rider can transport it to the tower faster and also get protection from swarms.
Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand.
The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up small spell.
Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value.

[h1]This is my review after 61 hours of game play:[/h1]

A. [i]Survival game with a harsh learning curve. What doesn't kill you makes you stronger.[/i]

B. [i]There are options the player can choose to make the game easy to extremely difficult.[/i]

C. [i]Graphics are nice but somewhat dated.  But still it's beautiful and playable.[/i]

D. [i]Speaking from experience, as a beginner, it is very intimidating. [/i]

E. [i]I found that it's best played with others on PVE and/or PVP servers.  Choose your server wisely or start your own.[/i]

F.  [i]There is an active player base.[/i]

G. [i]Player base has declined over the years,  but, there are still a few partially working mods that a player can choose to use on Steam to help soften the learning curve.[/i]

H. [i]Each dino has a different use.[/i]

[u]BOTTOM LINE:[/u]

[b]There are a lot of content maps to choose from, so it should keep a player challenged to survive, adventure, harvest, craft, build, trap, kill  and tame wild pets/mounts to do a lot of their dirty work and/or mate to have better pets for many many many hours.

Enjoy[/b]

I am a 41 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 16 now. My son got this game for Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

Guys! I found how to move! you push w to go forward, a to go left, s to go backwards, and d to move left. This made the game quite a bit better because it allowed me to look at different rocks on the beach, but then! I learned how to look around! I moved my mouse and it moved my camera. this let me look at trees and even more rocks. the only downside is you can't look down and push backwards to go into the sky, which limits your freedom. However, once I moved over to a tree to look at it, Get this! I clicked and I punched the tree! I finally got some wood and this made the game harder because I started to move slower, and I picked up rocks to by pushing every button on my laptop and it worked out. This game is really hard and maybe even harder than dark souls, but not nearly as hard as some of the other games I played, like celeste. The graphics in this game kinda look like polygons which reminds me about geometry class in highschool, and I didn't like that class much, but at least my teacher was nice. The polygons also remind me of a diferent game named geometry dash, which was the easiest game I ever played. Also I just discovered that you can push a button to open some kinda inventory, and this is where my wood and rocks go. In conclusion: This game is alright.

I love this game, and its because I fell in love with it long before the server transfers. In its hayday the game was amazing and fun, but with the introduction of server transfers with tames and kits its become nothing more than people taking overpowered duplicated dinos and breaking smaller tribes and starting players bases. This game is not friendly at all to new players and I dont suggest you buy or play unless you know someone with an established tribe already that is willing to welcome you in.

I am a 40 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started Ark Survival and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching black women twerk on Tiktok. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, chose a server, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I mean Ark is good, but not quite as good as Cinnamon Pull Apart Bread!

What you'll need:

- A goofy ahh nonstick pan
- Non Stick Spray
- 2 Tubes of Biscuits (Pillsbury or Otherwise)
- A social security number
- 1 and 1/2 sticks of Salted Butter (Unsalted also works, just be sure to add a 1/2 teaspoon of salt in step 3)
- 4 Teaspoons of Brown Sugar
- 1 Teaspoon of Cinnamon
- 1 Tablespoon of Honey
- 2 Tablespoons of Milk, Heavy Cream, or Buttermilk (Non-Dairy Milks work as well. See Step for more info) (More as Needed)
- 2 Cups of Powdered Sugar (more as needed)

Step 1. Preheat your oven to 350 and give your pan a light coat of non-stick spray

Step 2. POP THEM BISCUITS OPEN BABY!!

Once you get the biscuits out, grab a butterknife (or use your hands you filthy animal) and quarter them. Start laying em out in the pan. Spaces in-between the biscuits is A-okay cause we want that buttersugar to get down in there once we start pouring. Likely, you'll run into the issue of "too many biscuit pieces, not enough space" so just kinda squish em down and try to fill in the edges and corners with an extra biscuit piece. Once you've got all the biscuits packed in there, we're on to step 3!

Step 3. BUTTERSUGAR TIME

Grab your 1 and 1/2 Sticks of butter and we're gon' melt that son of a gun. Personally, I like to melt butter in the microwave, but if you wanna get all fancy and pull out the saucepan then go for it. Ain't nobody stopping you.

So for the rest of us common folk, put your butter in a microwave safe bowl or Pyrex measuring cup. I throw it in there for like 1min and just check on it closer to the minute mark, but we all got different microwaves. Basically, you just want the butter to be melted with no chunks left in it. So however long it takes to do that. DON'T leave it in too long or it'll burn and then you gotta go get more butter.

NOW. You've got your melted butter. Add the Cinnamon and the brown sugar to it and stir the everliving life outta that thing til' it's all nice and pretty. Once you've successfully crafted the buttersugar, pour it over the biscuits in the pan. My two main goals here are "1. Make sure every biscuit gets some love" and "2. Fill in all the cracks" So pour slow and steady.

Step 4. MAKE IT HOT

Okay. Let me level with you here. I am not a classically trained baking professional. I'm just a regular schmegular person who likes the sweety sweets. I have messed these up before and this is the step that made my dad leave. And why did he leave? I ran out of milk.

Double check the oven is on 350. Put the little biscuits in the oven so that they can grow up to be big and strong. Leave them in there for about 10-13min. Be sure to check on your biscuits throughout the process. What you're looking for is the tops to be golden brown. Like that real fresh baked brown, that you see in the movies and tv and recipe sites. Once you see golden brown, open the oven and don't be afraid to get a little greedy. Grab a biscuit off the top so you can see how the middle section and bottom of the pan look.

If it looks doughy Turn the oven off and let the biscuits sit inside for maybe 5 minutes. Again, note the color of the tops and go back to your reference piece that you took out. You want them to look like done biscuits. I can't put pictures but I'll make a guide if people are interested and go back through all the steps with pictures.

If it doesn't look doughy Well then what the heck are you doing? Move on to the next step champ! We got biscuits to eat!

Step 5. Make the Glaze

In a good sized bowl, whisk together your Powdered sugar, honey, and milk. If you don't have a whisk, that's fine. Just go grab a utensil or something. Personal preference: Fork. They look meaner than the other utensils.

NON-DAIRY MILK USERS UNITE!
I really like an almond milk substitute here, but whatever works, works. Just know, with the amount of ingredients we're using here, your glaze may come out thin and runny. If it does, don't panic and cry. Just add a little more powdered sugar in tablespoon increments. Add, whisk and repeat if it still comes out runny. Once it's thick enough, go ahead on.

Take your goofy ahh mixture and and drizzle it over the finished biscuits. And boom done.

First of all, Ark is a good game. Its fun, and has a ton of cool features. Taking everything into account, this is one of the best survival games I have played. Sadly, there are some things that take away from it.
1) PvE gets boring, and you eventually switch over to PvP servers. All the good PvP servers have tribes of people who have poured hours and hours into this game, and as a new player, you have NO CHANCE. Ark has never done server wipes, and most likely never will
2) It takes up around 150 GB pf storage, but you will probably need around 250-300 or so.
Overall, this is a great game, sometimes it can be hard not to be killed by dinos, but thats just my problem! Looking forward to Ark 2!

I'm not sure if this is supposed to be a game, or a load/unload screen simulator.  I have 70 minutes in the game, maybe 10 of which are actually playing it; the rest are spent on an almost entirely black load screen of doom, with no progress bar.

Yes, it's on a SSD, though it's almost completely idle during load.  No, I'm not using mods.  CPU, a 5700X, is pegged at 180% (1 core being constantly used = 100%) while on the load screen.  I think you'd probably have more fun mining Bitcoin.

I love sandbox games and this has quickly moved to the top of being my favorite!  The initial gathering is very, very easy allowing you to get decent gear early on in the game.  
Once you start taming dinos, it becomes even more interesting!!  Especially if you have others helping you.  I had some initial issues early on, dying quite a bit.  Once I was helped to get a better dino, things got even easier (again).  
I haven't fought any bosses yet.  That's on the horizon.  Currently just having fun building, taming and constructing things.  
If you like those kinds of games, this is a great one.  I'll return and update my review once I get further into the game.

I enjoyed this game for what it's worth and I'd honestly play it again, but this game is a 400 gb memory and resource processing vampire, ergo I couldn't play this game if I wanted to. At the very least i ask that the Devs at least try to optimise their first game before working on a second. Why does a game like this need a sequel in the first place when you have 11 "DLC" packs? and this last point is a personal gripe but the game has strayed from simple prehistoric survival to sci fi shoot-em-up. Wildcard if you want people's patronage please at the very least make sure your game isn't limited to running on supercomputers.

TLDR: game is 400 gb, doesn't run on modern gaming PCs, is making an unnecessary sequel, and cares little about QoL patches.

Would recommend 10/10.  Rage - Yes. Fun - Yes. Laughs - Yes - Sadness - Yes. Do I continue to play - Yes!

Review: I regert not buying this game sooner, but I did get it for free from steam by waiting a couple of years. This game is pretty fun hands down. Survival is a byotch at first. Learning the ropes will lead to your death so many times. But its worth it. Once you evolve and learn taming tricks, your gold. The fun soon begins and man, I could only imagine how fun this would be on a private server with friends.

Tips: Raptors suck, garbage tames. Your first *carnivore* should be a baryonyx, found near swampy areas. 1-2 of these guys will be pretty strong until you get some of the later game tames (keep them after, they are great for mid game under water play). And EVERY resource is important, dont dump any of it. If your low on space, build more storage.

Where to start, first let me say that even though I have purchased all the expansions for Ark, both times I have gotten the base game were when it was free, once when it was Free on EGS to see if I even liked the game, the other when the base game was free on steam a few weeks ago. Though I have purchased the base game as a gift for multiple people in the past 3 years base game and both battle passes. Ark truly is one of the best survival games I have played, and though most of my experience is playing via my private cluster with slightly higher than normal rates (its Evo Event all the time) I also see the appeal of playing on the official servers. The modding community is one of the best, and the fact is some times no matter how long you play the game you still get jumped by a kapro after you think everything is cleared out and it makes you jump in your seat a little. Every play through is different, because the world itself is alive.

I've played this game multiplayer with my friend for some time now in steam and epic, i had played a bit of single player as well but mostly multiplayer. and we nearly played together nearly for 720 Hours in epic and 100 in steam.


i remembered  the first day we spawned in the island easy location beside a river in a 5x PVE spanish server.
my friend's character, Grandpa Rick, died in the time it takes me to make my character ,Rose, by a Raptor.

when i spawned i find myself scratching my hand with a weird thing inside my flesh ewwww. first i gathered stone and punched some trees to gather important stuff as my friend said i would need to make stuff. as i was gathering berry i saw a 
black crocodile (Sarco) i knew crocodile are dangers but damn they run fast. here it goes my first death about 5 min after i started game. we joined together to make a base we started making or house with wood. of course im not a builder my friend is i am a man of doing the job. if it is with me i will make a cube and call it home, but my friend makes gorgeous house out of wood. we started taming dinos. then we made a raft and we called it a day.
day 2 was a great day we went north with raft from east side of map it took us about 1 day of game day. we went to mountain to tame argantavis. i got a great white argantavis decided to name her Snow(it was the time GOT movie) and we got another male one he was yellowish color like noon called him noon.

after that some one called for Help an alpha Carno and alpha raptor attacked their base. it was a call to arms all players in server gathered to go help them. we didn't know how power full an alpha carno is, but we went when we arrived we were the first Host to come for help. we started with Raptor and placing our defenses. we nearly got Raptor we were there duck till dawn. if only she was not a deadly beast. i died and my friend killed her. it was in that time the next Host arrived to help 3 people together we were 6 people we got  the alpha Carno and called it the best day ever.

after that we went to a PvP server(oh S#IT u know how it is going to be) in pvp we made our base with stone in east near swamp. we tamed lots of things, but we got our first Rex. and then we saw a GIGA ,damn beast, we tamed GiGA with some tricks and made him trap on some stone so he couldn't move after he got to sleep my friend went to bring food for him but the torpor went down like CRAZY i was near sea i killed a jelly fish and got him like 1000 poisen XD. we tamed him and went to our base, suddenly 2 players came with DRAGONS(wyvern) wtf was that we both didn't knew about wyvern we had no defense a they laughed and killed every thing we had. we went to another server and again some players attacked our base. we had defenses but they had the upper hand we ran to crystal map.

now start good parts- in pvp we were in love with crystalmap. we saw wyvern and ran our as$es away(we didn't know crystal wyverns are passive) we made a base in far north east side of map in an frozen island with extra defensiveness and we got ourselves lots of wyverns. one day i saw a base in east side of map on floating islands (name of tribe nobody) 3 turret tower 50 in each (one of towers were empty) i wore my ghily suit found a bush and began spying on them for 3 real hours in first day. i had their dinos counted lots of gigas, Rexes wyverns... i stood there for 1 more real week there and began writing when they are online on a paper a had their schedule of when they get online i counted 3 people . we started to make plan. we had details of every tree every rock. we decided to attack them on Monday 2am. when we woke up to start the attack the server were offline due to update. but we had plan B we should start the attack in 7am that day. 

the time came we moved our X plant, 5 turet, quetzal and 2 extra wyverns. first i shot the gigas so they followed me, i trew them off the clif. easy pz lemon squeezy. we started to plant the X plants and turets. we shoot the wyverns they came, they died. we managed to find a way near them without their turet tower attacking us(poor planing from them) we made an entrance inside their base some aggressive dinos where there killed them easly. we went upstairs they were 4 players i counted wrong but they were sleep we handcufed them and looted them GOOOD. after a wrong C4 planing turet towers now began to shoot us we tried to stop them with Rock elemental but did't work so we returned happly. we laied low for a while. it was from 7am to 11:30 am. after some day we went there every thing was gone. they went somewhere else.

we decided to go to Ragnarok when a hacker got us out of no where with extra fast griffin. it was like griffin was flying in creative that fast. they imprisoned us. but i was smart they were hacker, i can eat s#it. i ate my s#it so i got unconscious after i woke up i was out of prison (when u drop it moves a little bit) i freed my friend we began typing /suicide. he went west i went east. the hackers again got him he said they got on top of my head like they knew my location. i saw them coming for me but i went to another map(Crystal) my frind got himself suicide again a ran somehow. we came to our base and gone offline. tomorrow they destroyed our base again how did they find us? 


In conclusion; this game is a lot of fun playing PvE is alot more fun we are now playing pve. single player is a little Boring if u ask me ). But if you have friends willing to play it with you, this game is truly magical, and no other game in it's class can compare to level of drama and storytelling it provides.

I hope this review has encouraged you to buy this game, or at least, brought you some entertainment.

You are dropped on a desert island, naked with no direction and no idea how you got there. only if you are lucky enough to survive and thrive, will you find an actual story that you happen to be a few hundred years late for.

I've played for 771 hours... obviously i like it. I only play single player, and want to beat every map single player, and it is a punishingly difficult game until you are established and in being so difficult, it is that much more rewarding when you finally succeed!  I would recommend changing some server settings to make things less grindy in single player (hatch/mature speed, resource respawn time/distance, day/night cycle) but only once you have surpassed those hurtles and they become less hurtle and more hindrance.

If you play on a server, you will likely be given end-game dinos and become OP quickly, but to me that takes the fun out of earning it yourself.

yes... there are bugs. this game is almost known more for its bugs than for its dinosaurs, and yes it is greedy (379 gig download and you will need more than 8 gig ram to play)... but if you are looking for a truly difficult single player survival series that is incredibly rewarding when you do finally succeed, then play Ark.

This game is such a great concept... but the execution is maybe the worst survival game i have ever had the misfortune of wasting time on.

The game was free when I got it and honestly with how unfinished it feels I cant believe this game ever made it out of Alpha let alone so many downloads.

Pro's 
Dino riding can feel fun.
The game is aesthetically very beautiful at times.
Pooping randomly is still funny.
If you liked dino's as a kid this game feels oddly nostalgic.


Con's
Feels like an awful port that was meant for a console, all of the controls are set to horrid circle menu's and all of the button configurations are so bad the only thing they got right was quite literally WASD and space for jump.
Every single aspect of the building feels awful, from crafting in your inventory to putting the buildings down. Between the awful snap system that is at best so poor it makes Fallout 4 seem advanced... right down to the awful way you need to place random wall foundations that make everything you build look awful.. the whole system needs scrapping.
The Dino's AI, the AI for the dino's is really tragic.. from wanting to be so close they are trying to crawl into your chars mesh and preventing you from moving, down to randomly doing things you specifically said not to leading to the Dino's demise again a rework is needed.
Fortitude as a stat is so imbalanced your char is always loosing health from being to hot or cold, regardless of how much of your hard earned experience you waste in this stat.
Paper items, the speed your armour and other items degrade through use is so fast it feels like your wearing paper or trying to break a rock with a brittle stick, so expect to waste to much of your resources and time on fixing stuff.. its simply anti-fun.
Every biome seems to have an anti-fun Dino's who's only task/ability is to knock you off the dino that your riding and for more anit-fun! they normally have some kind of stun/pin to keep you off and down until you die leading to full equipment loss + the dino you were on dieing.

I could keep going but I think I have made the point here, this game has the potential to be magnificent if your willing to invest an insane amount of time finding mods to make it even remotely playable. 
The entire game feels like it wasn't played by the Dev team or they mistook the word “hard” for the word “annoying”, between basic stuff like building just being beyond frustrating, or you loosing all your equipment because randomly 1 of the dinos you attacked was level 100 among the level 6 ones you were fighting before.. the whole game just feels bad and like it was made to annoy players rather than give satisfying game play.

My Boyfriend loves dino's so im stuck playing this but honestly it feels like more of a let down than it should as you can see with a bit more dev time, or a bit more care into the gameplay this game could have been so good but its garbage.

I have this game on PS4 and PC and I love it. It can be hard to get started, but once you get yourself a few tools and a weapon the game gets really fun and there's so many things you can do. I love building homes and taming the animals. You can ride the animals you tame and use them for various tasks to make life easier. You can grow crops and breed animals and many, many more things and that is just on single player. You can play the multiplayer and build and battle with other players. I haven't tried that yet, but if you're into multiplayer games this would be really fun as well. It's an open world game with multiple maps to explore and each map has it's won unique animals and landscapes. Lots of replay ability.

The game is actually very fun, but that's not why this review is going to be a bit negative.

I sincerely DON'T recommend this game for it's over-engorged file size. You will literally need to uninstall 90% of your library if you want to even run this game with only two of the maps installed. Trying to install more maps than "The Center" and "Scorched Earth" will end up having the file size amount to an abominable 300+ gigs. You will have to install and run CompactGUI to compress the file size, but this will be futile as the developers keep updating the game with more uncompressed files to bloat the game's size even more.

Still after years, the game is still incredibly buggy. Between having items/tames fall through the mesh, to having players aimboting and killing you from outside the bandaries of map or even under the map. The bugs that are fixed are usually only bugs that unintentionally help the player such as stacking taming buffs to reduce the time it takes to raise/tame creatures which take hours. The developers way of keeping players around was to release new dlc instead of fixing the game. 
Everything in this game takes hours to accomplish so if you truly intend on playing official servers, be  prepared to spend hours doing something and have it all destroyed while offline.
Its currently free which is the only reason to think about playing the game. But more often then not you will find your unable to build or tame anything on a pve server due to metal foundations covering entire maps, and on all pvp servers you will likely log in one day to find your entire base flattened, raided, and all your tames killed or stolen simply because the top player on server got bored and went around wiping everyone because they can. Added with the fact that server transferring is easy and you've got maps being owned by one group of players with max level tames and bases everywhere. Servers are /70 yet you'll find a group of 8 maps being owned and patrolled by a single group of players. If you dont like having all your time and effort destroyed while being offline don't play this game. 
If you try to play pve to not have your stuff broken, good luck. The maps are covered entirely with metal foundations that you cant destroy and you cant build near them. All pve maps are extremely laggy and you will find it difficult to even move around without lagging constantly due to the people that were there "first" having massive bases that cant even be loaded in on one screen. And even if you can get past these issues and are able to build on a pve server, the community is extremely toxic. Be prepared to put all your tames in cryopods because if you dont, you will log in to find your tames got picked up by someone and dropped in a hostile place to get your tames killed.
Playing solo the game can be fun simply because you won't lose your stuff, however this is a heavily focused multiplayer game.
Overall the game is fun, but you should only try it if its free. This is a game that many will likely play, have a little fun in, and then rapidly uninstall due to offline raiding, bugs, or the realization that this game is a massive timesink with developers that don't care about their playerbase.

A great survival game with diverse playability. I've been playing for years and have many hours in this game. I get tired of Ark, go play other games for a while then return to Ark and cater the game play the way I want (I run my own server(s) using ASM)

Learning curve is more like climb a very tall skyscraper straight up. I'm not gonna YouTube or Google how to play the game, there should have been a basic tutorial on literally basics with the game, I know the keyboard controls but I have no idea how the heck to use a simple campfire, it acts as a storage, WHAT?? How do you cook?? There's literally no explanation and the menu that "explains" stuff but doesn't explain how to do them!! Give me some small goals/objectives to start SURVIVING but with but NOPE. Good luck figuring out stuff. You're like a baby in this game with knowledge how to survive but somehow it's impossible to figure out how things actually work. Resources, taming, building, stats, controls etc. good luck learning all of them. I don't have the time to play the game if it fails to even teach it's weird mechanics to begin with.

You're better off to watch others to play the game rather than watch numbers of tutorial before you even get to actually START playing the game. That's just the BEGINNING! Am I stupid? Probably, I won't deny it but you can't get anywhere without starting small, it's throwing you right to PHD when you're just in Primary!!!

My friends required we play with mods and so do most servers. And at this point everyone just wants "quality of life" mods that ruin the sense of progression or they want "mods meant for veterans" that make the game so unplayably hard that you can't learn how to play it. And as with most online games, people are not friendly to new players.

Also, the game doesn't look nearly as good as it should for how absolute garbage it runs. My computer could fry and egg and it's sporting a 3080 and 32gb of ram. And that's vanilla; don't even get me started on how it runs with my friends' mods.

Do not buy this.

After years of inferior Linux support that goes beyond incompetence or neglect into outright hostility, the game dev company responsible for this game has pulled Linux support and hosed all our installs in the process without so much as a warning, an apology, or an offer of a refund. Some people say the Windows version works better through Proton than the Linux native port ever did, but some people also say it doesn't work at all for them, and it also takes up way more harddrive space and runs slower. I can absolutely NOT recommend anyone buy this game or support a game dev company that behaves this way.

If you enjoy crafting supplies and breeding animals/dinos and exploring different lands and finding lost notes and treasures this game is for you. you can make this game as easy or as hard as you like so if there are parts you struggle with you can easily change the settings to make the harder bits easier 
e.g. dont like the night time? you can extend the day cycle and shorten the night cycle - so its always daytime. not very good at keeping your character alive? you can make it so you dont keep needing food or water. there is also a creative mode you can go absolutly wild - no strings attached. there are also input commands you can use like in the console version - admit its easier to input commands on console but its not that hard to get used too. also a great way to learn about dinos - apart from 'The land before time'

Although very fun, and a game you can get lost in and spend a whole day playing, it's end-game mechanics are insanely grindy and unfun and offer very little in the way of reward. You can spend dozens of hours first looking for a max/ near max level dino (rex, etc.) for bosses and then find one only for its highest stats to be oxygen and food :) Once you find a high-level AND good stats, you'll spend WEEKS at minimum breeding the wild tame, hoping for good mutations. These RNG mechanics make the game extremely infuriating at times. And for raising the dino, you need to return every 45 minutes just to come up to the baby and press E. If not done, there was no point to raising the dino as it becomes very underpowered.

In addition, the game is VERY, VERY badly unoptimized, causing even the best of PCs to fall their knees in terms of FPS and stutters. JUST to load into the game, it takes around 3 minutes (having mods increases this by a considerable amount.) I'm running an i7-7th gen and a 1060 6GB and I barely get 60FPS on medium settings, 1080p (I get around 30 when at base with my tamed dinos.)

And the glitches. Oh the glitches. Many encounters and multiple-hour long tames can be ruined due to glitches and stupid annoyances (Shadowmane keeps resetting tame progress; insects can come out of nowhere, attack u and ruin taming effectiveness on an ongoing tame; frequent no-reg when shooting a dino, and many more.) This makes it such that the most effective way to tame a dino is through exploits and structure traps.

All this isn't even taking into account PVP gameplay (I spent all my hours on PVE servers,) where game mechanics are exploited to their very limit. Players hiding loot in underground dinos, bases being made in unreachable areas, and extreme dino power unbalancing are just scratching the surface when it comes to PVP issues.

To defeat just one alpha boss (imagine all the bosses), you need to play the game like a full-time job, except there is very little skill involved, making actions in the game very unfulfilling. If you want to sink hours into a game and absolutely lose yourself, ARK is an alluring option to newcomers but is ultimately not worth your time or effort as a player.

It's ok. However, when you decide to pick up a game and play it, there is opportunity cost to consider. There are a lot of things competing for our entertainment time. There are a lot of other things that I'd rather do than to play Ark.

Recommend only non-official servers or single player where you can mod the heck out of it. Th official vanilla game is insufferable, there are so many inconveniences, so many limitations that don't make any sense and so much unfairness on official servers that it's nothing but frustrating. Some, of course, enjoy that, but having almost 4k hours on my Ark timer half on official, half on non-official, I would NEVER go back to official. Not if you paid me.
The game overall is great, I love the idea, the audiovisuals, the content, it took me several years to fully exhaust every single thing that there is in this game and by the time I had, there was something new out :D

There's some broken aspects to the PVP of this game, like not being able to build near others bases (meaning players will build objects all over the map so you can't build anywhere). The other big issue is transferring between servers. I want to play on a fresh server, so I join an arkpocalypse map and then immediately get met by someones max level dino of death that constantly kills me. Another example is when I want revenge on a tribe, so I kick their butts just to be met by more dinos from other servers. No matter how many times I destroy their bases they have other bases stationed throughout different servers so it's pointless to fight them and I can't find their main bases because I have no idea what server their stuff is coming from.

I spawned in punched some trees, and dinosaurs, died countless times, made a base, tamed my first pteranodon that died 5 mins later and put in me a state of despair for a few days. Went back after recovering from the loss of my beloved pteranodon, tamed multiple dinos without getting emotionally attached this time, and killed the pack of raptors that had been terrorising my land only to be ambushed by a trex a few days later that wiped out all my dinosaurs. 10/10 despair simulator would recommend.

I tried playing this multiple times with 2 different people, one who put hundreds of hours into the game and another who was just as new as I was. Both times I felt the janky building mechanics, unfair combat system, and the terrible user interface, I played 6 hours total between the 2 people (on different versions of the game). The whole inventory and crafting system is poorly designed. All most these games need to do is copy Minecrafts systems and add their own flare to it. In survival games it is mandatory to have this aspect well made. 

The game is WAY too difficult in the very beginning of the game. You die over and over again with no clear direction where you are supposed to go or what you are supposed to do. This is simply not fun to me and more frustrating than anything, and I am a Souls vet... 

To put the icing on the shit cake they want 300GB to put this game plus all the maps on your PC, Call of Duty Warzone which is notorious for having a over-bloated file size is only 175GB and this game does not have the right to be this size. Valheim whitch is one of my favorite survival games is only half a gig...

I tried ARK a few years ago but I couldn't get into it. I was recently looking for a new survival game and eventually decided to try Ark again and I have to say its a really great game. 
Don't just run off into the forest when spawning, level up, unlock some engrams and get yourself some easy tames to get started. I recommend maybe a Parasaur to help you farm a bit and a Raptor or 2 as some bodyguards/rides then snag yourself a Pterosaur and take to the skies, just keep an eye on that stamina, 
Also a top tip, 2 low level Raptors are no match for an alpha Allo, I learned that the hard way and we all ended up his dinner :)

There's lots of free Dlc's also, so far only tried the original Island map and the Ragnorok Dlc but they are really good.
Highly recommended game, I just wish I'd got into it sooner.

I do love taming dinosaurs, exploring the environments, and building bases.
But the game is riddled with bugs that have been there for years and the devs doing little to nothing about it.
If the devs would have worked to fix the bugs i'd give a big thumbs up, but since it's been over 5 years and i still can't equip the item-skin "nerdy glasses"  without my underlying helmet still being there, the water still is very broken in multiplayer, several of the maps have creatures randomly hovering in the middle of the air or being stuck in a random rock, the ichtyosauruses still beach themselves and die randomly, i can't really reccomend this game.

If the devs focused on fixing what's already there instead of releasing new DLC every once in a while, that would certainly be preferred. And for chrissake, making the game a bit smaller wouldn't hurt either. With the near 400-gig space needed for the basegame + all the DLCs, this one game is taking a huge chunk out of my computerspace.

If there was another game, just like ark but with less bugs, likely i'd move over to that game instantly.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there’s fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a 56 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing ARK. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son recently started playing ARK. After less than a week, he already had 20 hours of playtime. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account to play with my Son. I started playing, but this was my first time playing a video game since the 90's, so i was quite lost. I asked my Son for help and together we spend hours playing ARK. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my Son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. ARK reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Spent hours downloading the game. Finally finish it up. Friends noticed there is developer sponsored mods so we go and get those since clearly the game dev should be making it easy to play their games with those mods. Then spend an hour after that trying to get into my friends game. Nothing in the multiplayer menu indicating I'm loading in. After 10 minutes i get a timed out message. We talk to our friend who has played it before, says its totally normal. You just have to wait for half-an hour without indication that your actually loading in before you an load in. And if you do the normal thing of clicking "ok" and trying to relog. it blocks you out from getting in without closing the game. For all the good i heard from this game, I can't believe the developers fucked up that bad on basic multiplayer infrastructure. Instead of trying to build a new game, how about you fix this crap so its possible to even play it.
