My experience has been wasted within this concept.  I have 126 hours into just the first map in single-player and 9 different characters.  In that amount of time I learned how to circumvent the software but I did not learn how to play the game, in that amount of time.  Supposedly there is suppose to be some point to the software, but I haven't figured out what that is.  So what have I been doing for my 100+ hours?  I learned how to build a building.  

I learned how to use admin commands to bypass the taming convention by simply hitting TAB and typing: cheat summontamed trike_character_bp_c and then hit enter and a trike of various age will appear. Whoops!  Going to need a saddle: Hit TAB and type: cheat gfi trikesaddle 1 0 0 ,  Going to need some food: Hit TAB and type: cheat gfi kibble_base_special 100 0 0 - if this software had had structure - I probably wouldn't have learned that.  That will save you a helluva lot of time in this game because the Trike is the  number one dinosaur for exploration because if you put points into "Oxygen" your Trike can swim underwater or just on the surface, really well - if you want to go fast the Trike is one of the few dinosaurs whose movement speed can be increased considerably - a Trike in the short-term - is an amphibious - all-terrain tank

I used two mods with my game - Auto Engrams and Pre-made Structures and once I found it I began using "Creative Mode" to quicken the game - instant crafting without the need for ingredients.  Just double-click the item you want and you'll get between 20 to 100+ in an instant.  And that's fine that opens up a whole new aspect of this software.  But I still don't know how to play the game. and I can still only carry just so much - which limits that ability.

If you are going to use mods from the Steam Workshop be advised that to remove any mod that you "subscribe to" from your game.  It must be done from inside the workshop and not the game, manually.  So how do you do that?  Inside the game there will be a window that list available mods that you can activate.  Write down the name of each mod you want rid of, on a note pad.  Exit the game.  Open up Steam and open the Workshop.  Enter each name into the 'search' bar and then unsubscribe to that mod and it will remove it from the game.  

So is there a reason why you might want to keep your mods down to a short list?  Within this window there will be two sections for the mods - the first window just holds the mods and the second window contains those that are active.  However, let's say we have 20 mods in the first window that are inactive and we have two mods that are in the second window that are active.

Exit the game and then re-enter.  Make it all the way back to the mod window and click on "Single Player" button and an error message will appear to tell you that the "loading screen" is installing 20 mods to the game.  You'll have to wait until that's done.  The game is going to do this every time, you try to enter the actual game - it is an extra 10 minute in loading time for you to play this game - so you really want to keep your list down to only those "mods" you actually use.  This game doesn't remember that you have already loaded and installed these mods between sessions.

Little things add up, eventually.  I'm really starting to hate these types of games.  If you a wild hair up your bum and think you might want to increase the level cap of your game and your thinking of looking for videos on YouTube - been there - done that - broke game.  There are two videos one is by a girl who will explain how to raise the level by 250 and then there is Havoc and he will tell you how to increase your level cap to 500.  But to do this you have to be willing to add some information from an out-sourced-document from Google to the game.ini file from within the actual game.  When you do it make a directory and place a copy of the game.ini inside of it for safe measures - because your going to screw this up.  

Go ahead and make the changes by copying and pasting the various paragraphs from the google document.  Although there is one name for the file there is actually two files.  The one by the girl has three paragraphs and Havoc's has five paragraphs.  Now save the file and re-engage with the game.  I was told through these videos that I would get about 418 levels as oppose to the 105 levels I now have and that I could do something similar for my tamed dinosaurs.  Seems worth while -- why wait?

You've heard of "Pandora's Box" right?  I got the 418 levels for my character as a existing character and a new character - my dinosaurs didn't get shit.  It made other changes to my game which neither videos mentioned.  That little bar at the top of the Inventory window that denote your XP, it no longer has the animation that would suggest that XP levels, are increasing.  For my character I lost the ability to interact with the game.  While you can still pick things up using the "E" key.  You can't defend yourself - found that out the hard way - the hot-bar items don't work any longer.  Well, that's real helpful.  The animation for swinging an ax is missing - since I made the change.

To fix what I had done.  I had to do more than replacing copy of the original file in the proper directory.  I had to delete every thing in the "Save" directory: Config, LocalProfiles, and SaveArkLocal.  Before I made this change to my game.ini file I had just revealed all the Island map.  What a pain that was.  After the change I was force to delete the character who had done all that work and now I'm going to have to re-do that.  It took me 3 days, to do that.  Now I don't want to do any thing on this map.

I still don't know how to play this game.  Clearly, you can understand why I can't recommend this game to you.  To do that I would have to know what I'm doing and as you can clearly see, I haven't a clue.

Tl;dr - Do not

The UI is a MESS, things don't look like clickable labels, but absolutely are. Sliders for server settings not only don't work in whole numbers, they also don't give you any kind of idea of scale! There's no VSync option, thanks for that...(You need to manually edit a configuration file to enable it, have fun) and the default settings for non-dedicated servers make other players just teleport back to host if they go too far away, like.... WHAT? Everything just kind of piles up into this huge orchestra of annoying garbage that drags you down and slows down the learning experience, which in turns leaves you extremely vulnerable because YOU'RE IN YOUR MENU LIKE CONSTANTLY TRYING TO FIGURE OUT WHAT THE HECK IS AN ENGRAM????????? So you just keep getting destroyed by random beasts that have decided you look delicious! I can easily see so much potential here, but I can't honestly figure out why people like it, after just this little taste of the game...

You start the game and go yep, this is a fun little diddy ... Then run into bugs and go this game is rubbish. And then you find yourself almost 6000 hours in scooping dino poop to put into poop bugs that will give you fertiliser, that you will use on your crop plots in order to get veggies. Veggies you will use for food and food. Then after feeding your dinos (if not all of them are frozen after 10 years), you go and attend other things, like getting petrol for electricity or getting materials for building stuff. Look game is awesome. No way about it. I do not like reliance on sci-fi, i preferred it as a dino game. But other people love it, I just play Island map even though i do enjoy comforts other maps provide :).  Have a go, you will not be sorry. Do note Ark 2 is coming out soon.

As Someone who has played this game when it first released on PS4, watched videos and lets plays even before that.. To See how far ARK has come as a game is amazing. I probably have well over 1000-2000 Hours in total... The Game itself is a survival game set in a future where Humanity has fled Earth because of many Lore reasons. And created "ARKs" As a way to survive. These ARKs were land masses floating in space around Earth, Which held the rest of Humanity on them. It was also home to many creatures, Extinct animals and Dinosaurs. I wont go over the entire story here.. but Basically Rockwell was a big meanie who was looking for a power to defeat the Titans  who had taken over the planet, but another survivor Helena, also was looking for that power. And in the End Rockwell finds and uses the power to become even more powerful which sets him on a dangerous life changing path. Eventually he gets onto the Colony Ship. You team up with Helena to take him down and in doing so Destorys both him, Helena and the infected part of the ship.. This then Leads into ARK 2.

The game itself has seen better days. Optimization is Abysmal on some maps, Especially Gen 2.. But The Main game, which includes The Island, Center, Ragnorok, Valguero, Crystal Isles, The Lost Island and Fjordur. Is Amazing.. You now have access to most if not all of the DLC Engrams and creatures. And they are planning on adding one more creature known as the Carcharodontosaurus. Over the years they have updated, Patched and fixed a ton of things.. But they also have added a ton of bugs and issues like the optimization for some maps. There are still some bugs that have been in the game since the initial Early Access Release.. Some are pretty funny like how some dead dinosaur corpses just become Eldritch Beasts. But there are some where whole days of progress can be wiped out... 

When this game is working.. It is an experience that can truly not be replicated. Yes there are other survival games like Rust or even The Isle.. But the act of completing a whole map in this game, ascending and progressing to the next.. bringing friends along the way.. defeating whole tribes and becoming alphas or even forming an alliance and taking on these bosses.. Its.. Amazing.. Obviously there are bitter memories as well.. Loss of progress because of bugs, Glitches and probably a hundred other possibilities.. Starting over from scratch.. You will have these memories if you play this game.. You will also have Fond memories too. Ones of your First Tame, Triumph and first Home built.. Your first true loss of your fav dino.. 

The developers have tried to fix everything.. But many will say they didn't try hard enough.. And that is probably true. They deserve criticism for that, Especially when they are making an experience for the next generation. Our feedback will be used as long as we keep providing it.. All these mistakes in development.. Will be used as a example for them to look back on.. as a way for them to Do. It. Right.. ATLAS is a kind of example too. It shows how much they progressed in development..

I Recommend this game fully.. You WILL have a hard time at first.. You WILL probably get frustrated over some bugs(both Physically and also technically lol), You WILL contemplate how much time you want to put in this game that has such a huge grind.. But once you get into it.. Once you found your footing, Watched your first few videos on how to tame a creature, how to efficiently progress.. You will laugh at those first few moments you had.. You will enjoy sipping on your Mixed Berry juice recipe you made, while laying down in your Metal Fortress. And you will look toward the future.. wanting more and you might download a few mods to play around with.. 

The Sheer amount of Dopamine/Accomplishment this game will make you feel greatly outweighs the negatives..  I could sit here and type for hours.. and hours on how much this game is good.. and bad. But the best thing I can tell you is once you have sat here for hours/days possibly weeks/months playing this game.. You will understand what I mean. The Community this game has is also amazing, The Sponsered Mod Program, The ARKitects, The PVP Wars and Alpha/Mega Tribe Wars.. Its amazing.. So many things.. SOO much history is in this game. I Just hope you and many others can be a part of it. 

If you want a more detailed video on the Development on ARK and the history of it up until Fjordur.. I actually Recommend a video I made quite recently. It misses a few things as there was so much to go over.. but It goes over the Game wayy better than I can here.. To anyone reading this I Hope you have a wonderful day..    -   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KsrRDPcK-Ao

Ark is all in all a good game with many great features. The survival aspect is cruel and unforgiving (which i think is a good thing), the overall gameplay feels robust with a few hickups here and there but most of these can be fixed with mods or by tweaking settings which i think is my favorit part of the game! The developers allowing you to customize allmost every aspect of the game with the provided settings menu before launching a your game is awesome! And if there is one aspect of the game that bothers you that you can't seem to get rid of thorugh the provided settings then there are quiet the handfull of mods out there that may/will improve of fix issues. 

I think the game shines the most in singleplayer or with a couple friends messing about, taming dinos and fighting bosses together. And don't make me talk about the DLCs, most of the are great but genesis 1&2 are not that great.

All in all if you are a sucker for survival games and dinosaurs then this game has no superiors, pick it up as soon as you can!

Well holy shit is this game fun.

The maps official and modded are awesome to explore and play with. 

Dinosaurs are fun to run away from, fight and tame for all of the modded and official.

The bosses are certainly quite challenging and tough to go against.


However, here's a few basic things to know and learn. 

1. Stay the fuck away from ANY official PvP or PvE server if you have any interest in keeping your sanity intact.
Plenty of russian, chinese hackers, zerg clans and mesh cheaters galore. These servers will constantly crash and are so laggy, it'll throw you back into the stone age. Not to mention progress is rolled back often so that 7 hours spent on farming resources
or you looted a dungeon and got some super cool loot? Nope, fuck you. It's gone mother fucker and good luck trying to find something like it again.

2. Buy this game ONLY if you have a high end PC, at least a 2080TI if you want decent frames because the performance/optimization is absolutely terrible.

3. Play either single player, private servers with friends you trust completely or unofficial servers with active admins who don't abuse their powers.

4. Do not play with the basic rates for the game unless you really want this game to become a micro managing job all day long.
How long do you think taming a dino can take? 
A: A couple minutes? 
B: A few hours?
C: A couple days?
D: A week?
E: A month?

Answer: Every answer except A. 

Taming dinosaurs takes forever and you have to guard it the ENTIRE time unless you want to redo it all over again. If 
ANYTHING hurts a knocked out dino that's being tamed, you're fucked. If it wakes up mid tame, you're fucked. If you didn't bring enough tranq darts or arrows or you didn't bring enough kibble or food, you're fucked. So you have to wait and watch 
over it the entire time and not be AFK once. Does that sound fun? Oh, let's not forget players can steal your knocked out 
dino you're trying to tame if you're not quick enough.

The same goes for hatching eggs and raising baby dinos until they become an adult. While you deal with less threats, they
still take a long time so that means you're micro managing them.

If you play the game with trusted friends, with boosted rates so taming, hatching and raising dinos are fast, you will be 
playing the game and having fun, not mommy simulator.

If you ever played Rust, the survival PvP game and thought the grind was bad and how the game turned into a chore/job? Ark 
achieves that and far worse on standard rates.


Most of the modded maps on the workshop are incomplete and some are dead with development being canceled.
Tons of new creature mods, new weapons or armor mods out there. TONS and tons of QOL and building mods for all types 
of themes.

Do be wary that mods have a strong impact on your performance, be it from taking longer to load or by lower fps. Don't go 
crazy with installing 30-100+ mods on a map unless you want a slideshow. Your best bet is 5-15 mods that are small in size. Big mods that are 1-2GB's big takes much longer to load so do try to stay away from them even if you have an SSD. 

With no mods on the Island map with an SSD, I can load the map within 3 seconds which turns to 20+ seconds when I add 5-7 small 50MB to 250MB mods.

With the game on a regular HDD and no mods, it'll take anywhere from 7 minutes to 15 minutes. With light mods or big mods installed, that can take at least 30 to 60 minutes long.

Buggy.  Typically for me, it crashes about five times during startup.  Usually once it makes it through startup, it goes for several hours without crashing.  But yesterday, it crashed over a dozen times in a row during startup.  Enough.  I've had it.

Incredibly grindy and unforgiving.  It takes forever to gather the resources you need to do anything.  VERY high learning curve.  Make the slightest mistake, and you die a horrible quick death, losing all the gear you painfully collected.  For a brief time you can return  to your death and recover your items, but if the dinosaur(s) that killed you are still around, forget it.  Basically impossible to play without researching everything on the WIKI.  (What does it take to tame this dinosaur?  etc. ad nauseum) 

The building mechanics are terribly quirky, making it very hard to do what you want.  You only have about 30 seconds to change your mind if you placed something wrong.  After that, fixing things means flushing your hard earned resources down the toilet."Creative mode" lets you get building materials for free, but that seems like cheating.  There is something wrong with a building system when the only workable approach is to bypass its requirements entirely.  The Structures Plus mod was supposed to fix that by allowing you to pick up things even after the 30 second countdown (among a lot of other improvements to ARKS's silly build system), but crazily they decided to de-implement that!!!  What are they thinking?  Is ARK's weird design philosophy catching?  I was trying to switch to the Super Structures mod (which is basically a fork off the Structures Plus mod before they disabled late pick up), but that's when I ran into ARK crashing over a dozen times during startup.  All but about three of those were before even getting to the part where I tell it to load my Island in single user mode with that mod selected.

There is great potential here.  Sad.  Their focus is now on ARK 2, so don't expect them to ever bother fixing the bugs.  Instead they will generate a whole new set of bugs to never bother fixing.  I got this free, presumably as a promotion to get you hooked into buying ARK 2 when it is ready.  Fat chance I'll waste my money on a developer with such a buggy product with such needlessly difficult mechanics.  (They do have an impressive set of sliders and check boxes to let you modify the difficulty, but I don't get the chance to experiment with them when it crashes on startup so often.)

I am a 41 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 16 now. My son got this game for Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

ARK started out as a game that showed promise, despite the bugs and performance issues. Dinosaurs and guns? Count me in!
However, as time went on, it became apparent that the developers (or maybe investors) didn't care to take input from the community regarding the future of ARK.
The game used to be a fairly simple, easy to learn survival game, with dinosaurs and basic weaponry. Then next thing we knew, there are fantasy creatures, paywall animals, and dinosaurs that shoot lasers. So many ridiculous features now exist in ARK that blindsided us.

After 4 years of giving ARK a break, I decided to give it a go, and see if anything's improved. I'd say that it's only gotten worse. I was overwhelmed with the sheer amount of creatures with unpredictable behaviors that infest the map. I finally managed to escape the chaos of the island on a neat raft boat I built. However, even when I thought I was safe, some gargantuan fish came out of nowhere and destroyed [b]HOURS[/b] of work and frustration. The final straw that broke the camel's back was seeing that the developers (or maybe their investors) have now decided to bring politics to Steam. [b][u]I play games to escape politics and other nonsense.[/u][/b]

In summary, if you enjoy playing games that introduce an unhealthy amount of stress and require a vast amount of your time for the grind, then ARK is for you, otherwise, I [u]DO NOT[/u] recommend ARK.

Oh yeah... if you do end of getting ARK, expect to lose 150+ Gigabytes of space if you plan on using any of the DLC. The developers didn't bother with file compression.

If you want my opinion on some of the dlcs scroll to the bottom of this review

Overview-
Ark is a sandbox-survival game, a game where the world wants to kill you but you have the freedom to make your own choices and do what you want. With a wide array of game mechanics, maps, and creatures, you have an insane amount of things that you can do and obstacles you can overcome.

Graphics-
The graphics are really good and help you feel immersed into the world. Not much else to say here.

Gameplay- 
The gameplay in Ark can simultaneously be the most engaging and most boring part of the game. On one hand, Ark can get very grindy and boring(especially without the right tools) and can take hours of your time for a project. On the other hand, the gameplay can get very engaging when hunting down creatures to tame or kill, or getting hunted by creatures. Most of the time, your gameplay will be in a middle ground when doing things such as exploring, building, or crafting. Earlygame is generally much more fast paced with danger lurking around every corner, and as you progress the gameplay slows down and gives you more control.

Audio-
The audio in Ark is my favorite part about it, with many ambient noises and soundtracks that play during events or combat. The Ark soundtracks capture the feel of each place you go, and generally stick to a theme in each map. The noises help make the maps feel alive, and most also indicate certain events going on around you

Other things-
-Singleplayer is customizable; play on a pace you like
-Play with friends on official and private servers
-Official pvp servers are basically anarchy and should be avoided (offline raid protection is an exception)
-Bosses that give you an endgame to work towards
-Lore that tells a story about the arks through notes
-Plenty of events that boost rates and add small fun features

DLCs- What I recommend
Scorched Earth- If you like challenges get this one
Aberration- A beautiful but deadly map. I recommend for anybody but be prepared to die.
Extinction- I Recommend for PVE enthusiasts
Genesis- A faster more action filled map. If you get bored of grinding normally this is the map for you
Ragnarok- The island but better. Get it if you have the space

My favorite part of the game overall has to be the dinosaurs and building. While the building does get annoying I've always enjoyed running around with my dinosaurs. I wish we had more interactions available for tamed dinos like petting, or even them interacting with other tamed dinos. Overall the game does have a few minor annoyances but nothing that will make you no longer want to play the game. Very excited for Ark 2!

The only game where you're expected to grind resources endlessly and inbreed your dinosaurs a ridiculous amount of times only to lose them to the easiest version of the bosses, then do it again. 

Seriously. I've only spent about 5 hours actually playing. The rest has been afk'ing waiting for my rex mutations. 
Super fun to play with friends, but this game is super grindy so if it's not your thing dont bother. It's super easy to get stuck in the "mid-game" phase because you either dont have strong enough dinos, don't have enough resources to craft certain items, or you don't know where to go next. The game doesn't tell you where to go or how to do anything, so don't be ashamed to look up a guide on how to progress or how to breed dinos. 

Lastly, I only recommend playing on official (default) settings if you're on a server because the timers for breeding, imprinting, baby growth, etc keep going once you log out and in some cases it can take a week to accomplish certain tasks. Look up good singleplayer settings or decent rates for smaller tribes if you play a private server. Don't be afraid to adjust the settings to your liking. If you dont have a ton of time to play, consider faster breeding, gather, and taming rates.

Just an absolute blast of a title to play. From the base building to player advancement to environmental interactions, it's all done exceptionally well. There are a plethora of settings and adjustments you can make before launching a game or a server so that no playthrough is ever the same. The ability to transfer characters from map to map is also a nice touch, although I don't use it much because I enjoy the move from 1 to 105...which is really quite short and grind free. A lot of jump scares, and "Oh S*@#" moments....at least until you get your pump action shotgun...then all bets are off.

So ill try to keep this as short as possible as I don't want to waste anybody's time... I am a 49 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories. P.S. He loves the dinosaurs haha
Monkey kills Rex Monke very strong

I can see why this game was so cheap. It's just honestly not a very good game. Even after you adjust difficulty, it does nothing for the poor quality of clipping, and the fact that dinosaurs can jump on everything better than you the player can. As soon as you start doing well, the game will throw you a giant dinosaur that will come in and kill everything and destroy everything forcing you to restart time and time again. That says nothing for the fact that connecting to a non-dedicated server is extremely difficult. My wife and I spent a few hours playing just fine together, but then out of no where she could no longer connect to the server so we couldn't play together. I am of the philosophy of "I've spent $11 on dumber shit" but for this, save your money. Spend it somewhere else.

EDIT: I do believe that Ark deserves for me to say this at least. I -want- to love this game.

Ark is a game that is both amazing and terrible at times but ultimately I believe it's a game worth trying because there is no game like it out there. The game is rich in content, the world and most of the lore are riveting, the dinosaurs are interesting and fascinating and some maps are downright aesthetically breathtaking. The sense of wonder, adventure and the challenge in the early stages of the game are fantastic in my opinion. The game however, has serious and frustrating flaws like its quadrillions of bugs and glitches, terrible and unbalanced multiplayer experience on official servers and performance issues that frankly feel more like a feature than a flaw at this point. I recommend playing this game non-competitively (PvE), with friends and on boosted, modded unofficial servers unless you're willing to devote your life to this game as the grinding and the ease of dying and losing all your stuff can be deal-breakers. Overall though, it's a game that you should give a try and if you love dinosaurs and survival games, perhaps a must-try.

All together this game is an experiance.  It will both infuriate you and humble you.  Take breaks least your blood pressure shoots up.

Ark has its fair share of bugs and glitches, and an abundance of stability problems, but beyond the rust and wear of the game sits a real pearl to enjoy and indeed a deep story and lore if you care to search out all the notes and pieces scattered about in the wilds. 

The game certainly does not hold your hand, you learn as you go while you try to survive the bitter harshness of the cruel and unforgiving environments that deteriorate your health, stamina, hunger, and thirst, amdist the dangers of real predators around every corner. Weather you play it hard core on an official server and spend the next four weeks hatching an egg, guarding, raising, and growing your new dino, or an unofficial server modded for ease of enjoyment and fun among like minded friends, Ark has something for just about everyone. Do you enjoy gathering and building? Ark has that too, not a fan of fighting and slogging through the harsh wilds? Build, craft, and help your team by staying at base and making sure the process of creation and crafting continues moving so your tribe always has an edge to fall back on.

Suspect you'll be raided on an PvP server? Find a secret place to build a back up base with materials, dinos, and more to defend your namesakes and keepsakes! With Ark 2 on the Horizon there is no better time than to learn what Ark is about by getting the game while it is still hot. Find those servers online, join up, make friends, and survive the Ark! Survive the simulation and learn the truth behind it all. You are the survivor!

Pretty fun survival game in single-player but really shines with friends. In my opinion, ARK can be a pretty grindy game but one thing I love is that this can be easily overcome by altering pretty much any stat in the game. One thing I never enjoyed though was the official and non-official public servers as they are very unfriendly to new players and can be pretty toxic in general, which is why I stuck to mostly just single-player and hosting a server for me and a few friends. But, overall I do recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a fun open-world survival game as the dinosaur theme is very fun and with numerous DLC there is no shortage of new adventures, if you have the option please play with friends as to me this makes the game way more fun!

Pros:
-Cool Dinos, which you can tame and ride
-Great multiplayer, if you're into that
-Graphics are good, if you can run it

Cons:
-Dinos take forever to tame. And it really sucks to spend hours taming a dinosaur only to have it die on the way back to bas for whatever reason.
-You're basically forced into multiplayer, if you want to have fun. A singleplayer world can be good, but you're missing out on half the fun that is the chaos of other people, and it gets old. Play alone on a multiplayer server, and people will constantly bully you whenever you try to achieve anything.
-Poorly optimized, last time I checked.

While there have always been issues with the game, Ark is a good game. If you love dinos and survival/building then this is a game to ad to your collection. Lots of variable free maps to enjoy and the paid expansions are fun and challenging. Be prepared to wait for the download as this is a large undertaking, but your patience will be rewarded. Ark is an amazing game, that Wildcard has shown they got lucky with. What I mean by that is they are lucky, not good developers. They are lucky the good parts of the game are SOOO good, the non stop issues that have plagued this game since Beta players still over look 7 years later. I have played since day 1 across multiple platforms, 7,000+ hours. Wildcard has shown they are not only incompetent developers, but also lazy and insulting to their player base.


Ark 2 has been announced and from what I've seen and can tell from the community, most of the player base has lost all anticipation and excitement. From what they've released, they are going to a 3rd person only souls like melee combat, and mostly gutting anything that made Ark 1 the gem that it is. BUT let's not forget they are adding in Vin Diesel, which NO ONE WANTS OR CARES ABOUT. He's literally a horrible actor. This just further shows how Wildcard doesn't even understand what players enjoy about Ark and how lucky Wildcard got with this game. 

Official server review - how the game was made to be played

The Bad 
---------
Bugs linger for years - check
Meshing issues, for years - check
Losing characters and anything associated to those characters - check
Abusive official game GMs and poor customer support - check
Servers as stable as a unicyclist balancing plates on their head - check
Non region locked servers that get over ran by Eastern cheaters - check
Developers rely heavily on the modding community
PVP and PVE are not balanced independently, which causes issues for each
 
The Good
----------
Sandbox - you make your own fun / adventure
Awesome dino armies
Both first and third person
MMO - Community and player interaction (on official servers)
Basic yet solid combat
Offers both PVE and PVP

======================================================================

Unofficial servers 
-------------------
Strip away most of the bad list above, but you also lose a few of the good points.

The Bad 
---------
Bugs linger for years 
Meshing issues, for years
Losing characters and anything associated to those characters - you can at least not lose everything on unoffical with good admins or single player/local/etc
Abusive official game GMs and poor customer support - still possible depending on the server
You either have to rent a server, play single player, or have a spare PC to host a server
Hosting cluster servers can be expensive 
You are at the mercy of the server owner to pay their bill and can be turned off at any point
You lose the MMO aspect you get with official servers (why I ONLY play official)
 
The Good
----------
Sandbox - you make your own fun / adventure
Awesome dino armies
Both first and third person
MMO - Community and player interaction (on official servers) - sadly, this aspect of the game goes away
Basic yet solid combat
Offers both PVE and PVP
Customized rates and balancing to make it more life friendly
Mods - who doesn't love mods?! (A lot of these mods are what Tek SHOULD have been, not what they gave us that ruined the game)

Great concepts horrible implementation. ARK feels untested, unrefined, and unpolished despite the overwhelming amount of content. The diversity of creatures and beautiful maps make this game seem complete but don't be fooled.

This game has been out for years and the amount of game breaking bugs is astronomical and actual game mechanics are clunky at best. 

The list of issues I've had trying to play this game is extensive and I don't think I've ever complained about a game so much while playing so I'll stick to what I believe are the biggest issues.

1. Collisions:  What can't you get stuck on and glitch into? I'm constantly getting stuck between dinos, rocks, trees, and sometimes there's nothing you can do but let yourself die (or cheat) because I can't move while standing on a solid surface? Not to mention how when you walk among the dinos you have tamed that their animations can move you around and block your path. 
These collision mechanics are so poorly done that the smallest dinosaur can completely stop all momentum from the biggest dinos in the game but hey let's add cold snaps and heat waves because we want to be realistic... ???

Next, when I play a game I want to be able to play the game. Filling my time with boring chores like transferring and sorting inventory is absurdly lazy development. Small area linked inventories is a very easy fix for this and helps qol and just makes sense. Moving one stack of heavy resources at a time (like metal) from my dino to the chest right next to it is ludicrous. 
The heat waves and coldsnaps fall into this category for me as well because they keep me from playing the game. I understand they were added to increase difficulty but me leaving my character afk in my base so I don't drop dead is not that hard but is very boring. Additionally, I'm not sure how I feel about night time as there is no way to skip it without cheating (like most other survival games) and it's so dark early game that you're better off AFK in your base until the sun comes up even though you don't really have enough to fill your nights.
I understand trying to implement realism in a game but I also want to play the game and a lot of things in "reality" don't make for a fun game in my opinion. I'd love to see devs be a little more creative in how they extend game length and difficulty instead of the chores that just waste time and make the game grindy. 

As far as bugs, I don't even know where to start. Things disappear and reappear in my inventory with regular frequency, Dino's blink in and out of existence, sometimes my character will drop through the world, you will tell a Dino to stop moving and it will still walk to wherever it pleases before stopping, UE4-ShooterGame bug, etc.

I really want to like this game but it's definitely not worth buying and especially not at full price. Wait for ARK 2 to see if the game actually has some polish on it so you don't rip your hair out just trying to get basic mechanics working.

The game reaches 400 gig in total of storage space with all DLC installed leaving the base game at 125.I have realized that the new maps range from 40 to 60 gig where the old one's are 6 to 12 gigabytes.Which means the maps should be much larger, and they are not they are smaller and take up to almost 4 time's more storage(bad optimization).Hosting or joining servers are ridiculous it take's forever, sometime's it is because of mods but you will have to have over 10 and it disconnects you frequently causing you to restart the game or click the join multiple times.Ark 2 is releasing and i am very excited but i really hope they fix these issue's.

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Ukrainian men French kissing canines on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Why recommend ARK? Because it's one of a kind. Like many games, it has bugs. However the bugs are outweighed by the gameplay.
It is badly optimized, but not unplayable. I can run this on a rig as bad as a 1 GB dedicated GPU, and FX-6300 (a CPU from 2013).
A short summary of the game: you are stranded on an unknown place, without knowing anything of your origin. You find a glowing crystal lodged into your left wrist that allows you to store and craft. The wildlife is filled with dinosaurs to your surprise, so you must gather resources in order to protect yourself/yourselves, and maybe even tame said wildlife.
It's up to you to decide who is your enemy, and who isn't.
With that being said, ARK II will release soon, and many veterans and new players who just got a taste of ARK excitedly wait for it - myself included. It will run better, and hopefully have even more majestic creatures and environments.

This game is amazing on its own but the mods which the community have made makes it feel almost new. I've racked over 6,000 hours on PSN and these mods bring new life to the game. its amazing for people who love dinos and even people who dont love dinos its just a very very beutifle game

PvE:
If you are looking for a survival PvE experience with tons of creatures and places to discover even without buying the dlc's and you are not spoiled by questlines leading you step by step through the story and can set your own goals and try to uncover the story then i highly recommend this game

PvE2:
If you are looking for a RP game with many great RP communities ranging from game of thrones RP servers and medieval settings without any dinosaurs or any similar type of RP i recommend this to you.

PvP:
If you are looking for a survival sandbox PvP experience i would also recommend it to you but be aware that there will be frustration and there will be enemies that you cannot defeat in terms of their group size or that they just simply cheat. But on many unofficial servers PvP is more balanced and monitored so no cheating is happening.

PvP2:
There are permadeath servers where most of the sweaty big tribes wont bother with and you have much more relaxed people there because nobody wants to risk their boss engrams and character level with raiding your base if you know how to build (that can take a long time)

TLDR:

I recommend this game if you can set your own goals and find your own playstyle may it be PvE Official, a private Server with your friends, PvP Unofficial or anything in between but you will learn a ton of new things about this game when ever you play it. I have 5000 Hours and still learn new things because they suddenly add something to a old dino or a mechanic literally nobody uses that i just didnt knew about because i dont look everything up in the wiki.

PS: Yea there can be bugs, yes the building and other mechanics can sometimes be frustrating, but overall and if you give the game a chance and not give up right away, set your own goals and find your path, you will be getting your money's worth out.

Ark: Survival Evolved is definitely a must-have game. The early game is a bit difficult at times but you can adjust the settings (I always adjust taming and hatching speed) to your preference in single-player and building your character is the most hilarious and enjoyable experience. The graphics in the game are adjustable and on High or Epic are extraordinary, the dinosaurs and landscapes look real and the developers really put a lot of thought and time into the little things, such as how the grass sways in the wind or the pattern of the scaling on different dinosaurs. The prehistoric and mythical creatures look very real and have very realistic movements, sounds, and looks. The AI is OUTSTANDING! The animals react to situations as they would in real life. They are found in their corresponding habitats and can be seen battling and hunting out in the wild. On top of all this, nearly EVERY single creature is tamable and the larger ones are ride-able. You can name and level up every single creature and even command them with different whistles! It is absolutely incredible. The building mechanics are a bit difficult so I recommend using Structures Plus (or S+) to help make it easier, but once you get the hang of it you can build some pretty amazing bases and structures. I personally prefer to play single-player because your bases, creatures, and characters can be taken or destroyed while you are offline. With single-player, you can create servers yourself that sync to your single-player data for only your friends to join or for only you to see and play. Overall, the game is absolutely amazing and I would HIGHLY recommend playing it.
It's fun to see what each new map has to offer with a few friends!

ARK is a game with many dinosaurs in it; running on Oculus Rift, anyone who plays on PC can see dinosaurs in the distance and are shown a distant glimpse of a giant bird swooping towards them. This isn't something that I'm familiar with in other games. Where else do you run into a giant dinosaur flying through the sky?

Leaning in, it's hard not to see that ARK is a game that I can't just put aside. I can't see it as just another spin-off, or another shooter with a wild sea. That ship I ran into? It was stealing boats, to try and find a way to get home.

Many have already discovered ways to tame sea monsters in ARK, but stealing a boat at sea? That's on another level.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a Virtual Youtuber empire for over a year now and using me as his recruiter. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my Live2D knowledge to recruit talents, which he would then hire using his connections in the Japanese utaite world. Connections that he made through his career with Niconico. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small indie channel could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Motoaki "Yagoo" Tanigo, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Yagoo threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Yagoo had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Yagoo flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Yagoo was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Riku Tazumi , he plotted to kill Yagoo, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Cover Corp, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my vtubing activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Honestly, this game should be called early access. It is completely full of bugs and oversights. Network optimization is so horrible you will regularly teleport around with mere 100 ping. Hitboxes are so awful on dinosaurs. There can litteraly be 10 arrows sticking out of dodos head as it sits their oblivious to you point blank shooting him. Due to this the only reasonable way to tame many dinos is to use bolas/traps and play fortnite as you trap them in stone, so they cant move while you shoot them. Example there is 7 stats on a dinosaur. Useful= Health, melee, stamina,and weight. Practically useless= Oxygen and food. Useless= speed. The Base speed stat on a dino does nothing at all. If you only have a couple hours to play this game a day, you cannot play online due to absolutely awful long time it takes to tame and raise dinosaurs. I understand that this game has a huge fanbase and it's very successful, but I personally think it's much more due to the uniqueness of the game than the actual value of it. I don't have hundreds of hours and I've never beaten the game (more on that later). 
The way I see it, the three main appeals of this game are: 1) Taming Dinos 2) Exploration and 3) Survival. I'd like to individually look into them so that it's hopefully clear why I do not recommend the game based on my experience in these 3 categories.
[h1]Taming Dinosaurs[/h1]
SUPER COOL! Being able to have pet dinos is AWESOME! However, taming dinosaurs sucks and once you have them, it's honestly pretty one-dimensional. For the taming, it comes down to one of two methods: stand around and feed it stuff (possibly go fetch stuff to feed it), or shoot it until it goes to sleep (tranquilizer arrows, darts, and bullets). The feeding is obviously boring, because you literally just sit there. Some dinosaurs even need you to feed them corpses, but the "drop corpse" prompt literally covers the "feed to creature" prompt at most angles which makes it infuriating. As for the sleep taming, it's fun at first, until you realize you have to start building traps or abusing the game's AI to get them stuck between trees. Building traps is kind of fun (it's not a traditional "craft me", but actually using structures to get it in a mini-house). Unfortunately, you very quickly realize there's one design that is very simple, inexpensive, and effective, AND IT SHOULD BE USED on almost everything. Once the animal is asleep, you have to babysit it for SOMETIMES A REAL-LIFE HALF HOUR, manually feeding it narcotics every few minutes. Unless you're willing to grind for annoying kibble recipes that you can ONLY FIND ON THE WIKI. More on that in my rant about Exploring the World.
Great, you tamed a dinosaur. Their AI sucks ass. Your flying creatures will fly in circles AROUND you instead of coming to you when summoned, but when following you hover just above ground level (perfect for getting attacked or eaten by sea creatures). Any non-boss creature's attack AI boils down to "run straight at target and keep attacking". The game has a cool set of commands you can issue your dinosaurs with a surprisingly intuitive UI, but they have a tendency to literally ignore your commands. Has resulted in many deaths for me and my creatures. Very unfun and annoying. Even when they are listening, they generally suck at that, too. They'll happily run into lava/pits, push their friends to their deaths, or take obscure paths to get to a destination right in front of them. "Ah yes, a 3-wide player-made ramp in front of me that leads right onto the raft? No thank you, I'll head UNDER the raft and start drowning myself instead :)" 
All of these things individually don't ruin the game, but each one individually just feels so sour, so when there are so many of them happening back to back (sometimes reverting hours of progress) it's just... not fun. That's it. And why play a game if it's actively unfun?

[h1]Exploring the World[/h1]
Let me start by saying, the maps are HUGE and they are COOL. Many very diverse biomes, landscapes, and terrains. But it really bites the game in the ass, BAD. The BASE GAME is [b]ALMOST 300 GB.[/b] Even that aside, the maps are generally TOO big and navigation with the wiki is a MUST. I tried to play blind for the first 20 hours, but a lot of the features of this game are simply locked behind the wiki. It's really f*cking stupid. Remember how I talked about things taking to long to tame? Well you can make something called Kibble, which helps a lot! How do you get the recipe for that though? You don't. You just don't. [url=https://www.reddit.com/r/ARK/comments/tbawdl/where_to_find_kibble_recipes_in_game/]Here is a reddit thread full of players talking about how recipes for Kibble, with a majority of them writing it off as impossible. OP and his GF have played 40 hours EACH and never seen it either. [/url] Is it actually possible? I don't care. For something so fundamental to the game, to have it locked behind the wiki is disappointingly stupid. Back to the maps though, it's very sad to see YouTubers with thousands of hours talking about how they still use the wiki for navigation and cave coordinates (and then coordinates of where to get special items WITHIN those caves). Shit, I didn't even KNOW there were HUGE underwater cave systems until I started watching ARK YouTubers. Why? There are no good indicators of such within the game, and no good navigation tools within the game. Map, compass, GPS (WHICH ONLY SHOWS XY COORDINATES). You can make markers on the map and see yourself if the admin has enabled it. If you're hosting, your friends can always see your nametag from across the map, but you can't see them unless they're VERY close. It just sucks that a game that gives you a suit that lets you fly and punch through rocks can't even give you more than "here are your X and Y coords, go get 'em tiger!"
Again, [b]it sucks that you are forced into using the wiki.[/b] Maybe ARK needs a tutorial, but games like Don't Starve, Terraria, and Minecraft have no real tutorials yet seem to be doing pretty well for themselves. I personally unlock engrams (this game's equivalent of level-locked recipes) much faster than I have use for them. 2k extra engram points atm because I haven't bothered spending them on stuff I know I can't even craft or make use for. Again, ARK isn't awful, I just wouldn't recommend it.

[h1]The Survival of ARK: Survival Evolved[/h1]
This review is getting too long. Rapidfire time.
Combat and bosses come down to just, "pile on all your dinosaurs, have them essentially W+M1 the boss while you buff them occasionally!!" Maybe you can shoot the boss, but your damage is so negligible compared to what your dinos will be doing it's honestly a waste of time.
The building is is surprisingly disappointing and honestly pretty shoddy. I'm not convinced fences really work, even after watching tutorials. Think to yourself, if someone is looking up tutorials on how to PLACE FENCES in a game AND MULTIPLE TUTORIALS EXIST,  that should say a lot about how bad it is. Pillars clip through floors/ceilings, so they can't be used much for cool builds. Trying to build on a raft? If you don't want your foundations built at shoulder lever, your only option is abusing a glitch with pillars so that your floors don't stick far above the raft. You can't even construct your own bridges, which sucks with how many rivers/bodies of water there are. Especially because water creatures are so annoying. A lot of them are pretty easy to kill/avoid, but I digress. Let me build my bridges :(
This game is REALLY grindy. You can get dinos that autoharvest or greatly assist in harvesting (at the time of this, I have Therizinosaur, Mosochops, Giant Beaver, Ankylosaurus, and Triceratops). Even big ARK YouTubers like pterafier increase drop rates, which is just disheartening to see.
//end rapidfire 

[h1]Conclusion/TLDR[/h1]
I didn't point out many positives of this game, but there certainly were plenty. It's just that as I'm playing, and whenever I close the game, it's very rarely with a good taste. The bad parts are just so much more memorable than the good parts; there are way more "well this sucks" moments than "woah, this is awesome" moments. I'm writing this because 4/4 of the friends I've played with also didn't like this game, but we couldn't find a negative review that honestly encapsulated how we felt (so many "wouldn't recommend, 3k hours, 1k since review, hahahaha I'm so funny").
Its an okay game, and it's certainly not [i]awful[/i]. I just don't recommend playing it.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

If you like games such as Rust then you'll likely enjoy playing this game. However the reason why I don't recommend this game is due to the massive hungry data space requirements. The game is always updating which is great due to an active developer, but when it takes nearly half a terabyte of space is something to take a step back and say no thank you. Furthermore character creation is very limited and feels heavily outdated to the early 2000's MMOs. It's a great game, but not enough for me to be able to continue playing. There are a lot of bugs in this game involving the AI and 3D models. AI sends a Dino down only to clip into or through a mountain face or building. You'll die a lot in this game, but keep your progress as you continue on improving. It's a great concept which I do enjoy. The player base is both non toxic and toxic pending on the server you join. Overall, get this game if you have the time. It takes a lot of time to download and install, but if you don't have the hardware just avoid!

So bad. First off, to even access half of the servers/maps, you need to buy the battlepass. Level 1 new player dropped into an "easy" low level server to play for the first time. Immediately killed by a level 150 dinosaur before I could even control my character. This happened 3 times in a row. WHY TF IS THERE A LEVEL 150 DINOSAUR IN AN EASY SERVER CAMPING THE SPAWN POINTS?! Night time is too dark to see or navigate anything. The sun kills you. You need to eat, but if you fight anything to get meat, you die because everything I saw is level 50+ in the EASY LOW LEVEL AREA. One of the worst new player experiences I've ever had. Glad I didn't have to pay for this, but even as a free game, I'll probably never launch it again. Frustration level = 9.5/10

Game is so janky it's an accomplishment to get anything done. For me, those tiny accomplishments don't outweigh the majority of frustrating game play that I feel I have little control over. General movement being perplexing difficult, getting stuck on pretty much everything, resource grinding and crafting ranges from simple to rather extreme requirements, and then there's combat where if you don't just use a ranged weapon to whittle enemies down till they die in an exploitative manner then it's better to just give up and start over from scratch over trying to fight while getting stun locked until you die. 
I want to like this game and enjoy it with my friends. I've spent hours researching on the wikis and trying different strats. But I'm bashing my head against a wall here and it's not an enjoyable experience. I can't recommend this game currently, it's got potential but it's also got a long way to go.

GIVE THIS GAME A SHOT! Great "next/current" gen survival game! Has a lot of great promise but a rather steep learning curve if playing alone (similar to Don't Starve), but has a ton of potential for being the next great survival game. Lots of solo and community driven gameplay elements and a pretty immersive world to be in. Not the most "realistic" survival game in existence but it does take a more grounded approach to movement and fatigue (i.e. If you are swimming to long and you run out of stamina you may actually drown just like in real life).

Biggest issues are that it does take a pretty meaty rig to take full advantage of the graphics (seems like a modified Crytek engine) on the highest settings. This game is JUST in early access so I expect to see some of the animations, bugs, and slight clipping issues get resolved over time. I only have about 5 hours with this game so my review is based on initial impression and overall potential the game has

Super fun game if you are looking for pve dino game(I never got into the online side of the game so I cant say how that affects it) as will most games it is a far better experience with friends but ive had plenty fun on my own, one thing is be prepared for a real grind if you want to go anywhere in the game, you can tweak different settings on your own world to help with this if you want but this is not a game to be played for only an hour a day

Very hard to learn, and extremely time consuming and difficult to master. There's a lot of online resources to help you, but you still need to have a lot of time on your hands, a good amount of before hand experience with survival games, and a shit-ton of patience to really get the full experience of Ark. This game is very fun once you get into it, but without friends and just starting out can make the learning curve unbearably tedious and monotonous to climb. If you have a friend who's willing to host a private dedicated server, I feel that's really the best experience from Ark you can get in my opinion.

overall; it sucks. I've never left a review for a game before but holy shit. why. there is no tutorial in the game at all from what i found, other players will always result in pvp at some point and that's not why i got this game. you're left to look up how to pick up a rock because you're allowed to punch for wood and thatch but boulders are just off limits for some reason. you are not allowed to know anything in the game or about it. you have to memorize survivor note locations and go on a run to find them all in order to get experience to level up. unplayable at night because of how dark it is. arbitrary "easy" and "hard" zones to spawn in because guess what, now they don't have the resources you want or the dinosaurs you need. might as well just kys at that point and spawn somewhere else with nothing then take however many useless dinos you might have tamed at that point. default stats for tamed dinos are also rigged against you with wild dinos (in advanced settings I think) having a "higher" (or default) level of health and damage. meaning you would need either about five raptors to kill just one or a single raptor roughly 5 times higher in level. constant dying from external dangers but the need for water and food is practically non existent, eliminating the entire "survival" aspect of the game. it plays more like minecraft in the sense that it really isn't about survival, just progressing with the materials you can find around you and exploring but this game has it impossible to farm or even find those in certain locations of the map. because of the dangers of higher level predators the trek to go to the correct environment is going to be even longer. piranhas are just annoyingly annoying for no reason. if it had skill trees, for example seven days to die, you could improve the armor you make or maybe let it last longer, create it for less resources, etc. but no. always the same level of thing no matter what. never any better, just get the next set of engrams for armor. but also they might provide a different level of insulation or varying degree of physical protection so not always inherently better. you can never, ever, no matter what, ever learn anything about this game from playing this game. everyhting you could need or want to know is online in encyclopedias and not a trace of it is in game in any shape or form. you won't know a certain predator has a boost from eating bugs, or harvests specific resources better than others until it happens. then it's a question of what other dinosaurs might harvest this good? does this one suck and the only one i know that harvests wood or is it "top of the food chain" in that sense? you can't inspect them to learn. there's a magnifying glass that does god knows what, identifies materials or something. i don't know because I've never had access to some of the materials required to make it.                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                        TLDR: it's a terrible game that does not even fit in the survival genre. feels like it could so massively benefit from having skill trees or a system that rewards you for performing certain activities like farming, crafting, fighting, taming. etc. but just doesn't for some reason. you have to look up too many answers because why would you even think about randomly hitting this button looking at this thing. it's a 10 second tutorial that you could sweep through in a breeze but still doesn't have. horrible default settings stacking the odds of a dino fight winning in your favor at five to one, not in your favor. locks the more accessible, nicer items to craft behind high amounts of material only certain dinosaurs can harvest in the amounts that would make them more easily attainable.

Lots of Maps to explore (some of the best ones are actually the free ones!), caves to dive, Dinos to tame, bases to build & a endless level of freedom to put the cherry on top. I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone in need of a special gaming experience.

This game gives me a harder time to express my feelings about it, because there are some things that I don't like but a bunch more that I do!

     So lets get past the things I didn't like; grind. This game is all about grind, and dinosaurs which you will eventually tame take a very long time to pacify. Obtaining resources are made easier after some skills so it isn't awful in that regard but it gets harder when you progress Balance? The weapon system is really strange, as there are all sorts of factors and I remember finding a crossbow that was better than a whole assault rifle because of the stats it spawned with. This is because some blueprints you find have better stats, which is funny in some cases, but also quite annoying if you just figured it out after grinding a gun.

What I do like: SO MANY DINOSAURS. They are really cool, and I found it really fun to try out all the species. I'm sure there are plenty I haven't even seen, and they are not the easiest thing to fight if you are unprepared. Another thing I like: base building! This allows you to build an idea that you're dinosaurs are safe.

Overall, in terms of the game, I say you would have to fall into a niche category of dinosaur fan and survival game fan to fully enjoy this game. It is harder to have fun by yourself, and can get stale if you don't bring someone along. If you are thinking about buying this game, I would say wait for a sale or getting a good deal.

You wake up on a beach with a crystal in your wrist and a pair of shorts. Then you get bombed by what you assume are seagulls til a giant turtle waddles past you with a white, clawed Big Bird in the treeline. Collect a herd of parasaurs, they all die, cry about it, tame more. Become obsessed with the game til your mother learns to stop trying to peel teenage you off it. Involve your friends and impress them with how quickly you can come up with half-decent names for your toothy children.

I had over 700hrs on Xbox. Beyond that, I had been following the game since it was still in beta. It's been absolutely beautiful to watch its growth and progress. I was fairly certain those early days, it was an indie game. Now? If you told me it was AAA or something, I wouldn't be able to argue. However, it's not entirely optimized, it will rain inside sometimes, you will think the difficulty is low enough and then lower it further just to be able to walk a few steps off the beach. The worst by far is how all the storyline Arks are paywalled as DLC.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

There is no balance to the bullshit, no recompense for your trouble. 
Save yourself all the heartache and stress and anger and frustration and just walk the eff away from this steaming hot pile of useless garbage that is this game. And don't look back.

After playing this game for 23 hours, I really don't understand what the hype is about this game. Even Minecraft had better mechanics when it was still in beta :/

Pros:
-Graphically, looks nice
-A lot of things to do

Cons:
-Crafting recipes are WAY too expensive
-Dino's are way too difficult. I play with settings that basically make me as overpowered as I can be without god mode, and I still come nowhere near killing some of the alpha dinos, let alone the bosses unless I wanna spend hours taming and training an army of dinos.
-Tamed dinos are a PAIN to travel with. They get stuck on EVERYTHING and if you don't realise it fast enough, they're just gone. No teleporting them close to you if they get too far away, just gone.
-Inventory management sucks, as far as weight limits go.
-The ui is a maze of things placed in unintuitive "folders" that make no sense
-Everything wants to kill you, and they will. All at once. . . . .in about 5 seconds
-The quickest multiplayer option is a non-dedicated, locally hosted server, except that you are "tethered" to other players and they can't get more than about 500 meters away from you without hitting an invisible wall and being dragged towards you. While setting up a dedicated server fixes the tethering, be ready to either dish out cash to have one hosted for you, or spend hours upon hours downloading the files from steamcmd (I'm not kidding. I left it to download for about 8 hours before I finally gave up and canceled it,and I have no idea how close it was to being finished.)

Even if there were mods that fixed everything I listed (and everything I didn't) this game still wouldn't deserve a positive review as at it's core, it is a broken, buggy, unbalanced mess. Save yourself the anger and wasted time, play a game that's fun instead.

It's quite the challenge and I do like a challenge. The only things I do not like is the building mode.  I need to destroy something instead of being able to just move it.  The land is not flat and sometimes, the perfect spot for shelter wasn't perfect after all which means I need to destroy parts of the building to rebuild it. I can't put crates inside, they need to be outside, Placing objects can be difficult at times, for instance, I needed to stand outside my shelter just to place the bed inside the shelter. But hey, survival isn't easy right? lol. The little things will not stop me from playing.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

As many recent reviews have stated, politics are not to be mixed with gaming unless a game is a political commentary. After 1000 hours of support, I sadly must cut myself loose from ARK. As a recent announcement has stated, part of their sales will be donated to a slew of pro-abortion activist groups. This is not only a mistake on the part of the devs, but a mistake that they must learn from if they are to survive as a company. The simple truth is that most players do not wish to be making a statement on real world events with the purchase of a game. While it may not be to late for Wildcard to recover from this, by issuing and apology and delivering a solid ARK II, I fear this whole event may taint their storyline in the next game. As for my review, it may once have been a positive, assuming you can run it, but if you are looking for a survival game to get into that wont make a political donation, skip this one, and watch ARK II very carefully before you buy. May the public backlash be a lesson Wildcard, and may it teach you to follow the big rules of gaming companies.

Everybody knows,
sting someone, you die.

I love this incorporating

Hallelujah!

please welcome Dean Buzzwell.

graduating class of...

  
...9:15.

Wow.

  
Wow.

  
We know that you, as a bee,

to get to the point where you

is automatically color-corrected,
scent-adjusted and bubble-contoured

  
into this soothing sweet syrup

  
with its distinctive
golden glow you know as...

  
Honey!

  
- That girl was hot.

- She is?
- Yes, we're all cousins.

  
- Right. You're right.
- At Honex, we constantly strive

  
to improve every aspect
of bee existence.

  
These bees are stress-testing
a new helmet technology.

  
- What do you think he makes?

Here we have our latest advancement,
the Krelman.

that hangs after you pour it.
