There was a village on the southern shores of the island. It was peaceful and happy. There was fishing and farming and building. 
[b] Until the Therizinos came. [/b]

10/10 game.

I recieved the game during the giveaway, and was somewhat afraid to load it up as I've heard horror stories about the game's bugginess.

Turns out those fears were unwarranted, as I've encountered practically nothing worse than minor visual glitches or slight annoyances.  If this game is somehow more buggy than Skyrim, it must entirely be people whose PCs have no business running the game.  That or poor saps running the Windows build on Windows add OS complication BS to the mix to make it extra spicy, bug wise (running the Windows build via Proton has worked flawlessly so far).

So ignoring the bugs issue that frankly is vastly overblown...

ARK is a game where you play as a human whose combat abilities can be summed up as "dino fodder" at the beginning.  As you gain crafting recipes, you learn new recipes alongside increasing skills that allow you to survive for longer, as well as taming dinosaurs, birds, fantasy critters, sci fi beasts, robo-dinos, and whatnot, that further improve your ability to survive.  Taming is usually a pretty straightforward affair, being basically "knock the sucker unconscious, then give it food before it wakes up".  Some beasties however require other means for taming, especially some of the rarest and most unique from DLC maps.

The game, even at lower end settings, looks wonderful.  Only annoying thing is that reflections are always on and aren't terribly well done, but everything else looks fantastic.  I'd highly recommend spending a while tweaking configs until you've got the game running smoothly while looking good (protip: disable light shafts and bloom; they don't actually add true bloom or lightshafts, they just cause the game to run worse and look worse; also if everything looks blurry as hell, try turning on "low quality streaming assets"; if loading from a slow HDD it may just take the game from "ugly as hell" to "actually pretty nice looking" as it drastically speeds up asset loading and makes the game buttery smooth at the cost of some prettiness)

In terms of how difficult the game is, solo-wise it's a nightmare at default settings.  However, virtually every aspect of timing, leveling, dino behaviors, and even natural phenomena can be tweaked on your singleplayer/LAN server, and I highly recommend cranking up the settings hard for your first time playing solo.  Once you've gotten to understand how the game works, feel free to neuter the settings for future playthroughs, or if you plan on playing online.

Speaking of online, the public servers are apparently a toxic mess.  While I haven't played on them or private servers, if it's as bad as the stories would have me believe, your best bet is to find a friendly non-official server with a small number of people, or even just play the game with IRL friends who you're cool with.  I'm assuming some of the bugginess can also be attributed to toxicity online and the netcoding being messy, which is a long way of saying "stay off of large official servers if you value your sanity".

For "endgame" content, after reaching a high enough level and obtaining relics strewn about each map, you can take on a "boss dino", which is different for each map.  Killing said boss dino is your ultimate objective, but it takes a loooong while to get the resources needed to not die, and/or the friends with enough gear to help you succeed.

I personally love that some of the dinos use famous dinosaur-themed sounds, like how raptors sound like a certain movie franchise's dinos.  Most critters have distinctive sounds, but outside of things like raptors, most of them are pretty standard for a game like this.

In terms of tutorial...sorry, there isn't really one.  You're thrown into the game and left wondering what the hell you need to do.  I'd normally be critical of this, but there are enough player made resources out there to drastically reduce the frustration level this would normally cause to not be as big a deal as it would be in other games.  Still, I would hope that Ark II would have an actual tutorial map/mission/whatever to help newbs not feel overwhelmed.

Music wise what's there is nice, but there isn't really much.  You do get more music when playing on official maps though, so there's that.

The lore of the game is introduced via "explorer's notes", which are scattered across the various "story" maps and together help paint a picture of what happened in the past.  They're nicely written and illustrated, but a bit of a pain to find.

Basically, the game's great.  At full price I'd be leery of it, but on sale, or when they gave away the game to literally everyone on Steam who paid attention, it's probably worth it.  I've already clocked in almost 45 hours in the past week alone, and actually lost sleep over it.  It's that kind of almost addictive quality.

I would only recommend buying this game if you can get it and all of its expansions for $15-20 total on a MASSIVE sale - and ONLY on the Epic store (more on that below). Even then, the general headache factor might not be worth it. You've gotta be a particular kind of masochistic. You will require a... particular set of skills.

The base game experience has always been pretty awful, but mods have been its (sole) saving grace... since day 1. Don't even consider playing on official servers; that's indescribably terribad (also since day 1) and the overall experience has only grown increasingly horrendous over time. Likewise, trying to play without a handful of critical QoL mods is nearly as much fun as getting a root canal.

On the other hand - IF you are very comfortable with using (and troubleshooting) mods in UE titles, and IF you are very comfortable editing massive .ini files in games, AND IF you play exclusively on private servers self-hosted either by yourself or by (good) friends, there is plenty of fun to be [strike]had[/strike] made. Most of the expansions are dumpster fire cash-grabs, so ignore those until you can get them all at 90% off or better. Until then, just download the free Ragnarok and Valguero expansion maps and play there whenever you outgrow the Island. The paid expansion maps are worth a brief foray eventually—just to tame certain overpowered dinos and unlock some character levels—when it's uber-cheap to do so, but they add very little collectively and can safely be ignored if you don't care about min-maxing every little thing. (You can also get mods for the aforementioned maps that add all remaining DLC dinos to them, which is an even better option).

What else... oh, yeah: play only with your friends and people you meet through them. Definitely stay away from the community in general. And absolutely ignore any form of official interaction or communication from/with Wildcard. They're both death sticks; they will make you want to go home and rethink your life. Don't peek your head out of friendly private server games for long, or you'll end up with ulcers and a bad taste in your mouth.

[hr][/hr]

Regardless, do NOT buy the game on the Microsoft store if you do decide to get it. That version of the game does not provide the option to self-host private servers (meaning you must pay out the ass to one of Wildcard's awful "official" hosts), does not support mods (though it is technically possible if the host will allow it, albeit with a massive headache factor), and does not allow multiplayer with Steam or Epic players. You'll be stuck playing with the 0.2% of the human PC gamer population who own that version of the game, and... ugh... [i]xboxers[/i]. *Shudder*. It's stupid. MS is even more stupid. Windows Store games are the stupidest. Avoid all of that stupidity like the plague that it is. 

[b]I'd also STRONGLY recommend that you NOT buy it (or anything else) here on Steam, either.[/b] Steam has grown to embody all that is wrong with PC gaming, and its interference in the industry is a major factor in PC game development continuing to devolve annually - increasingly favoring the quick turnaround of attention-deficit garbage instead of the interesting, quality products that gamers actually want to play. Notably, Steam is also increasingly stepping up their efforts to aggressively censor factual, useful reviews—like this one—as public perception inevitably continues to shift against their blatantly anti-consumer policies. Well-meaning gamers out to help their fellows avoid bad purchases are working against Steam's profit margins, and they'll only tolerate so much of it. 
As much as I hate Epic, in this case it is absolutely the lesser evil.

[hr][/hr]

Most recently, Wildcard decided to channel their development energy toward turning the game into a political platform. It's exactly as annoying and obnoxious as it sounds.

Astonishingly, (lol), the game is no more the better for it. 

Next update, perhaps they'll add a [b][i]"My game, my choice"[/i][/b] button to the dino-breeding UI, with a mouseover tooltip reading, [b][i]"I object to the circumstances under which this dinosaur egg was conceived and shouldn't be victimized by being forced to hatch it."[/i][/b]

Hey, Wildcard! Here's an idea:

Support [b]gamers' right to choose[/b]... not to be subjected to obnoxious white-knight virtue-signaling and [i][insert trending SJW politic rhetoric here][/i] in our games and gaming forums. We have to deal with enough of that :poop: every day IRL, and it doesn't smell any less like :poop: coming from you.

I don't care what they are or which particular arbitrary way they're bent; take your politics and GTFO! :steamthumbsdown:

– [u]and, once you've done that, fix at least a couple of the worst 4-year old bugs in the game, maybe[/u]?

Very challenging! Potentially many hours to come.. i have over 110 hours but i'm still a noob; there's so much content... thank you for the base game. I am seriously considering buying some dlc to go with it. Can't wait for Ark 2!

I'm not interested in the PvP aspects, that's too hardcore for the likes of me (I love PvP but not this game) but playing with a few friends would be great in a co-op Pve way, so we can chill, relax, and enjoy, and take our time. It's the journey not the destination right?

Playing solo PvE is very engaging and I'm sure I'll get a thousand or two hours out of that alone as I like to take it slow and enjoy the ride. It's alot of fun building homes and bridges and whatever else or just go exploring (but watch your back and keep your SA at 100%), there's some savage beasties out there.

I love the fact that I built my first noob home out of wood and was progressing nicely WHEN some giant carnivore I think it was a Soro attacked and destroyed my wood base. It was freakin' awesome.

You'll see birds diving for fish, raptors eviscerating their prey, the wildlife is really cool.

To close, I love how 'long' this game can be, you really get good bang for the buck. It's a marathon not a quick 'wham bam 40 bucks please' cookie cutter garbage game. This game is really special and I'm glad I found it.

edit: I picked the base game up for free on Steam recently and in appreciation I intend to buy Ark 2 should it turn out to be comparable to the first.

After trying to play this gave over the past several years, I would suggest you passing on this game.

Most every server is dead. You may find one of two LARGE players that are still on a map, but all the decent locations to build they have taken. most other locations you try to build they would have placed a few structures to prevent you from building. Sever lag is horrible on most every map some MUCH worse that others. Servers crash constantly and take about 15 min to restart, in several cases the servers will go down for days on. You must submit a lengthy ticket to WildCard and get no response.  Anything you tame dies after five days of not logging in, even if the server is down and you receive no notifications the server has returned to an active status.
This game is riddled with exploits and has no moderators on most servers. I see constant grieving or newer / smaller players such as single players to friends that are trying to play the game by much larger groups just for the fun and entertainment of the larger group. Although multiple reports were send it over weeks due to clear violations of the game rules and harassment policies, not a single care was given by the WildCard employees. No even a follow up to anyone of the people that filed the complaints.
As you trasnfer from one type of server to another to farm resources or tame new dinos, you stand a huge chance to by kicked out of your own tribe due to a server glitch and loose everything you have worked so hard for over you life in the game. and again.... WildCard will not assist you with this. They will tell you that"Sometimes" the servers glitch and "things happen"  "Sorry for your loss" and end the response. 

PVP is riddled with players using Aimbots, meshing hacks, or just one shot your base due to a new hack they find, and the admins do little to nothing to stop this much less slow it down. 
PVE larger player tribes will place hundreds of dinos around smaller players bases preventing them from being able to play if the smaller player does not give way to the larger player and give the larger player everything they demand. This goes unchecked on most servers with again.... no admins.  WildCard will openly tell players  "Sorry, we do not support your server any longer, but is you leave everything you worked for behind we can start you on one of our new maps where we do offer limited moderation. 

Over the past months Wildcard has been pushing controversial political agendas in the discord as well as in the game itself. I am one that plays a game to get away from life and politics, I do NOT want those being forced on me in a game. regardless if I agree or disagree with the topic or not.  Please just let us all be humans that want to have fun and find friends. 

Take it from someone that has spent thousands of hours trying to overlook all the game flaws as well as listened to all the games community managers try to tell me the game will get better soon... Just to watch every update make the game slower, cause more lag, cause multiple other issues in the game, just to have another update released a few days later to cause again.... more issues.

Save your money, This is a dying game that very few play for any length of time anymore. servers lag often making it difficult to play.

While the premise is interesting this game suffers heavily from poor execution on both a technical and game mechanical level. 
Outside of performance problems most recurring issues I faced revolve mainly around dinosaurs (pop-in when exploring, them getting stuck on terrain a lot or straight up falling out of the world upon leaving a cave and general dino AI issues like them becoming unresponsive and not reacting to whistling) and building (clunky placement, the tedium of having to craft all parts of the build individually and the high resource requirements for crafting things in general).
Progression is heavily based on grinding to a point where you basically grind one thing to unlock being able to grind another thing. The engram system can be very awkward especially with how saddles are distributed among the unlockable recipes. I very often had the issue that could tame a certain dinosaur long before getting a saddle for it which made a lot of them rather pointless (for instance I managed to tame a Baryonyx quite early into the game but while following me around it died to getting stuck on terrain). In other cases early unlocks included saddles for dinosaurs I never came across while playing.
Overall the only well executed aspect of this game is the visuals of the dinosaurs. While they may not be scientifically accurate they are not over the top and very distintictive. It was fun to discover new types of dinosaurs and on many occasions I was able to spy one in the distance and correctly guess what it was by dusting off the remains of my younger selfs interest in dinosaurs.

As Ark has stated they will be donating to abortion funds as of 6/25/2022, I intend to no longer patronize them.

Separate politics and gaming, please. Thanks.

What used to be a great game has lost its way. If it were not for the modding community, this game would have been dead years ago.
As Jeannieinabottle said in their review "I cannot condone or speak good of a game developer/s when they are using this platform to push their own political agenda, this is not the place for this sort of thing and the fact that they are allowed to come on here and state their own belief system, the viewer/follower is not...sound familiar therefore I would go against buying this game, I hope that in the future I will be warned of developers like this as that is not why I come to play games, I come to play games to escape what is going on not to get involved."
Hopefully Studio Wildcard will focus on just doing their job and release quality product on time with Ark 2, but if past is prologue, Ark 2 will be late and lacking features.  It won't be until the modders fix their product for them, that Ark 2 will be hopefully something special. 
Their are plenty of other quality survival games being developed by studios that focus on just the game and listening to their communities. I would rather support those developers.

Good parts:
+ The world is pretty and nicely detailed, starry nights being the most beautiful part of the nature and the dinosaurs look lovely too.
+ Lots of stuff to do, it is not too boring.

Bad parts:
+ The game is clunky and buggy beyond belief. It feels like it was brought together using sticks and rubber tape. UI glitches and artefacts are disturbing.
+ Dinosaurs might be pretty, but oh how dumb they are. Running circles around you and ignoring entirely just to rip into parts at a random moment. But maybe that is by design.
+ It is not terribly engaging and in many ways feels half-baked, like an alpha version of a game concept.
+ It takes way too much space on the disk.

I've enjoyed the game for many years, bought it for my kids and hosted servers together, the game has some issues but overall is an amazingly fun time.  If you have no politics then its a good purchase, if you have no ethical stances unaligned with Wildcards then its a good purchase.  

Sadly the company has come out as a politically woke and donates income from its sales of their games to political organizations that support practices that are at the least, divisive socially.

Sadly this means purchasing their games or products, as they've publicly announced their actions and intentions, means supporting their political causes directly.  If you support those causes then this is a great way to get politically responsible, if you don't then its unethical to promote or purchase these products any longer.  

I personally wished my gaming space to be free of such division and strife, I've long found games a middle ground to reconnect socially after arguments and fights with friends over the years, finding common ground to build on.  I guess the world and corporations have moved on from these safe spaces though and laid down their political axes to grind so grind away I guess.

This game is absolutely void of Quality of Life features. You feel that the devs didn't put any love or though into it, just wanted to make money. You miss features in every corner of the game. I got it for free and feel robbed.

- Why can't I cancel current crafting progress?
- Why doesnt clip half the objects to other objects?
- Why is the building system so fucking awful compared to games like Valheim?
- Why is there a tube system which is fucking horrendous to look at? Why even bother?
- Why can't you rotate things which you wanna place?
- Why cant you call back dinos if you set them to wander and ignore signals? Why is one of the main features of the game so fucking barebones after all those years?

It's just so fucking void of Quality of Life features that it feels like a game just recently released in early access. Man I feel so robbed

This is my first ever review on steam but I feel like I have to tell you that this game is so not worth it.
Ark is the first game to make me so mad, like really mad. I was so excited to play this with two of my friends BUT 1st of all, it takes ages to download. It completely consumes your storage for literally nothing.

2nd: I came to the game completely clueless, I never watched Ark content neither did I know what it was about and it should stay like this. The game explains nothing. NOTHING. I tried to figure out how to craft something for straight half an hour (without watching a video obviously).

Then, 3rd point: the next hour I kept dying. CONSTANTLY. It was a never ending loop. Dying, respawning, dying, respawning... And somehow I managed to escape this loop and found a place to build a little base. All was fine and I even enjoyed the game after surviving the first 2 hours that were the WORST 2 hours I had in a game. BUT the happy time was over quite fast because when I had some stuff gathered, some mf raptors showed up and killed me in like 3-4 hits and destroyed my whole base. So again I ask myself how does it come that there are only dinos out there that can kill you in literally one second and are so much stronger
and faster then you. There is no balancing.

My last point: Why cant I play with my literally only two friends on a private server????? Why do I need to spend extra money on this crap??? Even the undedicated server (or whatever it is called) is not working. It brings me to an window where I cant do anything except closing the game.

So yeah I hope you did not spend any money on this crap. I luckily did not.
I will definetly not play this any minute longer, there are so much more nicer games out there and I need my storage space for these. So I will uninstall it.

I'm sorry for the long review but yeah, worst game I played in my entire life.

Of course this is my opinion, many are free to disagree! Obviously the community is quite large. I wish I could give a neutral option, I really do. But if pressed for how I lean, truly, then I have to say no for recommending.

I've put countless hours into this game. I really love it for everything it *could have* been. But, in my experience, mods shouldn't be the thing that makes your game the most enjoyable. The defaults on this game are dumbfounding. Its obvious that Wildcard is improving, see: the genesis expansions..
But why not balance your game better and make sure that it isn't so frustrating to play on alone and brand new before doing all the DLC? Optimization? Whats that? So many QoL things that are just lacking entirely.
Some players really like the weird jank and work around the systems rather than with them, I think that's totally fine. But my take is that its offputting to be playing against the game and deliberately fing around to do things in a way that isn't frustrating as hell.
If you want to play with mods, are fine with checking a wiki for unstated info (If you don't want to facecheck every mechanic), and have a friend or two to play this with, then sure, I think it can be for you. But I can't in earnest recommend this game unless you get it for free or you are very sure that the weird janky parts are something you can love despite it all.

tldr: I really love this game. Its not really as good as it had promise to be. If you've got friends, patience and you look at this game and REALLY think you'll like it even despite any weirdness in mechanics, well, why are you looking at reviews then?

On the surface this game is fun and addicting, but after losing so much of my hard earned items time and creatures do to bugs in the game and server lag, I can't recommend this game in conscience to anyone unless you are a masochist. I am a late-comer to this game so as many years as this game has been out to still have this many alpha and beta level bugs is unacceptable. For example: there is a feature in the game where if you die, you are supposed to see a red X on the map to show where your body is to give you a chance to to go and salvage your items and any tamed creatures you had with you. however, apparently there is this issue where sometimes it arbitrarily just does not show up, for no apparent reason. This is basic game dev 101, not something that should still be an issue this many years and expansions into games lifecycle. That being said the actual game and mechanics and depth are great, so if you are cool with spending 40 hours+ days/weeks/months taming and leveling up a pet dinosaur, only to lose it all when the game inevitably decides to bug out at random, then by all means, have at it. You think may think, well that was a one off, that was a once in a lifetime glitch, and computer is super fast and you have a top tier internet speed... nope, it doesn't matter these glitches are running rampant, they are NOT rare, they are the norm. I am uninstalling now, I just wanted to try to save you from wasting your time and DEFINITELY don't pay anything for any of the newer premium DLC, that only encourages the devs to keep churning out new maps without fixing the bugs in the core gameplay. Rant over, Good luck!

It seems more like a proof of concept, or an early access build, despite now being years old. It seems pretty all over the place with ideas, balancing, themes etc. In some ways this creates variety, keeps the game fresh and helps the game in a lot of ways. But hurts it in just as many, especially with balancing and power creep. Hopefully ARK 2 provides a more polished, and well rounded experience. Still enjoyable to those willing to put in time. Not worth the price tag normally, but on sale or for free (which it is currently) it's a much easier sell in my opinion.

Was also quite nostalgic since I grew up loving dinosaurs, but lost interest as time went on. So coming back to ARK reignited that interest in some ways.

Frustrating at times and the official servers suck, but with some basic knowledge you can make a world you actually enjoy to be in or join one that is. Gather, breeding, and maturation rates need to be pumped slightly more than official IMO to keep it from really feeling like a fat waste of time if you lose everything. As you will lose everything. I used to be mad at Wildcard for the shit service of the official servers, but at the end of the day they give you the tools to, like I said before, make a world you actually enjoy to be in. With the thousands of unofficial servers you don't even have to go through the effort of trying to configure a world you want to play in. Dinos, survival, fairly extensive building, bosses, and exploration. There's even a story connecting it all if you really feel so inclined to find it all out. It can seem like long and hard work but in the end I think it's worth it. At least I'm hoping so. My steam hours aren't reflective of my all time play, but I still haven't ascended or even gone through a complete cave yet. Hours upon hours wasted for what feels like nothing, and yet the game keeps calling me back... I just want to feel satisfied finishing what Wildcard has to offer, spending probably over the last decade or so making and polishing this tool for the community to enjoy. I truly believe, as of now, I will be when I get there. I will update when I have become worthy...

I actually cant believe im just now playing Ark this year, having looked at it for a long time it was a no brainer to claim it for free when I could, this game is honestly pretty great.
The graphics are pretty beautiful to look at, and as long as you have a sense of adventure and curiosity you will constantly find yourself enjoying new stuff in this game when you start playing.
That being said it is a survival game and it can be a bit difficult, I would highly recommend watching a quick beginners guide and try to learn patiently, you will likely die a lot starting out to random carnivores near "safe" starting areas and you may even starve to death while trying to find a peaceful spot for a hut.
Once you get a little house with a bed to respawn at though the game immediately opens up to different things to do, if you like crafting and survival games and enjoy occasionally being lunch for a T rex this game is worth getting even at full price.
Also worth noting that its worth messing around in single player and then finding a unofficial community server to play on, official servers are very hard to start on and can be quite toxic with no online moderators to help you with issues.

Every 15 minutes, the server lags for 15 - 40 seconds while it "saves".  Server has about 10 - 15 people on at all times out of 70 MAX, yet the server dino tame limit is almost maxed out.  This means that you will not be able to breed or tame any new dinos, especially during events, because many of the tribes are sitting around with about 500 (the tribal cap) tamed dinos, most of which serve no purpose whatsoever.  If they need more room, they create a second tribe to store overflow dinos there.  Meanwhile, virtually all of the players from the tribe are off on other servers (like the new one, Fjordur), and only come back every so often to refresh decay times and restock feeding troughs.

Lag and rubberbanding aren't nearly as bad as it is on console.

Kibble recipes are different now, and dino eggs are classed by "size".  And for some reason, a Compy egg is considered to be the same size as a Trike egg.  A Trike's poop is literally BIGGER than a Compy, but because a Compy can only be tamed with Raw Prime Meat (maybe kibble?  not sure), it magically craps out eggs of equal size to that of the Trike's.  

One of those games that had amazing potential, but executed very poorly because they hired out an amateur development studio to write the code for the game, then paid for the cheapest servers they could.  A different company owns the game now, apparently (or whatever happened), and they've made dramatic improvements over the years.  But, still very questionable decisions are being made, existing issues have been ignored in favor of making an Ark II (which, to be honest, is probably for the best).

I'm hopeful for Ark II, so long as they have a different development team working on it; programmers with experience and know what they're doing.  And, hopefully, they don't go as cheap as possible on the servers again.  Better servers would have allowed larger capacity without bottle-necking and crashing, and the in-game performance would be far better.

I play this game as a distraction from the stresses of life and it is very relaxing even when i am being chased down by a ravenous raptors. The crafting, building, taming elements can be a bit laborious but once mastered(or tweaked in the settings)it becomes second nature and serves as a path to the ultimate prize, beating the bosses. Preparation is key to success and taking shortcuts will only serve to put you back to square one(it can be like playing snakes and ladders and landing on snakes all the time) so be patient and you will be rewarded. A great sense of achievement awaits those who have the mental endurance  to tame an army to beat the powerful bosses and it doesn't stop there as your can continue your adventures on the many extra official and custom maps, great entertainment and value for money. Oh and did i forget to say it is a fantastic educational tool as my 8yr old son has learnt to recognise and name nearly all the dinosaurs in the game.

Ark: Survival Evolved (stylized as ARK) is a 2017 action-adventure survival video game developed by Studio Wildcard. In the game, players must survive being stranded on one of several maps filled with roaming dinosaurs, fictional fantasy monsters and other prehistoric animals, natural hazards, and potentially hostile human players.

The game is played from either a third-person or first-person perspective and its open world is navigated by foot or by riding a prehistoric animal. Players can use firearms and improvised weapons to defend against hostile humans and creatures, with the ability to build bases as defense on the ground and on some creatures. The game has both single-player and multiplayer options. Multiplayer allows the option to form tribes of members in a server. The max number of tribe mates varies from each server. In this mode all tamed dinosaurs and building structures are usually shared between the members. There is a PvE mode where players cannot fight each other.

I came in wanting to play mods, and it turned out that I couldn't last in the island for 5 seconds without my game shutting down. 

I spent days optimizing my PC, I pretty much multiplied it's performance ten-fold. 

Yet it couldn't run the normal game, with a fully optimized PC, the lowest settings possible, and even worse graphics via the launch menu. I couldn't last 20 seconds without an error showing up. All of my playtime has been:

1: Downloading mods for 45 minutes
2: The rest of it was spent trying to actually load onto the island. 

It's poorly optimized, Steam is essentially lying to us, I met the "minimum requirements", and still had to turn the settings all the way down, even then, I could not load into the game. The fact that WC has not bothered to fix this gives me very little hope for Ark 2, no one wants a game where only PC builders can actually play it. This game needed to be able to be picked up casually. It's a rare sight to see the console version doing much better. The console version of Ark ran so much smoother compared to PC that it's an embarrassment. In addition, my PC has better specs than my Xbox One x, which could run Ark no problem. I don't know what Wildcard was on when they were messing with the PC version, but they sure did mess up. Until I fix this issue myself (and I might now), I cannot recommend this mess, I just can't.

I blows my mind that the game has any positive reviews. We spun up a private server for like 8 people. The game is so poorly optimized we had to change nearly every factor in the game to make it remotely playable. If you play the game as designed you will spend all your time starving, dehydrated, and unable to craft. If you optimize the game yourself on the server side you will find that the game is boring as hell. The building is terribly broken. I tried to make a doorway using premade parts which snap together and had to duck to get inside (like that makes any sense for snapping blocks). You cant move objects after 30 seconds so building anything is a total hassle because you lose all your building materials if you want to try out one thing and then decide you dont like it. 

I lost 40 hours of a build because a trex spawned inside my base for no reason and ate everything. 

People who like this game are modding it until its playable, which says a lot about how bad the base game actually is. Its basically unplayable, and when it is playable its not fun. Huge letdown in a genre of games that I absolutely love.

This game is for fantasists and animal lovers, and for Minecrafters who are looking for something new but not entirely different.

Progression takes the form of levels of technology, and engrams or crafting recipes are revealed gradually, allowing developments ranging from spears to cannons, thatched houses to metal ones, and things like boats.

One of the highlights is the ability to tame almost any animal, and use it for farming, fighting, or as a mount. It's very enjoyable.

The disappointing element of the game is how it punishes a spirit of adventure. You can stay at home and farm, and even keep progressing, in relative safety from the elements and hostile creatures. As soon as you start taking risks to go and explore, you die.... Sometimes it's a real effort to recover from a setback like that.

On the other hand, this is a game that is gonna keep on surprising you. Highly recommended.

First of all, its really good and well done game. It only has a few bugs and glitches but nothing really big, except for one giant problem. A ton of players wants to play on non dedicated server which sounds pretty simple. I played with my friend two days in a row without any problems at the third day i got the "unable to query server information ...." error after fixing some stuff i was able to join again. (non dedicated servers are locked to 4 players and we have been 5, so we kicked one) After a few hours of playing my game crashed, so i tried to reconnect but i always got the "connection lost timeout" error. The help for these problems in the internet are basically useless. They give the advise to change the ports of the host, but if that would be the problem the other 3 players wouldnt be able to join. The ARK support itself is even more useless, they just tell you that they dont have an impact on the non dedicated server, so they cant help you. I did every advise that you can find, but it still dont work. I can join official servers, unofficial and even non dedicated servers in the ARK list. 
I really tried to enjoy the game, but these errors made it one of my worst games that i own.

Who doesn't love a good game with dinosaurs and alien creatures, especially when you can tame, ride, and fight with these beasts? If that sounds appealing to you, then you're in luck. You can even play co-op with people, raid others' bases, or maybe even work together to build a massive base for you and others to live in. Not only that but you can subdue massive beasts and tame them with various foods so that they will fight alongside you. And you can also breed tamed dinos, make a massive army, and take down a list of different bosses. One thing to note, however, is that this game doesn't have a true tutorial and as a result, does have a slower start. And even when you do know what you're doing, it does take a bit of time and work to get to the resources necessary to create guns and other late-game gear that you need to start taking down bosses and the like. So this game can require somewhat of a time commitment. On the flip side though, if you want to play single-player, you do have the option to customize your in-game settings to make things give more resources, certain things spawn faster, make eggs hatch sooner, and even how often you and your dinos poop. In addition to all of this, if you enjoy mods, there is a nice-sized community that makes really amazing and unique mods that undoubtedly spices up your gameplay a bit. But at the end of the day, I would highly recommend this game. It's positively unique in many ways and has a lot of work put into it. I'd say if you're looking for a new game to try, why not pick this one up?

Decent game first and foremost. Online is where it shines. Decent people ( for the most part ) with a few bad apple's like in many online games. 

Pro's-
-Looks ok.
-Plenty of things to do to keep you busy.
-Many discord groups running in game shops so nothing is off the the table to obtain.  Nothing costing real money as it's a trading system with in game items.
-NO MICRO TRANSACTIONS thank god.
-Challenging game for sure at the beginning.

Con's-
-The game will be dumped by Dev's at the end of 2022 with no foreseeable support after that.
-The only DLC (Genesis) is broken beyond all belief. Pray to your God every time you enter Gen 2 that the servers don't crash immediately and you loose your character or things forever.
-Seems like the more they update the game the more it breaks.
-After a bit of time in the game it just turns into Dino day care and becomes a super repetitive cycle.
-No regional only servers so who knows what language the server will be using in chat.
-No real story 
-PILLARS ( if you know you know )
-Getting support for in game problems (i.e. Bad players or pillar spam) can sometimes feel like a waste of time due to very slow dev response if you're lucky enough to get a response.


Overall it's just a decent game with no narrative. If you like mindless sandboxes with dinos in it then you should like this game. But if you like games that have ANY kind of story to tell, Don't like game breaking bugs and/or glitches. If you want a stable server you can count on not to loose anything at a moments notice and you want support from dev's then avoid this game.
I would totally recommend this game for people who are looking for a tough multiplayer/single player game that is survival and fun to play with friends.

Bang Bang Chicken:
Prep: 15 mins
Cook: 10 mins
Additional: 15 mins
Total: 40 mins
Servings: 4
Yield: 4 servings

Ingredients:
⅓ cup milk
1 egg
1 pound boneless, skinless chicken breasts, cut into 1-inch cubes
¼ cup potato starch
¼ cup all-purpose flour
½ teaspoon salt
¼ teaspoon ground black pepper
¼ teaspoon shichimi togarashi (Japanese red pepper condiment)
oil for frying
¼ cup mayonnaise
2 tablespoons honey
2 tablespoons sweet chili sauce
1 teaspoon gochujang (Korean hot pepper paste)

Directions Checklist
Step 1
Whisk together milk and egg in a bowl until smooth. Add chicken to egg wash and marinate for 15 minutes. Drain.
Step 2
Combine potato starch, flour, salt, pepper, and ground red pepper in a bowl and transfer into a large resealable bag. Add egg-washed chicken pieces and shake until each piece is completely dredged.
Step 3
Heat oil in a large skillet to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
Step 4
Add chicken pieces into the oil in batches, about 5 to 8 pieces at a time, so as not to drop the temperature of the oil. Fry for 90 seconds. Remove to a paper-towel lined plate to drain. Fry remaining chicken pieces.
Step 5
Increase oil temperature to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). The oil should be continuously boiling at this point. Carefully re-add the first batch of chicken and fry another 90 seconds. Remove to a paper-towel lined plate to drain. Fry and drain the remaining chicken. Transfer chicken to a medium bowl.
Step 6
Stir mayonnaise, honey, sweet chili sauce, and gochujang together in a small bowl. Toss fried chicken with sauce to coat.

Enjoy!

Sadly I cannot recommend this game from my perspective for a few reasons.  

1.  It does not feel beginner friendly - I just wanted to play the game solo and when trying to set things up, there are SO MANY settings to check and go through that I had to go to YouTube to get an understanding about some of it.  It does not feel like a 'pick up and play' sort of game.  

2.  Poor game optimisation - The first time I tried to play a map on Ark it just instantly froze and crashed on me and I have quite good hardware so that surprised me.  I once again went to YouTube to get some suggestions on what all of the graphics settings should be to make the game playable.  This is where I have to mention the game Rust as it is much easier to get your settings just right to make the game playable for you.  I think the developers of Ark focused too much on trying to make the game look good, they should have put more time into the optimisation first.  

3.  User interface -  Although part of the new game experience is to get familiar with your HUD and understand how all of the things in the game works, I just felt overwhelmed by all the options and I wish the design of it all had a more simplistic look. Sometimes less is more and once again, that's where Rust does it so much better in my opinion. I just felt so alienated trying to navigate through everything. 

I know there are a lot of people who love this game for one reason or another and I am happy those people enjoy it.  

Sadly, I am not one of them.

IF YOU HAVE THIS GAME KYS 
                                                                          Period 6 
                                                                          Dale The Balls Taker 
Right now what are the issues with ark? Giant laggy egg farm bases, OP Gigas, and the current balancing mess are what is most discussed.
I will add my own feelings to this list. To many Dino spawns, too little difference in use of Dinos, and flyers make most others obsolete.
I will start with to many dinos. Compare the long and detailed search for a good high level quetz. They are rare, you have to really search for them and it feels like an effort, but a good one. Anything else is pretty much common as dirt. From playing on Valhalla map it really feels different, some dinos are common, others are damn rare.
Follow this theme, huge numbers of smaller plant eaters. Tons of dodos, turtles, parasaurs etc, with about the same stats as now, and maybe a little less meat drops. Common dilos. Fairly rare raptors and carnos, with a bit more health and damage then now. Really rare Rexs with about the same damage and alot more health, but slower. Rare brontos with 100k or so health, bit reduced damage. Really really rare gigas with the same health but less damage and are really really slow like encumbered bronto slow, but with some form of really good drop so its worth teaming up to hunt. maybe with spears and guns since its so slow?
Increase meat and hide drops proportional to health. Gameplay would then be balanced around speed vs size health and damage. Want to go get some meat and hide? Take a raptor and kill a bunch of dodos phiomias etc. Want to get alot at once? scout for a bronto, take a much slower rex to kill it, maybe a 5-10 minute fight now, with withdrawing a bit to heal, but not burst damage so the risk is manageable. Kill it and get a few hundred meat and hide.
On the survival aspect, take away some of the chance. Give rexs a footstomping sound with a larger range a la jurrassic park, so you have to pay attention for it, and carefully retreat, but you have a good chance of escape if you pay attention. Larger no spawn range so an alpha or giga doesnt randomly spawn close to you with no control. Carnivores other then raptors are slower, so if you pay attention you may escape.
Alphas should be good and hard with high HP and fair damage but not huge. Multi dino fights for sure, but not a roll the dice to loose a tame fights

On Flyers:
Pretamed stat changes with a damage ptre, Argent or quetz there is little need for others. I took my Ptre farming as it slaughter brontos as easy as rex. same with and argent. And Quetz is gamebreaking. Too fast too damaging and insane with plant turrets.
Make the ptre a scout flyer only. Little damage other then against other flyers. Maybe slower. Use it to travel between bases and scout for that rex or bronto.
Make argent a hauler/ do a bit of damage but not a huge ammount. Keep its speed about the same or a little slower.
Make quetzal have much higher HP but travel slow, like encumbered slow, so its the flying base intended. Take a trip to the volcano, or a mountain, mine for a day, haul supplies between outposts. Maybe take away its damage entirely.

Probably remove PVE wild pickup as it trivializes alot of taming.
Then we are back to a game where there is a reason to be on the ground. Which makes the map feel bigger once again.
Now what takes up the map and created huge lag? Egg farms. Why do we have egg farms? Because its easy and efficient. Reduce kibble needed, and make tamed dinos not lay other then for breeding, maybe even make kibble the only taming food for each dino Want kibble? go out into the world and find the eggs. Spend time playing rather then running in circles and sitting afk.
Other related elements: large and behemoth walls, that clip into terrain, and weigh alot. IE go out farm the elements for one, like gates are now, and you need say a bronto or mammoth to carry it back to base once made and then place it. Maybe a few more resources as well. Like say teeth for an upgraded form of arrows dropped from carnivores in relation to their size.
What will all these changes give us? A less laggy, more varied world where you have reason to go out and run around and play. No more clusters of half a dozen brontos at a spawn point constantly, so dinos are rare and meaningful. A somewhat varied viable playstyle. A raft with a couple raptors and a trike would be viable, or a bronto and paracer base, that had high enough hp you can actually take it out and use it, and not worry about logging off with it out in the world. Want to go hunting? take a raptor and hunt lots of fast little stuff. Or a carno and hunt trikes and stegos. Or a rex and fight paracers and brontos, while everything little outruns you. With the huge hp increases on large dinos, no more raptors easting brontos, but at the same time the raptors now needed to be fast enough to hunt smaller things. Resource gathering is fine other then I would take away berries and thatch from mammoths and brontos. Male em haulers/ wood only.
If you are working person of a society dont buy it otherwise hell yeah baby

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he sat on my laps while dressed like an anime girl and we started playing it. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This is only my 2nd or 3rd review, and I felt it necessary to describe my short time in the game.

I only have about an hour and a half in the game.  It's not very long, but it's long enough to understand that this game is NOT for new players.  It may have at the beginning, but the entire starter area is completely spammed with structures from other people; namely pillars.  They are everywhere.  I cannot even place a campfire, which is needed to not die.  The only option is to start heading away from the starter area to a land that other players claim is open, but I can't get there.  My level is too low.  Within minutes of leaving the starting area, some dinosaur kills me.  I can't actually decide where I respawn, so I have to choose to do so in a random location.  I do, and within minutes, I'm dead again.  

I was told by the other players on the server to built a raft and go north.  I have no idea what level I need to be in order to build a raft, but I wasn't close.  I'm not interested in just running around and chopping trees and picking up rocks until I am a high enough level just to leave so I can start playing the game.  

The game looks interesting, but I will never know.  I can't even place a campfire.

Don't get me wrong, i'm grateful its free.  I've wanted to play Ark for a while but i was too cheap.  But had i bought this game and didn't realize that it requires 328gb i think i would have shat myself.  I don't know any game other than ark that requires 328gb of space.  holy hell.

I missed out on this game on release. Finally have a PC strong enough to play and its one of the best video gaming experiences I have had in a while.

Only issue is that with all of its DLC this game is like 400+ GBs kinda ridiculous.

Edit 1:
This game is really awesome but it does have its issues. 
I personally like the futuristic stuff with the prehistoric but thats just me.

1. DO NOT play on official - I strongly advise avoiding PvP at all. I recommend playing with a few friends on a PvE environment.
2. Very buggy - A good amount of bugs will not make that big a deal but there are several bugs that you will run into that can be frustrating after running into a lot.
3. Very grindy - I love me a good time sink but sometimes it can be a bit much. This will differ from person to person but I had to mess with server settings for a couple hours and adjust them to how me and my friends liked it. This game is damn near unplayable with a job without boosted gathering.
4. Playing on Non-dedicated is basically impossible - At first me and my friends played on Non-dedicated for The Island and Scorched maps. This was fine but there are three major problems. Number one is that some days your friends will join just fine some days they cannot connect for no reason. Number two is the tether. I have a beast PC now and had the tether maxed out to what it would allow me and yet my friends would still be teleported back to me. The other issue being that they are not allowed to explore caves/dungeons without the host. Lastly Most of the timers even on single player settings seem to be balanced around having the server on at all times. Eventually it was unplayable once we made it to the Abberation DLC where each biome is a separate instance where it will teleport you to the host. So we caved and bought a cheap dedicated cause I hate port forwarding and all that garbage. 
5. Modding - Luckily we are on steam but this game in my opinion is unplayable without mods. If you were planning on doing cross platform with some friends or something you might wanna reconsider.

This game is truly way more fun than I ever thought it was gonna be though. Several very in-depth systems and mechanics each map is very unique and adds lots of new creatures and biomes to explore. Expanding your base and slowly gaining access to better equipment is awesome. Taming creatures is one of the best draws to the game for me even if a creature isnt necessarily useful I like getting everything I possibly can like a pokemon game. If you can see yourself past these issues its amazing and the modding for this game is incredible.

The main reason I had never purchased this game is because purchased and played Atlas at launch, without ever having tried this game before. Atlas had cool elements but ultimately was poor experience and launch in my opinion (can read my review).

It's actually extremely difficult to quantify and describe, but this game comes across as much less serious and more childlike visually on the surface than it actually is. Once you actually try playing, it's quickly apparent. It also feels visually superior, vastly better UI and much better performance than Atlas.

From my perspective Atlas did a disservice to this game. I've had this game on my wishlist and it took it being completely free for me to even give it a chance. By the way the game is incredible, it's literally pure unadulterated crack. This game is the #4 game solid on Steam with concurrent players for multiple days now, even if temporary this exposure should be positive long-term.

It's refreshing to see, especially from a game that's been developed for years. Maybe allowing a demo or another free claim period may bring in even more potential players. I now am fully convinced that you just need to try the game for yourself because it delivers on it's own merit. 

In Ark you spawn on a beach and start gathering materials and surviving intuitively just like you would in Rust. This style lends itself perfectly to the single-player game mode. In Atlas you sit at a port aimlessly gathering enough stuff to build a raft, waste hours sailing to every island that's already completely claimed by zergs or other hostile players. 

It's genuinely impressive how much fun to play and good Ark feels in single-player. It's similar to Rust but with dinosaurs and skill trees, which if you're also an RPG fan like me is pretty cool. Many common mods in Rust are how this game is inherently designed. Things such as being able to fast-travel between placed beds. In Rust the /home or /tp commands are custom mods that are not part of the vanilla game.

Ark is an improvement visually from Rust as well. So far the feel of the game and how it plays plus how buttery it runs feels much more smooth to play than Rust. A large part of that is due to servers and the game being online.

I feel like anyone who bought Atlas and didn't have have Ark already in their library should have just been give it for free anyway, without needing to claim it manually. With that being said, it was free and I finally tried it. I played for 16 hours total in my 1st session and I couldn't put it down. I literally fell asleep in my chair sitting up before having to log off. This is the experience I wanted all along. Not the same gameplay, but the enjoyment factor I was seeking when I purchased Atlas, and the promises that I felt it never delivered on. 

I do appreciate the fact that I was able to give it a chance free of mental expectation. Honestly it never had anything to do with money, I can afford the game no problem and had the funds already in my steam wallet when it was on sale for an extreme bargain price. I had the game in my cart and when I went to purchase I thought about it for a minute, the summation of everything discussed here.. and I just went, "meh" and cleared the cart. 

Feeling rushed and like you have to decide whether you like the game or not within 2 hours can be an unpleasant experience all on it's own, regardless. Not having to worry about refunding or anything like that and just playing it made it a lot easier to take in and attempt to objectively enjoy the experience.

As far as the whole dinosaur aesthetics coming across childish to an outsider. I'm not sure exactly how you remedy that or overcome it, my idea would be to make the media for the game more focused on the skill trees and character progressions. Maybe consider reworking the character creation slightly to be a more traditional RPG style as opposed to so outlandish and cartoon like. 

Had I been exposed to more of the intricacies of the skill trees and game design elements I may have potentially had a different disposition as opposed to just being blasted with images of colorful dinosaurs without really having any ideas as to why, or any context of what it even means for the game and it's gameplay experience.

The serious and devastating world that the game takes place in is not represented fairly or accurately by photos or clips of bright multicolored dinosaurs with no context. The flying also looks somewhat far-fetched from an outsiders perspective. There's a lot of things that visually don't translate accurately or properly represent in media how they actually present or feel on screen to encounter in game firsthand.

Just focus on the depth of the skill trees and how unique they are. The trees are fantastic, so methodically placed out and an immense number of levels. It's thoroughly good in an RPG inspired style system. Highlight the fact that it's survival game with a sweet open world, awesome skill trees and outstanding character progression. That's what people actually care about and enjoy. That's what real single-player fans are after, and have been in a draught.

Another game that somewhat parallels my experience with Ark is Minecraft. For years I always talked down on Minecraft, thinking "why would I play that, it's ridiculously blocky, looks terrible and the gameplay looks primitive". Well just like Rust, during 2020 lockdown desperation I tried Minecraft for the 1st time. Now I love Minecraft, it's one of my favorite games now and the modded game has endless replay potential.

Overall the game is really fun and great to play so far, super immersive and a massive scope on the gameplay timeline and progression. That's the best way I can describe to depict how you just won't know unless you try it firsthand. I just wish that I had tried this game 1st before Atlas. The game a lot of the time so far reminds me of a combination of Conan Exiles and Rust when in the single-player format.

I haven't tried playing at all online yet, maybe it's a less favorable experience. I honestly don't care about that at all though. I can have an unfavorable online experience in literally every other game that exists. They are all just pumped down people's throats nowadays. What we have been missing for years is a genuinely good single-player experience. So far this game delivers on that. No server, ping, lag spikes, cheaters, griefers, a-holes, zergs, etc. to ruin your experience. 

Single-player games always have always been and always will be the best games. Without any question or doubt. There is no opposition, they are the industry standard. It's what sets the tone for every other game that exists. The gameplay for every single multiplayer game ever created was inspired by or derived directly from previously existing single-player games.

 Whether doubters realize it or not, all multiplayer games are derivatives single-player games from decades past. Without Doom, Duke Nukem etc. there are no other shooters. It's the core and essence for the gameplay mechanics and world designs. Philosophies from single-player games are the foundational basis making up every "multiplayer" game that exists now.

You've heard of, "What came first, the chicken or the egg?" Well here, single-player games are the egg, and they came first, indisputably. There used to be no internet, single-player games were all there was. It doesn't matter if you don't believe or agree, the truth is the truth and that fact is a constant that is unchanging.

The only style of games that you could make an argument were born as "multiplayer" games are absolute garbage like 'Among Us' & 'Fall Guys' that contribute absolutely nil to the gaming zeitgeist. They are a parasitic trend that have nothing truly original to offer. Zelda, Mario, Tomb Raider, etc. you name it every great game of all-time was born as single-player.

Thank you for the game!

I have only recently downloaded ark when it was free to keep, I have hundreds of hours on PS4 however.

This game is a royal screw-up of a fantastic concept. Gameplay is plagued with bugs and crashes compounded by major singleplayer balance issues. Don't get me wrong, it is definitely a fun game, but the way that it is balanced almost forces you to play on a server if you want to make late-game progression. There's a reason this game has a reputation for being buggy, within 10 minutes of playing it on Steam the game crashed and messed up my system files somehow. Now I can't even play most of my games for more than a few minutes because it will simply crash, after launching Ark once. I still love playing with friends on PS4, but the extremely frequent bugs, unrealistic balance, and computer breaking bugs ruin the experience for me. The developers have made a good game, and their hard work shows. But can they stop and take a minute to fix major issues with the base game instead of adding DLC after DLC? Seriously guys, we get that giant mechs and fantasy creatures make money, but just fix the actual dinosaur game before making whatever these new DLCs are. I have hope for Ark 2, and plan on buying it, but I cannot bring myself to recommend this game until Wildcard actually takes time to fix their game, which probably will never happen. Unless its on a ridiculous sale and you have 125+ gigabytes of storage you are willing to throw away, don't buy this game.

I have played this game on and off for years on the PS4 and can confidently state that this is the absolute worst, most frustrating, buggiest, and poorly designed game you will ever spend 2000 hours on. I don't know why us Ark players put up with such a broken pile of garbage and a dev company that doesn't seem to give a flying foxtrot about fixing anything as trivial as the game simply not working half the time, but we do and we keep coming back. 
This is a game that, every few months, I get a hankering for and I come back to it and play it nonstop for a couple months before getting so fed up that I quit again. Yet, as much fun as I do have during my time on it while it works and in between the bugs, I couldn't possibly recommend this game to anyone. Us long-time Ark players know this game, warts and all, and we've accepted it as the buck-toothed, hunch-backed runt that it is. I'd feel guilty getting any of my inexperienced friends to play it because I know they won't be able to see the kernel of fun below the layers of refuse. 
I've never wanted so much to simultaneously give a game 0 and 5 stars. What it does well, it does VERY well. The level design, music, aesthetic, gameplay concepts, etc, but when asked to actually be a game and do things like detect hit boxes, register where floors and walls are, or even load a server then it all falls apart. Somewhere in here are the makings of the best game I've ever played in the same way that somewhere in my septic tank is the best burger I've ever eaten.

Pros:

- Very nice concept
- looks kinda nice at first
- Dinos

Cons:

- Starving/Dehydration way to fast, but u can just drink salt water no problem
- Most Dinos are too easy to kill/tame
- Movement only in the direction u are facing (especially annoying when flying/rafting)
- Terrain is badly meshed
- They fucked up ambient occlusions
- depending on ur settings L.O.D. dithering gets applied even to the skybox and clouds
- EVERYTHING REFLECTS LIGHT, Get ur retinas toasted by looking at a leaf
- Ur dinos will get stuck on a branch on the floor, while the wild ones clip thru everything (even ur base)
- Cooking mechanic is trash
- Gunplay sucks, big fat ugly crosshair that stays on screen even in ADS so u cant see anything
- Base building is the worst of all the games i have played
- Cant build a big nice base (like in the trailers) in solo survival unless u have infinite time and no soul
- awkward structure placement
- sloped roof obstructs placement of sloped wall, u have to build roof first
- 1 Tree ~ 50 Wood, 1 Foundation ~ 10k Wood (U can use tamed Dinos later to farm more efficient tho)
- Crafting mechanic is trash
- Inventory management is a nightmare
- Run 5km for supply drop, get thatch door and water bottle blueprint
- U have to google everything (7yrs of development and no tutorial)
- gamebreaking bugs are not nearly as frustrating as the mechanics itself
- u freeze to death at night so all u can do is stand between 2 campfires for 20 minutes or u will die
- EVERYTHING POOPS, Cant disable pooping sound (have fun with ur Dodo farm)
- Files are all uncompressed so get rdy to download 300GB 
- UNICORNS

Fazit:

I would love to love this game because there is a lot of potential and it is actually fun for the first few hrs but after encountering all these annoying things i listed above i just cant play anymore without grinding my teeth down. I really enjoy survival games (RUST, DayZ, The Forest, Valheim, etc.) even when they are not that good. This Game has Everything, just in the worst way possible. Seriously, how can u fuck up so much with so many good games out there that are basically the same minus the Dinosaurs?

Oh yeah, but thanks for all those Laser Mech Dinos, Mythical Creatures and Unicorns.

A broken, unoptimized mess. Don't get me wrong: there are good things about this game, but the experience is badly sullied by how incompetently it is put together. This plays and feels like an early Early Access game, not a finished title! I recommend getting this game for free or for a few bucks at most if you can.
Here's a summary of what I found good and bad about this game in my 7 hours of playtime:

The Good:
- Huge map to explore, though it does feel a little empty.
- The environments look pretty and there are moment of genuine atmosphere.
- The concept is really neat and hey, can't go wrong with dinos. You can even ride them! :)
- I am a bit of a sucker for survival & crafting games... and a bit of a dino nerd.

The Bad:
- 125GB install and 400GB with all the extras is just nuts. The game seems to lack general optimizations and polish and this is reflected in performance as well as the install size.
- Many, many visual glitches. Had the lighting break on me a few times. The bloom/glare effect is absolutely horrendous too, often blinding me completely. In general the graphics tend to be a bit of an assault/strain on the eyes. Otherwise the game is quite pretty, though I feel this is purely thanks to Unreal Engine.
- The AI barely functions, I constantly see dinos get stuck on things, completely break their pathfinding (seen a Megalodon beach itself, nose down and ass up, and killing itself... twice), stuck in attacking something invisible or not able to move at all. This really took me out of the experience since they play such a big role in the game.
- There are just bugs every 5 minutes, really. Some are highly entertaining, some are just frustrating.
- The interfaces are rather clunky and can be a little confusing at times. Some things lack important explanation (such as the sleeping bag being a one-time use, I had to start over due to not knowing that).

I have played this game since in preview on the Xbox and i have always ended up coming back to this game and starting anew, always finding ways to explore and mess around and make new discoveries. It is a game that is not very forgiving but very rewarding if you play correctly.
I have so many stories from this game that I could not write them here as it would be half a or even a whole HP book. I have found that the best way to experience this game is to go out there and make the discoveries yourself thinking way outside the box. you never know what you will find. I recommend giving this a go, if its your first time look at the settings on single player and make it a little easier on yourself, if not look into boosted servers as these can be good too for new people. IF you want a real challenge though then go for the hardcore servers and see how long you survive. The only shame I have with this version is I need to get all my skins and all of the things I had on the Xbox again, thats tough

It's literally free for the next 9 days, and it's one of my favorite games of all time, having easely put 300 hours into it on PS4. But, while I do love this game, it has a lot of issues. There are sooooo many bugs, like seriously. I was playing with friends and we made a lot of progress( a lil wooden hut, a pte lvl 100, full metal gear except flak, ...) not that much but still 3-4 hours of my life. next day we start the non-dedicated session again and... gone, everything except our levels. It took only about an hour to get everything back, but I was so mad. Also, this isn't  as much of a complaint as just a warning, but be warry of the "easy" on some spawning locations on some maps, because the bog in genesis 1 is probably one of the worst areas out there.
Anyway, just get it. It's free and if it isn't anymore, I do still believe it's worth 20eu. Also, DLC is fantastic(for the most part) so don't pass up on that, except genesis 1 and 2, cuz it's actual shit.

This game is amazing to play with your friends. Although, unfortunately, multiplayer has been really inconsistent. The first time I played with my friend on his non-dedicated server, everything worked just fine, but the next time we tried to play together, his server would not come up ever, and on the rare occasion that it did come up, it would not let me join. We have now spent hours today just trying to play together rather than actually playing the game. The guides online for fixing theses issues were incredibly unhelpful too. This game has been around for what, 6 years? And it still has issues like this? Anyway, the actual game is okay if you're not including the bugs and garbage server system. ARK is a little different than your average survival game. Starting out can be a bit rough. Be patience. Once you start to level up your character and tame some dinosaurs, the survival aspect becomes much easier. Ark has it all; Base building, growing crops, taming dinosaurs, breeding to achieve stronger dinosaurs, crafting to advance your armor and weapons. Both PVE and PVP servers to pick from, just look for a community that fits your play style. Solo player? no problem. Most of my 3,000 play hours have been playing solo. Have some friends join you, and share some laughs. No friends you say, then join a tribe and work with other team members. Having trouble or need more of a challenge, then check out online video guides to spark your imagination. Ark has several maps and lots of dinosaurs, endless adventure possibilities.

Ark is like a drug or something, you always come back to it no matter how much you hate it. 
The game itself is okay, except from the huge lack of explanations when you play in solo, I won't even talk about pvp official problems here because it was a really bad experience for me (basically everyone with a life I guess). 
Overall I mostly played with friend on non dedicated servers and the game is very buggy, gamebreaking bugs sometime, per example I lost a huge amount of time trying to restore my saves because the game crashed while I was loading. Just imagine being 100hrs on a world and then you load in and nothing's there, no character no tames no constructions nothing, and this happened to me several times. 
Basically If you already started playing then it's too late , you're doomed to play ARK for the rest of your life, however if you didn't play this game yet I really wouldn't suggest it to you.


Anyway I'm saying all that while still playing this game, I'm really looking forward to Ark 2, I hope WC will be able to make a good game and maybe this time it could be optimized.

Glad I never had to pay to play this game before... Joining a server and not being able to set camp because I'm "too close to an enemy foundation or gate" so you just walk like a stray dog along the seaside with no place available to start to play. Great experience! Gonna save some disk space and uninstall this huge piece of 125GB waste. 
And that is why, imho, this type of MMOs are the plague of video gaming. We're lucky we have so many other better survival games that we can play and really enjoy the most, simply because they're just not MMOs. So instead of running a private server just to BE ABLE to play, the best I can do now, is to mitigate that stupid hype for ARK with a negative review.

Played for nearly an hour because the game is free right now. Tried it before and had it refunded. I hoped the game had get better now.
Was I wrong...
Character creation to begin with is really barebone and really not good looking, visually and technically the game now feels very dated. Then came the UI, outdated by fifteen years I'd say. Very unpractical, very unintuitive. Craft unlocking through leveling is made in a very unlogical way in my opinion, ressources gathering is ridiculous. Hundreds and hundreds of wood units cluttering my inventory when I only needed more and more thatch. Except this comes from downing trees, in very small quantities, but wood is everflowing rendering inventory management ludicrously cumbersome.
After 45 minutes I had a small platform, a bed, a storage box, a fire, and finally my character learned to wield a stick to defend itself. You're basically playing a monkey here.
Exited the game because I was getting really bored, returned, launch single player again... The game asks me to create a new character. Everytime I leave and comeback the world is back to its initial state and I must start another character. I don't even care how to fix this at this point, having to learn how not to lose progress on an auto-save title shouldn't exist.

I have to mention also the crashes at launch, the game not saving your settings, the window popping side when logging in or out... Extraordinarily unpolished for such an old game. I had this game for free in the ebd and somehow I still feel robbed.

With how long this game has been out I genuinely expected it to be a lot more polished when I got my hands on it. In all honesty, it feels extremely janky to play and I don't get how it's been such a 'hit'.

Ichtiosaurs swimming above water, trilobites on the beach, land dinos getting stuck in terrain (and each other), terrible player animations (don't go into 3rd person mode, trust me) etc. - all this on a local game that I can't blame lag for.

Overall, while it may have some deep and complex systems in there somewhere, the basics are nowhere nearly polished enough. And yes it may occasionally LOOK pretty, but only if you look at a static image - otherwise if you let it run you may notice that triceratops keeps walking into a boulder for all eternity.

PS: Why is thatch so much harder to source than wood? How does this make any sense?

Game is good but very poorly optimized

I got the game for free. It usually runs for 17€, determining the amount of scrutiny.

The game is missing the following basics:
1) a "start new game" button in the main menu. I had to consult web research to figure out how to launch a new game.
2) menu navigation. You cannot just start a new game. If you click "local/host" which is "start new game", you cannot just start the game; instead, you have to set ~100 parameters. Only then you can actually "start the game", however only by clicking "make player" (yeah, so that is another thing you have to do first, duh).
3) When the game then actually starts, you get sent as a hulk-like man onto the beach of an island with two big dinosaurs in front of you. You are cold but then 5mins later without leaving the spot you will also be hot. There is no introduction what to do. You literally have no clue. There is no character that will introduce you to the game; that will tell you what to do. Compare this to any person player game, like pokemon red, ocarina of time, or horizon, or even doom. Everytime the game has to start with someone telling you what to do and how you do it. Not so this game. You would have to go on youtube and let someone show you what you are supposed to do. But because this is a laisure activity, I won't.

A weird aside notice:
The game looks like an N64 game which is fine for a free game -- not for a 17€ game in 2022.
I run a Radeon VII from 2019, which is a strong card.
I noticed tho GPU ran on 100% load, which is crazy for that low quality. So I scaled down the grapics from middle (preset) to low. *Now* the graphics looked really poor. This always puzzles me: how some games look effortlessly preme and others crank the nob out of your GPU and look poor anyways.

Pros
[list]
[*]Dinosaurs
[*]Survival base builder
[*]High tech influences (and late game high tech gear, etc.)
[/list]

Cons
[list]
[*]Zero tutorial
[*]Zero guidance
[*]Very grindy
[*]Starter regions are all water locked-- and you'll very likely to die crossing the water
[*]Starter regions can be invaded by much higher level aggressive fauna-- and you'll die multiple times (possibly losing your whole base and all your gear)
[*]Starter regions don't give you access to the resources you need to explore further, not even in limited supply
[*]Without crystal you can't carry water anywhere else, and without water you will die quickly
[*]Taming Dinosaurs is never tutorialized-- it doesn't teach you how to do it. And some dinosaurs require you use kibble to tame them, which is a hidden recipe. And in order to get much needed resources, you are pushed to taming a Pterodon so you can fly to the resources you need, but to do that you need kibble, which takes a secret recipe. Did I mention this isn't tutorialized?
[/list]
