I'm just going to start out with the building mechanics of this game are extremely grindy and no wall or roof section rotation are just a breaker for me, can't even get into the game with how terrible it is. Stay tuned, I will give it a little longer and update this review, but at this time I cannot recommend it.

Continuing with my review, more on building, apparently building causes all resources within a set distance to stop respawning, now while this can be tailored in the settings, that leads me into my next feedback.

All the settings that can be tweaked were a bit confusing, some you had to turn up to decrease them others you had to turn down to increase them while some you had to turn up to increase, and well, you get the idea, but there are so many and you can end up screwing up the feel of the game so easily, it's all a bit much and seems completely unnecessary.

Purpose, this game is pretty well purely a survival game, I am sure there are those that would call it a sandbox survival, but as I've said, the sandbox aspect is so minimal it just sucks.  As for the survival aspect, I have played a couple of these pure survival games and it just ends up being a chore to the point where I would rather dig a hole in the backyard in the real world over 3 hours of getting enough stone to make a 4 bedroom house.  My thing with survival games is, well, if you want the real feel, then there has to be real risk, as in if you die, you lose everything, and I mean everything, but it is never that way in these type of games, you drop your pack and lose an hour of farming and crafting, so really survival just isn't enough of a point to like the game.  They did add a little "quest" to defeat the almighty overseer, but first you will need to beat a limited number of bosses, but first you must visit several horribly balanced caves to obtain an artifact that when combined allows you to fight a boss, then you get the joys of going to those caves again for the next boss........grind.

The dinosaurs are cool and the graphics are lovely in my opinion, however the gameplay lacks so much that I would have to say I enjoyed PixArk more.

If I were to recommend an alternative, Conan:Exiles, at least the combat is fun, the building is much better and more indepth, the survival is just as pointless, but it does have a similar objective that is less grindy.

The best dinosaur survival game out there. Games like Beasts of Bermuda, The Isle, Path of Titans and others cannot compete. This game is a grind, and commitment is required. Friends make it easier (and more fun!)

Ark:se takes survival to an unfathomable level. You must face starvation, predatory dinosaurs, harsh biomes, and other players all while struggling to survive. You will die many times over, but you will overcome the challenges.

There are currently 180+ creatures in Ark, and most of them will kill you or die trying. Each has its own special use, with some overlapping. You will need to tame them to succeed. Many of them make harvesting resources much easier so you spend less time grinding. And plus, there's nothing that beats the feeling of slaying the dinosaurs that have put you in the grave using a better dino.

Vanilla is very adjustable and almost every setting can be tweeked. There are thousands of mods that make the game so much easier for casual style players. My favorite mod is definitely Structures+, however there are plenty more if you don't enjoy strict vanilla.

Because this game has such a steep learning curve, most players will be discouraged from attempting to learn. However, the community is truly amazing and has everything you will ever need. There are written guides, video guides, websites specifically for resources and taming guides. If you have a question, the community has already answered it!

There are so many issues that just ruin the game:
1.) Its laggy, you will be ported around a lot.

2.) The performance is poor. I can easily play games with much better visuals, but ark just looks terrible and is still slow.

3.) Skill system is simply increasing max of what ever.. e.g. max stamina, max water etc. there are no real skills.

4.) Hunger jumps back and forth . You eat, it goes up a bit, than rapdily falls down, then jumps back up, etc. It seems to be random.

5.) But the worst of all, are the controls. There is a toolbar with up to ten usuable items on it, and the mousewheel does not scroll through the toolbar, but instead changes to third person view and back to first person.
You cannot harvest stuff while you have something in one hand, so you need to unequip it then harvest then equip again.
Even the campfire has a full circle menu.
When you build a house, you need to build all walls individually then place them.
If you want to pick up something you get to visible response, meaning you sometimes pick up the wrong item etc.

This is a perfect example of developers and gamers thinking that making a game super grindy is fun and challenging. ARK fails to be both. The game-play is repetitive and boring. The crafting lacks intuitiveness and logic, the map is completely useless, and the game overall fails to have any real direction. Even putting on a couple cheats and exploring the world left a ton to be desired. I got this game on a free weekend, and I still want to ask for a refund. Not sure at all how this game became popular, unless it was just from a bunch of trend followers drooling over youtubers. Have at it if this is your thing, but this is a terrible game in my opinion.

Have played Ark religiously for the past 6 years, finally have it on a decent PC and I've been missing out. If you love survival games, cave diving, boss fights, hunting for that perfect tame, breeding armies to your specifications or raiding other people's bases....this is absolutely a must. I play a lot of single player as I am older and dont have time for raiding much anymore, and even the singe player customizable settings are worth the purchase.

This game is terrible. For a free game, it has some quality, but it is not something I'd dedicate meaningful work into. Whenever you die somewhere remotely far from your spawn, you're forced to either fist-fight raptors naked or  make equipment, by that time your equipment would've despawned. Even if you make it to your body in time, the thing which killed you still sits there, camping your body to fight you again. Not to mention the absent moderation on official servers and/or admin power abuse. Adding to the idiocy, the the animals that can steal your items have the worst balancing. One moment, you're doing whatever you may be doing, the next, the weapon you have  is stolen by a random bird. Then it proceeds to thieve the rest of your food and equipment because you have no ranged weapons. The whole game looks to be some sort of freak show. The shaders are absolutely terrible, making the water too reflective, and the day-time sky near blinding. If you happen to die at night, you can't see 5 inches in front of you, and have no easy way of lighting the area around you. Not to mention how the garbage temperature system is intuitive, wanting you to cool down somehow then immediately asking you to heat up. Not to mention the obscure way to progress, forcing you to sit around and wait for something to happen. There is also no tutorial (or anything similar), leaving me to wander spawn, confused on what to do. I don't know if I'm doing a mistake in any of these ridiculous things, or it happens by chance, but it just happens to make this game one of the worst I've ever played. It may be easy to start out with for others, but I can barely scrounge up a reason to barely like this game.
JUST A GOOD GAME SO PLAY IT

Wasted a few summers on this game on the ps4 version. Great time killer and the process of leveling up is addicting. Starting from nothing and eventually building up to something. The grinding never stops so there is always something to do to keep you busy. Having more people to play with makes the re-buildup process much quicker after you log back on and find out your base/tames you spend hours, days, weeks, or even months doesn't exist. Find people you trust and form alliances to help ensure everything you worked for doesn't get wiped. Build Conquer Thrive. Just remember that once you devote yourself to ark, there is no turning back... It will always find a way back into your life. Long live the Great Khans.

Survival games are a second jobs, but this game takes it to the extreme.
Combining RPG style level progression with multiple skills.
You can go into pvp and get murdered by 12 year olds and get your poor shack raided while you're offline... kind of like Rust.
You can play this in a PVE or single player mode, but then you see that the game is made for groups of people and it is not made for single player.

If you want a second job, or maybe you just don't have one and you need to feel like you're doing something, sure, download 120GB of 2017 game that spent years in early access and released paid DLC before a full release of the game.

There are so many horrendous bugs, sometimes even game ruining ones, like bloodstalkers floating off into the sky and other tamed dinos falling through the map, but you get to ride T-Rexes so I give it a 7/10: would recommend riding a T-Rex.

Well, I wanted to play this game but it kept crashing.  It's not like my rig couldn't handle it.  I have an i7 with a GTX 1050 TI and 8 gigs of ram.  Another thing I noticed was Windows 10 itself came to a screeching halt even though the game was closed; and when Windows did work, the files took forever to load.  After uninstalling the game, I was able to get my computer back and my files load immediately.  I never had this issue with any game I installed in my system before.  And don't give me "it's a spec issue" because I have run Cyperpunk 2077 full settings 116 to 132 FPS easy!  I wanted to enjoy this game but I simply couldn't so uninstalled.

No need for a long list of pros and cons here. With Ark, we own more content, more action, more survival, more mounts, more crafting than you will ever need...ever. 
This title has been in my library for some time...years, I think? I kept pushing it back for other titles and opportunities that are no longer viable. And well, after a brief download, I went in with zero to none knowledge of the game. Within a few hours, I was able to complete my quest for survival on a whole other level than I anticipated.
Am I mad that I waited so long to play? Yes, and no. I missed out on several expansions over the years, but the sweet part is that I can jump into any one of the creative expansions available (most are free atm) and team with the pros. The pvp and pve both have the NPC to overcome...and believe me, you haven't lived until you narrowly escape the relentless pursuit of a pack of wolves...not any kind of wolf though, it's the Pre-modern man kind. 

What are you waiting for? Why are you still here? Get out there and fight for your other real life...Ark.

This game is alright, with excellent graphics and terrain....but this game should focus more on quality and features.

1. Tether. I shouldn't have to explain this. Tether is the worst feature in this entire game. It throws other people off the land or gets them killed. Even at max tether, it's still not that much space and they should add a way to stop tether.
2. Crashes. During multi-player, people have crashed or glitched out.
3. Lag. It takes at least a minute to load an artifact cave.
4. The amount of space it takes. It takes about 200 gigabytes for the game. It takes so much space but then gets rid of space it doesn't use.
5. While people are happy about Ark being free, the people who paid for it didn't get their money back. We didn't get anything back.
6. In Ark 2, please add a feature that gets rid of Tek and Riot armor. This is a dinosaur survival game. Not a game where you become Iron Man. I know you can get rid of engrams but things like terminals and boss portals are still a thing.
7. I have had multiple Dinosaurs fall through maps and could not get them back. Please add a command to teleport dinosaurs to you or some sort of structure. 
8. Dino taming. Please add more passive tames. It doesn't make sense how you fill a dino with tranq darts, force-feed it food with no other option, and it's somehow your friend?
9. Ragdoll. It may not seem like a problem until you get swarmed by dead bodies that somehow stretched across the map. There is clearly enough money for death animations. You did it with Bosses and...Compys?
10. When other players crash in the non dedicated server, it takes more than one try to get them back in the game.


These are only a few problems with Ark. Please fix your game or get rid of these in Ark 2.

I wrote a more in-depth review, but Steam decided that it went missing. So, here is the short and sweet version.

If you can pick up this game for free, then great, enjoy some time with it.

If you don't own it yet, and the sale is over, you may want to reconsider. By no means am I telling you not to purchase ARK, if you have your heart set on it, then get it. 

The reason why I wrote this review isn't to comment on the game itself, but rather the studio that owns it and the side-effects of "ARK overdose".

Studio Wildcard is about as unreliable as they come. Without fail they constantly delay DLCs and updates, break other features with said updates, and don't fix the current problems with the updates. If ARK was just an elaborate cash-grab, then I wouldn't even be mad, because it worked well, very well.

Just take these words as another viewpoint of ARK. Consider if the investment into this game is worth it, worth your time and energy. For the many hours that I played this game on my Xbox account, It certainly wasn't worth it for me. Most of the time that I had fun while playing was with friends. We weren't even taking it seriously, just a couple lads screwing off for a couple hours, and ARK was how we did it. But when you were just playing by yourself, it got depressing. I mean, the burnout that I had from this game was second to none. I had stopped playing a few years back, tried it out at this recent Steam sale, and it is exactly what I expected.

If this sounded like a rant, I'm sorry about that. I probably vented too much. All that I ask is for you to consider what I said above.

Is it really worth it?


Edit: I forgot to mention that you need a NASA supercomputer and their storage space to even run this game. Seriously, the base game is 125 Gb? Not even including all the DLCs, then it goes up to 250+! The DLCs also cost about as much as the base game, each!
GOOD GAME SOLO OR WITH FRIENDS

God bless Ark Survival Evolved. Similarly, there would be a hint of irony and it would be very hypocritical for oneself to ignore the fact that although such historical work like Ark Survival Evolved does have a place in all of our hearts, from its engaging characters, advanced mechanics, varying terrain and a complex ecosystem that teaches you from very early on that this isn’t a normal game. This game is designed for gamers, particularly those who practise against minorities. Ark Survival Evolved is more than a video game, it is the foundation for many strong relationships where love is cherished. This is where E-girlfriends are most common. E-girlfriends, E-girlfriends as far as the eye can see. Even the most experienced and battle tested veterans that have graced the immersive and welcoming community that resides within Ark Survival Evolved will spend days searching for the perfect E-girlfriend which has loyalty and a keen sense of respect. They even remember important dates and anniversaries such as Birthdays and they are often prone to assembling cucks from far and wide in order to appease their Boyfriends from yonder lands through parties which mostly take place at the Centre Arena on Friday nights around 8:00PM PST.

Ark: Survival Evolved has the potential to be a wonderful game. It's clear that the developers put a lot of work into the 3D open world that comprises the players' environment.

Unfortunately, the game experience comprises more than simply the world environment. The interface between the player and that world, especially in a game that requires extensive crafting, is vital to the gaming experience. The Ark interface is a failure in that regard. It is clear that it was created by coders, rather than people who have actually done UX design before.

It's funny. I saw game streamers #Markiplier and #JackSepticEye playing a pre-release version of the game, and the interface was much simpler and cleaner than the current hodgepodge of unrelated features that make up the crafting, inventory, tech, and animal training functions.

Oh yeah. A lot of the text on these screens is impossible to read from more than 2 feet away from the monitor.

Rating 2/5 stars for unpleasant gameplay, but the potential for a 5 star game is there.

Running up a snowy mountain firing a machine gun at a woolly mammoth from the back of a tyrannosaurus is a fantastic example of the reason many video games exist: living out ridiculous childhood fantasies. ARK: Survival Evolved has plenty of that to go around across its multiple sprawling maps - which it calls ARKs - which can be explored solo or crowded with up to 100 players. Some lingering technical issues, bad dino AI, and an extreme amount of grinding to reach endgame are the main factors keeping it from being as sharp in the tooth as it could be.

Like many of the survival/crafting games of the genre it partially helped popularize, ARK dumps you on the beaches of a massive, foreboding island with just enough clothing to stay modest and your own two fists. From there, the challenge is to stay fed and hydrated while avoiding a huge variety of terrifyingly detailed dinosaurs and other beasts long enough to progress up the tech tree. Early in the life of a character, you might be taking out dilophosaurs with throwing spears and hoping a triceratops doesn’t come and knock your thatch hut over in the middle of the night.


From there, there’s a really nice flow of technological progression that makes advancement feel like more than just an increase in stats. Thirty hours later, you may preside from a sturdy stone castle from atop which you snipe pterasaurs out of the air with a rifle. By the endgame, it’s possible to have a massive steel fortress full of blast furnaces, complete with electric lighting and gas generators, churning out components for building rocket launchers and SCUBA gear.

label=A%20Lumbering%20Beast

But the excitement is dulled as the amount of menial grinding required to reach the higher tiers of technology goes up exponentially, to the point where it could take an entire day of playtime just to stock up on ammunition for certain weapons. This can cause things to really start to drag when you’re just getting access to some of the most interesting tech - especially if you don’t have a large tribe of other players to help you divide the labor. It’s one of those games that can be played solo, but at least on PvP servers, I wouldn’t recommend it.

Players are your greatest opportunity and your greatest danger.On public PvP servers, other players are both your greatest opportunity and greatest danger. As I learned the hard way more than once, making sure your shelters are hidden from potential looters is far more important than making sure they are strong, and I often returned from less than 12 hours offline to find my barricades wrecked and hours worth of resource harvesting hauled off. Things get much better if you can work your way into a strong tribe of players that can protect your stuff 24/7.


In offline single-player, there’s actually an extensive and detailed sort of campaign to follow that will take you to a variety of monster-filled caves to acquire artifacts and summon three challenging bosses. There’s a giant spider queen and a bona-fide fire-breathing dragon! These encounters show quite a bit of attention to detail, though they rely a bit too heavily on summoned minions to increase the difficulty. It’s also extremely punishing to lose in one of these encounters because not only will you lose any armor, weapons, and ammo you had equipped - potentially several hours of gathering and crafting - but you’ll also lose the artifacts needed to summon the boss, forcing you to replay those challenging caves all over again.

Narrative flourish distinguishes ARK from its genre brethren.Defeating all three bosses unlocks an endgame dungeon that reveals a surprising amount of backstory behind the ARKs and their purpose, which came as a pleasant surprise in a game that’s ostensibly just about riding dinosaurs around and smelting ore on first glance. It’s this narrative flourish more than anything that really distinguishes ARK from its genre brethren. The sheer amount of time and effort required to get there the traditional way is probably more than most solo players have the attention span for – even after more than 60 hours of focused play I had to resort to using console commands to shortcut certain steps just to be able to access the final area in time to write this review.

label=Every%20Size%20and%20Shape

Beyond the bosses, I was highly impressed by the diversity of creatures crammed into each ARK - most of which can be tamed, and many can even be ridden once the appropriate saddle is unlocked and crafted. From bumbling, docile dodos all the way up to the colossal, carnivorous Gigantosaurus (Latin for “I bet you wish I was merely a T-Rex”), each looks fantastic and has a distinct set of behaviors you’ll have to learn to deal with them. Riding with a pack of direwolves or taking flight on the feathered argentavis for the first time were major highlights of my ARK experience. The process of taming itself is just annoying, though. It consists of knocking your future pet unconscious and then feeding it while it slumbers, waiting for a painstakingly slow (especially on larger creatures) taming bar to complete. It’s the epitome of the “Sit around waiting for something to finish” activities that are ARK’s weakest components.


Though ARK has emerged from a long early access period with most of its nastiest bugs fixed, there are still weird graphical glitches all over the place, like shadows popping in and out randomly and intermittent frame rate dips. Worst of all is the fact that the AI on larger dinosaurs is pretty terrible. The best strategy for killing anything beefier than a raptor remains getting it stuck on the terrain and plinking it in the head from total safety. Even my own tamed dinosaurs often get stuck in trees when moving through a forest if I don’t babysit them, and in some cases became so badly stuck in caves that I had to kill them to recover the items they were holding and move on.

Verdict
When I’m having a good time in ARK, I’m having a really good time. The problem is that those moments are usually one part to every nine parts menial grinding and crafting - especially at the later tech tiers. Having to repeat so much work after failing an attempt at a boss feels far too punishing, and some really dumb dinosaurs can take a lot of the challenge and sense of danger out of the many primal locations. Even with all of those quirks, however, I’m still hungry to play more after the 60 hours I’ve spent so far. There aren’t a lot of survival games that have legitimately held my attention that long.

ARK Survival Evolved, the title alone makes so much more sense once you played the game. It truly is an evolved survival experience! ARK is one of those games you‘d imagine in your daydreams. Lots of unique Dinos that you can tame and ride, building your own Jurassic Park and all of that with your friends. And they did a phenomenal job!
There are some downsides like Loading times, file size (this game is 375GB for me not including 2 DLCs) overall smoothening the game experience and I‘d suggest to truly appreciate this game you‘d need quite a decent PC. Despite that this game has everything you can wish for! More than 400 unique creatures in total to see and tame, Bossfights, base building, workshop mod support and events after 6 years! Plus, it’s for free now! (Not including Genisis 1 and Genisis 2). There is a lot of content to see and experience so it is hard to put it all into words. This game has a very wide variety of content and I do believe there‘s something for everyone in this game.
I‘d rate this game 8 out of 10 due to the downsides I already mentioned. My biggest issue is probably that my game is taking nearly 400GB of space and that it‘s not always the most smooth running game. Despite that the massive amount of content and mod support is just amazing.

It's terrible.

First off, the game is HUGE.  Like, ridiculously huge.  The game assets are poorly optimised and duplicated, so it's astounding how much disk space it consumes for the relatively mediocre graphics and models.

Secondly, it's very, VERY easy to get caught in a loop of respawn -> immediately die.  IMMEDIATELY die, as in within seconds.  The tryhards will stress "it's a survival game" and "you need situational awareness", except neither of those factors mean anything when the game can and does repeatedly respawn you right next to a dino that can both outrun you and kill you in 2-3 hits.  That's not fun, that's frustration for the sake of frustration.

Thirdly, the game is extremely directionless.  There's absolutely no help at the lower levels.  You'll look up guides on how to sleep.  How to pick up rocks.  And so on and so forth.  The game is made for people who already know how to play it, which means complete newbies are going to experience nothing but frustration.  And then, I assume, many will (like me) question why they keep around a game that consumes such a collossal amount of disk space when it isn't fun to play.

I paid absolutely nothing for this game.  I died 3 times in the span of 5 minutes.  There are no tutorials, no indications on where to start, the only on-screen indicator was that I had levelled up and it didn't even tell me how to open up my inventory.  No Man's Sky was better value for my money and I paid (#DIV/0!) times as much for it.

Yeah, I know there are tutorials that I can access on the Internet, but for an $80 game it's garbage.

I played on a priv server - not a public one so I won't comment on what the community/culture of the game is like, just the gameplay! 

Starting off is a little complicated, and sometimes annoying. In first 10 spawns I got ganged up on by a pack of huge dinos that wouldn't leave me alone - which made starting out a bit of a bummer. The game can also feel  a bit overwhelming. I had to look at a lot of tutorials on how things work, how to build, tame, etc... plus also found out there is a compost bin bug which is annoying.

HOWEVER - Dinosaurs made it so much fun! I made a saddle for a Parasaur i named Banana and a got triceratops named Jevin, and they are great as carry mules and fun to ride :) Me and my partner have been building a small base, and now that we have the basics all learnt, we've been taming dinos left and right, and i'm currently building a little Dodo pen for our Dodos. It's a really fun game once you get started and i'm really enjoying myself! Again - not sure how public servers are, but I love the priv server we made and it's definitely a fun game to play with friends.

Picked up the original, pre-tek cave on the island, ARK long, long ago.
At 1.3~k hours deep, it's still fun.
The game is very unforgiving, and extremely time consuming if you play with normal, unmodified tame and breeding rates, unless you are playing online, with friends, where the times keep moving when you aren't.
There's still a bit of jank in it, even now, but over all it's come a long way and admittedly, will likely remain one of my favorites for some time to come. 
As someone who greatly enjoys PvE-survival, where I'm not also forced to do major combat every thirty seconds to 'survive', it's got my 'Do play, is fun' seal of approval.
I will forever stand by this statement however; Leeds suck, and are pointless unless you have a severe issue with PvP rafts, Ichthyornis needs to be disabled because they're still not fixed, and Gigant's can fall off a cliff and die as a collective whole, but at least they serve a purpose other than pissing off players.
Replace all 3 with Dodo's and have fun with ARK: Survival Evolved, it's worth buying when it's on sale. (It's a very large, and now expansion heavy, game, so I will always recommend 'sale price'.)

Dinosaurs! Survival! DInosaurs! Crafting! DINosaurs! Exploration! DINOsaurs! Leveling DINOSaurs! PvP! DINOSAurs! PvE! DINOSAUrs! Taming! DINOSAURs! Feeding! DINOSAURS!

If you made it this far, I applaud you. But in all seriousness, this game is really fun. I usually don't enjoy survival games, but the flow of leveling up, stat allocation, dinosaur interaction, and every other thing I mentioned simply flow SO WELL together. If you love dinosaurs, you'll love this game. Is it without its faults? Absolutely not. Is it free on steam (til Jan 19th 2022) and worth a try? HELL YES!

Also there are MODS! Everything under the sun that you could think "Dang if only they'd done X as well/instead" trust me, there's a mod for it in the workshop. Come try it out, I guarantee it's worth the time.

Eh... as a big fan of survival games, I was expecting better. The UI is confusing, the animations are pretty bad, and there's a lot of RNG-hell. Also, the description is wrong... you don't start naked. Big disappointment to those of you who wanted to play nekked girls, haha! :) But there are better games for that anyway. It's not all negative though... the leveling system is decent, some of the visuals are pretty good, and the confusing UI is eventually workable. Also, I can't help but chuckle like a school child whenever someone rips one... even though it makes no sense in the context of your character, who could be wearing a suit made of chitons and out comes a dookie. Poop jokes aside though, there were just too many rookie mistakes in this game for me to really enjoy it. And inb4 someone comes back with "but it's free!"... yeah, that doesn't cut the mustard with me. If I had to pay for this game, I'd probably have been rather upset. Play it for some laughs if you want, but to be brutally honest, your time would probably be better spent elsewhere. An alright effort by the developers... the potential is there, but it needs a lot of work.

EDIT: I played the game for more time after I wrote my initial review but my opinion hasn't changed in the end. Honestly, the game got a bit boring after awhile too. I guess if you're into team play then it's more fun but as a single-player survival game, look elsewhere.

Anyway ARK used to be my full time job, playing 16 hours a day just to hatch my babies and raise them to 100% boosted lvl, i would only sleep 4 hours a day to protect my base and always hide my dinos in the transfer and I used to always live on a boat or build a secret base in a underwater cave. I would always get offline raided and my addiction finally stopped. But I am glad that I played this game. But I do not recommend playing official ark if you are not prepared to play 16 hours a day.

I love the game, I just don't like the cheaters. I've been playing the game for years. I started on Xbox, and then moved over to PC for a better experience, but it ended up being a worse experience. With so many sites that can track your character, many users are using the name of "123", which helps prevent tracking, but it also limits any type of punishment for abuse for those particular players. I don't mind the game play, when it's played the right way. 

Yeah, there are people that complain about bigger tribes picking on them, but it happens. That's part of the game. There's just more to it though. With the use is ESP, aimbot and other cheats, it just makes a game that is already based on survival, even harder. Wildcard can't stop the cheating, so they don't even try, they just keep releasing content to grab and much $$$ as possible. I hope Ark 2 is better, because I'm looking forward to playing it, but if the same cheats are around for Ark 2, you can count me out for that as well.

I played some of ARK, and I like the ideas, but sometimes the execution just isn't there. It's minecraft with dinosaurs. Good  enough

but building is a huge pain, taming dinosaurs can be a bit aimless not to mention time consuming (I spent about 25 minutes taming a dinosaur after spending an extra 8 or so trying to find out just what it prefers to eat), the path finding on the dinos are broken at times, the map could use a tiny bit of improvement, these all sound like complaints, but they aren't because I "get it", it's meant to be an immersive experience, and that's cool, but a "survival" campaign and a more "arcadey" campaign would've been a bit better. Getting lost in the woods because night time may as well be a black screen while a raptor comes up and shanks you can be...eh, kinda annoying, but the options to change these settings do exist. There is technology like torches, lights, and even electrical equipment, but the constant juggling of items due to weight limits and trying to work with storage is just as much a pain. I can offload my cargo to my tamed dinos but they have to not die from everything to be useful.

and then ARK's probably biggest offender is time itself, I get it's supposed to be satisfying to build up to a fully sustained agricultural society but man it turns into a huge time sink quickly. I got it for free from the ARK 2 announcement, and there are things to enjoy it but really it just makes me want to play dwarf fortress which I'm waiting for the world to build while I write this.

This is the first bad review I've ever written, and the first game that I actually think that it's unplayable. It's a fantastic idea, it has epic scenery, good graphics and so on.

What isn't great is choosing the easiest location and still getting clapped by raptors that you can't run away from, can't fight, can't sneak past and will lose all your dinos and items you have grinded for thus far, because they will stay where raptors killed you. So I got locked in endless cycle of making the most rudamentary weapons and armor and then losing it.

From the technical side - the ubiquitous high mouse latency, that makes it hard to aim at anything (but I can't take it into consideration since it is common for almost any modern game). Inventory and menus drops my fps to about 5, making it pretty annoying. And 125 GB of space occupied because of uncompressed files? 

And where I even have not gotten - getting base destroyed by RNG spawn of OP dinos, getting griefed by non-rookie and higher level players in multiplayer.

This game is absolute grind that pretty much guarantees you that you'll lose everything. From my experience - one of the few games that is literally unplayable.

Edit: So, I was fortunate enough to not get attacked by agressive dinos and actually could play the game. After getting 3 trikes, I could actually travel somewhere. After a while T-Rex (AFAIK it's supposed to be one of the hardest dinos in the game) spawned and I thought it was over, but I completely destroyed him - for some reason, when I was starting, I almost couldn't move without dying at the start and now after getting few a dinos in about an hour I'm unbeatable by regular dinos, makes sense. But my PC crashed and now all my settings and world settings are reset and my character is gone. Anti-corruption backup file didn't work, steam cloud does not contain any ARK file. I can see a chest I placed earlier, so maybe my dinos are still there and the new character owns them, but that means I have to get to them from scratch, which means I'm going to be dying for a long time before i can think about getting any progress. I think I'm done with this game.

There are a lot of cool survival games out there.  Not this one, though.  This one is stupid.  It confuses arbitrary difficulty for fun, at least in the early game.  It's like this:  Die, respawn at your sleeping bag which is destroyed because you only get to respawn there once, get killed immediately by the thing that killed you last time, now respawn "randomly", in the middle of the night, with no weapons, clothes or torch, find your way back to your home in the dark, dying about 20 times, finally get there and try to grab your stuff, get killed by the thing that already killed you twice, respawn randomly again.  But hey, if you grind a few more hours you can build a bed which you can respawn at more than once.  Hooray.  Or, even better, go play Valheim.

I have no clue how this game was ever 60 dollars. TL;DR, buggy mess is a gross understatement, its free now and can be really fun with friends once you figure out how to get it working. try it out but make sure you have weed or or a cigarette nearby.

Ok. I love Ark, I've sunk a ton of time into it, and most of the jank I've been willing to look past. But after years, the company refuses to fix any of the visual glitches, the camera shake makes me motion sick and turning it down doesn't work anymore for some, and even on higher resolutions the game looks like it's playing in 240p. It has been YEARS. But instead of fixing it, they're trying to shove more content in and make an Ark 2 when the game is already overly massive and poorly optimized. I want to recommend Ark, but this studio does not deserve the thumbs up. I'm probably still gonna pour hours into this game, but I cannot recommend this game. I genuinely feel bad about buying the DLCs now since they clearly didn't put that money towards finally fixing things

Decent game, but the difficulty curve solo is garbage.

being ambushed by packs hostile mobs, raptors spawning a foot away from my front door, carnivores AI only focusing on you even though there are plenty of other delicious meaty sticks that you run past, over-levelled mobs in easy areas, AI being able to attack through geometry, knocked out tames and them waking up and eating all your narcotics and meat you pack into them(Like they just disappear).... someone needs to playtest this online solo and actually balance some of the things to make it an experience you can survive, because as it stands, the game is really cheap in the sense that you will die constantly to things you shouldn't even be seeing until you have basic gear.

On the flip side, man, playing with even one other person pretty much stops all these problems, unfortunately, reliably getting people to play any game is just not even a thing... basically don't bother if you are planning to get people on board with the game and just talk to others online and create and online tribe (personally I don't like doing this as my work schedule means I can't reliably be online for ages or on certain days) 

Oh and guys, please stop building your bases at the spawn points and locking people into the easy spawns.... another major problem of being locked in or out of certain places essentially stopping you from gathering any resources online and bottlenecking you into spawning in the medium and hard zones.

Great game in concept, needs better spawning and levelling or I need better friends.

(Also used to play this on Xbox one, so 12 hour playtime is completely inaccurate.)

I got this game for free, and played single player for seven hours. 

The game is unforgiving and grinding, and progress feels meaningless. 
It's just as easy to die with resources as without. 
Cannot sleep in game, so you're wandering around in the mostly dark for half the game. 
Taming dinosaurs is irritating and time-consuming, and in the end there's barely anything you can do with them. 

I realized that I was not having fun. I was just irritated, struggling from one task to the next, only to realize that it wasn't even worth it in the end. There's a big sense of "...Now what?" 

On top of all of this, the game is super buggy and glitchy. So. It sucks. Not my thing.

i have a love-suicide relationship with this game. By the way, don't let my game time fool you, i have plenty more hours on the ps4. Also this review only talks about the single-player experience because i don't have enough free time for servers.

at some points i feel giddy with joy over all the possibilities and things i can do, all the dinos i can tame, all the shit i can build, the places to explore, the landscapes and caves to scavenge; it draws me in every time i see the icon on my desktop. At some points i look out on the island or cave i currently inhabit and i truly feel accomplished over what I've done over the many, many, many, many hours I've grinded. And that's just it. Grind.

The thought of it puts me off, can i really be bothered to collect, mine, chop, or otherwise massacre 300 of whatever material i need? Chances are the answer is no, and yet i sigh and slump in my seat, and get on with it. A simple way to fix this is to put the harvest gain from resources up several notches, a fix that i definitely could've done with many moons ago. However, this may gain the attention of sweaty virgins who haven't looked into a loved ones eyes since the last base raid, who will then proceed to list off your IP address, and call you a fake gamer. 

Exploration is my favourite part of any game, the preparation, the perilous unexpected situations, all par  for the course in many of my favourite games. Ark is a game that practically relies on exploration for you to progress, which is fine obviously, but the deaths are so ridiculously unforgiving and stressful that the mere mention of the mountain biomes makes me break out into a nervous sweat, and i begin reminiscing on when i flew over the aforementioned mountains, pressed the wrong button, fell off my pterosaur, plummeted several hundred feet, which was then proceeded by hours of trying to retrieve my best gear, only to give up and silently weep into my hands at 4am. 

Other cons that bugged me:

- Bugs, so fucking many bugs 
- atrocious combat
- bugs
- lacklustre base-building
- maybe im just an idiot but i couldnt find a simple way to play with a friend without playing on public servers
- b u g s
- the game lacks style or any semblence of imagination, no artisitic direction to capture my imagination

Overall, this game is ridiculously flawed, but, it's the definition of a guilty pleasure.

[SPOILER WARNING] the game is about getting of the arks(the island you start of) on to a corrupted earth,destroing said corruption and killing rockwell(main bad guy) to stop him on his crusade to take over more planets whit his aberrations of normal life.Yes this is a dinosaur game, and its great.
Gameplay:Survival PvP/PvE/Solo sandbox where you try to survive the extream enviroments the game puts you in like:
-a tropical island,

-a corrupted earth whit ruins of the old tehnology (TEK) with bigger than godzilla titans and a GIANT titan made of corruption,
-a simulation taken over by rockwell with him trying to keep you from beating it and getting out of the simulation
-a GIANT Halo like space ship with two rings,one taken over ba rockwell and his abberant creations like a 
 fish/lion hibrid.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

The graphics are okay. Game play sucks. The character is suppose to explore but can barely jump a log let alone climb a small boulder a 5-year-old child could climb with ease. The second you go into a jungle you're hot and need to find somewhere cool. Three steps back to the beach and you're freezing and need to find some place warm. When swimming, the character drowns, even when you keep his head out of the water, which lessens his exploration abilities. For beginners, game play is entirely trial and error, with no instruction on how anything functions. I got the game for free, so for me, it's a good game to use in creative mode, using the LeaveMeAlone cheat, when I need to relax after a stressful day and can focus more on building and less on exploring and fighting off dinosaurs. If it wasn't for this, I would delete the game and never play it again. Needless to say, I will not be trying the new Ark 2 when it comes out.

Buggy unfinished Roblox looking game with horrific performance, uncompressed files that take up way too much space, and art direction that looks like it was directed by a 3 year old. Survival mechanics seem non-existent and the menus and UI are horrifically cluttered and unintuitive. Feels like a broken buggy tech demo for a bad indie game. Not worth the mental effort of thinking about.

None of the files are compressed so it results in the base game taking up over 150 Gigabytes, let alone the dozens of gigabytes from the DLC maps, The performance on any system rarely goes above 80 frames besides the lower or medium settings which look like a 1990s experimental digital animation from Disney. The graphics are some of the worst of any survival game and they haven't updated them whatsoever. The prompts and menu navigation is dated and looks unfinished despite it being out for years. The only good thing is the funny experiences running from dangerous dinos with friends, but besides that the game is grindy and poor. I wasted £50 on this, should've been free from the beginning.

There is a severe imbalance here. Trying to play solo, every time I get a house built, start making machines to progress myself, the AI spawns a bunch of predators that kill me, often before I am able to get inside my house. The predators glitch through even stone walls and do damage. I can't get away. When they do kill me, I can't get back to my stuff and my house because the predators linger, stuck in some weird kill loop that has them endlessly attacking my house when there is no one (and no meat) there, or attacking some random herbivore corpse that wasn't there before, but is oddly so close to my corpse that I cant get my stuff back. 

Whats worse is the tuneable aspects of my single player server do not help. Turn down the dino damage? The AI just sends a pack of seven raptors instead of one or two. Heck, why not make a nearby triceratops attack randomly while im minding my own business chopping down trees? Those weird acid-spitting dinos? Lets make them appear randomly early on to spawn kill the player 7 times in a row til they rage quit.

Bruh' if you don't already own this game and you call yourself a gamer then you got a problem.

I spent literally the entire day taming a few dinosaurs, trying to build a house, not being able to find stone inside giant boulders, and then having a dinosaur that was marked as "level 1" appear from nowhere and kill me and all of my pets in 1 hit

there's a "tech tree" where you level up and spend points to unlock the ability to build a square full of dirt but all you can do with that square of dirt is spend multiple days growing berries that you can just grab from literally any bush or fern in the game

everything in the game requires absurd amounts of resources you can't really get without the style of grinding you would find in a game where you could pay real money for resources

I unlocked the ability to smelt metal only to not be able to do it for two hours because I couldn't find dinosaurs to farm the 65 hides required to build a stone furnace that wouldn't kill me in one hit

and at the end of the day, all you can really do is build a house and then replace it with a better house. if that's what you're into, you'll have much more fun with a dinosaur themed mod for The Sims

Purchased on EGS before learning that Studio Wildcard specifically went out of their way to gimp that version of the game to disallow the use of mods. You can download mods. You can put them in the folder. You can configure everything to work. And then the game is still hard coded to not allow them.

They said a long time ago that mod support will come to EGS but they haven't done it, not even going so far as to remove the deliberate artificial block.

Now it's available for 'free' but I still can't play half the game because I refuse to pay $40 for access to DLCs I already have.

Just can't condone this kind of developer attitude. Purchased the game on EGS specifically to support the devs more and that's their attitude on it all. Fun game (in a small community setting with 'solo' server settings as "normal "settings are beyond laughable and just into the realm of bleak and depressing) but screw the devs.

I both absolutely love and hate this buggy, optimized mess of a game. Beware that the size of the game is very large, it will take up a lot of space. I love the gameplay aspects of taming, riding, and fighting dinos; and hate falling through the map at random points, frame drops due to terrible spawn management in certain areas of some maps, and generally trying to manage the bugs that come with each major update. Aside from the issues, Ark is addicting and the grind feels rewarding until near endgame, there is tons to explore and mods make it even better. Recommend picking this up when it is on sale, its not worth paying full price.

I know this game is played by more people than there are people who live in some smaller countries, so this negative review will probably amount to naught. But maybe the devs will see it, maybe I just want to vent because I'm really annoyed.

I've tried so hard to enjoy this game but I must be missing something fundamental because the incredible aggro and damage of these dinosaurs in "starting easy areas" are nuts. I started the game in single player and made it easier by changing some settings like how much damage I deal and how much damage monsters deal. I chose the easy starting beach on the basic map and quickly got murdered in the forest so I thought, "got it, forest dangerous, stay on the beach for now." So I stayed, created armor, weapons, made a beach camp, and even tamed a mount to ride. I then thought, "alright, I have defenses and weapons and a chunky dino, let's explore just a bit. So I walk about 100ft down the shoreline and a pack of 3 level 35 raptors tear me to shreds in about 6 seconds. I was still only around level 18 in the starting area. The raptors then proceeded to never leave my dead body so I couldn't get my stuff back.

Okay, slight set back. So I make new armor and weapons and shields. Less than one in game day later a deinonychus decides he's fond of my camp so he decides to literally just stand around my base while I cower inside and he stays hovering around my base for TWO in game days. Never straying more than 50 ft away. I finally try peaking out to just run away, he sees me, kills me, then destroys my camp.

I absolutely rage quit for a day. I then google some tips like a noob. Most say you should get an army of dinos to protect you. Okay, I can get on board with that, let's try again. I rejoin the game, find a new private beach and slowly start building up again. I get 3 dodos tamed and 3 dilophosaurus. I finally get the nerve up to try leaving the 100ft radius around my house and within about 5 minutes of carefully exploring another deinonychus spots me, sprints through my dinos WHO ARE ALL ATTACKING HIM, comes right to me, breaks my shield in 3 hits, then kills me in 2 more. So, I'm done. I'm glad so many of you found enjoyment in this game but I'll be damned if I understand how I'm supposed to stand a chance against high level monsters that just patrol the starting area and pretty much insta kill you.

After doing some building, the game gets very boring. You're either taming dinos or unlocking recipes. Also multiplayer is very glitchy making it hard to play with others, and it's less fun by yourself

Ark is one of my favorite games of all time. I also like to call it my therapy game. I went though a tough divorce about 5 years ago and this game kept me sane. It was my form of escapism. You feel immersed into another world that you get to explore! I have mostly done PVE and a little PVP. I started off playing vanilla on The Island years ago and I've played through most of the maps modded.  
As much as I love the game, it's fragile in the technical way. I've had a lot of technical things go wrong like servers not loading in right, audio cutting out, having to uninstall and reinstall the game several times... but the game has worked out for the better and they have made improvements throughout the years. 
So, overall I recommend Ark: Survival Evolved! Have some patience and you'll be rewarded with an awesome experience.

When it was first released it was horrible. But i t got better to a level of "meh, kinda cool". Its still so big that the basegame and 1 dlc take up around 100 GB of storage, but the game itself is quite enjoyable. That is if you play offline. otherwise you may loose almost all of your progress after 10 hours total cause the server got reset or you got raided and you cant even savescum out of it. Otherwise its a very beautyfull game with an abundance of stuff to discover, a variety of available playstyles and the constant feeling of having achieved something eventhough there is still so much mre to discover. It can become kind of grindy at times when playing with default settings so dont be afraid of setting gathering multipliers up a notch or two. And reload if you lost all your stuff insead of trying to get it back by running naked into a horde of predators.

So i played this game yesterday and today, and i just installed the game yesterday, so during my time playing it i experienced alot of lag, and every now and again it comes and goes, and eventually it stays away, however i'd like to nail dark firstly is that, please for goodness sake compress the games files, it took a huuuuge shitload of disk space which bugged me alot, lastly try to rework around the main menu of the game, add a tutorial or whatever for beginners! cause i had a hellish time trying to figure out stuff, whats worst is that i struggled to position buildings in a way i'm happy with, but most ended up going terribly wrong, or won't clip into the building, the first case is the wood platforms for when i wanted to add a bed in the interior made, and didnt wanna add on the platform in the interior but rather outside of the interior directly under the platform.

Next i'd like to mention, is where to find things, like i searched things up and nothing were really helpful, the map on Lost Island where i started off first came off different looking compared to the maps i looked up, i was hunting for obsidian but couldnt find it, whats worst is everything around you attacks you when your trying to get your barings or move around, which is good and all but the problem is the lag, last i checked my internet isnt the problem but rather the game itself, which lags at the worst possible moment when you wanna defend yourself, or run away, and you end up killed either way which i'd like to note is infuriating.

And my last complaint is that when you want to host your own server, the game doesnt seem to wanna host it, and i ended up remaining on my own in my own server patiently waiting for whoever to join, whats more of a bigger issue, you have like zero clue how to make it host or ping, which i'd recommend probably try working on a easier way on that than rather hard as hell for big brainers to easily solve, where i am however a dummy :) so i can't quite figure that out plus that i'm a noob who was looking for fellow players to learn with or teach me how to play games, so note the reason why i wanted to host my own server, cause i kept running into other players who spoke in other kinds of language and i couldnt understand them and they can't with me, which is another problem.

So i'd like to add to perhaps add like... language servers where people can pick their own prefered seperate servers based on their language and play their game from there, and people can pick the english, japanese, or whatever other languages, and make their own servers in those languages which focuses on people who speaks mainly of those languages and make things easier for players, instead of just like awkwardly struggling to find a place for themselves and whats not, i been joining random servers trying to find myself a spot but always ended up with people speaking entirely in other kinds of language, and otherwise making things srsly awkward.

As for character customization, i liked the idea to how your char's hair grows in game as soon you get started, but what bugged me the most was that there was a lack of customization to how you wish to design your char's face, like example getting rid of the rinklish bits around the lips section, and the lack of more hair colors, (I hadnt played too far in the game but people can correct me at the hair color bit if they wants), but otherwise the game is really good, and i was laughing my butt off at the case at how you can design some kind of mistake of an abomination human in a weird way possible, but otherwise, my main problem is pretty much the insane lag that strikes at worst possible moments, aand when ever your char die you lose all your junk in process, and you have to run back and forth to get your stuff back, only to die again and again and again, till your safe with your junk in hands.

But otherwise for my last complaint, as i mentioned above about hosting the game, the last straw to why i uninstalled the game, is due to attempting around hosting the map i made my char and his progress in, ended up crashing and giving me an black error screen of sorts, not too mention the game as a whole flatout crashed on me and shut down my steam in the process, soo do please make hosting servers more easier and fix the game propperly as people been complaining, reviews such as this is meant to help improve the game, and based what i've seen quite a huge number of people has gone ignored it seems, but i get some is okay to ignore and just progress with unique and interesting creativity, but those with the huge amount of disk space and other problematic issues, i'd request in their behalf to please kindly fix your game in order for many good souls to enjoy. Thank you. :)

Okay, let me save you some time. If you're from the Americas, this games population seems to be pretty dead. There's plenty of EU servers, but I only see one Americas PvP server that's got any decent population. Granted it's like 7:30 am, but if the games population was doing well it's really not all that early.

Secondly, when you install the game, you'll notice it recommends a whopping 120gb of free space, but only downloads 40gb. Well guess what, if you wanna play any of these DLC maps it's a whole ass other games worth of data and that's where the 120gb recommended is coming from. That said, between the time it'll take me to find a server to play on that doesn't have garbage ping and the time to download a map the size of a damn game, I could've already found and been playing on a Rust server.

Since the update, the game has been held hostage at 100% download with literally nothing left to download for couple days now since i started it. Since i first got the game, it's been a serious pain with minor and major bugs and glitches that varied from clipping through terrain, seeing through the entire world because "fake visual-only terrain" loaded, real terrain is loaded on top of things that were built like the entire floor of a home, the small, medium and large plots being underground because of it too rendering them impossible to use and forever gone (unless you quit and reload several times). The dinos get clipped into objects like giant boulders or trees, if friendly and following you, you need to break it yourself or you won't see them again. if looking to play with a friend, you better pay extra for your own 3rd party server because the official servers are not friendly at all (the concept of the servers specifically, not the people) and local hosting for it is just plagued with so many inconveniences and issues that trying to play as the host or with someone else that is hosting will cause inconvenience to both of you at the same time. Mods for the game are limited to what they do. some interestingly good ones and some quality of life ones exist but of all the mods that exists, they are either abandoned, have 50 or so copies of it that are abandoned or are popular enough and still function but just feel like you are playing an alpha version of the game for how poor the game handles the mods (mods function great, it's the system of how the game handles the mods that becomes an issue running mods)
if you want the free map dlcs, you best be ready to download the game. and then, download the game. after that, download the game. basically, everytime you add a dlc, you have to download the entire game. of course, you can stop the download and then grab the other dlcs and only actually bother downloading after you added them all but, you have to do that multiple times and naturally someone who doesn't really think of that, would just be stuck downloading the ENTIRE game just because they grabbed a map DLC and have to download the entire game everytime the get 1 map dlc.
nice that the game is free. hard to complain about it being free. but, I paid for the game when it was on sale sometime ago and honestly with how the game performs and the lack of care i've seen just from the gameplay i've experienced personally, the announcement of ARK 2 makes me think this game was abandoned in a state similar to what 7 days to die "looked like" 2 years ago. honestly, looking at the games now, 7 days to die looks near the same state as this game now except all the systems in 7 days to die tend to function better for what currently exists than this game. I mean, 7 days to die shows a mountain that can be physically walked on. Ark sadly has mountain terrain that doesn't exist and you will fall through the map and die.
I'm sure I can uninstall and reinstall the game to fix the current issue I've been having with the stick at 100% download for several days bug I'm dealing with but tbh, think the best answer to this bug specifically is to just uninstall and move on.
In fairness, my biggest gripe is the frozen download problem but everything else mentioned is just something that piled on to make this bug a nail in the coffin for my tolerance.

On fjordur release on all pc official servers people just tamed desmos and griefing people on the beach as soon as they spawn or not long after they make a thatch or wooden hut, i have not seen one stone base besides my own and the global chat across all four oc servers was filled with people complaining about not even being able to run after spawn due to a tribe with multiple people just spamming echo location with the desmo.


Either remove echo location or remove ark from the steam store because its falsely advertised as a sandbox survival game when the reality is you cannot play how you want at all you are most definitely forced to play a specific way even on pve servers & unofficial.

Which leaves solo or your own server.

Wanna run your own server from your pc your playing on? Well you have a cap of 10 people that can join and they all need to be within 300 of the host or you get teleported back to the hosts location.

Wanna host a dedi?
You will need to pay 3rd party to host a server for you ($80ish dollars per year) 

Or build a pc good enough to host the map and amount of players you want (upwards of $1000) and then ongoing upgrades to keep it running after each graphical update and tlc patch.


This leaves you forced to play solo or seeking hardware or services from a 3rd party, which means wildcard does not provide the necessary infrastructure to run their own software and services, which literally means its illegal to distribute ark survival evolved within Australia as it does not meet the minimum requirements for a digital product or service.

Furthermore upon request of refund, steam attempted to only refund me 33.41 for ark and all addons, i paid 74.53 all up and even cross referenced this with my purchase history in steam which confirmed they tried to refund me nearly half what i actually paid.


Valve corp, you will be receiving an email from either me or fair trading  Australia or both, i’m surprised you’s didn’t learn from the first fine issued.

نشط: يدخل Jax في Evasion ، وهو موقف دفاعي ، لمدة ثانيتين ، مما يتسبب في تفادي جميع الهجمات الأساسية غير البرجية ضده طوال المدة. يحصل Jax أيضًا على تقليل الضرر بنسبة 25٪ ، مما يقلل الضرر من جميع قدرات منطقة التأثير التي يتم الحصول عليها من أبطال البطل. يمكن إعادة صياغة Counter Strike بعد ثانية واحدة ، ويتم ذلك تلقائيًا بعد انتهاء المدة.

RECAST: يلحق Jax ضررًا جسديًا لجميع الأعداء القريبين ، ويزيد بنسبة 20٪ لكل هجوم يتم تفاديه ، وزيادة تصل إلى 100٪ ، ويصعقهم الصاعقة لمدة ثانية واحدة.

This game is a parasitic leech on your free time that feeds off negative emotions. It's great!
In all seriousness it is a decent game, but there came a turning point where I realized I wasn't having fun anymore. I was simply logging on to feed my creatures so they didn't die. It became a chore I had to do before I could do other things with my free time. After I realized that, I quit. It is worth to mention that its a very unforgiving game, and will expect you to just tough it out. At times it is extremely unfair, as it will spawn you nearby predators even in areas designated as "easy" zones. Additionally. the online community is absolute trash. Perhaps the worst most toxic community I've been part of. Not nessecarily in the sense of people who will call you racial slurs in chat, but those who gatekeep, demean, and ride their high horse so often it has been fused with their ass. While I have no personal experience with the PVP side of the game, it appears to be a hellish experience. Constant wipings on bases for no reason, contributing to a problem where if you are not in a "mega tribe" or an "alpha tribe" (the biggest tribe on the server) you are basically screwed. Mega tribes are generally cross server tribes (groups of players, similar to guilds in mmos) who may contain several hundred members across various game servers. They are often invasive, and will simply invade and claim entire servers for themselves, due to the fact that the outside man power will always beat single server tribes, unless they are also facing similar "mega tribes". From my understanding, the mega tribes generally ruin the pvp experience due to their position of power over other tribes, with the ability to effectively stop them from playing the game if they choose to. If you are not in either a local seat of power in the form of an alpha tribe or have the support of other servers in mega tribes, you will be met with a horrible experience of constantly having your progress reset for no reason. Even if you pose no threat, nor are encroaching on any other players territories, you may be squished simply under the assumption that you may be a starting point for a mega tribe to gain acess to the server. Moving on to PVE servers, the official servers are ok at best, but have many problems. A large one is pillarring, a process by which a player or tribe constructs hundreds or thousands of cheap pillars to place around the map in places they aren't nessecarily claiming. This disables building of other tribes and players in the areas, and due to the PVE nature of these servers, it is impossible to remove without decay or claim timers on the server. The only way I, and a lot of people. find enjoyment in multiplayer ARK is through unnoficial servers. However, due to these being run by players, they may simply shut down and loose all progress within them. The main way I would reccomend playing ARK is through single player, however many core aspects of the game are designed around multiplayer play, and many would argue that single player takes away from key points of the experience. However, disregarding the multiplayer component and the capacity in which you play the game, the game is simply buggy. It has a reputation for being on the the buggiest games that has a relatively large playerbase. Some range from minor visual glitches, up to gamebreaking ones.

Game is a grindfest, if you want to get anywhere, you better make this game your job (make sure you quit your job and/or school beforehand). It is realistically impossible to reach endgame content alone granted you play with base settings even on singleplayer. To get anywhere, you have to tweak every single settings because I sure ain't breaking 50k iron ore nodes alone to get myself an industrial forge and I'm not waiting 7 fucking real life days ingame for an egg to hatch. I only have 80 hours on pc but have about 600 hours on console and let me tell you this, unless you mod the living shit out of the game and look up how to tweak the settings for a balanced experience you're not going anywhere. (trust me, me and my friends tried out thousands of different settings back when the game just came out just for the game to be playable) Not to mention you can't even play with your friends on an actual private server without having to pay for the server monthly. Private games are pure cancer given the fact that everyone is limited whithin a tether distance that is based on the location of the host (it's 250 meters iirc). At some point, they added an option to change the tether distance in the settings but they promptly removed it because then people don't pay for servers so less cash coming in. The whole idea behind this game is making profit, there are bugs that were present on launch that still exist to this day but they are never going to fix them.

Overall Opinion: Grindy, in-depth, a bit buggy, and jam packed with fun unique survivor content. Especially fun with a group of friends, but PVE or local servers play so much better than PVP.

Pros:
- Gratifying progression system
- beautiful landscapes and creatures
- lots of unique creatures with unique abilities
- decent structure building allowing for creativity

Cons:
- PVP is too grindy and time consuming to want to get into
- various bugs mostly with the game engine
- Too much tech was added in, so later stages of the game lose the unique charm of being a pre-historic survival sim

Ugh... didn't know it was so bad until I got it for free... if you don't get grieved by players, an oversized pelican or a baryonix will do you on your spawn point until you scrape the keyboard with your fingers, and if you random respawn to avoid such camping, you will be tossed in a spider nest if you are lucky and you manage to escape with your skivvies intact before getting yourself yeeted down a cliff by a diplodocus that was passing through. After being camped 50 times by angry fauna every damn time we respawned and saw people saying that the game improves if you turn off all wild fauna, they gave up. My 9 hours is a testament that I tried at least. A pteranodon ignored my freshly caught salmon to then being yanked away by that damned baryonix that ate me first and then the salmon. Curse you, Why the pteranodon ignores fish in front of itself for 10 minutes but a baryonix and that friggin pelican leap towards it from miles away? it beats me, I even tried to put narcotic on the flesh but in-game instructions were not clear about that and I ended eating all in frustration. Made me want to commit seppuku at the jaws of a nearby megalodon because I was fed up of trying to retrieve my equipment where the baryonix was camping and of trying to follow a tip from a random player saying "tame a pteranodon and ask it to kill the pelicans!" hooray for the tip!
2 days was enough. At least I got a single achievement for my trouble. If the sequel still has this crummy player experience, wait for it to become free so that you don't pay for an anxiety simulator unless that kind of thing is up your alley.
tl;dr
UGH...

As a survival game, ARK is lacklustre and most other games in the genre do it's mechanics better. The game is also poorly optimised, the base building mechanics are awful, official servers face unacceptable rubberbanding and lag issues and there are a number of technical glitches that cause connection issues and CTDs. 

The graphics are pretty good (aside from the UI, which is easily the ugliest I have ever seen in a fully released title), and riding big dinos around with some friends can be fun, but otherwise the game is a huge disappointment and I can't possibly fathom why it is so well-regarded. 

I probably say "I hate this game" at least 5 times every time I sit down to play, but that's not entirely fair. I do not hate this game. It's fine. I just can't recommend it unless it's heavily discounted (or free like it is at time of writing).

This game is has so many emotions and feelings bottled up inside of one package, and it's truly hard to explain. Some days you can be on top of the world (and your dinosaur babes) while ruling your ARK with an iron fist and an iron hut. Other days, you're getting gobsmacked by angry pint-sized birds and getting your hut evicted permanently from your cozy little cliff. You can go at this painful and jolly experience alone or with a few coherent friends that can be used as bait later on. With the amount of replayability and freedom you are given, this game is definitely worth spending some time in. Have fun, roleplay as Bill Cosby with homemade narcotics, build a cult, or just not die. I can wholeheartedly recommend this game to people who enjoy teamwork, going solo, exploring, building, farming, surviving, fighting, and experiencing breathtaking creatures.

A really fun grindy game. It's especially fun with your friends whether you play on official or on your own private server. There is basically no end to what you can do in this game. There is a plethora of mods to use and there is just so many maps to have fun with as well. Highly recommend

1. I wake up, unknowing of my surroundings. I scratch my wrist, noticing an interesting gem planted into my veins.
2. I look around, to see I am on a beach. I lick my dry lips, and I hear a... Russian man?
3. I see a man on a giganotasaurus and a screaming Russian man riding on top of it, fully clad in metal armor, wielding a pike.
4. I get torn, limb from limb.
5. I respawn
6. I run around, gathering materials for a good few hours, progressing from a fists to primal gear consisting of clothen armor and a stone hatchet and pickaxe.
7. I settle down on a cliff overlooking a pond, building a thatch base, and night falls.
8. I decide to tame a dodo in the morning, my first companion!
9. I hop off for the night
10. I get on next morning, a beautiful Sunday morning
11. I was killed by [EZ] 游戏大师
12. Repeat
