(I just wanna say I have around 500 with steam epic games and ps4 combined) okay with that out of the way I just want to say this is the best game I have ever played and I'm still not bored of it after 500 hours. It's crazy how much content there is in this game all the free maps, mods and different ways to do stuff. There might be a few bugs here and there but that doesn't matter the game is just too good for it to matter. The only bad thing about this game is: it takes like 200gb or something like that and that it's kind of laggy for medium computers otherwise it's amazing and atm it's free.

Started playin this game on Xbox release . I was captivated in 10 minutes, yet ready to quit in 30 as there was no tutorial on what to do, how to craft, make tools or harvest. You just spawned in scratched your arm and found out. Over the course of the years I moved on from legacy servers to official's, purchased the game for PC and PlayStation. I ended my tour of Ark before Crystal Isle release. It was a love hate relationship to say the least. Ark is a magnificent game, both in crafting, building, surviving, and living on the edge. You can do it solo or with others, however word of advice, I hope you trust the others as it is very , very easy to get insided and robbed in this game, made easier by the cry pods. So adjust your clan settings and hope for the best lol. However amazing this game is, is foreshadowed by the fact that the developers are not really keen on fixing issues in a timely manner, nor do they come off as efficient as many servers lag bad and rubberband alot (example ragnorok map). Which causes you to die in all manners or loose tames at times if not extra careful. The fact that this game is so amazing that the players put up with the devs and lack of fixes speaks to the game itself and the content, which you will not find lacking between bosses and mini bosses, cave runs, temple runs, loot drop harvesting for Blueprints or maybe you wanna craft your own special blueprint (60 berries, 20x3 of any type makes a great drink), (50 raw meat makes a great food source once crafted into a bp and it bypasses the cooking stage and no ill effects) and as you learn the game you can make even better stronger personal recipe's. Back in the start element was a pain in butt to get and utilize as you cant transfer it, however they have made that quite easier to obtain and even transfer now which makes the game overall easier and fun, Putting teleporters in strategy spots for easier harvesting and returns to base to organize, into tek storage boxes that show the item inside and number so you dont have to access it all the time. Cryo pods changed the game as back in day we had to hand feed a baby until it was able to get on the trough and then had to make sure that stayed full, it was a pain coordinating all that between a 9-5 job. Now you can Cryo your pet and when you have time to work on the tame throw it on the ground and hatch it from the cryo pod and continue where you left off. It also makes storing these animals so much easier as now you dont have 300 plus dinos out getting hungry every other day and at risk to griefing or natural eggro of wild animals attacking. (NOTE: if ever find a base with timers decayed and there is a crypod full of pod and the pods claim they have dinos inside but pods are dead and dinos say dead, destroy the floor it sits on and collect all the pods and place them into a working pod and once they are charged the dinos should say alive and no loss will occur, unless they fix this or haven't already lol) So in short this game is amazing and if your ready to combat the game and also the dev environments inside the game aka lag and rubberbanding, then you will have a blast. Mods make this game easier and even better to play. I prefer official myself. My review would be in end that the game is a 4 star game all day however because of the devs inattentiveness and lack of fixes at times or inability to resolve issues i would knock the overall rating to a 3, a low 3 almost 2. Hopefully Ark 2 is better, however i dont hold out much hope as i've been around long enough to see how the treated Ark evolved. I figure launch day is going to be a catastrophe at best

Playing this game solo vs with friends is like a whole different experience. especially if you and your friends are alright with a little competitiveness and fooling around. this game when played solo feels like an actual survival game with properly terrifying moments that will get your heart pumping and maybe sometimes frustrate you... okay may be frustrate you a lot and if played with friends its an amazing experience that you and your friends wont forget

The game looks much prettier than it does ingame, ingame it would look good in say 2013. While not being a total clusterfuck, the UI is bad. In the menu which shows map, inventory, group etc, there is no icon for Crafting, so you have to check keybinds to find crafting(!).

Also i turned down damage of dinosaurs to give me a chance to, you know, survive during the test, but suddenly i ran into a raptor and it killed me in a few hits. Great. Trying the opposite, i attacked a turtle and it took like a minute to kill - or rather stun. To kill it i needed to hit it a few more times.

Oddest thing is that you get XP for just existing - XP is literally ticking up as you stand still, and gives you points to spend on skills, you don't have to do anything - just alt+tab and watch some youtube videos while your character is leveling up.

My verdict is: No, just no - There are better games today like Valheim and other survival games that offer more with better graphics and more well thought out UI and game mechanics. I got this for free as a giveaway, but at the moment don't feel like playing more.

I remember getting Ark when it first dropped in Early Access. Looking back, the experience is very very much the same. They reached a point where what they had would "work", just not that great. Rather swing back around to tighten everything up and polish gameplay, they just left it and started focusing on expansions. It was insane to see an early access game actually offer paid expansions and the negative affect it had on gaming is one part of the entire rise in exploitative practices in the industry that's an issue now.

At the time, it was a notable entry into a relatively niche genre of open world survival games. Now, it feels like an outdated experience that the devs knew functioned sub-par, but opted to pump out easy content they could earn a profit from. Instead of reworking things, they directed their attention to getting the broken game onto consoles. No matter how many expansions they've released, they've never gone back to revamp movement, combat, dino interacting or any of the key KEY aspect of just the gameplay itself. Yes, dinosaurs cool, build house cool, but it feels like ass. And the dinosaurs lumber around, completely unaware of their surroundings, getting stuck on/in structures, nonsensical movement patterns, random dismounting...the list of things wrong with just basic function is insane.

If you can swoop it up for free or via Game Pass, have at it. PvP servers, you'll be raided at night, usually by cheaters. PvE servers and you still have to deal with nearly every aspect of gameplay feeling 60% complete.

less than 8 hours into the new map, chinese cheaters duped a bunch of stuff, and started the boss fight every 5 minutes for over an hour.  What a crock of shit this game is to allow this cheating to continue to happen year after year.  I know people that didnt cheat that got banned because of corrupted files on their computer, but these guys aimbot all day long and Wildcard sits on their hands.  Shame.  Could be so much more of a game.

I am a 51 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 13. My son recently downloaded ARK and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

You will hate this game. Bugs galore and unfair PvP (if you want to play that mess) will make you question why it is you play this hunk of junk. BUT, there is nothing else quite like ARK. Once you tame each of your creatures for the first time and take down the bosses that appear seemingly impossible to defeat upon just starting out, that is when you will feel a sense of satisfaction that may justify the pain and suffering you have experienced. Now ARK is free or not majorly expensive (depending when anyone sees this review) there is no reason why you shouldn't try this game. There are objectives for everyone: Speedrunners can try and smoke the bosses ASAP and completionists can try to tame every creature and through trading and breeding develop all their creatures into the strongest around. ARK isnt flawless and it never has been but it has always retained a very healthy number of recurrent players and there is a reason for this, its not half bad.

This game is meant to be played multiplayer, for you and your tribe to help each other out, to join parties and chase dinosaurs together, to build bases together, to better mankind together. The PvE experience on a private server is pretty good in this regard, though it does require a dedicated server which isn't free (unless you have a spare computer with the right specs to allocate to the purpose, which isn't free either).

This game has notorious public PvP servers. Be forewarned, some personalities may find this fun, but you're going up against ultra-skilled "hackers" who know just how to glitch-vibrate their way into small, nearly impassible ratholes via parachute as a grappling hook to throw grenades in and wipe out your turrets, wreck your nearly impossible to find well hidden base, and take all the stuff you've spent hundreds of hours trying to acquire. Consider that on PvP, predation on other players is the most effective and efficient way to play quickly and fast, and that this is in fact how the game is played on PvP.

Don't let my playtime confuse you, I played thousands of hours on different names and platforms. As a whole, ARK is a top 3 gaming experience of my life. The grind, the worry of an offline raid, the progression, etc. It was spot on. What was NOT spot on was the expansions and the direction the game went. It went from caveman technology up to current technology with sentry guns and armor. Once they began getting oddly mythical it all went to sh*t. Metal Dino's with lasers, flying electric birds, glowing garbage, volcano fire monsters, you get the point. Went from bush survival to space fantasy over the course of a couple of DLC's and they could bring those animals into your server, destroy the server, and leave again. I hope, I PRAY, that ARK 2 doesn't do this. Bigger isn't always better.

Though this game is not suitable for those who expect a game to tell you what to do and where to go, the freedom it offers is good. It does get quite boring as there ends up not much to do besides breeding dinosaurs to eventually fight bosses. There is no NPC's or quests and the only way to get the story is through the notes you find in the world. I just feel bored and don't feel there is enough variety in what you can do in single player.

This game needs a good PC to be able to play, but even so it is poorly optimised and takes up a lot of space. I always make sure my drivers are up to date so wondered why I was all of a sudden getting a freeze with fatal error report. I verified files and it said 2 files were missing and they were being restored. I have no idea what would of caused that and after that the game is running fine again. This game is really annoying it occasionally has errors and ends up with missing files. You often have to spend time verifying files. And also have problem where the sound cuts out completely even though the sound still works when testing a you tube video and then have to verify files which then says 2 files are missing.
I found the problem was that my power supply was dying and finally carked it. 

So far since playing Ark I've had to buy a new SSD and power supply.

Since being poorly optimised it makes your PC work very hard, it may make your PC components die quicker. So play at your own risk.

On the surface, ARK seems like a fun game that you could play with your friends, it's fun to go around the map capturing or hunting any animal that comes your way and bringing them back to your (or your friend's) base to either tame them or make use of whatever resources they have.

However, when you begin to install the game, you suddenly notice that the game takes like 89 GB of storage space, which means that if you have a low-end PC, you'd have to uninstall everything just to install the game, and even if you don't have a drive as big enough to accommodate the game, you better save up on a bigger drive. Even if you have a better computer (as I do), you would often find yourself uninstalling the game several times to free up a boatload of much-needed space.

That is just the beginning though, as soon as you boot up the game, you start to realize how much of a buggy pile of shit this game is, for example the physics is absolute trash, if you end up in a bad spot and get stuck in it, good luck trying to get yourself unstuck, you'd either be relying on your friend to get you out or just wait until you die later on. Of course for a game that came out 5 years ago you'd at least expect most of these bugs to be fixed. But it's clear the developers don't give a rat's ass about this game, they care about churning out new content every 5 seconds to give the illusion that they give an absolute fuck about this game.

I would only recommend the game if you're confident your PC could run it, and if the developers could at least rectify most of the issues they should've done years back, even by then given that ARK 2 is coming out, I'm not too sure if they ever will. Just pray that someday, they'll fix it.

*EDIT*: The game on Linux takes up 89GB, while the one on Windows takes up 125GB, which is even worse.

My statement on this game can simply be put as,
"I don't like this game."

It is an opinion, so don't let it stop you from trying the game. This game is free now, and even then, it's not worth your time. I got this game long ago very near release day when it cost a small fortune. It was bad then, and it has only gotten worse.

Let me start with a short description.
This game's purpose is to waste your time. It goes out of its way to take away your hard work and effort.

All games exist to waste your time, but at least it's a measure of enjoyment. Ark does not do this. If you go into this game, go into it expecting to lose everything, multiple times over, just trying to survive, let alone even beat the game. Also expect to look up a guide if you don't want to explore every square inch of the same looking island.
Oh, the DLC maps? They're better by technicality, but they used to cost money too, almost as much as the game itself - Each.

Let me tell you a story. 
You spawn on a beach, start swinging on a tree or rock, and suddenly, the neutral entity turtle chunks you for half your health because it thought you were swinging at it.
So you run a good distance away. You manage to work on a base, tame a few dinos, spend hours levelling up. Then an Alpha Raptor spawns in the starting zone, who demands fully automatic weapons, armour, and some of the best tames in the game to even kill.
You lose everything but your exp. All your resources. All your tames. You have to start with banging rocks together again. No guns nor metal.

This will happen to you multiple times in the course of a playthrough - completely unprovoked, entirely against your control, will everything be taken from you.

Everything is a lot, too. This game is grindy - and I personally don't mind that. I play BDO, I love BDO. But when you die in BDO, you only lose 1% of your exp, not literally everything you worked for. And in BDO, when you die, it's because you went out to choose to fight something. 
Not with Ark.

I have similar complaints with its other mechanics like exploration, but more so, especially how to breed dinos to be strong enough for the end bosses, you need to dedicate time out of your life as if you actually live in Ark to grow them. 5 hours for a Tame to mature to a Juvenile, and during that time, if a baby isn't fed constant attention, it dies very easily. Then you have to wait an entire 24 hours before you're allowed to breed the same pair of dinos again.

Of course, these are default settings, and after quite a few updates, you can actually change this - unless you're playing on a server that isn't yours.

There are stories of people neglecting sleep, food, and hygiene to even compete with the PvP in this game, and even if it's a PvE server, good luck getting to the major resource nodes when everyone has taken everything.

There's a lot more I could say, but it's miserable to talk about. I'll happily complain about it in voice chat, though.

Will I still play it? With friends, yes. But anything is fun with friends.

Game was fun when initially released, but Studio Wildcard soon began pandering to the massive hacking player base from a certain country where the facts about the *1989 June 4th Tiananmen Square protests and massacre* are controversial and twisted. Refusing to ping/region lock, or even ban blatant cases of hacking in some instances, allowing entire clans of hackers to take over and ruin servers, thus making multiplayer virtually unplayable outside of private locked servers.
Soon after they started pumping out comically overpriced DLC in an attempt to claw back money they lost in a legal battle.
But hey, now the game's free! and I hear Vin Diesel is super into it, he's a cool guy, right?
But seriously, this isn't worth the massive download, at all. Don't waste your time, even if it's free.

Strictly PVE Experience: I only started playing a year ago but there is an abundance of content to explore. With the base game, DLCs, and mods, there is bound to be something you will enjoy with this game. Build a massive base with elaborate designs or keep it simple and focus on other aspects. Scour the maps for high level dinos to tame and make your life easier. Fine tuning of settings allows for even more customization of game play. There is no way, with my play style, that I will complete all the content before ARK 2 launches but I'm sure I will be playing this game for years to come.

I have played the game for more than 100 hours. I have played on official and unofficial servers. I think I am qualified to leave a decent review.

I highly recommend this game to everyone, it has a lot of features that will make you lose the perception of time. I mean you can tame dinos, raise them and fight with them by your side.

Plus, you can build things like houses, traps and any structure you want.

It has its drawbacks, yes. It's extremely difficult, it has a lot of bugs and you absolutely must play on unofficial servers.

Please just ignore the negative stuff and experience this wonderful game for yourself. It is unique and deserves to be experienced. I play it every day and simply accept the bad things. Every single game in the world has bad things but people keep playing them because they enjoy them.

Great game if you have the money for $1700+ laptops/desktops. Game size easily gets to 400+ GB. Graphics could be better, bugs aren't absolutely game-breaking but are very irritating sometimes alongside game crashes. Good variety of creatures, activities, decorations, and scenery. Not a whole lot of good mods to choose from. Not good for single-player starters, but you're guaranteed to get your wacky little naked self eaten by a level 150 Dilophosaurus on the beach the moment you start in an official server. If you're not eaten, you're constantly fearing other players and probably waiting for your inevitable doom(s). Even if you have a group of friends to play on a private server with, its still pretty frustrating, and taming can take several DAYS (real time) whereas breeding can take MONTHS for optimal results. Creative mode gets boring after you've done just about everything there is to do and seen everything there is to see, and Genesis forces you through nearly 100 missions per zone (there are 5 zones, so this comes to ~500 missions) to progress, and then you get to do it again in Genesis 2, although there's only one 'zone' with ~4 sections to it. Play at your own risk (or utter frustration). Although I will inevitably keep returning to this game every few months, I will still warn others of what they're getting into with this game.

ARK: Survival Evolved is a great survival game with fun yet challenging PvE and PvP gameplay, and can pretty accurately be described as "Rust with Dinosaurs". The problems arise only once you've sunk a decent number of hours into your singleplayer game. Along with bugs faced by many open world games (pits you can't escape from, flinging especially with high movement speed) ARK has it's own slew of problems you wouldn't expect a AAA game that's been out for this long to have. Half of the time, with or without mods, singleplayer and non-dedicated sessions will not start at all, leaving the game hanging and leaking memory. This happens to all my friends as well as me. Crashing while joining a server will leave you unable to ever connect to that server again (until the server restarts), and even though crashing while in-game rarely occurs, it happens frequently when loading. World saves corrupt weekly, losing you hours of progress. Want a friend to play with you on a non-dedicated session? Get ready for hours of debugging on both sides, only for the issue to fix itself a while later.

Community mods can make the game much more enjoyable, but good luck loading into ANY modded world if the game isn't located on a solid state drive.

But overall Ark is A fun game with friends definitely not for alone game it gives a great dino challenge

But all in all, the game is worth the massive time requirement to learn, and get good at it.

Despite being a very DLC based game (which already makes it difficult to obtain for the average gamer), it's actually quite an engaging piece. I purchased this game while it was on sale around December 2019, and it is something that I enjoyed for every minute of gameplay. 

Something that I do find frustrating though is that it is near impossible to host a private server for you and your friends, and to have one that won't be overrun and griefed by randoms costs a lot to host. As someone who wanted to play this casually with her friends, that was my only real deal breaker.

If you've got a pretty penny to spend on DLC and server hosting, it is something that I recommend. If not, prepare to either play this game solo, or have your base completely destroyed and taken over by strangers on all of the openly hosted servers for the public.

Ark is once again a game with amazing potential and unique concepts that is absolutely ruined by its meager excuses of  developer and moderator teams. An astounding presence of bugs, and known game issues that we're never resolved and continue to not be address. The develops pay no sentiment to the players or listen to any sort of grievances and develop a holier-than-thou attitude when approaching reports. Their servers server stability is laughable, to the point where some Gen2 servers even drop into the 70%s of actual uptime. Many of these crashes resulting in item or dino loss, to which wildcards response is they cannot replace any items, and dinos can only be replaced with lvl150, random stats, color, gender of the same dino, essentially the equivalent of Gamestop's policy of buying back your whole library of games for $5. It's laughable and down right disrespectful. The mods don't care, and while a decent amount of the PvE community is friendly and kind, its spoiled by the bad apples who ruin the game for other while the GMs watch and either do nothing, or punish the victims. I'm absolutely disgusted by the way Ark is managed, and I have no doubts Ark2 will be as much of a poor excuse, my sympathy is to those who will wish to continue playing Ark1 but Wildcard has made it clear they're going to just about abandon the game. It's a shame this game was developed by Wildcard, it sincerely could have been such a gem.

I have been playing Ark since it was in alpha. I have played on every platform and it remains to this day my all time favourite game. There is a big learning curve for a first time player but that's what i love about it. It truly is a survival game. You learn to recognise the dinosaurs based on their footsteps and their individual noises. It helps you be very self aware of your surroundings which is important if you are to survive. There is quite a few people that will talk bad about the game but they all fall into the category of I hate the game but i still play it on a daily basis. I always described ark as a drug. You always come back no matter how wrong it has done you because it's so addictive. You can always re-build a destroyed base. re-tame new dinos you may have lost and re-craft your lost items. There's always something for you to do. It's such a great, surreal experience and i would highly recommend anyone to give it a try.

If you like dinosaurs, and crafting, or maybe even just exploring youll love this game. Some parts may be a bit glitchy but hey, its open map so its to be expected. Be prepared for several hours just to disappear as you journey through the Ark.

Hours played: 315 hours. This is probably the most immersive survival game I have ever played. If you have friends ready to dedicate some time to a shared survival experience, then I would highly recommend you make a private server to explore ARK within. Playing on official servers make you run the risk of getting griefed, loosing weeks of work.
Opinions of cons: game is grindy (unless you tweak the settings), graphics are poorly optimized so you need strong computer, new expansions are repetitive to the original one.

I had a huge house on island 395. I built it for a very long time. I spent an incredible amount of time and effort on it. But on the territory of my house, newcomers began to appear, who had just arrived on my server where my house was located. And since the players appeared inside my house, they could not leave it and complained to the developers. The developers, instead of moving the spawn location to another location, simply destroyed my house. THEY HAVE IT DOWN. It's their fault that players show up on my territory, but they were too lazy. All my work is gone. And so it is with everything in this game. Gen 2 keeps dropping and you lose everything. And more and more. I do not recommend playing this game.

I have fun at this game but the game is poorly reacting to everything and it is filled with too many problem for me to recommand it to anybody even if I enjoy the game.

- crash // I sometime crash even if it is rare and I have a good pc but I noticed that often the game give a blue screen to many player AT THE SAME TIME, I had at least 5+ player crashing at the same time so I had to protect the body of my friend in the dungeon and learn that half the lobby got a blue screen.

- Really stupid loading zone // they place loading zone in hostile spawn still, in lost island by example there is a loading time underwater, that is super long for most people, 1 person out of 2 drown before finishing loading, and it is so long that the piranha you killed respawn on you and kill you during that load.

- Worst hit registration I have ever seen. if you shoot a dino he is gona have a hole in his face but 1/2 time (often more) you wont receive a hit marker so it wont count.

- pillar PVE// I am already established but some people will put pillar so it prevent people from building (you cant build near other player structures) so I can't see someone being able to start fresh in 90% of officials servers

Man, what can I even say about ARK. I've spent countless hours grinding away just to make enough arrows and gathering enough resources to tame a dino, then babysitting the unconscious dino only for it to be mauled to death in an instant the next day.  I've gotten into death loops, losing tame after tame as I try to get back to my corpse and retrieve my gear before deciding to cut my losses and start over. I've gotten wiped before I could finish my first thatch hut, and quickly realized that unofficial PVE is the way to go for a player like me. I've had my precious Carno fall through the map, never to be seen again. The game can be one big, frustrating slog!

But I've also flown all the way up to the skybox on a snow owl, pausing for a moment at the apex to take in the view before diving straight down at top speed, dancing around wyverns and snatching their eggs from under them. I have conquered my fears and plunged into the caves, taking down waves and waves of impossibly high leveled bugs with my bear and emerging battered and bloodied but victorious, with an inventory full of loot. I've met and allied with small groups of players, each of us lifting each other up and building not just villages, but communities. And I've discovered and installed  incredible mods made with care and talent that improve on every aspect of the game. 

This is one of those games that you just get sucked into, and when it's good, it's magic. There IS a lot of grinding though, and I recommend trying out unofficial or single player so that you can mod the experience to reduce this, or at the very least change the settings around. Also my tip: start on Ragnarok. No DLC purchase required, and you'll have a much better time there than on The Island. Or you could also try Fjordur for a similar experience, but you'd better make a fire fast if you go that route!

Anyone who likes rust or games that allow you to do pretty much whatever you want, will love this game.
This is probably one of the biggest games I have ever played and I have been playing this pretty much since it came out on console and am still finding things on even the first map that I didn't find before. Even after you complete the game, the amount of mods that people make for this game will make it so it never gets old.

My advice though, if you have never played this game, play it normally first, then with mods. That way you don't get overwhelmed and not know what the hell to do, because you will be plenty clueless just playing the normal game for the first time, don't need the crack known as mods to make you any more clueless. 

After you get over that though, and get past any cheaters, which most of the free roam survival games have, you will probably develop a crushing sense of impending doom every time you log onto this game, only to find that no, you weren't raided last night... Usually.

The pvp in this game is pretty much the same as rust, drain turrets, kill dinos, blow through compound. That sort of thing, but if you raid while they are online, it can be like avengers endgame levels of awesome, going to war with a clan. It's rare, but if you know what your doing you can have battles at that level.

My only real gripe about this game is how time consuming it can be, even with modified server settings. That's just par for the course with this game however. Be careful of some of the admins on the modified servers too because some of them are kinda Dicks and just go around destroying stuff.

The other thing is that some of the stuff in this game isn't fully optimized and can be pretty buggy. I have a stupidly beefy computer so, I don't get any lag even with max graphics and all the intensive settings turned on, but always install this game on an ssd, if you don't and you play with mods, you will be loading in for upwards of 40 minutes, even on single player. With the ssd, it takes like 5-10 depending on how many mods you install

While generally paleontologically inaccurate, occasionally glitchy, and hard, this game is the most fun thing I have ever played. Are you bored of the island ark map? maybe try a desert, radioactive cave system, or spaceship map instead. This game has it all—dragons, serpents, dinosaurs, extinct megafauna, kaijus, robots, and folklore creatures that are all tameable. Not only are all of these mechanics, maps, and creatures available, I can not exclude the outstanding graphics from this review. The water looks real, there is a wonderful day-night cycle, and weather conditions such as light and heavy rain, fog, blistering heatwaves, sandstorms, lightning storms, blizzards, meteor showers, and earthquakes are all rendered in beautiful, realistic, graphics. Whether you find yourself playing with your best friends, solo, or in a tribe, you have never met, this game provides an open freestyle way of playing with almost no guidelines allowing you to do almost anything. And if the game was missing something anyway, modding is your solution! This is my favorite game and I would recommend it to any action and adventure lovers!

Deep survival mechanics, wide range of creatures and environments - all top class.
Trying to play solo as a story is less satisfying - no pointers to often well concealed artifacts requires searching the entire map (including in the deep oceans). The Dossiers and Notes scattered around help to make it seem like there is some history, but the player never gets to actually participate, except when battling some of the 'end bosses'.
I have friends with 1,500+ hours invested, but they are mostly playing multiplayer on private servers. Many of the game mechanics seem geared toward a multi-player group (in-game advice regarding Engrams explicitly states that no one player can learn all of the Engrams).
I'll be playing for at least another few hundred hours!

Been playing the game since beta (took a long break from the game after my cpu broke) and have accrued almost 2,000 hours.

There's always something to do in ARK. Varying on the type of server you join and what settings/mods they have installed it only gets better over time. Although nothing will compare to your first days of playing and experiencing ARK. That being said, the game is also enjoyable in singleplayer mode with your own select rates and mods. However, the best experience i've found is to join with just a couple other friends or strangers that you meet in game and progress together.

I would not recommend joining official servers for those who are just casually looking for a good time to grind and build but not excessively. I would also recommend these players to avoid any type of pvp server as you will instantly lose all progress you've made in a single night by other tribes. Your best bet is to join a PVE server with decently high server rates but nothing ridiculous. To give a perspective 1x Harvest rate will yield one stone if you pick it up off the ground. 100x would mean you pick up 100 stones from a single pebble and 100x that if you were to break a boulder. This becomes too easy and you progress the game too quickly to enjoy it thoroughly. I've personally found anything between 3-15 to be the best.

A side note to end: If you're just planning to get the base game, it's worth the full price. However, if you want to play the full game with all DLC content, i would high recommend waiting for a sale.

This game is great, it has so much content and it's constantly getting new updates and expansions which keep it fresh in an experience which is already packed with things to do. 

Even then, I think I should point out the elephant in the room. There's a LOT of bugs. A quarter off my experience playing Lost Island with friends has been struggling to join. Also in-game bugs can be frustrating. Sometimes when I need to go into creative to be able to fix things because of damage a bug caused for example: I was on a Phiomia and went in water the bug where whatever you're riding on water flies across the map happened. And I got flung to the snow area of the map to the Wyvern trench. Like come on, what am i even supposed to do in that situation. And I couldn't be teleported even when my friend went into creative. There just wasn't a fix. We had to spawn something to take it back and then kill what we spawned it was a whole situation that demotivated me to continue playing. A game shouldn't do that. 

The UI isn't bad, but sometimes it doesn't feel lively enough. I feel like it could use a rework. 

 
It makes me upset that the ARK 2 announcement made me happy but also stressed that I felt like ARK 1 has so many issues that making a new game my cause the developers to shift their focus to ARK 2 and ignore the bugs that haven't been fixed for years now. I'm even scared they might carry over. 

That aside this game is so UNIQUE. There's nothing like ARK I've seen out there. And even if there was I don't think they could make it as great as Wildcard did. I appreciate this game and I know it's nostalgic to lots of people and it's quickly become one of my all time favorite survival games. There's so many approaches you can take to ARK it's insane. Just playing it gives me so much dopamine. And THAT'S how a game should be. So regardless of the bugs, ARK is still played by many because it's that great of a game. And I'm glad Wildcard loves it as much as it's community to make more content. 

So would I recommend this game? As long as you're aware of the bugs, Yeah absolutely. And I can't wait for ARK 2

Similar to The Sims, I either forget this game exists or binge it non-stop for a period of around a month. Want to play a survival craft that has singleplayer and multiplayer capabilities? Want to grind out a lot of stuff to make other stuff, only to get incredibly frustrated when you die, losing that stuff? Want to spawn in to an "easy" area of the map, only to immediately be face-to-face to a raptor? Want to get emotionally attached to your first tame and be distraught when it also dies from raptors? This is the game for you! In a way, it is, as people say, "minecraft but with dinosaurs and better graphics". The end-goal is unclear beyond "survive" and "get really good at it" for a while.

What is different between this and Minecraft besides Dinosaurs and Better Graphics:
1. Clothing matters
2. Environmental conditions matter
3. Way more complexity in what you can explore, build, and do in vanilla version
4. Guns
5. The "official" fan-made maps are pretty amazing

This is a good game, lots of fun - and frustration. Ark is a prehistoric world with an anachronistic assortment of extinct creatures. Lot's of challenging combat. Valheim is similar to this game, I think they lifted a lot of concepts from Ark, definitely in the same genre. Valheim improved on some things and made much, much worse many others.

The graphics are pretty well done, very nice world construction. Combat is good, challenging for sure. There is a crafting/building element to the game which is also pretty good. There's resource gathering and a pretty rich variety of stuff to get and craft. 

There are some game play issues that bug me, but overall that's not bad. Things that bug me with the game play are like, I can't hold a torch and a sword at the same time, or any other weapon for that matter, so at night you can only fight in the dark unless you happen to be fighting next to a campfire. And even when you get advanced crafting stuff, it always seems like a huge let down. For example, since I was sick of fighting in the dark, when I finally got a flashlight attachment for my firearms I was hugely disappointed that it was so dim I might as well be fighting in the dark anyway... why did I bother using those valuable resources if it is a worthless item?

Some resources that are really needed to advance in the game  (I only play solo, so this might be different with a group) are extremely difficult to find and are also very limited in quantity.

So I have to compare this game with Valheim because there are so many things that are similar:

Graphics
Ark: very good, smooth graphics, colorful creatures and world
Valheim: not good, pixilated, often lagging, repetitive

Combat
Ark: very good
Valheim: good, but not as good

World
Ark: nicely detailed open world, get's extremely difficult when exploring beyond your home though (at least as a solo player)
Valheim: The nice thing about Valheim world construction is that it is always different and unique. Ark world is always the same. But, the Valheim world details are not very good, and poor graphics. But it is a HUGE open world and exploration is a really fun part of the game

Construction of structures
Ark: not bad, but very limited in what you can do with structures
Valheim: highly detailed and unique buildings can be constructed, probably the best part of the game in my opinion. You can build very detailed castles which some people have made into an art form.

Resources / crafting
Ark: fairly rich assortment and challenging part of the game
Valheim: rich assortment, but sometimes I just didn't get where the game designers were going with things

Pets
Ark: you can tame almost any creature in the game one way or another. Big or small, you can tame and use your pets in the game. A big part of the game is pet management and using them as utility animals or for defense.
Valheim: there are pets, they're not very useful though

Value for your money
Ark: more expensive, but also better graphics, smooth game play - worth the money
Valheim: not expensive, in many ways not as good as Ark, but dollar for dollar worth the money (I played for about 1000 hours for a $20 investment)

Overall I would give Ark a game grade of B+ - definitely worth the money

Ever wondered what would happen if dinosaurs came back? Or how will we live with them? Will it even be possible for them to come back? That's the case in this game called ARK: Survival Evolved. The game is about how dinosaurs came to life and how the player will be able to survive among them. This game is available on all platforms: PC, Playstation, Xbox, and on Mobile. On pc you can get it from Steam. On Xbox, and PS you can get it from their own store.
ARK is one of a few games that have a lore that the game is based on. Ark was made as an experiment or a simulation to see how humans would live if dinosaurs came back to life, so they made a simulation of an island full of dinosaurs, then they put the player on the island. The player would then wake up for the first time on the beach, not knowing where he was. He would go on to wonder and see his surroundings. The player would have to advance his technology to be able to deal with dinosaurs. Then he would find a way to tame the dinosaurs and make them help him. You can play ARK with friends online, offline, or even by yourself. I like this game because every time you play is a different experience and a different challenge. It has a variety of maps that you can choose from for a different experience every time you play. For example, every time you spawn on a different map, you would find yourself in a different terrain every time with varias new species of dinosaurs. This is a superb game that I liked, because of the experience and that it's one of a handful of games that have dinosaurs.
Overall, I would rate this game a 9/10. It's superb and it has great graphics. Pretty much anyone can play this game, but I would recommend it to teens aged 10 and older. But mostly to gamers who like playing survival or adventure games. All you need is a decent computer and the game. Then, you should be set to go on your adventure with the dinosaurs.
It's a thrill seeking game, when your taming Dino's. I enjoy every thing about the game, as well being able to play multiplayer. I would recommend this to my friends.

So, this game is really great. The only thing it lacks is some sort of goal system, be it quest/reward, or a story. If they could somehow figure out how to include that, I think it would be more appealing to a wider audience base. It would also be nice to have more challenges to overcome. Like dino invasions/attacks of some sort, or extreme weather that you have to survive in. I know some of the later maps have this sort of stuff, but some of the older maps feel very boring because of it's lack at times. The AI on dino's definitely needs to be improved sometimes, and there's other things like tail collision that really annoys me. It's not any reason not to play it, I'm just saying it would be a more well rounded game with these things fixed/added. 

The biggest reason NOT to play it is that it is incredibly graphics intensive. It was never optimized well and many computers have issues with it. Just make sure you're using something capable. Most newer cards shouldn't have too much issue with it at 1080p but if you're playing at 1440p or 4k, you need a beefy computer. 

However, the rest of the game is pretty good. It's fun, it's exciting, It keeps me busy for hours. I love building bases, I love the extravagant mod selection it has. I love the dino collection you get access too, I love that you can mod in more. I love that this game has events surrounding holidays, and coloured dino's and unique loot. I love the chibi dino's that you can have, the feeling of riding around on a T-rex making everything your bitch. I love collecting dinosaurs, breeding them for better stats(though it could be slightly better implemented). I love the biomes, and the caves. A lot of the bosses are fun, and you can go at them in many different ways. I took an army of about 200 raptors into one, all max leveled, bred for health/damage. The variety of maps that you can play is nice too. 

I do suggest this game, but be warned. It's not for everyone. It's essentially a sandbox, you make of it what you will. There are caves/dungeons to do, and bosses so there is some direction to the game, but many people never get to that point simply because they don't know what to do. The game has a lot of depth/complexity to it, and that can be an issue for some. Give it a try at least. I mean.. who didn't want a game like this when they were a kid, right?

Wish they offered a meh button to choose instead of just a yes or no but I will say this, the game despite being horribly buggy and glitchy at times is a fairly good game. You can have almost any Dino/creature on the Ark that you are capable of taming (if obtainable) and build impressive fortresses of solitude or crack shacks with friends. Although I do wish this game would be optimized more and the devs showing more interest on what the community wishes to see being fixed I do have to admit this game can be fun. Most times you will get your normal toxic player/tribe come rolling through and it'll take everything in your power to not rage quit the game when you are starting out and a high lvl player comes along on a overly powerful creature you have no hopes of ever stopping and steam rolls your entire building and gaming experience but every game you go to out there will have someone like this (chuck it up to kids being kids cuz honestly, only immature people will go out of their way to destroy something that really has no value to them whatsoever). I cant count how many times my friends and I would build a nice looking base to try and have some fun while off of work and a "alpha" or "beta" tribe came along and decided that our little thatch shack could possibly have anything of value in it should be destroyed.

ARK: Survival Evolved is an immersive futuristic 1st/3rd person Action-adventure/base building and survival game, incorporating a combination of prehistoric and post humanoid worlds that players can explore and conquer. As you dive into each ARK dazed and confused about your origins and the origins of the ARK's, you learn new skills to survive and master each creation in a bid to find out who or what brought you to this dystopian wonderland filled with friends and foes, humans and creatures. Each is unique in their role to assist you in bringing about an end to the beings who created the ARK... Whether by air, land or sea, survive on your own or with friends in this massively multiplayer title by Studio Wildcard powered by the Unreal 4 Engine.

Gameplay:

Focuses way too hard on "taming". If you like this kind of thing it is fun, but the actual "survival" aspect of the game is weak. It is easy to find food/water, but you'll randomly get killed by things much stronger than you, even in the starting area, often with no option to run away.

The challenge and fun that I get out of a survival game is staying alive. If it is easy to stay alive, and you randomly die to some unfair encounter, there is no survival aspect of the game.

You also level every 5 seconds, so what should feel like a milestone of progress turns into continuous tedium.

Combat feels bad. Most things do not seem to have damage animations at all. You just see a basic blood splatter and the game swaps textures for injuries.

Technical:

Lacks V-sync, which turns your graphics card into a flamethrower. Optimized poorly, so 2010 graphics somehow tax high end modern hardware. The game doesn't allow you to maintain multiple save files for an area, so forget about playing with your friends in one game and playing single player separately unless you manually manage save files. All kinds of synchronization problems even on pings under 10. (try driving a boat as the host with people on board.) And for a game of this age, it crashes a lot on up to date AMD drivers.

Verdict:

If you like mounts and breeding things, I guess this game is for you. It is a technical mess, easily as bad as many games in early access, and it is missing features that are baseline things you should have in 2022. The survival aspects of the game are poor and the balance of the world itself is also poor. I would not recommend this game, especially at it's $60 price tag for the "ultimate edition".

Get it cheap and keep expectations low.

Another negative take:

[TLDR] Ark / Wild Card has disappointed me over and over, with game and mod breaking updates. Even on private / solo servers, expect progress to be lost after some time. Either wait for the completed release, or just find another game (Rust). 

NOTE: I don't play on servers, only solo. Random servers too buggy, laggy or exploited and no friends play Ark for private servers. 

Don't be fooled by the 381 hours played - 1/3 or so alone is from AFK farming, or waiting for dinos to mature. 
Still, I gave Ark and Wild Card about 250 hours of chance, only to be disappointed time and time again. 

The vanilla (base) game got pretty boring rather quickly for me, so I went down the modded route, only to find that to be difficult to pursue. 

Every few weeks, sometimes a month or two if you are lucky, a new update would come out and break a number of mods or even the base game, making all previous progress null and void. Imagine 25, 50, or even 100 hours of effort down the drain because Wild Card can't release a complete game. 

This is a trend in many other games, and one which seems to only be growing in popularity, despite it being the prime reason for gray hairs in my twenties. 
Crashes are rather frequent, even with no apparent cause. (At least in games like 7DtD, you have an active console spewing tons of useful data to indicate what is wrong with the game)

As others have stated, even with decent hardware (above recommend specs), optimization is an issue, with graphical glitches a common place. Not the worst thing, but just an issue worthy of noting. 

All in all, its a graphically stunning game, with interesting mechanics and features but with poor optimization, frequent updates which annihilate hours of effort, and servers which will drive you to the end of your sanity and drop you off into the abyss of insanity.

I liked the dinosaurs and the survival elements.  I really like the raptors and the dilophosaurs.  I hope to have a raptor pack someday.  I didn't like it when I angered a brontosaurus and it killed my dinosaurs, but that was only in self defense for it, honestly.

Ark Survival Evolved is an immersive survival game situated in a mysterious, isolated realm with artifacts suggesting the presence of an advanced intelligence monitoring the player's progress as they learn of their environment, how to hunt and gather for self-sustainment, and how to tame the wide variety of animals and dinosaurs occupying their realm with you.  The game offers challenges to survival, such as keeping warm, or cool, as the weather changes, staying healthy and well fed, from foraging berries and butchering animal carcasses for their meat.  The technology tree offers phases of advancement from stone age through modern, and into science fiction.  As your character levels up with experience, you can customize your player character in many areas, such as weight carrying capacity, run speed, health capacity, Stamina, and even increasing the time to hold one's breath longer when swimming underwater.
Before acquiring Tek gear, I personally enjoy taming flying creatures that I can ride and scout my environment from a bird's eye view.  One goal I always strive for is to tame a T-Rex, the king of most predators found in the game.  One can also breed dinosaurs and raise the babies if you are interested in breeding for stronger characteristics.  ARK Survival Evolved has several free maps available to play on, and the game also supports player created mods to enrich the game.  I highly recommend the game to anyone interested in base-building/survival among the dinosaurs.

I'll make this brief. My issues with this aren't with the game play, the loop, the design, etc. But the optimization? And the number of graphical issues? Holy shit, this game is a mess. File sizes are absolutely ridiculous. 60 GB base game and 20+ GB for additional maps. Screen tearing galore and no option to turn on VSync or anything similar to stop it, and my system is decently above the only listed specs for the game. And when it isn't the screen tearing, it's the bloom turning anything even mildly reflective into an HID bulb right in your face. Ark can be a pretty game, but it desperately needs some cleaning up. I'm sure everyone appreciates all the new maps and everything that comes with it, but the base game needs a lot of attention first.

This game has it all; humans, humans pooping, dinosaurs, dinosaurs pooping, making structures, avoiding pooping in those structures, making tools, pooping while making tools, cooking food, pooping out that food after you eat it, gardening and agriculture, using poop for gardening and agriculture, and so much more:
- mining and refining metal
- gathering resources from multiple challenging biomes
- fierce creatures to contend with, and maybe tame
- brilliant emergent gameplay from all manner of systems interlinking with each other
- constant battle to stay alive against hunger, thirst, and the elements
- massive player servers to take the challenge multiplayer with thousands of official servers
- mods to further extend things
- quite nice-looking graphics
- building infrastructure for your bases, towns, cities and truly grand projects
- acquiring the power of modern technology, but with ridable dinosaurs
- unraveling the mystery of why and how you're in an environment with long-extinct creatures dotted by huge, imposing technological structures hovering above the landscape

The maps are huge and each one provides many, many hours of gameplay and adventure. Survive the diverse biomes by building bases, taming creatures (dinos), and exploration. Spelunk, climb, dive and fly your way to learning why you just woke up on a beach in your undies and keep waking up similarly if, and probably when, you die.

Ban together with your fellow survivors and form a tribe to conquer the land, or even other tribes. Breed up powerful bloodlines and trusted companions, the more time you put into raising your dinos, the stronger they can become. 

Grow crops, keep bees, breed giant turtles at the bottom of the ocean, put a frickin lazer beam on a Shark's head. This game has it all... Including a bit of a steep learning curve, but most keys and commands are bindable, or you can just use a controller.

Go watch Neebs Gaming's Ark series or Phlinger Phoo's Tutorials and Ark series on YouTube for a good idea of some the adventures you can have.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

Pitifully my whole review will not fit, so I'll be short (kinda:)):

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*]The game is very unique, great Dinosaurs diversity.
[*]Each Dino has its purpose in the game, almost no needless ones.
[*]Creatures are well-made and sounds are pretty-realistic.
[*]OST is great too.
[*]Ability to build mobile bases on Dinos is great. Even more great is that other players could be at the base while moving and not fall off.
[*]There are a lot of fun technologies and mechanics.
[*]Interesting idea behind the story.
[*]Underwater gameplay and exploration is okayish.
[*]ARK Server Manager is very rich on features and easy to use.
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
-=Poor Controls=-
[list]
[*]Cannot double-click in the server lobby screen to connect.
[*]"Enter" key is not working after entering password/entering numbers ingame, etc.
[*]Cannot swap ammo type using weapons on the go.
[*]Cannot cycle through items on the hotbar using mouse scroll.
[*]Cannot cancel particular item in the crafting queue, only option is to cancel everything.
[*]Poor Inventory and storage Management.
[*]Cooking stations craft everything at the same time, wasting resources.
[i]Some of these issues "fixed" by mods.[/i]
[/list]

[b]-=Uninformative Interface=-[/b]
[list]
[*]No information about dino wild/tame level, which is crucial for taming.
[*]No description about the taming process, wild stats, mutations ingame.
[*]Non-informative stats on dinos and weapons in percents instead of exact numbers.
[*]No mention about any torpor damage on weapons in the game.
[*]No marking/description about egg sizes needed to craft kibbles. 
[*]Food cooking recipes do not store/show in a pot, even after finding said recipes.
[i]Majority of these issues fixed by mods.[/i]
[/list]

[b]-=Boring Gameplay=-[/b]
[list]
[*]Cannot reconnect to the server approximately for 10-15 minutes if connection is lost.
[*]Player drop unconcious after receiveing 10% of torpor damage for uknown reason.
[*]If the dino that knocked you out is weak and you have good armor, you lie on the ground for 10-30 realtime minutes staring at black screen, listening to the bites and without ability to do anything.
[*]Player is not regenerating stamina underwater. If you lost stamina, you cannot swim up. The only choice then is to find a way to kill yourself, for example taking off your scuba suit..
[*]Some dinos can push you out of map border where you die and all your stuff gets deleted from the game.
[*]Taming some creatures requires feeding them a fish corpse by pressing "E". Most times the fish you are holding covers all the screen and you cannot press "E".
[*]For the most part taming process is very primitive, knock it down, put food "inside" and wait for it to become loyal.
[*]Oppositely some passive taming methods are insanely hard, and even more boring, like feeding a Gigantosaur to Troodon(feeding an elephant to the rabbit lol).  
[*]Some creatures steal entire stacks of items right from your inventory and desintegrate them in a second. This feature stays despite numerous complaints and requests from the playerbase.
[i]Some of these issues fixed by mods.[/i]
[/list]

[b]-=Messed up Building System=-[/b]
[list]
[*]Building is very limited, blocks do not snap properly, cannot intersect, even with terrain.
[*]Building blocks connect to each other at different angles sometimes, which leads to crooked buildings.
[*]A lot of micromanagement and unnecessarily huge amount of engrams, when they could just join all shapes to material type. (Example: 7 Days to Die, Empyrion.)
[*]Building of water piping and electricity grid is inconvenient and obscure and wastes a lot of time. Cables and pipes sink into foundations, snap automatically to wrong locations. Lots of buildings placed on pipes ONLY. Such buildings are DESTROYED if you'll remove the pipe first, which makes tries to place building in a particular place a pain.
[*]Font size on signs is so tiny you dont see a thing, reported for years...
[i]Some of these issues are fixed by mods.[/i]
[/list]

[b]-=Crazy Grind=-[/b]
[list]
[*]Waiting for days to tame creatures, months/years needed to have powerful high-level tame with mutations on official servers. 
[*]Harvest amounts are ridiculous. Even MMO's are not such a time sinks.
[*]Even 10x multipliers are not enough, if you dont want to spend your whole life in ark and see everything, x100 or even x1000 multipliers needed for some settings, and x0.001 multiplier for timers and cooldowns.
[*]Crafting recipes for top gear(using blueprints) requires thousands of resources. Imagine tons of iron required to craft a helmet. And imagine resource grind involved.
[*]The weight and stacks are so limited, which takes away most fun of the game, adds a lot of micromanagement, grind and limitations. In fact that is a reason that half of the mods in the workshop are stack size increase and weight reduction mods.
[i]These issues could be fixed in settings in SP or on your own server.[/i]
[/list]

[b]-=Worst AI Ever=-[/b]
[list]
[*]Medium-to-large size dinos are stuck in every second tree/stone, and cannot break free, making even strongest predators an easy prey.
[*]Tamed dinos that follow the player just go by straight trajectory, burry into the first available obstacle and stare at you.
[*]They also get stuck in each other or the player, which leads to overlapping hitboxes and the whole party stops very often.
[*]Tamed dinos love to jump off cliffs, especially into lava.
[*]Control over "taming groups" is a nightmare. Sometimes tames are not listening to commands. The distance of commands to ALL is very limited. "Following distance" is not working properly.
[*]Sometimes tamed sea creatures just swim in random directions, and you loose them, it takes tremendous amount of time to find them one by one.
[*]Titanosaur is a huge and powerfull dino. Developers failed to fix its pathfinding , and made him IMMUNE to attacks if it is stuck. Genius.
[i]There is no fix for these issues.[/i]
[/list]

[b]-=Weak Modding Support=-[/b]
[list]
[*]No Minimap mod atm in entire workshop at all. The game itself will not give you a replacement for this torn piece of paper. Imagine top-level player flying using jetpack, hi-tech weapons, super-duper sci-fi buildings and... a map on papyrus.
[*]Also there are no mods to fix majority of issues described in this post.
[*]Some useful mods get outdated and never find replacement...
[/list]

[b]-=Bad Coding=-[/b]
[list]
[*]Countless amount of bugs. I just tired of recording them at some point.
[*]250GB space needed. It takes more space than all my favorite games combined. It has less content than any of these games.
[*]The game crashes each time there are too many eggs on the screen, having like 10-20 eggs will crash the game or even turn off your VGA without doubt. This problem persist for a long time, but nobody cares.
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
The game had great idea and it was implemented partially.
The game has good graphics, realistic and fancy textures. Animations are good too.
The game sucks on almost all aspects with coding involved.
It seems like 90% of their staff are various graphic designers. I cannot find an adequate excuse to why this game sucks so hard on features, controls, UI, AI, etc.
Overall I do not recommend this game. It is fancy, but is an absolute time sink, poorly-done, bugged, requires a lot of googling.

Ark, when it decides to work, is a fun game. What more do you want beyond running around trying your luck with seeing what dinos you can tame and build up a base from scratch. Get some breeding projects going to get the coolest colour combo dinos, or just run around half naked shaking pointy sticks at rexes.

However the reality for me after my rose-coloured-glasses fell off is that most maps are buggy, there are MANY places where you are either above or below the visual ground because the mesh is half-assed. Good luck trying to play with a friend on a non-dedicated server. Rubber banding is horrible, the lag is intense regardless of setting combinations, and a myriad of other bugs which are regularly brought to Devs attention, but nooooooo let's not fix the existing game. Instead, lets release all this (buggy) DLC and oh look! Ark has a sequel now!

Ark is a crafting survival game with a focus on taming and fighting dinosaurs. You gather resources, level up, tame bigger and scarier dinos, while heading towards a set of final boss encounters.

The production quality of the game is pretty high, it can look good and sound good. There is a bit of a learning curve, but not more than any survival crafting based game. You have your typical chop down trees, mine rocks, build base and upgrade equipment, type loop. The gimmick is of course the dinos that litter the island that you can tame and use. Its a bit pokemon-esqu actually, as there is a large variety of them and they all have different purposes. Theoretically this all works, there is a really good foundation here.

The reason why I am giving this a negative review though is because of the tremendous amount of work I had to do to have fun with this game and it never really lasted. In my opinion the balance here is really, really off and it seems the game wants you to fix it yourself. When I started the game I had a good time until about 5 hours in when everything started to take an eternity to do. I tweaked the resource gather rate along with a few other settings and went back to having fun for maybe 10 hours. Then things got super frustrating as I couldn't progress because not high enough level dinos would spawn. Tweak settings again. Game balance drastically changes as all dinos are higher level now, need to tweak other settings to get back to having fun. Realize that some things I need are not available in settings. Begin looking at mods. Start using mods, trying to figure out which ones help. Spend a few frustrating hours with mods that either don't do enough or too much. Quit. I went through this cycle twice, roughly, with a few more started and abandoned characters in between.

I want to make clear, this isn't just 'the game got hard, so I made it easier'. The early, mid and late games, feel like different games entirely. And to an extent the game is aware that there is a problem. The game allows you to easily change its settings, from everything from resource gather rate to what you gain at level up to the level of the dinos themselves. And it also makes modding very easy too. But it shouldn't be up to me to balance your game for you! And because of the stark difference between the game stages, I could never figure out any settings or mods that work at all levels. Most dedicated players seem to mod it so the early and mid games get almost entirely skipped and then just focus on changing the end game.

Bottom line. There is a good basis for a game here but unless you are actually more interested in the community mods than the game itself, I can't really recommend it.

I grabbed this to play with a friend on a private server, which removes a lot of the gripes I've read about official servers. While taming dinos with friends has had its fun moments, especially at the start ,it has too many bugs mixed with weird decisions on mechanics that ruin the fun. New content drops seem to be far more important than fixing even simple things, like being able to stand on a slanted greenhouse without your character model stuttering around randomly. I know new content sells, but there are some long standing bugs and complaints that have gone unheard/ignored for years.

If you don't care about the list of niggles that come to mind, skip this next paragraph, but it does give you some of the spectrum of frustration that comes with the game.

Trying to tame things is a slog when hit registry flat out refuses to work. Lead a target to account for lag, then see the blood splatter and the tranq dart in the dino? Didn't count. Shoot thin air, and suddenly it hits with no spatter. Come out of a cave run and sometimes the gamma gets messed up or the textures for the rest of the world get extremely dark, nealy black. Some enemies *cough* golems *cough* can chain punt you 20 yards every hit. Loss of control actions like fear last 20s+ where you just get to stare at your screen and wait. Torpor buildup from dinos doesn't reduce with armor/level/fortitude like their damage, so when you have thousands of health and armor means you can stay unconscious for several minutes while they do <1 damage per hit. Dinos in any stance that will attack other creatures while you're not mounted on them ignore follow whistling and cannot be stopped unless you can manage to hop on their backs while they move around, which is an absolute pain with birds. Increasing speed on a dragon does nothing for its handling so you can't turn in the tiny arena with the Wyvern boss. I also died from full health in that arena for colliding with the force field's edge somehow. Clipping issues galore, one of the most annoying of which is when you get stuck INSIDE your dinos that are on follow and have to relog to free yourself. The list just seems to keep growing every time I log in.

At the end of the day, I would trade the next new season pass content for more bug fixes and tweaks to functionality to stabilize what could be a really great game.

This game is everything you could hope for. But their are tons of bugs and glitches. They rolled out an update that screwed up transfers. I lost months of work. I reported it and they offered me a pile of poop to replace gold. Stupid glitches like this often. I forget to go to a spot for 5 days and I lost something that cost me 800 tek which was a lot of work to obtain. Then I spend months gathering materials for a tek base. Find the perfect location on a new map for the expensive base. A day after building it, invincible trees started growing right through the foundations... foundations are supposed to prevent trees from growing. But I can't even tear down these trees and I have already built the base. Do I abandon months of preparation and rebuild? No. I report the bug very detailed with screenshots and videos. They have ignored this bug report like it doesn't exist. Then they start preparing for ARK2. As if those of us who hate this game and have already bought all the expansions, would be willing to give them another $200 for a crap game full of bugs that are ignored. But I play it anyways. I like some of the mechanics and there are dinosaurs. Every boys dream. I'm addicted and a glutton for the punishment all these bugs and glitches give me.

I would recommend this game if you want to get addicted, frustrated, and filled with adrenaline all within about an hour. Trust me you'll enjoy this game from exploring the different free maps or paid ones to testing how to tame creatures to fighting bosses. This game is one of my all time favorites. Have fun!

The game is still fun, and yes I am waiting on Ark 2 to come out at the time of posting this. With mods this game is insanely fun and a tip for anybody that only wants to play a specific DLC and has limited space just only install that DLC. Like I am playing on the Genesis map because I enjoy it but didn't have 400gb for every DLC to be installed. The Genesis DLC has all the assets and everything and has no dependencies nor does any of the proper official DLCs. So if you only want to play with 1 DLC then only install that DLC to save space.

I've played Ark more on Ps4 than I have on PC, but I can say without a doubt it's a very fun game. If you play with friends. On your own this game can get boring and kind of stressful, even on servers full of people! If you don't have any friends to play with it on, I would probably skip over this. Even as a dino taming simulator, it could be super overwhelming on your own! 

With friends, however, it's a wonderful experience. If you like games like Stardew Valley where you have to come together as a team to all do separate things to get your farm going, this is very similar! You and your friends will travel the lands (whatever map you pick) and find dinos to tame (or devour) to help your little clan grow! Build in dangerous areas, or a wonderful beach-house even with the threat of a megaladon coming to steal your dodos! Whatever you do, do it laughing with friends!

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

This game was torture. It feels like an early access game that has a lot of potential if they ever get it out of alpha. I found myself saying "man, this is annoying" every 30 seconds. 

The crafting is tedious. Weight limit, tons of tiny containers, millions of different mats to track. Everything expires super fast.  Everything expires and fuels get consumed while you're offline.  

Building is horrible. Walls will snap together but only at a 45deg angle for some bizarre reason.  I fought the horrible building mechanics, building and destroying, trying to get walls to line up and finally managed to finish a giant wall with spikes on it to defend my base only to find out spikes don't actually hurt dinos in PVE

Combat is broken. You can't melee a running dino even if you're following it at point blank.  Projectiles often just miss even when they shoot right through the side of a giant dino.  If you're unlucky, tough dinos will randomly wander into your base, one shot you, kill all your pets, destroy your base, camp your body until it times out and you lose all your gear, and basically reset your game.  

If you like the "challenge" of RNG and spending hours online researching every little aspect of the game just to figure out what to to then this game is for you. Having already played Valheim, Ark just felt inferior in every way.  It's a super tedious version of Valheim with more bugs and none of the fun.
