The game is good, very rough if you play officially, but good, and still has a lot of mistakes. Sometimes you can lose hours of effort and nerves due to the bug.Even though I like ark very much, I have to evaluate the game negatively. 
Why? My rating has several reasons.

Let's start with the nice side: The appearance and difficulty of the game have remained virtually unchanged after several years and with several DLCs. Ark offers official servers, but also "custom servers" or a single game.You can move freely on the map on dinosaurs. You don't have to teleport ... Oh GENESIS, doesn't belong here (he earned a special paragraph below). Number of dinosaurs and their detailed processing. That has a huge plus. In fact, it would seem that this game is really amazing and flawless. However, despite all this, I like ARK, but evaluate it negatively (there is no other option).

And now the sad part. The complexity of this game does not take into account weaker computers, which is a sad. Unfortunately, the game did not deal with bugs after a few years. (I have the impression that there are more of them).  I recently wanted to tame Giganotosaurus. It took me a while for Giga to fall asleep (single mode). After two hours, domestication was 20%. Suddenly, the tame meter disappeared out of nowhere. What happened was my first question. The dinosaur no longer even showed an animation that it would eat ...After about 5 hours of trying to solve it (but in vain) I decided to kill 150 GIGA (the biggest mistake). The dinosaur died and ARK died with him. So I start the game and we go looking for another GIGA. But the map didn't want to turn on. After a few hours of solution (without results and from the support that will write to you, it will erase the world and solve the problem) I was forced to delete the map, which was played for 150 hours + due to one error with domestication dinosaur (it will no longer leave nerves alone).
And now the famous genesis- I returned these DLCs to the steam after 15 hours of playing. The environment is beautiful, new dino, as are the "challenges", if I may call them that. But what bothers me a lot is the teleport. There is no longer free movement of dinosaurs to new locations (mountains, jungles, desert, ...), but you have to teleport to this location. Why? Why the developers destroyed the freedom of movement on the map and largely restricted it by teleporting.

If the rating was between a recommendation and I do not recommend. So I'll pick her.
Unfortunately, all the nice moments in ARK have dark sides. Which I think prevail.
I hope that ARK 2 WILL BE BETTER and there will no longer be such serious bugs and I also hope that people with weaker PCs will be able to play a game that is very nice on the one hand.

Without including DLC on a non-dedicated server with some friends, Ark is fun up until the late game. After a certain point, the game is just doing (literally) nothing and just waiting for progress to be made. To get dinosaurs powerful enough for completing a map, it takes an INCREDIBLY long amount of time, almost all of which involves pressing 2 keys and waiting 6 hours, 50 times?
Ark has a great concept and can be very fun and fufilling as both a sandbox and survival. But, at the point I'm at in the game, I can't say I would recommend Ark. And that's not even considering the bugs or unfair features like alpha enemies, which rely entirely on chance to spawn and if you aren't powerful enough, can completely destroy hours and hours of playtime. 
I'm going to continue playing Ark in hopes of eventually having more fun past the endless taming and breeding of dinosaurs I'm stuck at now, and I do hope that it does get better, because as it stands, I find the game interesting regardless.

Obviously I love the idea of this game or I would not have the sheer amount of hours that I have (Although as i will state later on, many of these hours have been spent troubleshooting a plethora of game issues on or offline). So to start let me fill you in on what this game does right. First we have a massive (and i mean massive) open world filled to the brim with foliage, dinosaurs and neat human structures. The dinosaurs in this world are amazing not only in the sheer diversity of different species but in their interactions with the game (each dinosaur comes with some usefulness to the survivor and can be bred out to make even more powerful dinosaurs for the player to use). The survival and crafting/building aspects were all a huge positive in my eyes as well. In saying this, in no way, shape or form do i recommend this game to anyone in the state it has been since launch. 6 years in beta, multiple paid DLCs and yet here i am still having the same issues that were seen present at the beginning of this games launch, issues that completely derail a players experience in a survival world (not just fun little quirky bugs as all of us see are in all games). Barely playable at best, the so called ShooterGame (as task manager calls it) can't even get the mechanic present in its name right. Hit registration (or the action of the server identifying whether or not your melee or ranged hit lands in game) is quite honestly one of the most laughable aspects of this game. Want to tame that dinosaur but have a finite amount of tranquilliser? Should have brought 10x the amount you need as only a fraction (sometimes literally a fifth of total shots) will register, even when the dinosaur starts to resemble Hellraiser (the game still shows all the unregistered dart hits as if they landed). But mind you this has been present since launch of this beta. And oh i do say beta with a grain of salt as many aspects of this game run like its in alpha or worse. Issues like rubber-banding, connection time outs, rollbacks and player data corruption takes what this game aims to achieve and craps all over it. The sheer amount of hours i have had to spend doing the 10 minute loading to login to a server because i have been kicked out, only to be told that I am already playing in game and can not connect is astounding. I do not jest when i say with this bug alone, nearly 500 of my playing hours come from troubleshooting this issue on my end. Unfortunately this issue has no resolution even in its 6th year of being present, except for waiting 5-10 mins each time this happens for the connection to fully time you out. I don't think i need to stress that in a multiplayer PVP survival game where your character remains in game for all of this time period, that this is not acceptable at all. Fighting other players and lose connection? You are dead and you lost all your stuff on you. Fighting a boss fight and lose connection? You instantly die (as well as all bred tames in said boss fight) and lose all your stuff on you because you crashed. Just tamed some new sweet dinosaur? Nope crash and its been killed while you try to desperately reconnect. Now lets talk rollbacks. See a nice dinosaur and want to tame? Take hours preparing to tame it? Build a brand new base in a sweet spot? Prepped to go into a boss fight? too bad, rollback baby. All that hard work and time just got used to wipe the servers (official and unofficial suffer this the same) arse because its gone and crapped itself for no good reason. Oh here comes rubber-banding though, don't worry guys/gals/other! See that player sneaking around your base and run up behind him to barrel stuff him?  Nope, you may see him at the end of your barrel, but they are actually 7 feet to your left or better yet, already behind you. Now lets talk data corruption. As if all I said previously had never even existed in this game, this issue of data corruption would still see me writing a poor review. Even if you suffer through all the other previously stated garbage this game has to throw at you, you still have a good chance (in single-player or multiplayer) of losing all of your character and/or world progress for no reason other than 'oops we are not sure why'. Seriously.... even famously bugged games like cyberpunk 2077 were more together than this and they got pulled from the market for a bit. Maybe they get away with it because its a "beta" (after 6 years). All in all for online it is not good as most of what you could call skill in this game gets replaced by brute force tactic due to these huge ongoing issues. Last point I have off the top of my head that really solidifies this as a no go for purchasing is that single-player has been bugged since the launch of Lost Island map (possibly even genesis 2 map release), to the point where I can not even begin the game offline without an instant crash. So for any of you thinking that you would avoid the majority of issues by staying away from servers, do not worry ark has unique game breaking issues for that too.
Side note for anyone discounting this review due to my computer specs: of all my friends that have played ark, I do have the most basic setup, but then again (even with their 2060 video cards) I lasted the longest playing this game. All of my friends could not stand this game even with great rigs, not because of them not liking the idea of the game but feeling that the execution was just downright shameful for the points stated above.
Other noteable issues:
-stupidly big download for game
-longest verification time for files (due to size of game and verifying files happens often with ark)
-meh graphics
-Poor frame rate
-meshing issues
-online cheating issues
-extremely long loading times to get into single or multiplayer or to really do anything
-server population right now is extremely spread out leaving very few populated servers (30-40 people seems to be the high end for populated servers)

Edit: some people will like this game as there is a reason some still play it and it is not completely dead. However these people are either die hard fans or are like me and keep coming back because we just want it to be good, but also do not want to feel like idiots by having spent money on an unfinished game + DLC. I really did want to get my moneys worth but in my own opinion, this game is a nearly unenjoyable time-sink and every time i come back I am left with the same bad taste that I was left with the last time I took a break from Ark.

Second Edit: Seeing as the game has decent reviews right now, I decided to read quite a number of them. All in all, a majority of these positive reviews are 1-2 line bullcrap about "hmmm dino gud, yes game gud" or other i love dino comments with no real substance about what the game puts you through as a player. For the love of God, don't bandwagon with these clearly sarcastic reviews by buying into that nonsense. If you really want to spend money that bad, go buy some gloves and slap some sense into yourself.

This game has a unique term called "getting ARKed".  You will experience moment where not only do you get screwed over, but PROFOUNDLY so.  Fortunately, there are some great mods out there that make the pain much more bearable if you're just looking for a game where you can tame dinosaurs, build a base, and just have a great time.

When I started in a private server, with added mods, I had about 250 hours of some frustration and TONS of fun.  This game is a blast, and the modding community can help you curate your experience either by yourself or with friends.

Just do some legwork first beforehand to look up a few things about the game, and look into getting a private server first before you jump into the deep end of public (official) servers.

I have purchased ARK since the previous year but I have paused playing this game when it's time for school. Now, I have adjusted to the complex Online-Learning system and as such, I have now spared some time trying this awesome game. So far, this is one of the best dinosaur games that I have played since childhood. Humans and Dinosaurs together in an Over-world based game is one of the best things that has existed on this planet. Being able to interact with multiple dinos is the  exciting part, especially taming those that had been popular to the public such as Trikes, Sauropods, and especially Rex. Added with the huge map, there are still things that I have yet to explore even though I have invested a lot of time in this game.

One major setback is how resource extensive this game is. Used up around 200Gb+ with only the island map being played (but with other dlcs purchased). For it to play on higher visuals, it costs a lot of CPU and GPU power just to have that best graphical game play. Overall, it is one of the best games that I have played.

Just a reminder that you'll have to invest most of your time just to tame one dino :D.

Why is this game rated 82% positive, who cares if it has dinosaurs, who cares if it looks nice, who cares if they release updates a lot, this game makes you say "bruh" a lot, the sheer amount of glitches that exist in this game is crazy. This game is known for its crazy unplayable bugs. I have 50 hours in this game, which is not a lot but it is still something, and this is due to the amount of time it takes to load in this trash game, why are the loading screens so long, how is it even permitted to publish a game this unpolished.

There are 400 000 reviews at the time of writing this, and you expect me to think that 82% of those 400 000 who bothered to review the game have NASA computers, like what! You can watch online tutorials or reduce your graphics, but this game is unplayable with most last-gen PCs (Since this game came out when the last-gen PCs came out). 

I know! I figured out why 82% like this game, it's because they saw the dinos and were like "Wow, I can tame that!" and just thought a game that incorporates taming is a masterpiece. Why is this game so popular is the real question I should be seeing in the reviews. Additionally, online servers are also unplayable, you cant start because you constantly get killed and even if you get a solid start there always comes someone with nothing better to do, and this person destroys your base, for fun, because he has nothing to do, because he is awake at 5 in the morning when no one is online and destroys peoples bases, not for loot, not to prevent potential competitors, but for fun. If you build a base it will get destroyed overnight without a dought, this game is not fun, this game is trash.

If you are wondering "why is he being so mean to a game he bought" or "why even buy it if it sucks" and the answer to that is the scam that they are advertising, this game looked so promising in videos and in the trailers, but it sucks. 

I am going to not recommend this game, save your money, patience and time.

But hey if you like this game then please continue liking it but I personally think it should have more negative reviews and it should not be as popular but if you like it then you like it, and good for you (not sarcastically).

Good game. I had fun playing it on a server that one of my friends owns, it was modded so my entire Ark experience was a modded one so please take that into account. Also I played as a PvE player, personally I don't have much interest in raiding and getting raided by other players. 

I was very impressed that you can tame, breed, and ride just about every creature you find. I had played Conan Exiles in the past and it was a big surprise to me to see how far Ark went in that regard, Conan was much more strict, I loved the collections of Dino's that I built up and bread. It does bring up some balance concerns with how strong they can get. I don't think anything natural in the world can take on one of my fully bread Dino's, whereas in Conan with one of your strongest bread animals boss fights would still be quite the challenge. Ark also lets you have large amounts of Dino'a follow you at once, which is far more than the 2 in Conan, but this also makes me concerned to what might happen when 2 PvP players fought against each other. It sounds awesome but from how optimized the survival games feel these days I wonder how the frame rate would be effected. Maybe it holds up better than I expect but it sounds like it would be cool in theory but a disaster in practice. 

Building was another aspect that I got fairly into and to be honest I think Conan was ultimately superior in this category. In Conan I was able to build vastly more interesting bases than Ark with the different building materials included in Conan's DLC's. What Ark does do better in building is allow you to place buildings in more locations, in Conan you are more likely to get the "invalid placement" error. The Conan issue is easier to be fixed with mods in my experience. 

The last main point that I want to touch on is an issue with all survivor games these days. They feel so old. they really could do for a massive overhaul in optimization, and add new mechanics to keep the game more modern feeling. One of my friends honest to god guessed that it was made in 2008, nearly a whole decade earlier than when it was actually released, because it actually feels that old in terms of mechanics. 

Ark 2 is slated for later this year (2022) and hopefully it will be even better than Ark 1. If you are looking to start an Ark 1 playthrough I do recommend it, but with friends, it'll be fun, but maybe wait for a sale, since the game is 5 years old at this point and Ark 2 around the corner.

So previous review still stands to an extent, especially for any servers with actual PvP which I can only imagine is absolutely heinous. However once I tamed an Argentavis and started getting loot on a server where things were made a bit easier things got more fun later on. It's addicting, possibly too addicting and other than the fact I've wasted hours looking for an otter that never showed up on the lost island it's been relatively fun so far once I stopped being annihilated by even the weakest creatures and started taming things.

Buggy and full of obnoxious gotchas, the game is fun if you're willing to suffer absolute NONSENSE losses all the time. I had a character leveled up and when the server went offline for a reset, all my stats went down more than 30% and I was missing half my stuff I got today. Yet my characters level was the same. So excuse me what?

They put buttons in the middle of places that say upload character and then it DELETES ALL THE STUFF YOU CARRY WITH NO WARNING. Like what does upload to server mean? Is there no user friendliness involved here? They don't seem to maintain anything properly or test the game for bugs before they release updates.  If you want to play a game where it's like Valheim with dinosaurs and other monsters and combat where half the time your arrows do nothing at all before you lose everything because of a server glitch or something then... Well, have fun!

But really, everything I do on this game I feel like their buggy software is programmed to take away and that's not okay. It's not even a game I'm fighting with, it's the bad software. To think I had issues with the software I design from time to time -- This takes the cake. I would never have greenlit merges to the code that made the server shutdown sequence eliminate progress players have made and forget custom settings. Oh, you have a setting that lets people get extra points per level here? Why not go and just delete that when it resets even though the server is set that way. Great idea right? Let everyone log back in with 30% lower stats because you never test rebooting a server with custom settings. Obnoxious. It's not even close to a "get good" situation which some of the "I died to a monster" situations are. (Even though a lot of the time the combat feels clunkier than a first generation Elder Scrolls game.)

If you know how to avoid all these bugs, I bet you can have fun now and then. But it's really, really, super obnoxious to new players.

Before you even look at my review just know I've played this game far longer than Steam says I have. I also own this game on Xbox and recently decided I would like to play it on PC. I will say I'm definitely no expert on this game and continue learning more every time I play. That being said... 

Overall I enjoy this game. There's so many different dinosaurs to see with their own strengths and weaknesses. A very diverse map and plenty of grinding to accomplish your goals. 

The issue I have with this game is there's a big learning curve. No tutorial to help new players just starting out. The settings for single player servers suck and it's hard to figure out what settings are ideal so it doesn't take hours to tame a dino but at the same time isn't too easy it's not even fun doing. 

I'd say this game is worth getting and playing but I'd really like to see bigger improvements to the game as far as tutorials, single player settings and better default server setting recommendations based on how difficult you want the game to be for you. There's still so much more potential for this game and I hope it continues to get better.

THIS REVIEW IS FOR NON-LOCAL MULTIPLAYER

The gameplay has greatly improved and it's super fun once you're in. That being said, my main reason for playing was to play with friends and family over long distance and I've never played a game that's so difficult to actually initiate playing with others. One day you're joining each other's sessions, the next day the join "fails" for inexplicable reasons. Sometimes you're loading into a server and then it just "fails" when things seemed to be going well (after researching this common issue, this is actually called "timing out" as apparently you take too long to load in).

If you're playing single player or local multiplayer, this game is amazing.
If you're trying to play long-distance, the server hosting and joining needs a massive overhaul or to be removed. 99% it, or don't offer it at  all

There are 2 types of Ark players because there are 2 ways this game can be played. Type 1 Survival: You harvest resources and try to survive in a hostile environment. I never played that way. Type 2 Sandbox/Simulation: You pay for a material and artistic content, aka 3D textured models and atmospheres. I always play only for this reason so the review will talk about that.
I'm writing this at 9 hours here but I had the game on PS4 in the past. The reason why I dropped it in the past was because typing the admin cheats (only way to play the game as a type 2 player) was exhausting without a pc, loading screens were long and the graphic was crippled. The reason why I bough it a second time once I built a pc with a 3080 is because now cheats and stuff are much easier to handle, because I play in max settings on an HDR4k Oled TV and because I still love creatures just like when I was a child.

Let's address the game.

Content: 
Its most shiny part. Creatures are infinite (they are literally hundreds) and you can't even memorise them. They are dinosaurs and mythological creatures. There's everything a lover of creatures would want to encounter and ride. Yes, you ride them. Just think how cool that is! It's a dream come true, a game where you can ride (also in the sea and in the air) literally everything. Dragons, Manticores, Wyverns, Worms, Snakes, Dinosaurs, Griffins, cute creatures, nasty creatures, sea creatures... And all is set in tangled forests, islands, grassy lands... There are jungles, vulcans, seas, structures, shores, mountains, snowy lands, deserts. I always dreamt to be in natural environments such as these and ride any sort of disparate creature AND NOW I CAN! So, this part of the game gets a full 10.

Graphic:
I noticed a serious improvement passing from a PS4 to a 3080. I'm playing everything maxed and I must say that it's much more immersive. Still, there's a lot to say. Everything seems to have been cured equally, this means that plants and the main character are basically at the same level. Debatable decision. I'm a 3rd person fan so I started playing with the character in full view. Big mistake. As soon as I experimented the 1st person I understood that the game looked so much better and much more immersive. That badly shaped human in front of you is just not meant to be, while the rising plants and volumetric grass are. Creatures also look better than humans. As a 3rd person fan i'm not really hurt by this because what matters the most in this game are the creatures and they can still be ridden in 3rd person despite having the character in 1st. Very good. I support this choice. Textures are very nice, even though models and shading systems look old in 2022. I often try this trick to check graphics: I play a game for like 1 hour (something I'm modding or that I'm trying on my new pc) and then open a recent game immediately after to check the impact. Ark looks... Let's say... Up to expectations. You don't really cringe if you are in Max Settings, but you see that many things aren't perfect at all. The overall look, though, is still very pretty. Sometimes creatures could have been coordinated better so as to give more artistic value to these lands. The result of not taking this into consideration is that many places look anonymous or drab. You often see dinos walking against trees or areas that are completely empty. So, yes, it looks good on a high-end setup (pc+tv) but it's not really the most shiny aspect of the game. Still, I want to underline, the elements are SO MANY (especially vegetation and distant lod, including grass lod) that my 3080 handles it by overheating the pc very fast. In some cases I had slight frame rate drops, and there's almost nothing that a 3080 can't do (I talk as someone that has modded Skyrim and The Witcher as much as he could). 

Gameplay: 
As I said, I don't actually play any game mechanic. I'm not interested in having any challenge. I saw the worth of the game in terms of the material/artistic content it could offer and I'm exploiting that as much as I can. As a type 2 player, on Pc, inserting codes isn't messy and exploration is gratifying. What I really can't find is the option to play couch co op (local) in split screen. I could on PS4, why can't I here?! I would like to be able to do that.

So, overall, it's a game that offers a vast content and the purchase is worth it even just for that. Highly suggested to someone in search of a natural paradise (or hell) to seek a refuge in. As for the game mechanics I'm not the right person to refer to, but they don't look attractive, nor stable, nor easy to handle. They actually look pretty boring if you ask me. I hope the next Ark is built more around type 2 than type 1 players. I think that its real worth is in the content rather than in the mechanics.

I wanted to like this game so much, I'm a huge fan of survival games, complex crafting, open world, and crazy fantasy dinosaurs.  This should be a huge hit in my world, but this game has just intentionally taken the worst attributes of all gaming and bundled it into one.

Unbelievable grind fest, like you may as well build a house IRL, it's about as much effort as building one in this game.  Brutal, unforgiving combat; it seems like "skill" is completely irrelevant at level 50 or lower, where most aggressive dinos will just kill you in about 3 hits, nothing you can do about it.  And then all the toxicity of an online-mmo adds up to present a game that its truly only for the most hardcore player, and even then, you've gotta be a masochist who loves to run back to your body over and over again.

[h1] Game Details [/h1]
[list]
	[*]   [b] Game Name: [/b] Ark: Survival Evolved
	[*]   [b] Game Release: [/b] 2017
	[*]   [b] Genre Tags: [/b] Survival, Action, Open World, Dinosaurs, Multiplayer
	[*]   [b] Estimated Playtime: [/b] 100+ Hours
	[*]   [b] Personal Rating: [/b] 7/10
        [*]   [b] 240+ Hours on Xbox One [/b]
[/list]

[h1] Review [/h1]
[b] Summary - [/b] Ark: Survival Evolved is a 2017 action-adventure survival video game developed by Studio Wildcard. In the game, players must survive being stranded on one of several maps filled with roaming dinosaurs, fictional fantasy monsters and other prehistoric animals, natural hazards, and potentially hostile human players.

[b] Gameplay - [/b] The gameplay is awesome in this game. You get to live in a world with dinosaurs and other prehistoric animals. You can make your own base, and tame any dinosaur. Every dinosaur has its unique uses and you can even have some as pets.You start with spears, bows, you know the typical survival games. When you get farther into the game, you get guns, and futuristic type weapons and armor. You do fight against bosses as well. The game has a good amount of content as well. If you get the DLC’s, you will visit new and unique worlds that have awesome creatures that fit that world atmosphere and setting.

[b] Graphics - [/b] The graphics are okay looking. They are not bad, but are getting to the point of aging. The trees are dense and the map can look really dense and immersive. The optimization could be better in some areas in my opinion, but it's not terrible. If you play on low settings, be warned that it looks really bad in this game. I recommend a high settings preset.

[b] Multiplayer - [/b] Ark: Survival Evolve has a good multiplayer system. With a dedicated server, to make your own with friends. If you make a local server, you and your friend can only separate for so long before the game stops you from going any further. I don't like that system, because it feels like they are pushing us to buy our own server, or just join randomly which is a shame. The PVP is pretty fun in this game, but you can find PVE servers which is a good thing.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
[list]
	[*] Great content
	[*] Awesome setting
	[*] Dinosaurs
	[*] You can tame dinosaurs
	[*] Great map design
[/list]

[h1] Cons: [/h1]
[list]
	[*] Optimization could be better
	[*] Local multiplayer has tether effect
	[*] DLC’s can be expensive
        [*] Graphics have aged poorly
[/list]

The best dinosaur survival game out there.
You can do whatever you want, travel across multiple worlds, and tame almost every single creature of each world.
Biggest issues with the game is it is very much a make your own adventure game. A giant sandbox of creatures to tame across multiple well worth the money expansions(except maybe Extinction because of its fairly restrictive map).
It being a make your own adventure game is the biggest reason why I don't see myself playing it very much anymore. I miss objectives, reasons to tame certain creatures, reasons to redo bosses(do them once and there's zero reason to ever revisit them), or simply a story to complete across the expansions. I hope ARK 2 add this.

Most of my hours come from ARK's breeding feature, where you take creatures far beyond what should be possible, in terms of stats. And the worst part is it's honestly necessary to do to be able to deal with the game's poorly coded/designed bosses. There's no real difficulty with the actual bosses, except the fact that you just need a ton of stats on your creatures and great saddles. There are no gimmicks to each boss(unless you see a fire breath attack, dealing DoT damage, as a gimmick. I see it as poor difficulty design).

I played majority of my hours on private servers and I would highly recommend you find a good place to play, with an active community or simply play with your friends alone, rather than attempt to play on Official Servers. The gathering rates, breeding rates, taming rates, are terrible on Official Servers, and the amount of inactive players and their left behind structures will drag down your performance and enjoyment.

I recommend the game to any fan of dinosaur games as it is by far the best out there, even if it strays away from the primitive dinosaur only side of the game quite fast after the base game. First expansion goes straight into the realm of fantasy, with Wyverns, Deathworms, etc. but if you can live with fantasy creatures, even better.

The game is alot of fun but there are a few things about the game that make me have to give it a negative review. one thing is the player tether.....you have a certain distance you can go from the person who started the server. yes you can increase it but then you have a chance of the game bugging out. Case in point, playing on my family's server on crystal isles, I was flying a dragon looking for metal. All of a sudden it came up saying "you are too far from the host" and teleported me back to the base where the host was but not the dragon. It was just gone from the game. Also Some area's of the game the redwood forest for once, I was flying right next to the host of the server and it kept saying "out of range of host" and teleporting me directly under them. I am hoping that part 2 is much better then this, but after years of this game being out and still finding these bugs, I am losing faith that ark 2 will be any better.

I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who loves dinosaurs and a rust-like survival game. The PvP can get a bit heated at times, but both the PvP and PvE are very rewarding and fun. If you plan on playing official servers, make sure to have a decent group of people, because the grind is insane. If you can find a server with even a 5x tame or gather boost, I recommend that highly.
If you're looking for a decent unofficial PvP server to get started on, I've been playing on Korangar on and off for a few years, and would definitely recommend. It's died down quite a bit, so you don't run into a ton of people and you can play how you'd like.
I haven't beaten the game, I've never been able to stay dedicated long enough to complete the bosses on one world, much less the expansions. Regardless of that, it's the game in my library with the most hours, so I obviously have fun either way, and you would too.

So yeah, I like this game. I got it back in 2014ish, and I hated it. It was brutal, graphics were piss poor and I had no idea what to do. It was my first survival game. I took on many titles, then came back to this one with a few friends, rented our own server and I "got good". I fell in love with it! We built a castle on the beach, with a drawbridge, had dragons and trex as guards. It was beautiful,...then we went to a new map, and it sucked. Everyone died all the time, we hated it and went on to new titles. But...but...I tried a new map and it was right back to endless taming and building. So if you get this game, and do not like it after a 10 hour "trial", try a different map, try mods, do not play alone. Find a server or join some friends if you can afford them, and fucking enjoy this game.

I've got over 4,700 hours in this game at this point and figured Id write a quick review. 
This game is not for those who are frustrated with having shit go out of your control is random ways.
However, if you don't mind losing your shit sometimes even in single player then you will adore this game.
It has an immense amount to offer.

Pros:
-Great Story that you have to find yourself to follow, so its not pushed in your face if you don't care about it.
-Tons of creative ability.
--Breeding/Taming/Mutations are a blast
--Building with some of the many mods is also a blast
-The devs love their modding community. This means we get a lot of nice maps and sponsored mods.
-Lots of maps even for free.
-Both tek and primitive item sets and ways to play
-Amazing graphics
-Fun progression and grind
-Official PVE was a delight when I used to do that. We worked together as a community in the game.
-Fun boss fights and the Islands Tek Cave in the volcano is fun to complete for your first ascension.

Cons:
-Ark will F you constantly. 
--Random Dino attacking the thing you're taming because for some reason it hopped off a cliff chasing something else and thought your tame looked like easier prey than the thing it was chasing and F'd the effectiveness to the point you need to either put the thing down and try to find a new one or let it wake up and waste more hours of your life.
--Falling through the map on Aberration because you had the audacity to ride a Basilisk over some terrain decor.
--Why am I falling from the sky when I logged in and now dead on my roof?
--Icthyornis stole all my prime again on the way to my tame.
-Graphics come with a huge performance cost and lesser rigs wont be able to run this on max.
-You know what? Just Pego's and Icthy's in general. CON.
-Later DLC's made for group play and not necessarily solo so much

If you like grindy difficult games, you'll love ark. The maps and dungeons are beautifully designed, the tribute/boss system is great, i have like 5000+ hours on ps4+pc and i still havent beat the game. It's very unforgiving and there's alot of live and learn situations where you'll lose almost everything, but if you persevere (have a backup base, raise babies as expendables and keep your parent dino's safe, use sleeping bags often, and remember where you died.) You'll have a more enjoyable experience the next time you spawn, there is still bugs and lag, the game is known for it, all the grinds of finding rare perfect tames, breeding dino's for stat increases and color combinations, building huge bases, and looking forward to all the crazy bosses and dungeons keep you invested for months.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, go below, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

So, I'd pick it up IF IT GOES ON SALE. $9 for this game is about right. As far as a rating goes, maybe 5/10. 

There is a significant amount of content that feels patched and stitched together, instead of having one cohesive game. Even some of the settings and configurations for the game don't have a consistent pattern. There is also a lot in the game that isn't explained or described intuitively - not that you can't figure it out, it's just not very intuitive and usually requires looking up a guide online to save an hour or three of your time.

-----

To elaborate:
The building mechanics are, well, not broken, but not exactly polished either. On more than one occasion I've found myself frustrated with the fact that nothing will snap together correctly, and (as far as I can tell) the game will randomly decide if you are in a shelter or not, often leading to rain coming through your ceiling (this may have to do with the poorly built snapping mechanic for construction). Walls snap to stairs, but the stair height from one level to the next is different than the height of the wall from one level to the next, leaving odd looking gaps when trying to build a second floor. 

Dinos, while really neat, are often just as weird and "unpolished". I've seen dinosaurs get stuck on thin air, which required rebooting the server to fix. Dino behavior is almost always aggressive, as it should be, but leads to unintended (and often annoying) behaviors with tamed ones. On multiple occasions we have had dinos that ignore commands completely and get themselves killed trying to attack something too large.  

The survival mechanics are there, but feel stitched together. Characters overheating is a constant issue, though maybe I just haven't figured out that mechanic yet. That said, 10+ hours in, I feel like I should be able to - relating back to my statement about the game not being intuitive.

Lastly, the UI elements and interaction menus still need some serious work. There are a lot of situations that could have been solved with some default actions or a simple "E" prompt to interact. I have no desire to have the "change pass code" function be the default action if I'm a half-step further away from my container than usual, and there isn't any reason I need to see the health, owner, tribe, and status of a container on my UI unless one of those things would interfere with normal usage. I also don't need to have the "LEVEL UP AVAILABLE" at the top of my screen if I have an icon on the right that indicates that same thing - again, leading back to my statement of how this feels patched together.

-----

All in all, it feels like a game that never really got out of the "experimental" phase. For $9, it's not a bad buy and will keep you preoccupied with all of the content that it comes with.

I have played this game for quite a while now. I think that I can give an honest review.

So the platform is quite unstable and has a problem with crashing the server and you will lose dinos and gear if you are killed when it happens. This is a major down for the game. " ON PUBLIC OFFICIAL SERVERS " On private paid servers like PING. Awesome play time with zero lag.

Public PVE maps. Well they can get crowded and you might have a hard time finding a place to build a base. Some are quite toxic about you joining the server and will set pillars around your base so you can't finish building. But then you will find some that will help you all the way to the top.

There is absolutely no end to this game. Between building and catching dinos and breeding them to make more powerful dinos. You will not get bored. However remember that there are decay timers on structures you build if you don't log on in a certain amount of days it will go away.

Even with all that being said I have logged over 3600 hours of game play on this game and I just can't get enough. Even when you just get bored of a map. That's okay, pack up and change maps lol.

Have a great time and I hope you enjoy your experience. I know I did.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I dont want to keep this too long, but i feel like there are a lot of things that have to be said about this game.
First off, on this account i have around 6.5k hours, 2.5k on another and 1k more on epic games. All of that adds up to around 10k hours of gameplay in: modded, vanilla boosted rates and mostly official 1x

If you are looking for a game to just play with a group of friends on a private server, this can be pretty fun to get into and build your own little world.

Just be prepared for:
-an incredible amount of bugs and glitches
-high performance requirements
-a lot of lag
-the game crashing more than once in an hour
-a lot of boring farming
-around 300GBs of space, going up to even 450GBs if you plan on playing with mods
-more unexplainable stupid things happening during your gameplay

In fact, i wouldnt recommend playing it at all if you are planning to go on the official 1x cluster, because the game is simply broken and the developers dont care at all about the state of the game.

The official 1x cluster is basically just a lot of cheating, meaning you will get aimbotted, enemy dinos are moving and turning too fast, people go through walls to get into your base, there is an incredible amount of resources and the "ingame currencies" going around due to exploits that let people duplicate items. Every patch or release something else gets messed up and becomes broken, new dinos that are released are either too strong or too weak and stay that way for weeks since the developers are too lazy to fix anything quick enough. 
Sometimes the developers disable the server transfers if they messed something up and then roll back to an earlier state of the server save, reverting anything you have done during the time of disabled transfers. Very recently there have been cases of tamed dinos disappearing randomly on every server and they took a few days to revert the issue.

If you happened to travel anything to those broken servers that was important to you, the server would be reverted to before you traveled your items there and they were deleted basically. Happened to me too. Lost a lot of stuff on that already. 
Their "upload" and "transfer" system between servers is utterly messed up and under-developed.

This is a great transition to the next thing that is making this game absolutely unplayable: The developers themselves.
One of the developers called "Dollie" has around 100 hours in ARK on her steam account... the game she is supposed to develop properly.... how can she have any idea of how their implemented creatures and items will work out if she doesnt even play the game herself to begin with and doesnt know the meta? There have even been cases of head developers and people that work in the support abusing their admin powers ingame to help certain big tribes and spawn in items, blueprints and even dinos for them. So much to the "fairness" and "state" of the game. 

Speaking of big tribes, which are called "megatribes" since they have built up on multiple servers, basically owning them and consisting of hundreds of people. These megatribes form alliances which then consist of thousands of members and then end up going to war against other alliances. All while cheating and exploiting.
If you are a new player that wants to have a fresh start on a vanilla server 1x, these will be your biggest enemy. If you happen to spawn on one of their servers, there is a chance the tribe has blocked every single possibility for you to get off the server, meaning you are stuck there - forever, if you cant run around the map to find another way that they havent blocked off yet. Which is pretty hard to do when you are on a level 1 character that has no movespeed or health and there is aggressive dinosaurs running all around the map. You will have to simply exit to main menu, make a new character on another server and hope that one is easier to escape or not taken at all. Until you eventually take your character you spent hours to level up and accidently go to another server that is blocked again, making you lose your high level character. Sometimes they cage you and keep you in their base forever.

If you happen to get into one of those megatribes and you spend hours and hours of obtaining your personal items, riches and raising your dinos (which each take at least 3 days to raise on average with you having to come online every 8 hours to "imprint" them and make them stronger.), the game might be fun for a little while. But let me tell you this, there are three ways this can play out:
1. You get insided, basically someone in your tribe made a deal with another tribe and turns off all your defenses, making you an easy raid for your enemies and you lose everything that you built up.
2. You get raided by cheating people, that shoot through walls and keep killing you, keeping you on a respawn timer while they can start taking down your defenses, taking their sweet time while you keep getting aimbotted and killed. Or they just go through walls and ceilings, the map itself to begin with and turn off everything from the inside while you cant do anything. Maybe they simply get inside, steal all your loot and dont do anything else. So you are left with a base but nothing to defend it with. TL DR: Lots of cheaters will raid you
3. The developers themselves wipe you. Yes you heard right, they will come, randomly, because they heard some rumors about you cheating, got sent edited screenshots, or a single person in your tribe did something to break terms of service.
They will join your server, go to your base and they will type one command. You will die, losing everything you have on you and then your base will start to despawn and all your items and dinos with it. There have even been rumors about people/big tribes paying the developers to wipe an enemy of theirs.

^I have seen all three possibilities happen and it has happened to me. And i have lost a lot of items i spent hours getting and dinos that i spend multiple days raising, having to hop online every 6-8 hours to "imprint" them. Because on the official 1x clusters only 100% imprinted dinos will be useful. Some dinosaurs take 10 days to raise. You have to take care of them for 10 days every 8 hours and they can simply die from a cheating player or you lose them due to the already mentioned issues with the "upload" and "transfer" system.

And the community isnt better either, as you could see from the so called "insiders" that will destroy your base from the inside. If you trade with other players from other tribes and servers for valuable items there is a 90% chance you get scammed if you arent careful and have no information about them.
Sometimes your server will also get ddosed by your enemies and it will become unplayable with an incredibly high ping, maybe even crash and stay down for days on end without the developers booting it back up.

Big tribe wars are basically a big waste of time. You get on a server after pressing the join button for 3 hours straight since the server has 70/70 people on it and then play in extreme lag, rubberbanding back to a positon your character has been in 2 minutes ago. And if you are close to raiding someone's base by destroying their defenses, they will ddos the server, make it crash and roll back to before you did the damage.

If you try to report the cheating tribes/people by making a ticket on the support site there is probably a 1% chance that anything will happen. I have created countless of tickets myself adding proof through screenshots or videos to it. The only thing i have gotten back is a copied text saying they will do something but cant give info on the situation. (Nothing happens)

This is still only a fraction of what i have seen and experienced in this game. For your sanity, your health, your friends and family its probably the best if you just keep your hands off of this mess of a game. Play it with your friends on a private server and be ready for the worst to happen.

Let me preface with this; My machine has no trouble with any other game I've thrown at it; and over the years I've sunk over 1k hours into this game, from early access to last year. But I literally can't anymore, even when I want to. 

- Game now takes up 303GB. 
- Crashes consistently. 
- Runs like garbage. 
- Takes ages to load. 
- Updates frequently and bloats game size. 
- Has at least several bugs that have been around for years now, which hinder gameplay to varying degrees. 

The fact that the application name in the Task Manager still says "Shooter Game" should be enough to steer anyone away from this, what is clearly an unoptimized, poorly made money grab. 
Wildcard constantly pushing for more and more content which is just bloating the game further, rather than refining what they already have.

I've played a total of 2k hours on this game between ps4 and pc. I can positively say that this game has come a far way since first being released! When first playing the optimization was horrible and having an amazing pc was really the only way to play. Now that the optimization is a lot better, I'd recommend it to everyone! The base game is impressive but if playing on heavily modified settings completing the game goes by quick. If your computer  can handle the mods, I would always recommend some of the harder mods after getting to know the game. The community around ark is also great with wildcard using community mods to turn into official mods/maps. You can meet a variety of people on this game which is another plus to it. With so many mods you can really make the game whatever you want! [b]Highly recommend this game to everyone 10/10![/b]

"So, I'll make this simple: never, under any circumstance, miss out on this game. The Graphics were good especially if you can run a good high to medium settings. Gameplay-wise was exciting and it goes really well with the music and audio effects to the point that it made me stay up late during my working days. When you get down to it, there's really still much left you can say. Occasionally, you'll play a game that's so good, that you're done after a couple of days. This isn't the case with ARK: Survival Evolved. It's just...soo good. In conclusion you should differently get ARK: Survival Evolved!

One of my favorite games to come back to time and time again. The customization for private servers make this game a great option for people that may not have the time to grind out a successful base under default settings. All around, there's something for most everyone to enjoy. 10/10

GET IT ITS FREE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I want to like this game so bad, in theory it's my perfect game. I love the survival, I love extinct animals, I love building.

Unfortunately it's plagued with lots of problems, and they will never be fixed. The game is still being updated, but they only seem to be adding content (which seems to be sponsored mods), and no longer improving the game. Most of the updates seem centered on fixing exploits for official multiplayer servers.

cons:
- lots of glitches (such as getting stuck)
- unintuitive and hard to use UI
- excessive graphics processing, too high contrast even with all effects off
- build system is extremely finicky 
- unintutive mechanics, e.g. taming (you have to read the wiki)
- new content is mostly new maps, or locked to new maps
- the teknology is kind of stupid, and the built in "primitive+" game mode is abandoned
- server configuration is a mess (and much of it can only be done in ini)
- annoying holiday events
- lack of new construction or character customization pieces
- difficultly randomly ramps up hard (random predator / alpha spawns)

I played this game years ago, and jumping in, it still feels exactly the same. The core mechanics,UI and graphics have not seen any improvements over the years from what I can tell. Instead of improving the experience by fixing these core systems, or even adding depth to the game by adding new building parts or mechanics, they seem to have only added new maps or the occasional new creature (which is often locked to these new maps). 

They've recently announced Ark 2, which means they certainly wont be doing any more updates to the core of this game. And maybe Ark 2 will fix everything, but how long will it take before it has nearly as much content? And what's the chance they will fix the mistakes they made with the first game?

If you can get it for $10 and have some friends to play with it might be worth it for you.

If you like dying constantly and in a myriad of ways then this game is for you! I'm the kind of player that likes to be ultra prepared before undertaking any in game tasks but in ARK that rarely matters. You get killed often and the gameplay is difficult, but challenging so it keeps you busy. The gameplay is also fairly varied. You have a choice to play along the paths the devs have set up or you can just enjoy the giant open world of dinosaurs (even though most try to kill you). There's crafting, taming, breeding, etc. so something for everyone. The graphics are very detailed, but if you don't have a system for that I might not recommend getting the game because it is half its charm. Also, the game is VERY glitchy. Not in the sense it crashes, but in that you get stuck, the dinos get stuck, the building is very finicky and the shooting is not always accurate and unfortunately lots more. But weirdly enough its kinda of just an ARK thing and sometimes can even work in your favour. So in conclusion, definitely a game I'd recommend, though because of general lack of direction and information, make sure you have the wiki open at all times. Frustrating, but rewarding and has a steep learning curve. But as you can see from my 200 or so hours playing, loving every minute of it (except breeding. That's the WORST).

This game is a terrible mix between stupid, incredible fun with exploration and dinos to complete destruction of everything you love and have built up to. Anything you do in this game can be thrown away in an instant to a random spawn. It's all up to chance. The game never spreads out its annoying traits throughout the game either. You will have the best time you've had in weeks without a single hitch and then the moment something goes wrong for you, the game continuously stacks everything bad that could possibly happen to you within that one moment. 

And don't even CONSIDER this game if you get easily attached to digital pets. Because the game will take those from you in an instant with no hesitation. There is no sense of safety in this game until you get to the point of level 150+ dinos and getting the best equipment in the game. And even then Ark will find a way to screw you over. It always does. Don't let it fool you. Never let your guard down. Never play this game.

original Review:
Even on sale, not worth it. Buggy AF especially for a game this old. undo months of game time in one glitch, bug, or blatant AI failure. Way too complicated to back up a game or create a server considering the instability. Played this forever on epic and heard the steam was better so bought it on sale. It is absolutely worse. 0.2 hours over "applicable refund time" so I'm stuck with it. Most of that was spent in failing load screens or black screens that never went away. Non dedicated servers are completely unstable. 

And on a side note, If I could I give an entire extra thumbs down justfor this tether distance nonsense.

To start this game is buggy. Undoubtedly and honestly it is. To some that's enough to have them quit the game and I say fair enough to that. For me though, this game offers enough to look over that. The fact its nearly 300gb for me on disk is a good indicator of what this game is to me, just a mind blowingly indepth open world masterpiece. 

This game offers a level of play that I've never encountered in another game. Everything has detail, everything has its own little mechanic that once learned you can take advantage of to make your life on the ark just that little bit easier. And all those little mechanics add up to make a big difference, the difference between a good player and a bad player. And yet amazingly I can see a player with no experience being able to jump in and still not feel overwhelmed because the mechanics only are there if you look for them. It's not a case of OoH u DoNt KnOw How To Do ThIs oBsCurE tHinG So U DiE. 

On top of the mechanics is the lore in this game. It doesn't actually present its self unless you look for it and I love that. Rather than it being shoved in your face you see tiny hints around the map, so tiny someone not in the loop would never notice, but if you do know, then it'll make you smile (insert pointing Rick Dalton meme)

A few other things I like are: I think the graphics are pretty good considering the size of the maps.

Nearly everything is configurable if you are playing single player or running your own server 

The mods list is never ending

And dinosaurs... duh.

I got to level 16 and yet almost everything kills me. I've filled the map with green rays marking my corpses, which I cannot loot because then I get killed again by the same dinosaur that killed me in the first place. I've tried to play with the settings when creating the game. The result is that now I cannot damage the dinosaurs AT ALL. No matter how many times I hit them and no matter with what. They also cannot damage me, which would be something if they didn't constantly harass me and literally push me around everywhere so that I can't do anything. 
I've tried to exit to the main menu and see what the problem is this time, and the game crashed. I've had a very hard time even closing the process so I could access Steam again. I can't understand how this game has so many fans, it's broken and totally unplayable to me.

+ the graphics look good if you disregard the terrible way everything breaks and the robotic animations
+ you can tame dinosaurs

- no story
- no real tutorial 
- no health bars on dinosaurs
- almost everything kills you. the only pelts you can safely get are the dodo pelts, which happen to be very cute and die a very violent death by your hands,
- actually hitting the enemies you're attacking is challenging, because you need to align the middle of the screen with the creature you're trying to hit, and also be close enough. otherwise you'll just be swinging in their direction without doing any damage
- the creatures who can and do kill you can also attack and destroy your base, and clip through the walls to get to you even if you're inside your shelter.
- if a creature doesn't kill you, you can also kill yourself by mistake when hitting a dodo with your bare hands. hitting a tree is fine though, and does less damage.
- you need to hit a tree with your bare hands in order to get wood. this makes absolutely no sense.
- whenever you destroy something it breaks it huge geometrical pieces that sink into the ground after a while in a very realistic way (sarcasm)
- the game is basically one huge grind with you going back and forth between your storage crates (very small storage crates) and whatever resource you need.
- I haven't figured out a way to sleep so I can fast forward through the night when I can't see anything
- weird eat and sleep mechanics. I think I managed to drink some water, but I'm not really sure how. there isn't really a drink animation, so I've either tried to hit the water or harvest it. I also can't tell if the icons on the right should be white or grayed out when all's good.
- every time you die and get your stuff back you get another extra copy of some cosmetic items I don't know what to do with yet. so I now have 4 of each in my inventory and I cannot destroy them, so my only option is to drop them somewhere on the ground. 
- also, each time you die your corpse stays behind after you loot it. I now have 5 versions of me dead and decomposing somewhere on the island, contorted in weird positions of course (and some partially levitating). 
- you defecate randomly from time to time. no warning, you just let go with a prrrrrtttttt. And you can pick it up afterwards. This is just... nope.
- the screen goes blurry from time to time and my character drops like a ragdoll in whatever place she's at (even if she's in the water) and can't move for a short while. I *think* she's sleeping? what's weird is that the sleeping bag can't be used to sleep in it so I can prevent these strange fits from happening. I can only seem to use it for fast travel..

This is one of those games that I wish I could play again for the first time. The experience of exploring and building in a massive world full of awesome dinosaurs is exhilarating. Fortunately, there are a lot of maps and expansions to play on with each providing a different experience that lets you capture that first time feel a bit.

It's a game best played with friends, but you can definitely enjoy it solo. However, it can be a punishing and frustrating game. For example, you can spend the first several nights building a basic shelter and perhaps even taming a few dinosaurs, only to have it all destroyed because a Spinosauras spawned too close to your base. However, eventually you will learn how to keep your base safe and tame even the most dangerous of dinosaurs (with very few exceptions). There are a lot of customization options though to cater the gameplay to your preferences. For example, you can easily increase resource acquisition, speed up taming times, strengthen/weaken wild dinos, etc. Additionally this game is very moddable which makes the game significantly more replayable.

The game does have some flaws though. It has plenty of jankiness, especially in online play. Some examples: logging into a server to find you dinos somehow wandered through your solid walls and ending up in random places, sometimes getting killed in the process. The building can also be annoying, with mods being all but a requirement, so if you're coming from a game like Valheim don't expect the same building experience. With some mods though and a bit of patience, you can build some really cool bases.

One final warning: this game requires a LOT of hard drive space, especially if you intend to play the dlc or bonus maps. It can easily take 200-300+ Gigabytes of space. 

In summary, if you enjoy survival games, then Ark is an easy recommendation.

Highly recommend it!

I have not been able to take my eyes away from this game, and I haven't even loaded in yet!
The Devs have done such a perfect job of encapsulating the best loading experience for the player.

Not to mention the logo looks great in the bottom right corner!

Most would look at this game and believe that all there is to it is what is obvious.  Level.  Build.  Tame.  Then go fight a boss.  And while that is the real meat and potatoes to all of it, there's other bits that really bring out the flavor.  I have raised a village from the ground up.  I have owned a tavern, jousted on the backs of all sorts of creatures.  Hosted pit fights with both men and dinosaurs.  I've destroyed others while also being crushed myself.  Hell I've even developed a currency system out of chitin and colored gems that a server full of folks genuinely enjoyed.

What you should take from this game, if anything, is it's incredible potential to bring people together.  Both for the better, and well... the not so better.

Ark Survival Evolved is one of my favorite games, and 100% my favorite survival games. The two most important things to know about this game are:

 1.) You will die. A lot. Then you will build a base and get stronger armor and your own dinos. And you will get your sh*t wrecked by even bigger and tougher enemies. And this will make you rage quit, and then come right back. 

2.) This game is full of wonder and adventure. Exploring each map, meeting each different dino, uncovering Lore notes and discovering just why you are here. It will keep you on your toes looking for more. Each map is different and Unique and full of surprises and challenges. 

You can play this game solo, but its 100% more fun with friends, even if its just one or two more people. The modding community is great and so very creative and just when you've grown bored of the base game, they've got something to reignite that spark for you. 

Also, your settings for the maps are wildly customizable, so if you've lost your patience with dying 25 times, you can go in and adjust the difficulty of the map with things like your resistance, enemies resistance, spawn rates, and how good your loot is. Ooor, you can turn everything up and challenge yourself further if you feel you're doing pretty good, its all up to you. 

Fair warning, this game will burn your free time. You will sit down to play for just a few hours and before you even know it poof your weekend is gone lol

We rent a server with my family and play PVE mode together.  It's a lot of fun and a great way to spend more time together. An additional note: renting a server takes a huge amount of processing off of your PC and allows you to play at better quality with a less powerful computer.

Coming from someone that is not much of a modern gamer, this game has caught my attention. Truly a phenomenal master piece. You are free to do whatever you wish in this game. From building, to crafting, to hunting, to taming dinosaurs, to deep sea diving, to flying, to killing, to talking, to creating. Whatever you wish to do that other games doesn't have accessible, this game has in abundance. Blows games like call of duty, grand theft auto, and league of legends out the water! All the games listed has limitations that shouldn't be limited in 2022, and that makes Ark is just the perfect game to play in this time in life. This game is still ahead of its time, i am shocked it isn't as popular as all the latter games. This game is perfect for people that tests the limitations of gaming. PVP or PVE, loads of hours to play and much more to achieve than the regular game. Can be relaxing and adrenaline pumping all in one session. Beautiful game, hard to beat this concept of gaming.

[b] Highly recommend this game.  I have an additional ~300+ hours on the PlayStation 4 version. I mostly play single player, but it is much more fun and less time consuming to play with friends. Try to get it while it's on sale, it's definitely a huge bang for your buck. [/b]

You will learn how to play through trial and error(or just search up a YouTube tutorial on the basics, lol). If you like the accomplishment of working toward long-term goals, this is the game for you. If you care about your tames, then sob when they get stuck in a river and succumb to a pack of prehistoric jellyfish, this is the game for you. If you need instant gratification upon opening the game, or dislike grinding, this is definitely not for you. Get used to dying, it is inevitable. 

This game requires a massive amount of time and patience to progress through, but trust me, it is worth it in the end.

Best dinosaur game of all time.

... Also biggest hate-love relationship of any game I have played ...

You can really lose yourself in this world, extremely immersive. Beautiful world, dinosaurs, exploration, undersea stuff (One of the best underwater experiences in any game to date), RPG mechanics, building... Like legit has everything...

The frustrating parts were bugs and glitches, many of which I think are resolved now, but caused many ragequits / loss of hours and hours of progress etc back in the day. There are also some really *really* annoying dinosaurs, and the settings could use some tweaking which brings me to my next point..

The "hardest" part was tweaking settings so it felt balanced but still challenging, removing or lowering spawn rate of a few super annoying dinos, updating the loot beacon drops (thank you beacon app), changing XP rates, altering when engrams are unlocked, adjusting player stats... But after going through and tweaking everything to be *just right* (for me), it is hard to find much to complain about.

There are a LOT of hours of fun here, just be prepared to not leave the house for a few days.

I do like this game, but my god the file size with all maps installed is bonkers.  Don't worry, you can install/uninstall them piece-meal.  On the other hand, the reason the files are so big are the graphics.  If you have a high end computer the graphics are gorgeous.  If you don't, you can crank the graphics way down.  It will definitely change the overall experience, but hey, you can at least run it.

There isn't a lot of direction in the game.  There aren't quests to guide you, it's more of an upgrade route to follow.  You want to kill/capture that dino?  Get a better weapon/gear -> better materials -> better (more appropriate) weapon/gear loop.  The xpacs offer some rewards for completing specific things, but it's skippable.  I prefer games with quests over blindly exploring, but you will usually find something cool if you just decide to go in a random direction to see what's there.  Oh and death.  Lots of death.  Unless you change the difficulty/health/lighting/resources.  There's pretty much a slider for everything. 
 So you want a punishing game?  Got it.  You want a casual tourist game?  More or less got that too.  Plus there is a creative mode.

Crafting.  I play this game solo, so I've made resource drops a bit faster for my own sanity, but not too easy either.  I don't really have an issue with the crafting itself, though some materials will tie you in knots trying to get enough of them to do what you want.  My issue is with the building.  W.t.f. game.  Why can't I lay my foundations where I want them.   Why can't I clip walls where in any sane world a wall could actually be.  You can build some pretty amazing stuff in this game, but if you try to do it, you too will know my pain.  I've uninstalled this game so many times just because I got mad when I couldn't build a flat platform without doing some crazy trick using pillars and ceiling tiles and fence foundations.  There's guides for this sort of thing, but I wish the devs could have devoted a bit more time into solving some of these quirks.  This is going to be a non-issue for a lot of players, but if you are into building you are going to have to look up tips to find out how you can create what you had in mind.  There's also codes to spawn whatever you want, so if you don't want to spend hours regathering resources when something didn't work they way you thought it would, you can just spawn it in for yourself.  

They actually add new dinos and new maps at a good pace but it might not be enough though to bring you back to the game if you don't enjoy repeating what you've already completed on a different play through.

I can't recommend multiplayer unless you are on a private server (which I've never played).  I've just played where one player is the host and another player joins the game (which was me).  It was ... frustrating.  There is a somewhat short tether distance where if you try to walk too far from the other player you will hit an invisible wall.  If you are at or close to that wall when your friend walks the opposite direction, it will drag you.  Drag you off cliffs.  Drag you into the swamp (lots of things want to kill you there).  Drag you into lava...  Your character is overloaded and can't move?  Don't worry, your friend can drag you back to base!  I just hope you survive the trip.

Overall yes, I enjoyed it.  Yes I would recommend it.  It IS more fun with your friends, but you might also need a lot of patience for it.  GL

You can make a dino strip club... If you're prepared to lose 300GB of space.

Don't get me wrong, this game is wonderful. Big open worlds with tons to explore and a plethora of creative freedom to be had alone or with friends. I actually made a dino strip club once... Yeah you can actually do that. If you have an idea of a thing you want to build or create, you can probably achieve that in Ark. From building amazing fortresses across beautiful landscapes to taming a super wide range and diverse amount of creatures, this game offers plenty to keep the game fresh and inspirational. Genuinely one of my favourite games to play.

The downsides are:
1) It is unnecessarily massive. At least 300GB by the time you get extra maps etc... To the point where some people want to play it but can't due to its ridiculous size.

2) Some of the bosses are mental. You'd need at least 50 people and a ton of dinos to beat some of the bigger bosses. Realistically you'll end up spawning things in or using console commands in some way.

3) Finally; progression is slow in the long run. To genuinely unlock tekgrams etc you'd need to beat a ton of bosses on hardest difficulties which requires more hours than we're currently able to live for. So again, you'll likely just unlock things using commands.

I've played this game for almost 400 hours now and still get inspired to do new things all the time. I just hope one day they can focus on the gargantuan file size.
