The ARK has evolved into a gaming masterpiece since its days in early access. The maps are massive, lush and beautiful. The crafting is fun, and I personally find harvesting cathartic. The creatures in this immersive world are filled with life and purpose; with a majority of them serving as tamable vehicles for harvesting. If you were one of those kids with dinosaur sheets on your bed that dreamed of becoming a Paleontologist, this is the closest (I know) you can live out that ignorant fantasy.

Unfortunately, these creatures have the AI and will of a Terminator once they agro. You pray for glitches, you hope the creature traps itself on a rock, a tree, or some clueless dumb leaf eater decides to walk out the bushes and sacrifice itself for your escape. These creatures want nothing more than to tear your eyes out and laugh as you desperately run miles through an endless terrain searching for your corpse before nightfall, only to find your merciless cold blooded killer waiting for you to try and snatch your body from under its feet. That was fun right? "We have such sights to show you" - Hellraiser

If you have ever had the pleasure of playing the ARK, Im sure your more than familiar with how local players say hello. I do have to say, it is truly amazing that a game has the ability to cause so much PTSD, your questioning the legitimacy of your social relationships outside its coding. You don't trust anyone in the ARK! There is no room for weakness here. If you want to survive, you turn off all emotions in/out of the game because that is the savage mindset that knows only victory. You think those 30 sentry guns, Giga, Rex, Wyvern and rock golem stand a chance against bob, nooo! Bob is f-in crazy! If you see an idiot picking berries anywhere near your base, you implement operation psychological warfare. You recon, patrol and when he least expects it, you roll up on the most badass tame you got and say "Hey friend, my name is friendly and I'm here to help." 2 weeks of futile promises and grooming, you raid that berry picken hippies base at 4am Europe Time Zone, because you know he has to attend his Aunt's funeral at 8am. MUHAHAH who has the bullets now berry! Right? Wrong! Berry was a recruit sent by the Alpha tribe "Script Kiddies", u know that invisible base that has a no fly zone that manically grows overnight.

Then one day, you log on and you see it, the blue screen;  casually asking where you would like to spawn as if you never been here before. As you spawn in and walk twords your bases location, your heart, mind and soul is preparing for what you already know has happened. You hallucinate smoke coming up over the hill where your base wont be. It's gone. Everything is gone. All your tames were killed and probably eaten. The game became a job and your 401k ended up in the hands of a sadistic 15 yr old named "Haha" LVL 1, from Tribe "thanks for all your stuff". You are now an idiot.

After mending your relationships, you realize for 1500 hours, you got years of jokes about the time you traded your life to live with extinct animals and the ability to quietly assure yourself you know more than the Chicago Museum tour guide. A true savage never leaves the jungle ;)

I can earnestly say that 80% of the time I'm fighting the game itself instead of enjoying the gameplay.

The majority of the struggles I experienced would instantly disappear with a crafting UI rework. You will develop a workflow to crafting and building, only to have it smashed to bits as your crafting list gets shuffled around every time you learn something new. The folder sort seems the best choice, which is tragic because instead of hovering and pressing a single key in the list (usable! fast!), you are now double clicking in a sea of scattered category folders. That sorting isn't any better. Want to build a Wooden Triangle Foundation? It's not in the "Structures > Wood" category. Nope, it's in the "Wood" category! But a Wooden Wall is in "Structures > Wood." Got it? Want to build a roof for your house? I hope you can read, because the icons for "Wooden Ceiling" and "Sloped Wooden Woof" are identical. How about a hatch vs. a window? Well, the "hatch" icon is a rotated "window" icon - hope you know which one is which.

Notice how I haven't said anything about the joys of dino taming or the beautiful combat - because there are no joys or beauty, just Unreal Engine glitching out at you while you attempt to shoot tranq arrows at dinos that haven't caught up from their desync. You'll see them bleed, but nothing will actually register. Sometimes? Then, after 10 minutes of chasing them, they will glitch inside of you as they pass out, pinning you in mid-air, ripe for the Carnotaurus that just spawned in front of your face. Sometimes they skip the fanfare and go straight for the glitch, which is preferred, because I would rather suffer instantly than have it drawn out over 10 minutes. Sometimes?

All in all this game is fine and fun, but sometimes it can be so brutally, infuriatingly punishing in undeserved ways - especially if you don't know how to "play the game." I suggest you join an accelerated server (3x, 15x) and get to the meat, because learning how this game works is a process of never-ending, consummate suffering. I'm perfectly happy being Bob the Basic Bitch Builder, because the very idea of learning anything else in this game is stressful. Here's to ARK 2, glad they got Vin Diesel aboard I guess?

OK. This game is amazing, BUT everything about the gameplay sucks. The devs only want money, that is why they constantly have more DLCs. But they neglect the actual game, the mechanics. Instead of trying to fix the performance issues or add things to the old maps, whick people love, they only pump out more DLCs. Here are a few things I find problematic:

- The flight system is too clunky and awkward.
- It is too easy to cheat when playing singleplayer.
- Even though it is a survival game, it feels more like a simulator, because you can change anything at anytime, basically cheating.
- After getting a few mounts, the main aspect, survival, falls apart and it becomes an RPG.
- The devs have had many YEARS to fix the performance issues, but it still runs absolutely terrible.
- The AI of tamed dinos are horrible. They will constantly walk off cliffs and die. Even when you walk slowly, dinos that follow you constantly move in circles behind you, instead of just following your path in a straight line.

So to summarise, this game and mechanics are amazing, but the gameplay is bad. The performance and AI is  bad and it is too easy to cheat, whick makes it feel more like a simulator.

Ark is a great game. The PVP can be really nasty but that is kinda the point of "PVP".. It is really fun and exhilarating... Where I feel the game shines is in its PVE server... Each map has different bosses to work your way up and beat and some maps even let your character ascend higher than the initial level cap of 105 to the level of 180!.. It feels rewarding to reach higher levels to unlock things like tek gear and mechanics... I've played Ark since BETA and this game has changed sooo much since then.. I really enjoy it and feel there is enough content to keep you playing for a while.. dino breeding to take on boss's with 3 different difficulty levels makes you want to max out the stats of the dino's your breeding... its great...

Played ark on my Xbox one then Xbox series X and again on pc. This game is really fun especially for dinosaur lovers like me and many others. Mods make it a little easier at times. Game can crash if your running on high settings but my PC is pretty beefy so i don't have it happen to me. The DLCs add even more fun/play-ability. Exploring different maps and taming different creatures is a blast especially with a group of friends. Some bad things i can say are: Game play can be repetitive, there are no secondary saves so you are stuck with the singleplayer world you have. PvP is a mess unless you know wassup. But its super easy to sink hundreds of hours into it as i have over 1000 on my xbox. Would recommend

I've tried it for half an hour.

Technical problems:
The game first tried to run in windowed mode and 1600 by 900 resolution instead of 1920x1080. Changing to 1920x1080 did nothing at first. I had to switch back and forth.

Game mechanics:
There is no handholding or introduction to the environment. You have to figure out everything on your own. You wake up on the beach and... Nothing happens. No voices or quests or anything. There are no tooltips to indicate what items are interactable. You cannot see the level of enemies and whether they are friendly or not. A level 32 dino killed me in a starting area marked Easy. I became hungry and started suffering because of it fast.

I paid very little for the game and I am not going to refund it but playing it? Only if there are mods to fix what I cannot stand. A very strange game. I guess it is what Survival means after all but I don't like it.

This game can be both fun and frustrating at the same time.   Fun meaning the initial stress of building up and surviving in the game map can be intense with the excitement of your first tame and riding it.  Frustrating due to huge game size, crashes, getting killed multiple times when first spawning in, and waiting for mods to install if you want to play on a unofficial server.  

1 - My advice is your playing solo game selection is to load 1 mod at a time and keep it to under 12 mods.  Also, never rely on game to keep your save intact.  I've lost 25 hours of building because game crashed and corrupted my files.  Personally,  made a shortcut to ark > shooter game > saved.  Depending on what your doing in game (building, dino leveling) created two seperate folders to manually backup the game files every 30-60 minutes.  Better to lose 60 minutes than 50 hours.

2 -Use local files scan to check games files often. (It will take awhile).

3- Play with buddies if possible or a descent tribe on pvp.

4- Play on xbox game pass to try it out or wait for a good discount before buying.

Guide to ark.

1. Buy game
2. Download game ( its a BIIIGG one )
3. Play game
4. Land a custom ark ( There a bit more easy then story arks )
5. Dont land redwoods 
6. As soon as you land into a ark assess your surroundings, if you see a carno just accept your death or RUN!!!
7. Get a rock and hit a tree minecraft style.
8. Hit a rock with ur rock to get flint and craft a pick and axe.
9. Craft many bolas to trap raptors that come to munch you.
10. Use a bola to trap a pt and use a bow and arrows ( which i forgot to tell you to craft earlier )
11. Get to level 16 ( i think ?? ) to unlock the pt saddle
12. Take to the skies, explore, steal a wyvern egg, start a  family, do what you want.

Hope you enjoyed this review/ guide, BTW it is a wonderful game, no complaints :).

The game is really fun, exciting and very beautiful. It has a story with several bosses, and a lot of different dinosaurs to play around with. There is a lot of technology to learn as well (Weapons, defense item e.g).

Why the negative rating?
Well, to put it simply.... the game runs like horsepoo. You would expect an old game to be stable, but ARK lets you down. There is endless bugs and even game breaking glitches. Some of these glitches and bugs have been here for years. Why have they not been fixed? Because the game developers simply don't care about the game itself. They have made quite a bit of DLC's that cost A LOT for what you actually recieve. The devs, have become a lot like Microsoft and EA, money over satisfaction.

Ark is a fun single or multi-player game that has contains so many opportunities to advance and provides so much time to complete the game.  There is really no end to the game unless you count defeating all the bosses, there are lots of things harder than defeating the bosses.  Adding on to the abilities of the game itself, the mods are some of the best mods I have seen for any game.  Primal fear is such a well produced mod that looks like Wildcard made it themselves.  Ark is often on sale during holidays, I have seen it sell for under $10, and I would 100% recommend purchasing Ark if its on sale.  Just be aware you might need to lower graphics as it can be a very needy game.  If you play on official PVP servers then be aware that you have to play like 12 hours a day just to survive for a week, there are so many mega tribes in ark that will kill any solo or small tribes.  Most solo players only last by uploading all their loot into drops or obs.  If you don't have time to play multiple hours a day, then you should stick to single-player or servers with just your friends.

This game allows me to relive those halcyon days of my autistic obsession with dinosaurs with a bit of Minecraft and Turok-esque flare thrown in for good measure. I actually first bought this game when it first released in Early Access back in 2015 but I could never play it because my PC was garbage at the time.. I didn't sincerely get a legitimate opportunity to play it until about 2019 but I even held back then because I didn't feel like allocating the MASSIVE amount of space required just to install the damned thing. 

Now that I got a rig that can handle it I cam finally play out all my childhood fantasies of taming dinos with rocket launchers n' shit.

What can I say about Ark? Well..

Ark is a special game for me. It was one of the first survival multiplayer games I ever played. I started back when Scorched Earth had just come out and was still on my old account. But, just like even now, I loved every second of it.

Ark has a way of mesmerizing people who play it. Despite it seeming to be outdated at times graphically, it runs extremely well. For a long time I switched over to Conan due to the RP mechanics and items it had. But, with a little bit of modding, you can get those similar adjustments. (I highly recommend Castles. Keeps, and Forts but to each his own). In spite of Arks numerous flaws, I cannot help but find myself attached to it by the hip.

I have 150 hours on my original account. 447 at the time of this review here. Plus an unknown amount on PS4 (which I played with my girlfriend before her computer could handle PC version). I cannot recommend this game enough for those who enjoy this genre and the elements presented. If you like dragons, dinos, and guns? It's all there for you. If you wanna be a viking and rough it out there with no weapons that are space age? There is stuff for you too with primitive and such. It's a blast.

9/10. Mad you don't have more in-game cosmetics and RP elements built in, but still love you and your awesome dino's all the same. Will most likely plug many more hours into it (hype as all hell for Fjordur).

Lets talk about this game.. This mess of a game... I love this game! I love the taming, I love the adventures with friends. And I love that there is so much to do in this game. It is a time sync from hell so if you don't have the time I would not even bother enless you are playing on a private server. There is a lot of things you can do in this game but it will also frustrate the hell out of you. And to top it all off it you play on a pvp server. You will be flying around and bases spawn in late and suddenly you have 12 heavy turrets pointing at you. 

Despite all of its negatives, it is a game that I always find myself coming back to just simply for the adventures and the fun. I know people that have over 8k+ hours in this game and they wouldn't take back a moment of it. Avoid pvp when you first start playing enless you have friends to play with. Matter of opinion ofcourse.

Good luck survivors! And may the odds forever be in your favor.

It's a good game, with two probably fatal flaws that are dealbreakers for most people
1: load times on a HDD are absolute ass
2: The game with no DLC is 100GB, and with all of the DLC added up is almost 400GB. (which is ludicrous to say the least)
3: Outgoing Reliable Buffer Overflow, You will see this error a LOT if you play on non dedicated servers and have to have your player data reset.

If you can look past these just buy it already, if not, well either find another game or buy a really big SSD, at least the download is compressed to only 1/10th the size.

For years this game has been a balance between engaging with amazing potential and trying to overcome the frustration from persistent issues and absent, arguably negligent support.
Whether those issues arise from incompetent development, executive decisions to focus on new content instead of repair or just an abject failure to adequately provision hosting, by now it's largely irrelevant.
At the end of the day, the game is broken and the developers don't care. They already have your money.

Do not Buy this game. Its so buggy and it will cost you everything. You spent a week getting ready to tame a dino. the game will bug you will some how die. and your dino will die before you can get back to it. the game will time you out. and the smallest of creatures will kill you. or itll read your still in game, and your tame your ridding will sit there and die. tames can move for no reason, so expect them to run off sometimes and just die getting ganked in a wall. Building is broken unless you build next to no walls. so you better be with a squad cause if you are a solo or duo you cannot build in the open or itll get raided pvp. and pve people will block off every good spot to build even if they are not living there. they will block off all the loot drops so only they can get them. This game has so many broken bugs since day one it blows my mind. night time is pitch black. so you have to not play for what ever the amount of time night is which is so inconsiderate to people who cant play non stop but thats not even a huge issue. its the amount of bugs. rubber banding is horrible. you can get warped backwards into a dinos mouth and die. you can try to close a gate on a mount and die cause it nocked you off instead of closing the gate. you can be on a water mount and get timed out so you float and drown. all these will happen 100% so unless your cool with actually wasting days worth farming casue of bugs dont buy this game.

Played Ark on PS4 for a couple years but recently upgraded to a gaming PC instead on opting for the PS5. The mouse and keyboard controls took a bit of getting used to but I'm almost there. 
When you drop into Ark for the first time, it takes a bit of getting used to, I'd say more than most games. But after some rude awakenings such as, getting killed by a turtle you just punched and starving to death, you start to get the hang of it. Ark offers many worlds you can explore and build on. The crafting inventory is vast and overall the game provides just the right difficulty with a bit of comedic relief when you drown a friend! 

I'd give Ark and 8/10 and a must play for those who are into open world crafting and survival games. Nothing beats trapping and taming a wild lvl 300 Giga for the first time.
100% love this game.  Prepare to lose all your time on it! Super addictive!!

You can choose to play on large servers or create an local map or server on your pc, like i did. Great game to play with friends.

If you have played minecraft then this game takes it to another level. Remember, this is not an easy game, there are always predators ready to kill you when you spawn. This game is great with friends, lots of content, never ending adventures if you keep exploring various maps. Each map has unique locations to make your base, explore new biomes, do boss fights, and even PvP if you want to experience a battle between tribes. There are official servers which are mostly full but they keep adding new servers to play. They are also working on new creatures most of the time as we speak. 

Some maps of this game are really old like Island which are not highly optimised but they still work decent on a GPU like GTX 1060. Don't think that the game is really bad optimised because considering the time this was released, there weren't many games like this.

So many new maps and we can't forget that Ark 2 is also in development which is based on Unreal Engine 5 and you will be able to see Vin Diesel in it.
Super Excited for it to launch, go watch the trailer if you haven't.

Note: Would not consider buying this if you don't have a decent GPU. It's a heavy game.

This game is custom adventurer's paradise. Don't like something? Change the settings. Want More? Get a mod. Easy to customize almost anything your heart desires with a huge community to support you. As great as it is, there are always downsides. Survival in ARK means eating and drinking and pooping and managing those things to your benefit. Taming Dino's is great. Combat sucks. It's basically clicking till something dies. Building is awesome, though hauling materials to and from your base is tedious. The game is truly great with the right settings and utterly horrible with the wrong ones. I wouldn't play it without mods, especially structure and cosmetic mods, and not without adjusted taming speeds etc.

It's not optimized as well as other games (the Recommended specs should actually be the Minimum in my opinion). It's buggy in places but in my experience these are very few and far between. It does not hold your hand, not even a little bit. These are perhaps the only "bad" points I would perhaps mention to a prospective buyer. 

HOWEVER!!

The sheer size and scope of the developers dream is missed by a lot of players. This game is massive! Admittedly, I only play in single player. This is fine for me and is completely do-able. Yes, you can solo the ARK as many YouTubers can show you. The single player experience can be tweaked to accommodate almost any player. From the younger to the mature, from the casual to the hardcore, from the fast pace lovers to the hard-slog purists. It's all possible from the game settings menu.
For a Single Player experience just click on Host/Local and this will take you to your game settings for whatever play style you want. It does require some research as to what each setting is/does but once this has been sorted, and you have the settings tuned nicely to you, you will have a game that will keep you entertained for several weeks on a single playthrough (if you are a gaming God & dependant on settings) but more likely for months and years.
It is a sandbox game, with a storyline, that has been done in such a seemless fashion that you can play it in a purely sandbox style but you can also follow the story. No other game I know of , and in my opinion, has managed to present a true sandbox game, with a story, and it remained a true sandbox. 
Then there is ARK: Survival Evolved.

So, should you buy? Well ARK 2 is on the horizon. You could wait and see if it is optomized any better but then it will probably require an even beefier pc than it's older sibling. I believe ARK is worth every penny even at full price but seeing as it has been around for 6 years you should be able to grab it at some point for a reduced price. If you do decide to try it, I wish you many, many hours of thoroughly enjoyable gaming.

I really want to like this game.. But it is not worth the headache. Im sure this negative review does not matter much, as the game is so old and they have already cashed in on the community, but I wanted to share my frustration. This is one of the first PC games I purchased years ago, and I had only played like 3 hours. I recently talked my friend into buying it w/ all the DLC so we could play multiplayer. My other friend bought a server for us. Only to find out, I cant join any servers due to Fatal Error Line 516!!! I'd understand if this was a rare and random occasion, but upon troubleshooting the problem and finding no solution, I found that this kind of thing has happened many times to many ppl in the past. They, like myself, probably gave up on this broken game. Wanted to get Ark 2, but I dont think I can trust these Devs to not repeat this same fuckery, so I probably wont. Long story short, good game but poorly managed with many issues.
 
*Editing 2 months later. Still no solution in sight. If I could light this game on fire without damaging my pc, I would. There is no reason a game should be this difficult to troubleshoot, and no reason a largely PvP based game wont allow me to join any servers. I will not be buying ur new game, Ark 2, becuz u have shown me what u consider a "final product" and u have also shown me ur lack of support for gamebreaking issues! I made a support thread on your official website 2 months ago!!! Garbage!!!

*Another month and no solution. My support tickets have been met with automated systems sending me troubleshooting links that I have already spent hours tearing through potential solutions. I need a real person to give me definitive solution and it seems they are unwilling or unable to do so. Im sure Ark 2 will be as good a game as this, but know before u buy it that if u encounter a game breaking issue like mine, u will probably be given a big middle finger. They already have ur money, these Fukks hold all the leverage at that point. Good luck gamers, companies like these are ruining gaming.

This has perhaps been the most fun I've ever had playing a video game, and by far my favorite of all time. 
Unfortunately, it suffers immensely from requiring an ungodly PC strength and more than your fair share of error message know-how, but with some elbow grease, you can get the expected result, eventually.

Open world sandbox dino game that I personally think everyone should play at least once. It can be challenging and official servers can be a grinder's paradise, but if you rent out your own server and just play with some friends I firmly believe this game is one of the best out there.

This game is the sunken cost fallacy. It is unplayable without mods and finding a server with just the right amount of mods is very difficult. Usually I've joined friends who set up servers to the general expectations of the friend group. Also if you don't have at least 3 other guys who want to play this game don't bother. Finally, there are bugs in this game that have existed since launch. The developers do not want to fix any bug ever unless they have to and have banned people before who genuinely want to help the devs fix bugs. From dinosaurs that you're supposed to spend hours trying to tame falling through the map, getting stuck, or randomly dying you'll deal with a lot of bugs that make you want to quit. If this game goes on sale for like $5 and you have some guys who want to get it or already have it maybe consider it. Otherwise know that the devs took a dlc out of a season pass and renamed it as Atlas to try to take just a bit more money from their player base. Why do I still play it with nearly 2000 hours then? Sunken Cost Fallacy.

Ark. Ark, oh Ark.

This game. 

There is so much I can say about this game.

It's a piece of crap that's currently taking up almost 400 gb of storage on my hard drive. It's a glitchy mess, I often have to verify the game files to work with it, and there was one time I had to uninstall and reinstall the whole 400gbs of this mess because oh, something happened, I suppose. It's often hard to play with friends, because you have to either host your own "non-dedicated session" (which doesn't work half the time), find a server (which, well... it's a public server. things happen), or buy your own server. It's hard to work with, DOESN'T work sometimes, and it requires a lot of patience.

But man if it isn't worth it.

At the time of writing this review, Steam says I have over a thousand hours put into this game. Which... yeah, makes sense. It's an addictingly fun game with great graphics (most of the time) and a great environment to play in. I generally play alone or with a small group of friends, and I've had more fun in this game with my friends than I have in any other! Yes, despite the headaches and the bugs and the mess. It gives you the freedom to build whatever you want, tame whatever you want, to adventure as far as you wish to go... and, most of all, it lets you get attached to these fake creatures. You can get attached and love a creature, and then Ark can violently rip that attachment away from you because Things Just Happen Sometimes. It's simultaneously the best and the worst thing this game can do to you, and I wouldn't trade it for the world.

Yes, this game is stupid, and terrible, and it sucks. But, more than anything, it's amazing, and beautiful, and heartwrenching, and fun, and absolutely worth it. It's one of my most favorite games ever, and I will never not support it. I wouldn't buy all the DLC and play over a thousand hours of just any game, after all.

Really good game. I have been looking for a solid survival game for a long time. You can play this co-op with local players or online. There is a good balance of combat and building. The progression of skills is good. This game is super fun and customizable. You can make the game harder if you want to. 

The main drawback of this game for me is how often it updates. It is incredibly frustrating. It feels like every time I want to play this game, I must wait an hour or more for updates to finish. 

I have not played online, so I couldn't say what that is like. I appreciate the ability to play locally or single player. Massively multiplayer games are not usually something I enjoy and a lot of survival games are only multiplayer online. 

I recommend this game highly. Crafting, taming, exploring, combat, adventure - this game really has it all.

however as a somewhat experienced player i would recommend new players to start in single player with a few friends, or play on a private server as official servers can be quite toxic, however i will warn you this game is not for the faint of heart it is designed to be challenging and even brutal, though it is also very configurable though i warn you many people take this feature to extremes, personally i believe the default single player settings provide a fairly balanced experience while remaining challenging as the designers intended, though i would recommenced using pve for your single player as well you might want to increase the tether distance which is honestly silly as increasing it has a negligible impact on resources for the host.

So I've accumulated about 4,000+ hours across PC-PS4. And by now I'm certain I can give an honest review about this game. 
It's amazing. If you like taming dinosaurs, exploring with friends, riding dragons(wyverns), and getting your entire base destroyed in 3 minutes then you'll love this game. If you're afraid of the Official PVP side of this game, but still want some PVP action, go ahead and try the Unofficial PVP servers. They're a good introduction to what PVP life is like. If you do however decide to try Official PVP, be prepared to sink at least 5-6 hours daily, and thats on the low end. If you got the time, and the patience to learn everything, and dealing with getting wiped here and there, then you'll absolutely love this game. 

P.S  : Don't trust other players. Ever.

9/10

Running a Server is a nightmare, game is buggy as hell, grindy (but the bad grindy not the good grindy), unoptimized and only fun when playing coop on a private server but that's impossible to do without buying some dumb online server provider because running one on your own server is horrible because the server software sucks

Yes it has a lot of bugs, yes it's lacking optimization, yes the Official server playerbase sucks both on PVP and PVE, but trust me, join their discord and go to the PVE Servers channel. There, you'll find loads of big and small unofficial communities for ARK. They will change your mind about this game in a positive way. I have read many negative reviews for this game, and they ALL have ONE thing in common: They criticize the game after the Official PVP and PVE servers. Look, I'm not gonna deny it, Official servers are absolute bullshit, the player base is toxic as shit, and there's literally no game there for newcomers. What I don't agree with is that they downvote the whole entire game for that. People, official servers are not the only ones out there. Unofficial servers, dedicated servers with your friends or even solo, these make up the good part of the game. Please do not criticize the game if you don't like PVP. A lot of us dislike it, including me, so just don't play PVP. PVE exists, play that instead, and remember to never hop onto officials. You'll find the game much more enjoyable if you play on the mode you like best. If you also dislike PVE unofficials, dedicated servers with friends and solo, then yes, feel free to complain about the game. If you're scrolling though reviews, please avoid the ones that solely talk about the PVP aspect of the game. Bugs are very common, yes, but I do believe that if you get a good enough grip on this game, they won't bother you nearly as much. I highly recommend you try this game out for yourself, and don't let the negative reviews ruin your first impressions. You can always refund it if you don't like it.

Used to be a good game, with every new DLC ( which were not very good investments ) there was an entirely new overpowered meta. Not to mention that you can't obtain these new broken features without paying for and downloading the chunky DLC in the first place. Instead of fixing the game, stopping cheaters, meshers, etc, the developers of ARK have decided to push out more downloadable content, more paywalled creatures and maps. All of these things almost seem like they are completely designed to make the game miserable, boring, and frustrating to play, which has already driven majority of the playerbase off years ago. Not to mention the fact this game is littered with glitches that seek to ruin your fun. If you want to play on any multiplayer server, be ready to time out and disconnect at the worst times possible. Be ready for massive frame drops, be ready for poor game design. The game is NOT fun on single player because it was designed to be a multiplayer game, but every update would just scare more and more players off. Overall, this game is massively mediocre, had so much potential and was completely thrown away.

I tried, alright? 74 hours is not a small amount of play time. It's not fun to me. It's a tedious and frustrating experience where every hard earned win is quickly squandered by a quick and punishing failure. It's not satisfying to spend 2 hours crafting basic gear only to die to a level 130 raptor coming from behind you and killing you in just a few hits. 

But, I'm the odd one out, so perhaps all of this is fine to most folks. I'm sure you can enjoy the game then. But for me, and anyone like me, I cannot find any fun in this game. I know it gets better when you unlock more of the fun things to do in the game, but starting out, it feels so punishing and deadly that you just feel stuck, unable to do anything to progress without being killed and wasting more and more time trying to get back to the same place you where before you died.

It is a sand box game with all sorts of dinosaurs and other prehistoric creatures that you can tame and ride. In the end there are big bosses to fight. Microraptors are the worst though.

Has the potential to be a good game but is currently a waste of your time. Game itself is great, you can spend a full week Farming resources, building a base, taming some useful dinos and exploring the map. However you will wake up one morning exited to log onto the game only to find that someone that doesn't even live on the same server or even the same map as you has jumped over to your server and destroyed your base, emptied all your items onto the floor to despawn and killed all your tames (Most of which will have taken hours to tame) they will do this with creatures and items that don't even exist on your map.

If they created an official server that doesn't allow people to just hop over from another server and destroy everything then i would definitely come back to playing this game and i'm sure many more people would too, Raiding and fighting other tribes is part of the game, but only fun if you can see and interact with your enemies. It has the potential to have a map filled with different tribes all competing with eachother but this cant happen because your not only competing with the tribes living on the server with you, but also with tribes of 300+ people on other maps that have been around for months and exist only to hop between maps and wipe out tribes that have no defence against them. 

I'm not saying remove the ability to transfer between maps, But you could easily create an official server that is isolated from the rest and does not have this feature enabled. It would make the game actually fair and worth putting time into playing.

Awesome game if you stick with single player mode. The start is very rough and unfair actually but it's fitting. Ark was my first survival game and i love it. I originally got it for free on Epic but I enjoyed the game so much that I bought it and all of its DLCs on Steam. Also building mods are awesome. I love the building aspect so so so much. It's not very well optimized in terms of performance and eats up 400GB and also has a lot of bugs. I didn't play much on the Steam version unfortunately because it takes up too much space but I just remembered how much I enjoyed the game. I was obsessed with dinos as a kid and this game rekindled my love for dinosaurs even though I'm a 23 year old man now. The dinos and the building feature are the best thing. Also the DLC maps are great and the storyline albeit basic is cool too. It's like Minecraft but with dinosaurs. I never touched Minecraft because it's a kids game although it was interesting with the creativity and building stuff but it lacked dinos. I'm so happy a came across ARK. 
If you love Dinosaurs or prehistoric creatures overall and creative building then this game is the game for you. 
I feel like a little kid with the same passion for dinosaurs back then whenever I play this game.

This game is amazingly fun and I love the concept. It has its issues. They're pretty significant issues, but they would not stop me from buying it again if I got a chance or from recommending it to others. It's a fun, unique survival game that's actually a really fun concept. I think in the end that it was too ambitious for Wildcard's abilities at the time. While you can play official if you so choose, I highly recommend either getting your own server (as low as $13 a month from someplace like Nitrado) that you yourself can administrate or find a good server that's privately owned with active administrators. That's, IMO, the best way to experience the game since the major issues can be overcome with access to an admin account.

I had high hopes for this game, but between it's clunky UI and generally glitchy behavior, I couldn't take it anymore.  I'd like to note that the described experiences are entirely on a private server with no PvP.

Things I liked: 
*Taming the dinos has some interesting challenges and was quite a bit of fun.
*Using dinos to collect resources is pretty cool.
*arrows are automatically picked up when you walk over them

(some of the) Things I didn't like:
*The building in this game is about the worst I've ever experienced in any survival game because you have to prefabricate everything.  Also having any reasonable amount of building resources is way too much weight to carry.
*Setting dino behavior is very clunky and hard to do quickly which can result in large losses of investment in dinos due to them engaging in combat and not taking instruction to leave
*No matter what I was wearing, it didn't seem to affect whether I was freezing to death on a tropical beach while standing next to a fire.  Similarly, I was still too hot after removing all clothing.  Clothing does not appear to influence environmental temperature effects.  
*The default rate of food consumption has you eating an entire steak every 30 seconds.
*Weapons generally suck (mostly because ammo is annoying to make) but maybe that's to encourage training and using dinos in combat like pokemon
*tab defaults to opening the f****** command prompt instead of the inventory like it does in literally every other game of this type
*Dying in this game might be the griefiest experience I've ever had second only to Rust, but at least in Rust you can hoverloot to get your stuff back quick enough to make a play.
*Dinos grief your body pretty hard
*on the rifle, the scope sways but the iron sights don't.
*can't use the scope with tranq darts
*stone is best collected with an axe (wtf?)
*if you have any horizontal velocity when sliding on steep terrain, the game yeets you sideways down the slope so you can't just slide, therefore taking lethal fall damage.
*jumping and landing on a tranqued dino can render you unable to take any action for extended periods. 
 The only fix I found was randomly hammering on movement keys and flailing the view around.  Maybe it's because the game puts you in a falling state or something idk.  In any case, it's infuriating.

Bottom line: if you're here for taming dinos and are willing to put up with glitchy BS, you've got a shot at liking this.  Otherwise, steer clear.

This game is in a weird place for me. On one hand, it's the most played game on my Steam library. On the other, the vast majority of that time was just waiting. Waiting on the game to load, waiting on joining a server or singleplayer game, waiting on mods to install, waiting on taming dinosaurs, smelting/collecting resources. A lot of the game is just waiting, if you can't tell. A lot of the actual gameplay doesn't come down to skill, moreso it just comes down to "Who has more numbers than the other," numbers being health, how much damage you deal, how much damage your armor deflects. When the game shines, it's a bright, amazing, glittering gem, but other parts of it are horrible, such as the aforementioned waiting and the numbers game. 

Most of the time, the game fully expects you to have a massive tribe of people online and playing every single day. This is not how I played it. I usually play singleplayer, but occasionally I did play on small servers with a few friends, though most of the time I just kinda did my own thing. This is absolutely not how the game expects you to play and it is extremely punishing if you try and play it this way without boosting your stats in the settings screen before loading your game. Even then, there are points where that's not enough.

The game itself is chock full of bugs, ones that can render your saves gone forever, or your dinosaurs and/or gear lost under the map or just deleted for no reason. Just died and now you have to run back and try and find your ascendant gear? Tough sh​it the bag with your loot is under the map. Try and transfer your character or dinosaurs to another map or server? They have ceased to exist.

On big servers, more often than not they're absolutely dominated by a single tribe who, upon someone new joining the server, will immediately zero in on your location wherever you spawn and kill you immediately. Some servers have foundations or pillars placed all over the map, to block any resources or dinosaurs from spawning, to completely prevent any new players from making any progress whatsoever.

What IS good about this game, though, is the exploration. Seeking out new areas, new dinosaurs, new resources, new anything, was some of the best time I had in this game. Delving deep into caves and climbing the highest mountains, that's where this game truly shines, and the beautiful environments surely don't hurt the game in this regard. Riding my Tapejara, or my Tyrannosaurus, or Yutyrannus, or whatever mount I decide to choose for that excursion, and exploring these sprawling maps, filled with grand vistas, is genuinely the best part of the game in my regard.

Taming of the dinosaurs can be fun, when it's more than just the normal "shoot it full of drugs until it passes out then shove food down its throat" though this can also be annoying, such as having to passive tame a constantly moving, fast as all he​ll that, upon realizing you exist will kill you without so much as a second thought, is not at all fun, is annoying as hell, and is simply bad game design.

Due to the innate randomness with both spawning into a new map as well as where and how the dinosaurs spawn, you can often wake up on the beach to a raptor or a Carnotaurus staring you down, waiting for you to get done with the waking up animation. If you manage to get past that, the beaches are INFESTED with Ichthyornis and Pegomastax, both of which will steal your stuff with absolutely no counter, especially if you're a fresh spawn, desperately trying to get enough food to survive and struggling without little thieves swooping in and stealing your precious few berries. Once you've got your base all established and got yourself a few dinos tamed, all it'd take is a randomly spawned alpha raptor or Giganotosaurus to notice your little hovel and your Parasaurolophus and Triceratops and think, "They'd make a nice meal," destroying potentially days or weeks of work in one fell swoop, with, again, absolutely no counter. This random spawning can often be a good thing, too. Spawned in somewhere and get ganked by a pack of raptors? That's ok, I can just spawn in a different location, or perhaps the same spawning area but maybe it'll spawn me further away from the predators. It also means that you can't just go to the same parts of the map, expecting the same dinosaurs. You'll get dinosaurs from a group of ones that can spawn there, yes, but never the exact same dinosaurs.

The Arks themselves, the maps the majority of the game takes place on, are described in lore as artificial environments, with their own active, living ecosystem. It never seems like that, more like a giant sandbox with dinosaurs haphazardly tossed in with no regard to predator/prey relationships and other parts of an ecosystem that make it, well, an ecosystem. This is, of course, explained away by the lore, but Wildcard had a big chance to make this environment into a living, breathing world and simply tossed it away. You never see herbivores peacefully grazing, you never see carnivores relaxing after a hunt with their kill. Would it have been more work? Yes, but people like me would have massively appreciated it.

Speaking of lore, you will not at all understand ANY of it unless you spend the hours seeking out those survivor logs. Of course, you are incentivized for them, as they provide a substantial boost to your XP gains, which in the later levels can be an immense boon, as it takes so much XP to get your last few levels.

The modding community in this game is immense, and still very active, which I believe has helped keep the game alive all these years. Modders are constantly adding new maps, new animals, new weapons and armor and structures, or changing what is already in the game. The devs themselves are very open to mods, featuring the most popular mods and even incorporating some of them into the base game, mainly new maps, though they have introduced some features from Structures+, as well as a total conversion (which has since been left to gather dust by most of the community as well as the devs).

As for the technical side of the game, it's a bloated, unoptimized, uncompressed mess. Base game, with just DLC, is more than 200gb. A heavily modded game, such as my own, can easily reach 400gb or more. The game takes far too long to load into a game, even longer if it's modded, which can be the difference between getting your entire base wiped or repelling raiders if you have to sit through the loading screen while you know your base is getting chomped away on by a raider's Giga.

I've gone on far too long, it's best to wrap this up now before I continue. Overall, this game is, again, in a weird place for me. I wish Steam had a "maybe recommended" option, something between yes and no, as that's what I'd rate this game as. As it stands, I'll leave it as a no, but I encourage you to make your own decisions about whether or not you want this game. Search out information, watch videos, see what you think before getting into it yourself instead of just hopping in blindly.

Ark is the epitome of 'so close but not quite there' at nearly 2k hours clocked I can honestly say I gave this game many, oh so many, runs but at the end of the day instabilities ruin the game for me. 2015 launch, with them leaving early access two years later and there has been a consistent trend year after year of "let's put out more content instead of fix our bugs" and let's face it, they've certainly had the time to do so.  

That is not to say that the game isn't enjoyable and that's probably the most infuriating part about it, ARK is a masterpiece of the genre at its heart, especially if you avoid the toxic and quite frankly awful public servers and run your own for a group of friends.  It's a shame that the stability isn't there to back up the game play.  

If you're looking for a storyline that's easy to follow, or even makes sense in how you discover things about the world, this game isn't it.  While the story itself is incredibly interesting, actually getting all the pieces is a guessing game of stumbling onto caches of information and journals left behind by survivors before you and beating bosses in seemingly random order and then going back to read them when you finally get enough pieces for things to make sense.  Again, so close but not quite there.

I love this game, I've had many hours of fun with friends on this game, but I've had just as many hours of frustration, troubleshooting, crashing, rebooting, and restarting and it's finally come to the point where I just can't recommend it without also warning against playing it all in the same sentence.

[h1] Where I am at with ARK now:[/h1]
I run a free to play [i]Unofficial[/i] ARK cluster [b][i]3x (NA PVP & ORP) Rochester NY Cluster[/i][/b] maintained by donations from the community playing on it, on hardware I own and maintain [b](not rented)[/b]. [b](Discord link at bottom)[/b]

It is basically vanilla with server side plugins and me as admin/judge to keep people grounded in having fun.

The hundreds of people who have come and gone on my private cluster have enabled me to purchase and maintain an HPE Gen 8 rack server with 128GB of ram, 2 cpu, 4 top speed SSD, windows 2019, upgrade all my network hardware to handle packets at a commercial level and even maintain a vastly higher internet connection. And I learned tons of valuable knowledge along the way, both in the hardware, network and software management. 

All because those who play on my server are looking for the experience I provide in this particular game. Hundreds of people who see beyond the problems always present in this game and wanted to play it in a way you can't on official. They gave generously making this possible for all of us on the cluster while letting me learn and I couldn't be more grateful. It was a fantastic transaction and I look forward to ARK 2 to continue this.

[h1]My initial thoughts (from early days)[/h1]
When I first played this I was dragged into it by friends who thought Dinosaurs and a persistent world in a game were some badass thing. At the time I tagged along because I figured it would be fun for a week or two but honestly dinosaurs never did it for me.

I didn't like that my work stayed online and was only protected by what I could provide to get me through the time I was away, [i]it never did by the way[/i]. I didn't like that my character and Dinos required upkeep. I didn't like that some people only played to grief or troll. 

I did (do) like the PVP when it wasn't offline, absurdly lopsided, mean spirited or done using every bit of cheese meta currently available. 

But somehow, year after year, I keep coming back to this game.

[h1]Taming[/h1]
I enjoy the process of taming Dinos and breeding them, seeking out some with better stats or colors I thought were neat, then using the math to breed all that together. I'm not good at it, but its fun. Finding someone good at breeding in this game is like finding a valuable scientist whose knowledge will open whole new areas of exploration. Once someone starts breeding you the right Dinos both PVE boss fights and PVP become vastly more enjoyable! 

But taming isn't just shoot and wait. There are many different ways to go about it, some requiring buildings, some requiring other Dinos and others requiring more patience than I care to develop in myself. But its always fun and a mini game that other developers would have tried to sell you as a standalone!

[h1]Building[/h1]
Building in the game is almost a science at this point. I build boxes and rectangles, I am boring and bad at the game. 

Then I find a teammate who makes elaborate multistory buildings using techniques I still can't barely comprehend with defenses built in such a devious way that having them around is now a necessity not just for survival but also to be aesthetically pleasing. 

How you place storage and work areas is important, where you put spawn points and how you position defensive dinos matter in a big way.

You start at making grass huts that raptors rip open to eat the juice inside of [i](you and your egg laying dodo)[/i]. You can't wait to get a metal base with an auto turret to blast all glowing red alpha raptors. Well, eventually you have a base made of space age tech with doors made out of force fields that open for you and can have unique passwords, and dinos that could kill every raptor on the island at the same time, yet you are still somehow farming dodo eggs lol!

[h1]The world, graphics and gameplay[/h1]
The amount of life in this game is mind blowing. Literally hundreds of unique creatures with so many unique abilities I couldn't possibly list. Each one has its place in helping to make your life easier or safer. 

I prefer to play ARK in the winter months in NY state. The maps fauna and atmosphere combined with the beautiful graphics can be like sunlight on your face. It may be snowing and gross outside, I may be yearning to go for a 5 mile trail run (screw that in the snow lol), but in ARK it feels warm and on my server I can put it down and come back at my leisure. 

Speaking of graphics, its basically what they show above, the creatures and environment are stunning and legit look as good as the images. Take the time to look around and admire the detail put into this game. 

I know many people play with it set to "potato mode" so they can pvp more efficiently...well I cannot relate to that. Turned up to 2k ultra, 144hz refresh on a 1080ti looks absolutely stunning and runs above 60fps easy. See the last paragragh to get a feel for how I feel playing this game and its graphics. 

Gameplay is not a grind if you do not want it to be [i](at least not on my servers)[/i]. As you progress, those things that were hard (eating, water, shelter, other consumables), slowly becomes easier and easier as you obtain dinos and unlock technology through level progression. 

You upgrade your skills and become hardier, faster, tougher. Where before filling up a starter dino with hand tools took 20 minutes, terrified of being eaten by predators. You eventually have dinos of your own that can be commanded to protect each other and you while you clamber along on your herbivore collecting 1000x more than you could at the start in the same time. 

But that doesn't ever start to feel meaningless! Those materials can be used to further progress you to a point where endgame content is achievable. Boss fights that progress a loosely told story, unlock high technology and mysterious new maps to explore where death and loss is around every corner. 

This sense of danger is half the fun, you know you aren't invisible and the things you have aren't permanent if you do not take care. You could lose that prized named Dino you've had since day 3 if you aren't careful. But while that may be sad, it is extremely fun. 

[h1]CONS (I have few)[/h1]
Ark has its problems. If you play on official you almost certainly need to find your way into a "larger" tribe connected to the "humungous tribes" and get "your tribes map" on a protected list. If you get too big and they find you, no amount of guns, bullets and dinos will stop them for long. 

BUT! Imagine this, a robot 5 stories tall colored outrageously in a field (and a 2 mile high floating Obelisk overhead) fighting what amounts to a hairy Godzilla whose can be seen half way across the map and all the while you and others are harassing that captured unique beast with flying creatures and defensive structures built to slow its advance. This legit happens. It is amazing.

On official servers the latency can become pretty bad, but not unplayable! You'll be picking enemies off their dinos as they try to weaken your defenses and dropping them from the sky as they speak in proximity to you how much they love you. 

Cheaters exist. But Wildcard has put an amazing effort into halting their capability. I'm not saying it doesn't occur any longer, it does, just that WC has come a LONG way in dealing with it, even if its not perfect. Much of this has to do URE4, so much of it couldn't be changed without fundamentally changing the game. 

So, many of us hope that ARK2 using URE5 will solve some of those problems while building on what they currently have. Unlike most people I don't think WC made a busted game. I think they made a platform that too many people were not willing to experiment with or go outside what was simple in order to experience it in a more enjoyable manner. 

[h1]This is both an AD for my cluster and an honest review. I love ARK.[/h1]

Played this game for many hundreds of hours spanning multiple years and steam accounts, and havent even begun to scratch the surface. This game is extremely fun with friends, if you have a group of friends looking for a game to waste hours and hours on then this is the perfect game. However do not expect this game to be exactly flawless, it has multiple game breaking bugs but i guess that's what ARK is known for now.

ARK: Survival Evolved is a fun game for everyone who likes to pour many hours into one game alone. Graphics look gorgeous, and the models and creatures are fun to stare at (If you can get over potential inaccuracy to what we know of them in the real world.).
While starting a new world can always end up frustrating and tedious with multiple deaths, once you get your bearings or even when playing with friends, it quickly turns to a fun experience with lots of taming, dino fighting, cave exploring, breeding, up until eventual boss fights. The build system isn't my favorite in games, but I'd be lying if I said one couldn't make some stunning builds, and then color them into lots of different colors as well for anyone's liking. And if you're bored of all of that, even then there's still lore to find and read up on to understand the world(s) you're playing in.
ARK is a fun experience and when one world gets boring, get your friends and yourself to ascend to a new one. Truly, I feel ARK never really gets boring.

This game so far is pretty decent. It's fun learning to capture dinosaurs.  Building bases is pretty annoying at times because the build system is so wonky. It's also pretty grindy gathering materials if you are playing without mods. The game has nothing to help you learn to play so be prepared to do research on YouTube. Still there is a certain element of danger early on that makes this game intersting. It is NOT fun when your weak and dinos walk around ruining your day by eating you. So learn to tame dinos early and learn how to use what dinos for what tasks. Learn how to set up dino groups to make using them much easier. Don't be afraid to make cheap thatch fences to keep your dinos in a certain area and use their auto harvest functions.

At the end of the day though, you will need a nice strong group of killers to go and roam the world with. Taming them is dangerous so when you find an area build a small stone hut with a bed. Then build several taming cages. Some build cheap ones but I like building big ones that are easy to run in and out of. Sometimes the best cage is the one where you are in it but they are trying to get in while you tranq them up. I just use stone door frames 3 levels high and 3 foundations wide so I can stand in the middle and be safe.

GLHF!!!

You are going to have love/hate relationship with this game. One time you will feel so good about what you have achieved and another time you will be questioning your own life decisions. PvP is for people with no life so don't go there (unless you don't have life as well), it is very easy to spend HOURS in this game without even noticing. Bugs? Never heard of them :D.............TONS and TONS of bugs. This game is one big bug fest. Dinos are just stupid af. They just walk into a wall (or through), fly in the air ignoring your whistle or just going absolutely mental and fly all over the place. It's pretty tho, dinos and textures in general look pretty good and that's where PC specs come in place. I have RTX 2070 and Ryzen 7 3700x and I am playing on medium settings, sure I can do high but 40 FPS is not what I am looking for exactly. With medium I get around 70 FPS, it strongly depends on what is happening around you in game.
Overall it's great game, just don't play it if you value your own life

Pro tip.... quickest way to level gigas is their special ability to handle fall damage. when they lose their health to fall damage it doubles your experience. you'll be surprised at how quickly the Giga dominates everything around it.

A great survival game, you can play for 400 hours and still not explored a single map! so much crafting, taming, breeding, mutations, technological upgrades, weapons, and more! worth  every single dollar! get ready to lose your life to this game.

Just like a YouTuber's that review this game says.... You log into the world for the first time... see the beautiful world for a moment.... then you die. You relog in to the world a bit more cautious, walk 10 feet and... then you die. Dying is inevitable... if you don't like dying don't get the game! If you don't give a flying broom handle if you die, get it! It is challenging and fun. I have a con about this game that eats my shorts completely and its the building. If ya ain't on level ground, it sucks butt to try and build unless you watch 50 flippen youtube videos on something that should NOT be this difficult as to build a dang foundation. Fix it please! Other than that, I love that i can tame dino's, fly, swim, ride on the dino's. i want to say its kid friendly but i wouldn't suggest anyone that doesn't like to kill animals or they might also need to turn the volume off because of the horrific sound of killing one. i think the engrams are nice to look forward to opening. Being a chic that likes to build in the games i wish there was more to make the houses look nice and just enjoy being there. I love fishing and the quiet. I like that there are ways to write on things and change colors on dino's. It is a good survival game. Some find it boring if they are not in PVP mode. However if you like a laid back experience do PVE. As a heartfelt person in games i love naming the dino's and feel sad if they die fighting for me. It is an enjoyable game!

We've done lots of google searches, so many different methods of trying to fix things and connect, and nothing has helped. I'm gonna try to keep this extra brief compared to a normal review of mine. I love survival games. I had heard many things that started to turn me off from the idea of this game, enough to have it in my library for months without opening it once. I thought that I had a very thorough understanding of what to expect from this game. When I saw the character creation, and how you look, it was almost the final nail in it's coffin. Through some miracle, or maybe from being in state of delirious sleeplessness, I hit "randomize" and kept playing. Almost everything that I had heard that made me not like it was wrong. This game is amazing. Don't let other people's first impressions or time earned miseries spoil this for you. If you are like me then you will find this very worth playing, and I'm still just getting started.

--- Past Experience ---
I initially put in some hours years ago (when it first released) and found the PVP aspect on official servers to be annoying as well as the difficulty to tame, breed and raise some dinosaurs. while it felt realistic, it wasn't for me. 

--- Current Experience ---
Lately I have been playing on a PVE server with some friends and we have fully enjoyed the more casual experience PVE offers. We are enjoying more content and aspects of the game more freely. I would recommend for this reason.

--- Game Improvement Ideas ---
Below are just some additional thoughts I have on the game. I think they could add to the core experience, but I also know that mods could support these features and would lower the need to add to the core experience.

I do think that after all the years Ark has existed, a majority of its playerbase is focused on PVP content, Because of this, most of the content added is focused on the PVP aspects of the game. Since the game has both PVP and PVE game modes, I am disappointed that Ark has not created NPC bases to learn the raiding aspect of the game in a PVE server (singleplayer or multiplayer). Several dinos are more focused on PVP aspect and feel unnecessary in PVE. Having NPCs that are running around taming creatures, breeding creatures, exploring hotspots, resource gathering, and using dinos to mount would add more immersion to the experience. I would think NPCs would be diabled on official PVP servers, but for a small group of friends who prefer to Free-for-all or team up into a couple small tribes, they could benefit from an NPC feature as well. The base building for NPCs would need a systematic approach to create simple to intricate bases to attempt to raid. NPCs could even attack your base over time especially if you are nearby, or they see you as a threat. Threat would be determined by the amount of structure your tribe has, the quality(material) of the structures, the location of your structure, structure distribution across the map (NPC may discover several smaller bases and raid one or more if there is threat that you might have too much control.) NPCs also can only assess threat they can see. Some NPCs could passively scout and leave a base untouched, while other NPCs might try to interact with your base and try to open windows, doors, storages, tool stations, crops and more. Their aggression would be determined by their Tribe aggression and the Threat you pose to their Tribe.

 I think it would be a fun addition to the game to add base blueprints. This would be another system NPCs could use to guide them to building and upgrading bases or traps. The blueprints would create an overlay to show what type of structure is needed. it would be similar to the visual when placing a structure, but it would be more transparent and more grayed-out so that the placement overlay can be easily seen. Unique base blueprints would have a position requirement. They would need placed at a specific place and would "snap to" its world position. This would allow players to have blueprints for traps and unique blueprints for rat holes, caves, or other specific locations. Could also add a Surveying tool to the game with markers so that you could locate the exact bounding box area you want to include in a Base blueprint. once all the markers have been marked by the optical surveyor, You use a war map to create the blueprint. The optical surveyor could be made using a spyglass, compass,  electronics and metal. This would essentially be a multi-item tool.

I also think the game could benefit from a Quality of life update: Create books using 10 notes, 3 hide, and 5 fiber. This would allow players to create and write in books. The creator of the book can lock writing and/or lock reading with a pin code. Books could be useful for leaving information for your team mates, or for Role-playing where recording events creates history and unique items in the game that are priceless. These can be duplicated if you have an empty book. The time it takes to copy the book depends on how much text (in pages) have been used. A wooden, stone, metal, and tek Bookshelf could be added to store books. A Lectern could be added to place a book on for reading. This could be useful for a War room, where the lectern has a book of information about a base, what tames were found, potential weak points, location, etc. This could be useful alongside a war map to better update your tribemates with details.

Another Quality of Life update is improving the folder system. I think folders are great to use, especially for creating load outs (if you don't have the new Gen 2 load out structure). I think folders should also have a filter mode, so that it will automatically add any item it already contains. For example if you have a Resources folder on your inventory and you gather some wood and put it into the resources folder with the filter mode enabled, then any wood collected after that would be automatically added to that folder. hovering on a folder should also show the overall weight of the folder (just like Operating system folders show their overall size). The tooltip could also show a summary of the first 5 unique items (based on their folder sort). If the folder only contains one material, than the summary would show the total weight and count of that material. You should also be able to rename folders. Folders should also contain a single "withdraw slot" within the folder. Dragging an item there means that you want the folder withdraw mode to withdraw that item. if there is more than one stack, you can withdraw multiple stacks. right-clicking on the folder would give you the option to withdraw one, all(count), or withdraw amount (stack, half, other).  

Lastly, the Quality of life updates should also contain the ability to use note on an item. The first line of the note would become the item's name. and the second line would become the item description. This would be helpful to name gear if you plan to use it for certain load outs, or to give to a friend, or to indicate ownership. there might be other names as well (such as for fun after dying an item, or for role-playing).

This game reflects the greatest strength of humanity, our wits and tools. 
No human would stand a chance against a lion, we have no fangs or claws to attack with and our soft bear skin is very vulnerable. put a spear in their hand they might stand a chance. 
you have to use your tools to overcome challenges such as (building a trap for an animal you want to tame but its too dangerous to confront) or (building a shelter to keep yourself safe from the elements)
there are many different worlds AKA (ARKs) to play on with different creatures to encounter. different Biomes to explore. Some worlds have heat waves you can die in these as it is so hot your health and water will continue to drain untill its over. Other worlds at night it gets so cold your health drops so fast you could die before you can get down the snowy mountain into a warmer biome.  Another world has radiation zones that you need hazmat suits to explore. Another world is all massive underground caverns and the surface of the world is scorched aflame by day and over run with aliens at night. these are just some examples of challenges you will have to over come. There is a storyline, for the game but its not an RPG sinamatic its a little more sandbox with story sprinkled in. There is no skill tree rather you gain abilitys through tamed and or bred mounts, weapons, tools, gear. If your new to videogames in general you may not want to start with ARK because i do recommend a little research before playing. the game can also be buggy i myself have a perminant bug in single player that i "fixed" through settings. its the nodes wont respawn bug, i set resources radious for structures and players to zero and resources respawn period to zero to get them to respawn, things like that you might run into if you play single player you will have to look up a fix for glitches or bugs you run into. now you can play on offical wildcards servers can be laggy because lots of people and their structures and animals. i played offical on Xbox for years and loved it and also hated it at times because people can inside you and steal your hard earned animals and gear so do not expect people to welcome you with open arms into their tribe they will be sus about you at first untill they feel your not out to take their stuff. its better to play this game with friend in my opinion its more fun goofing around you can fight and kill each other lol also more manpower means faster gathering, building more guns to help you kill world bosses.  you can run your own servers as a dedicated or nondedicated you or your friend can control server settings and use admin commands spawn in anything you want. Yes this game is buggy in SP and laggy on offical but hey what can i say i fell in love with this game and recommend to all! what you can do in this game is limitless me and my friends built an arena where we have gunfights capture the flag i mean dodo lol fun times.

I tried several times to get into this game. It is fun initially but super grindy. I made a custom server with tweaked settings to get around the grind and it did feel better that way. The main reason I can't recommend this game is due to bugs that have been there from day one that still haven't been fixed. My frustration is really centered around the dinosaur AI. It is atrocious. You get super hyped to tame a dino, which takes forever if you don't tweak the taming time, only to have it get stuck on a rock or random object. This may not sound like a big deal, but eventually you will have several dinos following you and inevitably one will get stuck somewhere without you noticing. There isn't really any way to track where your dinos are at as far as I know and therefore you have to search for them like a set of lost car keys. Usually you'll find the corpse or get a message saying your dino has been killed by some other predator. Really kills the gameplay.

If this game looks cool, don't go out and buy it just yet. this game in singleplayer is more or less hot garbage, as many things simply aren't possible and singleplayer itself is bugged to hell even more than the regular game.

My recommendation is to get a group of friends together, and either play on a public PvE server (PvP in this game is so broken, full of cheaters, and other BS it's not even worth touching) or make your own using Ark Server Manager (youtube it, fairly easy process). This makes it so you control every aspect of the server, and can even use cheats to make up for the *inevitable* bugs that will kill you, your tame, and probably some of your items just to give you that extra middle finger (as this game does).

BUT, if you do this, this game is quite fun, infuriating at times, but overall super fun.

I'm going to be honest here: I haven't played this game in a year or two, so I don't know what it's like out of early access. I will say that this game is very difficult and unforgiving, especially if you are playing alone.

By yourself, this game is a slog and requires slow playing so that you don't accidentally die due to being underprepared. One small carnivore will eat those naked cheeks of yours easy. Even with friends this is a difficult game in a normal server.

However, if you are playing this on a modded server, able to speed up the rate of experience, taming, and other necessities in game, it is incredibly fun. The game progresses normally and yes, if there are dedicated players then you can beat the game fairly quickly as production ramps up towards the end, but if you played normally, this game would take far too long with far too little enjoyment.

Normally, this game is frustrating and slow. Modded, this game is a joy to play with friends.

0.5 stars out of 5.
I love this game. It's one of my favorites.
However I can't recommend spending money on this game because I feel it is unplayable without mods/cheats.
With mods and admin commands it's great.  Hours of fun building bases and riding dinosaurs.
Without mods it's 99% frustration.  Can I interact with this thing I'm pointing at with my crosshairs.  Nope.  Interaction often happens with some other object.  Usually something off screen.
Can I place a structure piece here.  Game says yes then places it somewhere else often deleting some other object in the process.
Can I snap an object to another object.  Often the answer is no and for no reason whatsoever.
Can dinosaurs fall through the map and become lost.  Absolutely.
Can I and my dinosaurs get stuck inside an object with no way out except to delete the object losing items and resources.  Absolutely.

Luckily, cheating fixes everything.

There are other annoying things that are just part of the game.
Checking your surroundings to make sure it's safe?  Yes.
Mini-boss dinosaurs spawn in within aggro range and attack even though you've been checking to make sure it's safe?  Yes.

The game looks Great.
Riding Dinosaurs is fun.
Building is awesome only if you are running mods/cheats.

Honestly, this game used to look like it had so much potential. I would have at one time even given it a recommendation. However, the devs really messed this one up. It's a glitchy mess that barely runs, even on a decent computer. The servers constantly crash, and yet the devs seem too focused on making new content (and now even a sequel) to polish the game that's already there. If I had to score it, I would give it a 2/10. It has some interesting ideas, and some pretty cool designs, but is basically unplayable, and I'm not saying that to be dramatic. This game is actually unplayable.

Ark is a pretty fun game. I know it’s meant to be played multiplayer, but I played through the base game and the first 3 dlc’s singleplayer without too many issues. Gameplay is really fun, though it can get pretty tough at times, to the point of wanting to rip my hair out on a few occasions, but it’s worth it. Story’s pretty good, though a bit hard to follow with the way it’s told. Masterful music, the fights I got into felt intense, and the bosses were epic. Keeping exotic pets was also fun, though the game’s reliance on them is a bit annoying. My only real qualms are that later in the game, certain things take unholy amounts of resources to make, and also I dislike the fact that ark takes up 1/4 of my disk space without any DLCs.

Greetings Survivor,
 
Thank you for contacting Studio Wildcard Customer Support. We are sorry to hear that you are having an issue with the hexagons!
