[h1] It's a great game with a lot of freedom. [/h1]

Just got to say I have played the games at least double this time on PS4 as well.

[b] Stuff I like: [/b]
- In-depth base building
- Exploring the worlds/maps (aka ARK's). 
- Dino taming and that almost every single dino has a specific purpose
- The game is hard by default and as a new player you have no idea what to do
- Progression from early to end game in a way makes sense and doesn't feel like a burden
- The lore is interesting and well written

[b] Stuff I don't like: [/b]
- Too many unforgivable bugs
- Weird snap points and angles limits your building possibilities
- PvP is a nudge too hard-core for my liking
- The game has become worse with the years. The first map is no doubt the best one, with challenge caves and a nuanced landscape. The last map is too big, to the point that it feels empty. It could've been 1/4 the size and still give as much to explore, just that you wouldn't get bored of it.
- Tech ruins the game. Especially on the last map, where you get a free tech suit, which is just mind blowing stupid. This counters more than half of my pro-points above. Progression doesn't make as much sense, as you can fly already. Exploring doesn't feel as engaging, especially as there are no challenge caves. The game becomes too easy, as you actually can tame an end game dino (Reaper King) at level 1.

There's a lot more that can be said and improved. I have good faith in ARK 2, where they can start with a fresh new primitive approach and get back to the roots of what makes ARK so much fun!

In my opinion, ark is a fantastic game for people who have a soft spot for dinosaurs. it does have some bugs and it has a lot of grinding, but every game has its own ups and downs. tldr; I am not interested in PvP. My review is based on PvE on a private server with a few friends. It has become my all-time favorite game and I would recommend this to everyone.

So I tried Ark some time ago and though it looked great and was fun, I decided it was not for me. There is a lot of DLC and game settings. Default game settings in Single Player, at least for me, was too challenging. I'll get to these later. In the past month my friends hosted a private server and began playing with them and Ark has become my favorite game of all-time now. 

So, why did my opinion on Ark change? Well for starters, there is no hand holding in Ark. Just starting the Single Player instance was confusing in terms of which settings to use, which map, which "game", etc. When I hopped on my friends private server, it was like a totally different game. Since none of us really have a lot of time to dedicate to games (this is a lie because I put in 275 hours and could not stop playing - be careful!), different rates were modified. On both a private server or your Single Player instance you can modify things such as max dino level, experience gained, amount of resources harvested, how fast you can tame and breed dinos, etc. You can modify these multipliers to fall in-line with the experience you're looking in terms of a challenge and time constraints.

[Here is what I think Ark does really well:]
- Graphics -
While not the best, I found the graphics to be nice. The lighting is superb and when the sun is rising you get some really beautiful scenes.
- Challenge -
One of the best games ever in this regard. You can literally make this game as easy or as difficult as you would like. There is an endless amount of configuration combinations to try. This may be confusing and burdensome to the new player though so make sure you research settings before starting.
- Base building -
It is not the most robust base building you will find. Not even close. But, it is very fun and rewarding. I spent most of my 275 hours gathering resources to build my winter base and then a castle up on the mountain. It never got old for me and enjoyed everything including the little quirks Ark provides.
- Size (maps are quite large) -
There are a few different maps to choose from. I have spent 99% of my time on the map Ragnarok. This map is absolutely enormous. Without a flyer you will need to be planning your adventures. Even with a very fast Wyvern it took me ~8 minutes to fly from one side to the other. 
- Biomes -
Some dinos persist throughout the map but most do not. You find dinos where you would expect them; dire bears in the cold, turtles near beaches, and sheep on the highlands.
- Player progression -
Ark allows you to invest points into things such as health, speed, carry weight, etc. as you level up. There is also an "Engram" tree. Essentially, it is just things you can unlock to build as you level up. Be forewarned that on default settings you are limited in the amount of Engrams you can unlock.
- Providing a "living" world -
There is a spot on Ragnarok where there are a bunch of penguins. I returned some days later to tame them and they were all gone. You will find predators leaving their spawn points to chase other dinos. As new dinos spawn in after death or ones leaving, some areas change a bit. I once found a beautiful Tek Quetzal in Murder Snow that I wanted to tame but it ended up flying off while during my attempt and I did not find it again for about a week and it was somewhere very far away.
- Taming dinos! -
The bread and butter of Ark. While the process is somewhat silly and dependent on your game settings, it is incredibly fun. I quickly progressed on our server and was able to find max level bears to tame and breed. Over a couple weeks I had very strong bears that could take on almost anything with ease. Such a fun and rewarding experience.

[Here are some things I think Ark should improve:]
- Dino AI/behavior
The dinos are stupid. Both wild and your own dinos will constantly get stuck on things. They will get stuck inside of each other. They will sometimes do things they should not like attacking something while set to "passive". Though it can be frustrating at times it definitely does not ruin the game and maybe even adds a bit to the game since you're constantly redirecting your dino armies.
- Flight danger -
This is probably the biggest downfall in Ark, to me. On our private server, once I got an Argent, the game was simply too easy. This happened in the first 4-6 hours of playing too. You will never encounter danger when flying and makes 90% of all dinos irrelevant. The only time I ever died in 275 hours was when a lightning Wyvern surprised me while getting milk and killed my Argent. To anyone reading this, I would highly recommend to disable flying or make a personal rule you don't use flying mounts. It completely ruins the game.
- Sounds -
The game is pretty boring in terms of sounds. Mostly annoying dino sounds while they eat or poop. You will never feel immersed in this aspect.

Lastly, we decided to start on a new map with no modifiers at all, and no flying. We spent and entire night and accomplished nothing due to the sheer volume of predators killing us. I personally had the best time ever on a game but some might not like the challenge. Just think about the modifiers before starting your adventure and adjust as needed :)

Be prepared to die, a lot, if you've never played before. There's a steep learning curve, but it doesn't last long. UI may seem clunky at first, but it gets easier to navigate the more you use it. Lag is prevalent on all PvP and PvE servers, so something you'll just have to accept and deal with. That's all before even getting to the tribal warfare, server's that never, and I mean NEVER, wipe, constantly inconvenient dino spawns, offline raiding, and just general internet people BS. 
However:
If you stick with it, the game does a great job of following the dopamine reward track in our brains. Each encounter with a new challenge, each death, each level, and so on, all feel like you've actually accomplished something. There's a little there for everyone, from single player to online, cheating on un-official servers, to quick leveling and base building, oh and lets not forget: YOU CAN RIDE A F***N DINOSAUR. Just make sure that you're prepared for some other a-hole to come around when you're offline and kill it just because they can. 

Seriously though, if you're looking for something to sink some time into and actually enjoy the fruits of your labor, it's a good game. Not for the impatient, weak-willed, or gullible. The people who play this game and the gameplay itself make it clear that your mistakes should be learned from. 
But I mean come on, who doesn't love watching hundreds of hours of work as a solo player go up in smoke just because some home-schooled 11 year old caught you off guard on a laggy server? 

Play at your own risk, but enjoyable overall if you like a challenge.

things turn around and the adventure begins. Building and taming are my 
biggest pleasures, but exploring and trying to acquire Artifacts are also cool.
Run, run away now because if you avoid the official servers and all the toxic people there 
this game might steal your life!

Yesterday I was riding my favorite dinosaur named Edward (lvl 300) he was a dodo and was abnormally sized for his kind. I would say at least 20 meters tall. I attacked another dodo which was much lower level in fact but this same dodo managed to murder Edward. I am so mad that my little Edward was massacred by a dumb chicken who was only level 500. Just as I landed on floor and broke my bones, my character shit furiously (like 5 times) which is so disrespectful considering that Gardudd's favorite food was shit. So overall, I would say that this game can improve overall 10/10

At 263 hours, I can say that the price is justified by the number of hours I've played. I will likely play this again in the future if any of my friends get the urge. Even writing this review made me itch to start it up. 

[b]Who will like this game... based on my own personal play-style...[/b]
► You enjoy survival games and building an aesthetically-pleasing base. In that order.
► You like Conan. Similar crafting. Similar base-building. Very similar set of bugs and issues. Servers operate roughly the same.  
► You have a few friends to play with. Two or three is enough. It gets exponentially easier the more people you play with.
► You wanted to play a game with dinosaurs, [strike]but The Isle disappointed you[/strike].


[b]Why did I stop playing?[/b]
☼ Breeding dinosaurs became a huge chore. The game encouraged giant bases (incredibly lag-inducing) of pure breeding grounds to get the strongest dinosaur or a certain color dinosaur. The timing of everything made it necessary to play daily at the bare minimum to min/max what creatures you wanted. You needed to log on at specific hours of the day to feed the dinosaurs, claim the hatched babies, and feed the babies before they starve. 

Basically, it became a dinosaur-breeding game only, which was still fun for lots of hours until we all stopped caring because there's only so long we can worry about running a whorehouse for dinosaurs as adults with jobs. 


[b]Suggestions for similarly-minded players...[/b]
Play this on a private server either with only your friends or specifically search out a private server community with good admins and reasonable rules.

After spending your first 15 hours on this game because you cannot stop playing, you'll be left with a gaping crater where your poop chute used to be. Absolutely fucking hate this game, but like an abusive boyfriend, I just keep coming back because I love it so much. 10/10, would recommend.

If you love survival games this is it then; this is what I think of and what all other games seem to be trying to compare themselves to in this genre. Theres nothing like waking up buck naked on a strange island and building up a base and skills to take on the wild environment all around you. Plenty of replay value and new maps to keep veterans on their toes. this is by far the standard for survival games now.

For those who don't have the money to buy this, I recommend asking for a friends card or for those under aged like me, I recommend asking for you're mom or dad to gift you the game. Or you can just gifted the game by you're friends, if they are kind enough, and if you know how to ask nicely. Lol. Anyway. Its a 8.5 score for me, I may only have 13 hours at the time of me writing this, but I do recommend it. It is fun, it has a lot of extra stuff you can add. But you do need a lot of space on you're computer for it. That's really one of the only BIG down sides for it. I recommend the 30 dollar, not only because it is cheaper but most people do not have enough space for this game. Even then this game is still decently sized.

You should not play Ark: Survival Evolved. It's fun for a while, but the truth is this: The game has more holes than good graces, and the developers, Studio Wildcard, are permanently leaving several mechanics and technical issues broken. They have never endeavored to fix long-standing issues in single player, preferring only to bug fix whatever exploits people found in multiplayer. The thing is, although this game might give you a couple hundred hours of fun, Studio Wildcard does not deserve more money for the frankly poor job they've done of crafting a meaningful experience out of what should have been a rock-solid no-fail intellectual property. They are honestly just really bad developers, and if you judge this game on the merits of its single player experience alone, it is a 3/10. Don't let my hours played fool you, I have 500 hours on ps4 as well. All of it on single player, because my internet is not capable of playing online. But even if you did play online, it's a highly toxic environment rife with exploitation and people glitching themselves into the ground so they can kill you from a position of invincibility.

i've played this game on and off for years. its a good game. always fun to jump into, smack some dino butts, build a sh*t shack then log off. i first played this on an intel pentium dual core with 8GB ram and a gtx 1050. it ran.. somewhere between 20-30fps. i've had many upgrades over the years and am currently at an i7 9700kf 64GB ram @3600mhz and an rtx 3060 and it still runs like sh*t (40-50fps) at high settings with the added bonus of looking like garbage if you turn the settings down. if they optimised it to run 144fps @ 1080p (like i can with a lot of newer games) on equal hardware then maybe it'd deserve its thumbs up. but given its age and the fact it still runs poorly it gets a thumbs down.

I have been playing Ark since 2018 and the game certainly has evolved for the better during that time. I run my own dedicated server and I believe with a little tweaking this is the game MMO's will evolve to eventually. I'm extremely excited to see what ARK2 brings. Having dipped my toes into what passes for a "Great Game" in "Lost Ark" recently I found myself rather disheartened with the state of affairs in the MMO genre and games in general. I cannot recommend this enough to players who once spent countless hours in a game. If you do this at your own pace with a small group of players it's an extremely rewarding game. You must be willing to explore and set your own goals. There's really no right or wrong way to play it. If you want spoon fed content, there's tons of that. It's bland and all copy of a copy of a copy at this point. Thank god for games like Ark: Survival Evolved.
Best game of all time hands down!
Ark is really fun, but you have to take it seriously. It is a very unique community of gamers. Be prepared to get frustrated, but as the game advances it all pays off.
